events.title: Revelation of Story Origins and Character Inspirations
detailed_summary: The author reveals that a significant portion of the adventures depicted in the book are rooted in actual occurrences.
A few of these real-life incidents were directly experienced by the author.
The majority of the source material, however, comes from the experiences of boys who were the author's schoolmates.
The character Huck Finn is explicitly stated to be based on a real individual.

The character Tom Sawyer, while also drawn from life, is presented as a composite figure, blending the traits of three specific boys known to the author, and is metaphorically described as belonging to the 'composite order of architecture.'

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Most of the adventures recorded in this book really occurred; one or two were experiences of my own, the rest those of boys who were schoolmates of mine.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Huck Finn is drawn from life; Tom Sawyer also, but not from an individual—he is a combination of the characteristics of three boys whom I knew, and therefore belongs to the composite order of architecture.

events.title: Acknowledgement of Period-Specific Superstitions
detailed_summary: The author addresses the peculiar superstitions featured within the story.
It is affirmed that these superstitions were genuinely common and widely held during the period the story is set.
These beliefs were particularly prevalent among children and enslaved individuals in the Western United States.
The timeframe for this prevalence is specified as being thirty to forty years prior to the writing of the preface.

events.title: Author's Dual Audience and Nostalgic Aim
detailed_summary: The author clarifies that the book's primary aim is to provide entertainment for young readers, specifically boys and girls.
Despite this focus, the author expresses a hope that adult readers, both men and women, will not disregard the book.
A significant aspect of the author's intention is to gently reawaken adults to memories of their own past selves.
This includes reminding them of their former feelings, thoughts, ways of speaking, and the sometimes strange or adventurous undertakings of their youth.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Although my book is intended mainly for the entertainment of boys and girls, I hope it will not be shunned by men and women on that account, for part of my plan has been to try to pleasantly remind adults of what they once were themselves, and of how they felt and thought and talked, and what queer enterprises they sometimes engaged in.

events.title: Tom's Evasion and Aunt Polly's Jam Discovery
detailed_summary: Aunt Polly repeatedly calls for Tom but receives no answer.
She searches the room, using her spectacles more for appearance than for sight, as they are her 'state pair'.
Muttering a threat, she pokes under the bed with a broom, only managing to disturb the cat.
She then goes to the open door, scans the garden, and calls for Tom again, projecting her voice.
A slight noise behind her alerts her, and she turns to catch Tom attempting to sneak away from a closet.
Aunt Polly questions Tom about his activities in the closet and notices jam on his hands and mouth.
She reminds Tom of her repeated warnings about the jam and declares her intention to punish him with a switch.
As the switch is about to be used, Tom cleverly diverts Aunt Polly's attention by exclaiming about something behind her.
While Aunt Polly is distracted, Tom seizes the moment to escape by climbing over a high board-fence.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Tom!”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The lad fled on the instant, scrambled up the high board-fence, and disappeared over it.

events.text_segment:
“Tom!”
No answer.
“TOM!”
No answer.
“What’s gone with that boy,  I wonder? You TOM!”
No answer.
The old lady pulled her spectacles down and looked over them about the room; then she put them up and looked out under them. She seldom or never looked through them for so small a thing as a boy; they were her state pair, the pride of her heart, and were built for “style,” not service—she could have seen through a pair of stove-lids just as well. She looked perplexed for a moment, and then said, not fiercely, but still loud enough for the furniture to hear:
“Well, I lay if I get hold of you I’ll—”
She did not finish, for by this time she was bending down and punching under the bed with the broom, and so she needed breath to punctuate the punches with. She resurrected nothing but the cat.
“I never did see the beat of that boy!”
She went to the open door and stood in it and looked out among the tomato vines and “jimpson” weeds that constituted the garden. No Tom. So she lifted up her voice at an angle calculated for distance and shouted:
“Y-o-u-u TOM!”
There was a slight noise behind her and she turned just in time to seize a small boy by the slack of his roundabout and arrest his flight.
“There! I might ’a’ thought of that closet. What you been doing in there?”
“Nothing.”
“Nothing! Look at your hands. And look at your mouth. What is that truck?”
“I don’t know, aunt.”
“Well, I know. It’s jam—that’s what it is. Forty times I’ve said if you didn’t let that jam alone I’d skin you. Hand me that switch.”
The switch hovered in the air—the peril was desperate—
“My! Look behind you, aunt!”
The old lady whirled round, and snatched her skirts out of danger. The lad fled on the instant, scrambled up the high board-fence, and disappeared over it.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: "Tom!" Aunt Polly called sharply, her voice echoing through the room. She looked around, but there was no sign of him. Frustrated, she rummaged through the cluttered space, her spectacles perched on her nose more for show than for sight. Muttering a threat under her breath, she poked her head under the bed with a broom, only to startle the cat that was curled there. Moving to the open door, she scanned the garden beyond and called again, her voice rising in exasperation. Suddenly, she caught a glimpse of movement behind her and spun around just in time to see Tom attempting to slip away from the closet. She caught him by the arm, noticing the jam on his hands and around his mouth. "What have I told you about that jam?" she scolded. "You’re going to get a switch for this!" As she reached for her switch, Tom, quick as a flash, exclaimed, "Look behind you!" diverting her attention. In that split second, he seized the opportunity, climbing over the high fence to escape.

events.title: Aunt Polly's Dilemma and Resolve
detailed_summary: Aunt Polly, initially surprised by Tom's escape, chuckles at his cleverness.
She reflects on her inability to anticipate Tom's recurring tricks, calling herself an 'old fool'.
She acknowledges Tom's knack for knowing how far he can push her and his ability to diffuse her anger with distractions or by making her laugh, thereby avoiding punishment.
She expresses guilt over her leniency, believing she is failing in her duty to discipline him properly, citing the proverb 'Spare the rod and spile the child'.
Aunt Polly recognizes Tom's inherent mischief but admits her deep affection for him as her late sister's son makes it difficult for her to be stern.
She describes her internal conflict: her conscience troubles her when she spares him, and her heart aches when she punishes him.
She resigns herself to the troubles of life and anticipates Tom will play hooky that afternoon.
She resolves to make Tom work on Saturday as a consequence, acknowledging it's a difficult but necessary measure given his strong aversion to work, to prevent his 'ruination'.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: His aunt Polly stood surprised a moment, and then broke into a gentle laugh.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It’s mighty hard to make him work Saturdays, when all the boys is having holiday, but he hates work more than he hates anything else, and I’ve got to do some of my duty by him, or I’ll be the ruination of the child.”

events.text_segment:
His aunt Polly stood surprised a moment, and then broke into a gentle laugh.
"Hang the boy, can’t I never learn anything? Ain’t he played me tricks enough like that for me to be looking out for him by this time? But old fools is the biggest fools there is. Can’t learn an old dog new tricks, as the saying is. But my goodness, he never plays them alike, two days, and how is a body to know what’s coming? He ’pears to know just how long he can torment me before I get my dander up, and he knows if he can make out to put me off for a minute or make me laugh, it’s all down again and I can’t hit him a lick. I ain’t doing my duty by that boy, and that’s the Lord’s truth, goodness knows. Spare the rod and spile the child, as the Good Book says. I’m a laying up sin and suffering for us both, I know. He’s full of the Old Scratch, but laws-a-me! he’s my own dead sister’s boy, poor thing, and I ain’t got the heart to lash him, somehow. Every time I let him off, my conscience does hurt me so, and every time I hit him my old heart most breaks. Well-a-well, man that is born of woman is of few days and full of trouble, as the Scripture says, and I reckon it’s so. He’ll play hookey this evening,and I’ll just be obleeged to make him work, tomorrow, to punish him. It’s mighty hard to make him work Saturdays, when all the boys is having holiday, but he hates work more than he hates anything else, and I’ve got to do some of my duty by him, or I’ll be the ruination of the child.”

Guilt crept into her heart as she thought about her leniency—she believed she was failing in her duty to discipline him properly, recalling the old proverb, 'Spare the rod and spile the child.' Her conscience troubled her when she spared him, and her heart ached when she had to punish him. She resigned herself to the troubles of life, knowing Tom would likely play hooky that afternoon. She decided that he should work on Saturday as a consequence, though she knew it would be difficult—Tom hated work and would try to avoid it at all costs—but she felt it was necessary to prevent his ruin.

events.title: Tom's Return and Work Avoidance
detailed_summary: Tom follows through on his intention to play hooky and has an enjoyable time.
He returns home just in time to supposedly assist Jim, a young Black boy, with chopping wood for the next day and preparing kindling before supper.
However, Tom primarily narrates his adventures to Jim, while Jim ends up doing the vast majority (three-fourths) of the actual work.

In contrast, Tom's younger half-brother, Sid, is portrayed as a quiet and dutiful boy who has already finished his assigned chore of picking up wood chips, as he lacks Tom's adventurous and troublesome nature.

Tom’s younger brother (or rather half-brother) Sid was already through with his part of the work (picking up chips), for he was a quiet boy, and had no adventurous, trouble-some ways.

events.title: Aunt Polly's Interrogation and Sid's Betrayal
detailed_summary: During supper, while Tom discreetly steals sugar, Aunt Polly initiates a seemingly casual conversation designed to trap him into admitting he skipped school.
Aunt Polly fancies herself skilled in subtle diplomacy, though her tactics are rather obvious.
She inquires about the warmth at school, hoping to lead Tom towards a confession about swimming.
Tom becomes wary but responds noncommittally.
Aunt Polly then touches Tom's shirt, noting its dryness, and internally congratulates herself on this perceived clever discovery.
Tom, understanding her suspicion, quickly explains his damp hair by claiming some boys had pumped water on their heads.
Aunt Polly feels momentarily outwitted but then recalls that she had sewn Tom's shirt collar shut that morning.
She triumphantly asks Tom to unbutton his jacket, expecting to find the collar unsewn.
Tom confidently opens his jacket, revealing the collar is still securely sewn.
Aunt Polly, half-disappointed her deduction was wrong and half-glad Tom seemed obedient, tells him she forgives him this time.
Sid then points out a crucial detail: Aunt Polly had used white thread to sew the collar, but the thread currently on it is black.
Aunt Polly exclaims in realization, but Tom, knowing he's been caught, quickly makes his exit, muttering a threat to Sid for revealing the truth.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: While Tom was eating his supper, and stealing sugar as opportunity offered, Aunt Polly asked him questions that were full of guile, and very deep—for she wanted to trap him into damaging revealments.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Siddy, I’ll lick you for that.”

events.text_segment:
While Tom was eating his supper, and stealing sugar as opportunity offered, Aunt Polly asked him questions that were full of guile, and very deep—for she wanted to trap him into damaging revealments. Like many other simple-hearted souls, it was her pet vanity to believe she was endowed with a talent for dark and mysterious diplomacy, and she loved to contemplate her most transparent devices as marvels of low cunning. Said she:
“Tom, it was middling warm in school, warn’t it?”
“Yes’m.”
“Powerful warm, warn’t it?”
“Yes’m.”
“Didn’t you want to go in a-swimming, Tom?”
A bit of a scare shot through Tom—a touch of uncomfortable suspicion. He searched Aunt Polly’s face, but it told him nothing. So he said:
“No’m—well, not very much.”
The old lady reached out her hand and felt Tom’s shirt, and said:
“But you ain’t too warm now, though.” And it flattered her to reflect that she had discovered that the shirt was dry without anybody knowing that that was what she had in her mind. But in spite of her, Tom knew where the wind lay, now. So he forestalled what might be the next move:
“Some of us pumped on our heads—mine’s damp yet. See?”
Aunt Polly was vexed to think she had overlooked that bit of circumstantial evidence, and missed a trick. Then she had a new inspiration:
“Tom, you didn’t have to undo your shirt collar where I sewed it, to pump on your head, did you? Unbutton your jacket!”
The trouble vanished out of Tom’s face. He opened his jacket. His shirt collar was securely sewed.
“Bother! Well, go ’long with you. I’d made sure you’d played hookey and been a-swimming. But I forgive ye, Tom. I reckon you’re a kind of a singed cat, as the saying is—better’n you look. This time.”
She was half sorry her sagacity had miscarried, and half glad that Tom had stumbled into obedient conduct for once.
But Sidney said:
“Well, now, if I didn’t think you sewed his collar with white thread, but it’s black.”
“Why, I did sew it with white! Tom!”
But Tom did not wait for the rest. As he went out at the door he said:
“Siddy, I’ll lick you for that.”

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text: While Tom was eating his supper, and stealing sugar as opportunity offered, Aunt Polly asked him questions that were full of guile, and very deep—for she wanted to trap him into damaging revealments. She began by asking how school was, and if it was warm enough, trying to coax him into confessing he had been swimming. Tom, wary, answered vaguely, but Aunt Polly, feeling clever, reached out and touched his shirt, noting it was dry. She thought she had caught him, but Tom quickly explained that some boys had pumped water on their heads. Aunt Polly, momentarily stumped, then remembered she had sewn his collar shut that morning. She asked him to unbutton his jacket, expecting to find the collar unsewn, but Tom confidently opened it, showing the collar was still sewn. Aunt Polly, a little disappointed but pleased that Tom was obedient, told him she forgave him this time. Just then, Sid pointed out that the thread on Tom’s collar was black, but Aunt Polly had used white thread. She exclaimed in surprise, realizing her mistake, and Tom, knowing he was caught, quickly made his escape, muttering a threat to Sid for revealing the truth.

events.title: Tom's Ingenuity, Resentment, and New Whistling Fascination
detailed_summary: Finding a private spot, Tom examines two needles concealed in his jacket lapels, one threaded with white and the other with black, confirming how he managed the collar deception.
He expresses frustration that Aunt Polly isn't consistent with her thread color choice, making his subterfuge more complicated.
He reaffirms his intention to punish Sid for exposing him.
The narrator comments that Tom is far from being the 'Model Boy' of the village, a type of boy Tom thoroughly detests.
Tom's anger and troubles quickly dissipate as a new, captivating interest takes hold of his mind.
This new preoccupation is a unique whistling technique, described as a bird-like warble, which he recently learned from a Black individual.
He is eager to practice this new skill without interruption.
Through focused effort, Tom masters the whistle and walks down the street feeling a profound sense of harmony and joy.
His pleasure in this new accomplishment is compared to that of an astronomer discovering a new planet, suggesting Tom's joy is even deeper and more pure.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: In a safe place Tom examined two large needles which were thrust into the lapels of his jacket, and had thread bound about them—one needle carried white thread and the other black.

events.text_segment:
In a safe place Tom examined two large needles which were thrust into the lapels of his jacket, and had thread bound about them—one needle carried white thread and the other black. He said:
“She’d never noticed if it hadn’t been for Sid. Confound it! sometimes she sews it with white, and sometimes she sews it with black. I wish to gee-miny she’d stick to one or t’other—I can’t keep the run of ’em. But I bet you I’ll lam Sid for that. I’ll learn him!”
He was not the Model Boy of the village. He knew the model boy very well though—and loathed him.
Within two minutes, or even less, he had forgotten all his troubles. Not because his troubles were one whit less heavy and bitter to him than a man’s are to a man, but because a new and powerful interest bore them down and drove them out of his mind for the time—just as men’s misfortunes are forgotten in the excitement of new enterprises. This new interest was a valued novelty in whistling, which he had just acquired from a negro, and he was suffering to practise it undisturbed. It consisted in a peculiar bird-like turn, a sort of liquid warble, produced by touching the tongue to the roof of the mouth at short intervals in the midst of the music—the reader probably remembers how to do it, if he has ever been a boy. Diligence and attention soon gave him the knack of it, and he strode down the street with his mouth full of harmony and his soul full of gratitude. He felt much as an astronomer feels who has discovered a new planet—no doubt, as far as strong, deep, unalloyed pleasure is concerned, the advantage was with the boy, not the astronomer.

events.title: Tom Encounters a Well-Dressed Newcomer
detailed_summary: The summer evening is long, and daylight still lingers.
Tom abruptly stops his whistling upon noticing a stranger before him – a boy slightly larger than himself.
The arrival of any newcomer, regardless of age or gender, is a significant event in the small, unassuming village of St. Petersburg.
This particular boy stands out because he is remarkably well-dressed for a weekday, sporting a fine cap, a new and stylish blue cloth suit, and pantaloons.
He is also wearing shoes, an uncommon sight on a Friday, and even has a necktie made of bright ribbon.
The new boy's sophisticated, 'citified' demeanor deeply annoys Tom.
As Tom scrutinizes the new boy's impressive appearance, he simultaneously feels a growing disdain for the finery and an increasing awareness of his own shabby attire.
Both boys remain silent, observing each other intently.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The summer evenings were long.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Neither boy spoke.

events.text_segment: The summer evenings were long. It was not dark, yet. Presently Tom checked his whistle. A stranger was before him—a boy a shade larger than himself. A new-comer of any age or either sex was an impressive curiosity in the poor little shabby village of St. Petersburg. This boy was well dressed, too—well dressed on a week-day. This was simply astounding. His cap was a dainty thing, his close-buttoned blue cloth roundabout was new and natty, and so were his pantaloons. He had shoes on—and it was only Friday. He even wore a necktie, a bright bit of ribbon. He had a citified air about him that ate into Tom’s vitals. The more Tom stared at the splendid marvel, the higher he turned up his nose at his finery and the shabbier and shabbier his own outfit seemed to him to grow. Neither boy spoke.

In the small, unassuming village of St. Petersburg, any newcomer was a noteworthy event, but this boy was especially striking. He was dressed remarkably well for a weekday: a fine cap sat atop his head, a new and stylish blue cloth suit fitted him perfectly, and his pantaloons were neat and clean. His shoes gleamed, an uncommon sight on a Friday, and a bright ribbon tied around his neck added a touch of finery. The sight of this 'citified' boy irritated Tom; he felt a mixture of disdain for the finery and a pang of self-awareness about his own shabby attire. Both boys regarded each other silently, each observing the other with curiosity and suspicion.

events.title: Verbal Sparring and Rising Hostility
detailed_summary: The two boys circle each other cautiously, maintaining constant eye contact.
Tom initiates the confrontation by declaring he can defeat the new boy in a fight.
This sparks a back-and-forth exchange of boasts and challenges.
The new boy dismissively tells Tom his name is none of Tom's concern.
Tom retorts that he will make it his business.
They trade insults, with Tom mocking the new boy's hat, and the new boy daring Tom to knock it off, adding a taunt about those who take dares.
The boys accuse each other of being liars and cowards.
Tom threatens to hit the new boy with a rock.
The new boy challenges Tom's threat, implying Tom is too afraid to act.
The verbal duel continues with each boy asserting his bravery and accusing the other of fear.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: If one moved, the other moved—but only sidewise, in a circle; they kept face to face and eye to eye all the time.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “You are.”

events.text_segment:
If one moved, the other moved—but only sidewise, in a circle; they kept face to face and eye to eye all the time. Finally Tom said:
“I can lick you!”
“I’d like to see you try it.”
“Well, I can do it.”
“No you can’t, either.”
“Yes I can.”
“No you can’t.”
“I can.”
“You can’t.”
“Can!”
“Can’t!”
An uncomfortable pause. Then Tom said:
“What’s your name?”
“’Tisn’t any of your business, maybe.”
“Well I ’low I’ll make it my business.”
“Well why don’t you?”
“If you say much, I will.”
“Much—much—much. There now.”
“Oh, you think you’re mighty smart, don’t you? I could lick you with one hand tied behind me, if I wanted to.”
“Well why don’t you do it? You say you can do it.”
“Well I will, if you fool with me.”
“Oh yes—I’ve seen whole families in the same fix.”
“Smarty! You think you’re some, now, don’t you? Oh, what a hat!”
“You can lump that hat if you don’t like it. I dare you to knock it off—and anybody that’ll take a dare will suck eggs.”
“You’re a liar!”
“You’re another.”
“You’re a fighting liar and dasn’t take it up.”
“Aw—take a walk!”
“Say—if you give me much more of your sass I’ll take and bounce a rock off’n your head.”
“Oh, of course you will.”
“Well I will.”
“Well why don’t you do it then? What do you keep saying you will for? Why don’t you do it? It’s because you’re afraid.”
“I ain’t afraid.”
“You are.”

events.title: The Escalation to a Physical Fight
detailed_summary: Following another tense silence, the boys find themselves standing shoulder to shoulder.
Tom orders the new boy to leave, and the new boy issues the same command back to Tom, with both refusing to yield.
They brace themselves and begin shoving each other with all their strength, glaring hatefully, but neither can initially overpower the other.
After a heated struggle leaves them both flushed, they pause warily.
Tom insults the new boy, calling him a coward and a pup, and threatens to have his (fictional) older brother beat him up.
The new boy scoffs at this, claiming his own (also fictional) older brother is bigger and stronger.
Tom calls this a lie, and the new boy dismisses Tom's assertion.
Tom draws a line in the dirt with his toe, daring the new boy to cross it, promising a thrashing if he does and adding another taunt about dare-takers.
The new boy immediately steps over the line, challenging Tom to make good on his threat.
After more goading, the new boy mockingly offers Tom two copper coins from his pocket to fight.
Tom angrily knocks the coins to the ground, and the physical fight erupts instantly.
The boys grapple fiercely, pulling hair, tearing clothes, punching, and scratching, becoming covered in 'dust and glory'.
The chaotic struggle eventually sees Tom gain the advantage, pinning the new boy down and repeatedly hitting him with his fists.
Tom demands that the new boy surrender by saying "’Nuff!".

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Another pause, and more eying and sidling around each other.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Holler ’nuff!”—and the pounding went on.

events.text_segment:
Another pause, and more eying and sidling around each other. Presently they were shoulder to shoulder. Tom said:
“Get away from here!”
“Go away yourself!”
“I won’t.”
“I won’t either.”
So they stood, each with a foot placed at an angle as a brace, and both shoving with might and main, and glowering at each other with hate. But neither could get an advantage. After struggling till both were hot and flushed, each relaxed his strain with watchful caution, and Tom said:
“You’re a coward and a pup. I’ll tell my big brother on you, and he can thrash you with his little finger, and I’ll make him do it, too.”
“What do I care for your big brother? I’ve got a brother that’s bigger than he is—and what’s more, he can throw him over that fence, too.” [Both brothers were imaginary.]
“That’s a lie.”
“Your saying so don’t make it so.”
Tom drew a line in the dust with his big toe, and said:
“I dare you to step over that, and I’ll lick you till you can’t stand up. Anybody that’ll take a dare will steal sheep.”
The new boy stepped over promptly, and said:
“Now you said you’d do it, now let’s see you do it.”
“Don’t you crowd me now; you better look out.”
“Well, you said you’d do it—why don’t you do it?”
“By jingo! for two cents I will do it.”
The new boy took two broad coppers out of his pocket and held them out with derision. Tom struck them to the ground. In an instant both boys were rolling and tumbling in the dirt, gripped together like cats; and for the space of a minute they tugged and tore at each other’s hair and clothes, punched and scratched each other’s nose, and covered themselves with dust and glory. Presently the confusion took form, and through the fog of battle Tom appeared, seated astride the new boy, and pounding him with his fists. “Holler ’nuff!” said he.
The boy only struggled to free himself. He was crying—mainly from rage.
“Holler ’nuff!”—and the pounding went on.

Another pause, and more eying and sidling around each other. Tom Sawyer, with his quick wit and mischievous grin, was always on the lookout for the next adventure. He knew that the best stories came from moments like these, filled with silent signals and cautious movements. As he edged closer to the fence, he remembered the time he had convinced his friends to paint the fence for him, turning a chore into a game. The sun was shining brightly, casting long shadows over the dusty street, and the town was alive with the sounds of children playing and merchants calling out their wares.

Tom's eyes darted around, making sure no one was watching, before he slipped behind a corner. He was thinking about the treasure he had heard about from the old pirate stories, buried somewhere near the riverbank. His heart pounded with excitement at the thought of finding gold and becoming the richest boy in St. Petersburg. But first, he had to be careful, for Aunt Polly was always watching, and mischief was not appreciated in her house.

He remembered how he had once tricked Becky Thatcher into believing he was a pirate, complete with a makeshift sword and a ragged bandana. Becky had giggled and blushed, and Tom felt a surge of pride. He loved the thrill of the game, the secret whispers, and the stolen moments of joy. As he moved stealthily through the alleyways, he thought about the adventures that awaited him, the friends he would meet, and the stories he would tell.

Suddenly, he heard a voice calling his name. It was Sid, his younger brother, who was always eager to join in Tom's escapades. Tom quickly hid behind a barrel, holding his breath. He knew that today was going to be another day full of surprises, laughter, and perhaps a little bit of trouble. But that was the way of life in St. Petersburg, and Tom Sawyer was ready for whatever came next.

events.title: Tom's Victory, the New Boy's Retaliation, and Maternal Intervention
detailed_summary: Finally, the new boy manages to gasp out "’Nuff!", and Tom lets him up.

events.text_segment:
At last the stranger got out a smothered “’Nuff!” and Tom let him up and said:
“Now that’ll learn you. Better look out who you’re fooling with next time.”
The new boy went off brushing the dust from his clothes, sobbing, snuffling, and occasionally looking back and shaking his head and threatening what he would do to Tom the “next time he caught him out.” To which Tom responded with jeers, and started off in high feather, and as soon as his back was turned the new boy snatched up a stone, threw it and hit him between the shoulders and then turned tail and ran like an antelope. Tom chased the traitor home, and thus found out where he lived. He then held a position at the gate for some time, daring the enemy to come outside, but the enemy only made faces at him through the window and declined. At last the enemy’s mother appeared, and called Tom a bad, vicious, vulgar child, and ordered him away. So he went away; but he said he “’lowed” to “lay” for that boy.

events.title: Tom's Late Return and Aunt Polly's Unwavering Decision

When Aunt Polly observes the tattered and soiled condition of Tom's clothes, her determination to convert his anticipated Saturday holiday into a period of hard labor becomes unshakeably firm.

events.title: Tom's Whitewashing Punishment and Failed Bribe
detailed_summary: The chapter begins on a radiant summer Saturday, filled with life and cheer, providing a stark contrast to Tom Sawyer's mood.
Tom is introduced with whitewashing equipment, his spirits sinking as he faces the immense task of painting a very long and high fence.
He views life as empty and existence as a mere chore while contemplating the fence.
After a token effort, he sits down, feeling defeated.
Jim appears, heading to the town pump, a chore Tom usually detests but now sees as preferable due to the social activity at the pump.
Tom recalls that Jim typically takes over an hour to return with water from the nearby pump.
Tom proposes that he will fetch the water if Jim takes over the whitewashing.
Jim declines, stating that Aunt Polly explicitly forbade him from helping Tom with the whitewashing and told him to focus on his own tasks.
Tom attempts to persuade Jim by dismissing Aunt Polly's warnings and offering him a valuable marble, a 'white alley'.
Jim shows signs of being swayed by the offer of the marble.
Tom adds a further incentive by offering to show Jim his injured toe.
The combined allure of the marble and the sore toe proves too much for Jim; he sets down his pail and becomes engrossed in examining Tom's toe as the bandage is removed.

A moment later, Jim is seen hastily retreating down the street with his pail, nursing a sore backside, while Tom is energetically whitewashing, and Aunt Polly is withdrawing from the scene, slipper in hand, a look of triumph on her face.

events.text_segment:
Saturday morning was come, and all the summer world was bright and fresh, and brimming with life. There was a song in every heart; and if the heart was young the music issued at the lips. There was cheer in every face and a spring in every step. The locust-trees were in bloom and the fragrance of the blossoms filled the air. Cardiff Hill, beyond the village and above it, was green with vegetation and it lay just far enough away to seem a Delectable Land, dreamy, reposeful, and inviting.
Tom appeared on the sidewalk with a bucket of whitewash and a long-handled brush. He surveyed the fence, and all gladness left him and a deep melancholy settled down upon his spirit. Thirty yards of board fence nine feet high. Life to him seemed hollow, and existence but a burden. Sighing, he dipped his brush and passed it along the topmost plank; repeated the operation; did it again; compared the insignificant whitewashed streak with the far-reaching continent of unwhitewashed fence, and sat down on a tree-box discouraged. Jim came skipping out at the gate with a tin pail, and singing Buffalo Gals. Bringing water from the town pump had always been hateful work in Tom’s eyes, before, but now it did not strike him so. He remembered that there was company at the pump. White, mulatto, and negro boys and girls were always there waiting their turns, resting, trading playthings, quarrelling, fighting, skylarking. And he remembered that although the pump was only a hundred and fifty yards off, Jim never got back with a bucket of water under an hour—and even then somebody generally had to go after him. Tom said:
“Say, Jim, I’ll fetch the water if you’ll whitewash some.”
Jim shook his head and said:
“Can’t, Mars Tom. Ole missis, she tole me I got to go an’ git dis water an’ not stop foolin’ roun’ wid anybody. She say she spec’ Mars Tom gwine to ax me to whitewash, an’ so she tole me go ’long an’ ’tend to my own business—she ’lowed she’d ’tend to de whitewashin’.”
“Oh, never you mind what she said, Jim. That’s the way she always talks. Gimme the bucket—I won’t be gone only a a minute. She won’t ever know.”
“Oh, I dasn’t, Mars Tom. Ole missis she’d take an’ tar de head off’n me. ’Deed she would.”
“She! She never licks anybody—whacks ’em over the head with her thimble—and who cares for that, I’d like to know. She talks awful, but talk don’t hurt—anyways it don’t if she don’t cry. Jim, I’ll give you a marvel. I’ll give you a white alley!”
Jim began to waver.
“White alley, Jim! And it’s a bully taw.”
“My! Dat’s a mighty gay marvel, I tell you! But Mars Tom I’s powerful ’fraid ole missis—”
“And besides, if you will I’ll show you my sore toe.”
Jim was only human—this attraction was too much for him. He put down his pail, took the white alley, and bent over the toe with absorbing interest while the bandage was being unwound. In another moment he was flying down the street with his pail and a tingling rear, Tom was whitewashing with vigor, and Aunt Polly was retiring from the field with a slipper in her hand and triumph in her eye.

Tom Sawyer, with his whitewashing tools in hand, stood before a long, high fence, his spirits sinking as he contemplated the daunting task ahead. The day was radiant, filled with the cheerful hum of summer, yet Tom felt the weight of his chore, viewing life as an endless series of chores and chores alone. After a token effort, he sat down, feeling defeated, when Jim appeared, heading to the town pump—a task Tom usually detested but now seemed preferable due to the social activity at the pump. Tom added that he would show Jim his injured toe, further tempting him. The allure of the marble and the promise of seeing Tom's sore toe proved irresistible; Jim set down his pail and eagerly examined Tom's toe as the bandage was removed. Moments later, Jim hurried down the street with his pail, nursing a sore backside, while Tom continued whitewashing with energy, and Aunt Polly, with slipper in hand and a triumphant look, withdrew from the scene.

The birds were singing their most cheerful songs, and the air was filled with the sweet scent of blooming flowers. Tom Sawyer awoke early, feeling a thrill of excitement for the adventures that awaited him. He jumped out of bed, threw open his window, and looked out over the peaceful town, which seemed to be waking up along with him. The sun was shining brightly, casting a golden glow over the river and the fields beyond.

Tom hurriedly dressed himself, eager to start the day. He knew that today was a special day—perhaps the day he would find treasure, or have a daring adventure, or simply enjoy the carefree pleasures of childhood. As he ran downstairs, he could hear the lively chatter of Aunt Polly, who was busy preparing breakfast.

After a hearty meal, Tom decided to visit his friends. He ran to the riverbank, where Huck Finn and Joe Harper were already waiting. The boys greeted each other with excited shouts, their faces lit up with the joy of a summer morning. They planned to explore the island across the river, to see if they could find any hidden treasures or secret caves.

The trio set off, skipping stones and talking about their plans. The river was calm and inviting, reflecting the clear blue sky above. As they reached the island, they felt a sense of freedom and adventure. They wandered through the woods, climbing trees and pretending to be pirates or explorers.

Later, they discovered an old, abandoned hut, which they decided to investigate. Inside, they found strange markings on the walls and a rusty old chest. Their hearts pounded with excitement as they tried to open it, imagining it might contain gold or jewels. But the chest was locked, and they had no key.

As the day went on, the boys played games and swam in the river, their laughter echoing across the water. They built sandcastles and floated paper boats, enjoying the simple pleasures of summer. The sun climbed higher in the sky, and the heat became intense, but they didn't mind.

Meanwhile, back in town, Aunt Polly was worried about Tom. She knew he was out somewhere, having fun, but she also knew he needed to be careful. She looked out the window, hoping to catch a glimpse of him, and smiled when she saw him returning with Huck and Joe.

As evening approached, the boys made their way home, tired but happy. They promised to meet again the next day for more adventures. Tom felt a deep sense of contentment, grateful for the beautiful day and the friends he shared it with.

That night, as he lay in bed, Tom thought about all the exciting things he had experienced. He knew that childhood was a precious time, full of wonder and discovery. And he looked forward to many more days like this, where the world was bright and full of promise.

events.title: Despair and a Stroke of Genius
detailed_summary: Tom's newfound enthusiasm for whitewashing, prompted by Aunt Polly's intervention, quickly disappears.
He grows increasingly despondent as he reflects on the enjoyable activities he had planned for the day.
The prospect of other boys, free to enjoy themselves, arriving and ridiculing him for having to work torments him.
He takes out and examines his collection of personal belongings—various small toys, marbles, and other trinkets.
He concludes that his possessions might be sufficient to trade for a small amount of help, but are far from enough to secure even half an hour of genuine freedom.
Feeling disheartened, he puts his limited resources back into his pocket and dismisses the notion of trying to pay other boys to do his work.
At this moment of deep discouragement and hopelessness, a brilliant and magnificent idea strikes him.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: But Tom’s energy did not last.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Nothing less than a great, magnificent inspiration.

events.text_segment: But Tom’s energy did not last. He began to think of the fun he had planned for this day, and his sorrows multiplied. Soon the free boys would come tripping along on all sorts of delicious expeditions, and they would make a world of fun of him for having to work—the very thought of it burnt him like fire. He got out his worldly wealth and examined it—bits of toys, marbles, and trash; enough to buy an exchange of work, maybe, but not half enough to buy so much as half an hour of pure freedom. So he returned his straitened means to his pocket, and gave up the idea of trying to buy the boys. At this dark and hopeless moment an inspiration burst upon him! Nothing less than a great, magnificent inspiration.

events.text_segment:
He took up his brush and went tranquilly to work. Ben Rogers hove in sight presently—the very boy, of all boys, whose ridicule he had been dreading. Ben’s gait was the hop-skip-and-jump—proof enough that his heart was light and his anticipations high. He was eating an apple, and giving a long, melodious whoop, at intervals, followed by a deep-toned ding-dong-dong, ding-dong-dong, for he was personating a steamboat. As he drew near, he slackened speed, took the middle of the street, leaned far over to starboard and rounded to ponderously and with laborious pomp and circumstance—for he was personating the Big Missouri, and considered himself to be drawing nine feet of water. He was boat and captain and engine-bells combined, so he had to imagine himself standing on his own hurricane-deck giving the orders and executing them:
“Stop her, sir! Ting-a-ling-ling!” The headway ran almost out, and he drew up slowly toward the sidewalk.
“Ship up to back! Ting-a-ling-ling!” His arms straightened and stiffened down his sides.
“Set her back on the stabboard! Ting-a-ling-ling! Chow! ch-chow-wow! Chow!” His right hand, mean-time, describing stately circles—for it was representing a forty-foot wheel.
“Let her go back on the labboard! Ting-a-ling-ling! Chow-ch-chow-chow!” The left hand began to describe circles.
“Stop the stabboard! Ting-a-ling-ling! Stop the labboard! Come ahead on the stabboard! Stop her! Let your outside turn over slow! Ting-a-ling-ling! Chow-ow-ow! Get out that head-line! lively now! Come—out with your spring-line—what’re you about there! Take a turn round that stump with the bight of it! Stand by that stage, now—let her go! Done with the engines, sir! Ting-a-ling-ling! SH’T! S’H’T! SH’T!” (trying the gauge-cocks).
Tom went on whitewashing—paid no attention to the steamboat. Ben stared a moment and then said: “Hi-Yi! You’re up a stump, ain’t you!”
No answer. Tom surveyed his last touch with the eye of an artist, then he gave his brush another gentle sweep and surveyed the result, as before. Ben ranged up alongside of him. Tom’s mouth watered for the apple, but he stuck to his work. Ben said:
“Hello, old chap, you got to work, hey?”
Tom wheeled suddenly and said:
“Why, it’s you, Ben! I warn’t noticing.”
“Say—I’m going in a-swimming, I am. Don’t you wish you could? But of course you’d druther work—wouldn’t you? Course you would!”
Tom contemplated the boy a bit, and said:
“What do you call work?”
“Why, ain’t that work?”
Tom resumed his whitewashing, and answered carelessly:
“Well, maybe it is, and maybe it ain’t. All I know, is, it suits Tom Sawyer.”
“Oh come, now, you don’t mean to let on that you like it?”
The brush continued to move.
“Like it? Well, I don’t see why I oughtn’t to like it. Does a boy get a chance to whitewash a fence every day?”

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text: He took up his brush and went tranquilly to work. Just then, Ben Rogers appeared, the very boy whose mockery Tom had been dreading. Ben was in high spirits, hopping and skipping around as he mimicked a steamboat, making lively sounds and gestures. "Now, look out, do you see that?" he shouted, as he made a big hop, then a skip, then a jump, and then a loud chugging noise. "Big Missouri, coming through!" he yelled, puffing out his chest and waving his arms. "Port side!" he commanded, then made a whistling sound, and then a chugging noise again, as if the engine was working hard. He pretended to be the captain, giving orders and then acting as the engine, making the sounds and motions of a steamboat. "Approaching the dock!" he shouted, and performed a final series of hops and skips, ending with a loud chug and a bow. Then he turned to Tom, who continued whitewashing, deliberately ignoring him. Ben watched him for a moment, then called out, "Say, Tom, I bet you wish you could be doing something else!" Tom kept his eyes on his work, not replying. Ben came up beside him and said, "I’m going swimming now. You want to come? Or do you prefer to stay here and work?" Tom looked at him, then asked, "What do you call work?" "Whitewashing, of course," Ben said. "Well," Tom replied, "it may or may not be work, but I like it." Ben looked surprised. "You like it?" he asked. "Sure," Tom said, "a boy might get a chance to whitewash a fence every day."

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
He took up his brush and went tranquilly to work. The sun shone brightly through the window, casting a warm glow over the room. Tom Sawyer, with a mischievous grin, dipped his brush into the paint and began to cover the dull, gray wall with a fresh coat of white. His mind wandered to the adventures he had planned for the day, dreaming of pirates, treasure hunts, and daring escapes. As he worked, he hummed a tune softly, the melody floating through the air like a gentle breeze.

Tom's aunt, who was busy in the kitchen, glanced over at him with a mixture of amusement and mild exasperation. She knew that Tom's mind was often elsewhere, lost in his own world of imagination. Nevertheless, she appreciated his industriousness, even if it was sometimes a bit haphazard. Tom, noticing her gaze, paused for a moment and grinned sheepishly. Then, with a quick flick of his wrist, he continued his painting, eager to finish the task and move on to the next adventure.

The room was filled with the scent of fresh paint and the sounds of Tom's cheerful humming. Outside, the town was bustling with activity. Children played in the streets, and the townspeople went about their daily routines. Tom's friends, Joe and Huck, were somewhere nearby, probably plotting their next escapade. Tom often thought about how lucky he was to live in such a lively place, full of friends and endless possibilities.

As he painted, Tom's thoughts drifted to the treasure he had heard about from the older boys. He imagined himself as a brave pirate captain, commanding his crew to find the hidden gold. His eyes sparkled with excitement at the thought of the adventure that awaited him. He knew that tomorrow would bring new stories to tell and new challenges to face.

After a while, Tom stepped back to admire his work. The wall was now a pristine white, ready for the next coat or perhaps some creative decoration. He felt a sense of satisfaction, knowing he had completed his task, even if it was just a small part of the day's plans. With a quick glance at the clock, he decided it was time to set off on his next adventure.

He grabbed his slingshot and a handful of marbles, then slipped out of the house quietly, eager to join his friends. As he ran down the street, he couldn't help but smile, thinking of all the fun that lay ahead. The world was his playground, and he was determined to make the most of every moment, living each day with the spirit of a true adventurer.

events.title: The Art of Persuasion: Ben Rogers Pays to Work
detailed_summary: Tom's clever re-framing of whitewashing causes Ben to see the activity in a completely different way.
Ben stops eating his apple, becoming mesmerized as Tom skillfully applies the whitewash, occasionally stepping back to admire the effect and add precise touches.
Ben's interest and fascination intensify with each of Tom's movements.
Eventually, Ben asks Tom if he can try whitewashing for a bit.
Tom pretends to deliberate, almost agreeing, but then strategically changes his approach.
He explains that Aunt Polly is exceedingly particular about this specific fence because it faces the street, implying it requires extraordinary skill and care.
He asserts that likely not one boy in a thousand, or even two thousand, possesses the capability to do it to the required standard.
Ben, captivated by the alleged difficulty and exclusivity of the task, earnestly requests a chance to try, promising to be careful.
Tom heightens his feigned reluctance by mentioning that Aunt Polly had not allowed Jim or Sid to do it, emphasizing the dire consequences if anything were to go amiss with the fence.
Ben, now quite eager, offers Tom the core of his apple as payment for the opportunity to paint.
Tom continues to act hesitant.
Ben then offers his entire apple.
Tom, displaying outward reluctance but feeling internal triumph, relinquishes the brush.

While Ben, formerly the 'steamer Big Missouri,' labors and sweats under the sun, Tom, the 'retired artist,' relaxes on a barrel in the shade, enjoying the apple and plotting how to entice more unsuspecting boys.

events.text_segment:
That put the thing in a new light. Ben stopped nibbling his apple. Tom swept his brush daintily back and forth—stepped back to note the effect—added a touch here and there—criticised the effect again—Ben watching every move and getting more and more interested, more and more absorbed. Presently he said:
“Say, Tom, let me whitewash a little.”
Tom considered, was about to consent; but he altered his mind:
“No—no—I reckon it wouldn’t hardly do, Ben. You see, Aunt Polly’s awful particular about this fence—right here on the street, you know—but if it was the back fence I wouldn’t mind and she wouldn’t. Yes, she’s awful particular about this fence; it’s got to be done very careful; I reckon there ain’t one boy in a thousand, maybe two thousand, that can do it the way it’s got to be done.”
“No—is that so? Oh come, now—lemme just try. Only just a little—I’d let you, if you was me, Tom.”
“Ben, I’d like to, honest injun; but Aunt Polly—well, Jim wanted to do it, but she wouldn’t let him; Sid wanted to do it, and she wouldn’t let Sid. Now don’t you see how I’m fixed? If you was to tackle this fence and anything was to happen to it—”
“Oh, shucks, I’ll be just as careful. Now lemme try. Say—I’ll give you the core of my apple.”
“Well, here—No, Ben, now don’t. I’m afeard—”
“I’ll give you all of it!”
Tom gave up the brush with reluctance in his face, but alacrity in his heart. And while the late steamer Big Missouri worked and sweated in the sun, the retired artist sat on a barrel in the shade close by, dangled his legs, munched his apple, and planned the slaughter of more innocents.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
```plaintext
CHAPTER II

That put the thing in a new light.

Tom Sawyer took up the brush and began whitewashing. He worked carefully and skillfully, stepping back now and then to admire his work, occasionally adding a precise touch here and there. Ben Rogers watched him, fascinated, and as Tom continued, Ben's interest grew. At last, Ben stopped eating his apple and said, "Say, Tom, let me try." Tom hesitated a moment, then said, "Well, I don't know—Aunt Polly's particular about this fence. It's facing the street, you know, and she says it has to be done just right." He looked serious. "I reckon not many boys can do it to her satisfaction." Ben looked eager. "Please, Tom! I’ll be careful." Tom pretended to think it over. "I don’t know—Aunt Polly’s never let Jim or Sid do it. If I let you, and you spoil it, I’d get into trouble." Ben was persistent. "I’ll be careful, honest." He offered Tom his apple. "Here, take my apple if I can try." Tom looked hesitant. "Well, all right," he said, finally. Ben eagerly took the brush and began whitewashing, while Tom watched, pretending to be reluctant but feeling secretly pleased. Ben worked hard, sweating under the sun, while Tom, the 'retired artist,' relaxed on a barrel in the shade, enjoying his apple and thinking about how to get more boys to do his work for him.
```

events.title: Tom's Thriving Whitewashing Enterprise
detailed_summary: Tom discovers an ample supply of boys eager to take on the whitewashing chore.
Boys who initially approach with the intention of teasing Tom find themselves persuaded to stay and paint.
After Ben Rogers becomes tired, Tom barters the next opportunity to whitewash to Billy Fisher in exchange for a kite in good condition.
Once Billy Fisher has had his turn, Johnny Miller secures his chance by trading a dead rat and a string to swing it with.
This process of trading privileges for treasures continues hour after hour with a succession of different boys.
By the middle of the afternoon, Tom, who had begun the day feeling impoverished, has amassed considerable wealth.

His collection of acquired goods includes twelve marbles, a part of a jew's-harp, a piece of blue bottle-glass for looking through, a spool cannon, a key that unlocks nothing, a fragment of chalk, a glass decanter stopper, a tin soldier, a couple of tadpoles, six fire-crackers, a kitten with only one eye, a brass doorknob, a dog-collar (but no dog), the handle of a knife, four pieces of orange-peel, and a dilapidated old window sash.
Throughout this entire period, Tom has enjoyed a pleasant, idle time with plenty of company.
Remarkably, the fence has received three complete coats of whitewash.
The narrator remarks that if Tom's supply of whitewash had not run out, he would have managed to acquire all the possessions of every boy in the village.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: There was no lack of material; boys happened along every little while; they came to jeer, but remained to whitewash.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: If he hadn’t run out of whitewash he would have bankrupted every boy in the village.

events.text_segment:
There was no lack of material; boys happened along every little while; they came to jeer, but remained to whitewash. By the time Ben was fagged out, Tom had traded the next chance to Billy Fisher for a kite, in good repair; and when he played out, Johnny Miller bought in for a dead rat and a string to swing it with—and so on, and so on, hour after hour. And when the middle of the afternoon came, from being a poor poverty-stricken boy in the morning, Tom was literally rolling in wealth. He had besides the things before mentioned, twelve marbles, part of a jews-harp, a piece of blue bottle-glass to look through, a spool cannon, a key that wouldn’t unlock anything, a fragment of chalk, a glass stopper of a decanter, a tin soldier, a couple of tadpoles, six fire-crackers, a kitten with only one eye, a brass door-knob, a dog-collar—but no dog—the handle of a knife, four pieces of orange-peel, and a dilapidated old window sash.
He had had a nice, good, idle time all the while—plenty of company—and the fence had three coats of whitewash on it! If he hadn’t run out of whitewash he would have bankrupted every boy in the village.

events.title: Tom's Discovery of a Human Action Law and Departure
detailed_summary: Tom reflects to himself that the world is not as dismal as he had initially perceived it to be.
He has, without formally recognizing it, uncovered a significant principle of human behavior: that making something difficult to achieve is the key to making others desire it.

The narrator interjects with a philosophical observation, suggesting that if Tom were a profound thinker, he would now grasp that 'Work' is defined by any activity one is compelled to do, whereas 'Play' encompasses any activity one is not compelled to do.

This distinction, the narrator elaborates, helps to explain why tasks like creating artificial flowers or operating a treadmill are considered work, while activities such as playing ten-pins or climbing Mont Blanc are mere amusements.

An example is provided of affluent gentlemen in England who pay a considerable sum for the privilege of driving four-horse passenger coaches daily, but would likely resign if offered wages for the same service, as payment would transform it into work.
Tom briefly ponders the substantial improvement in his material wealth and circumstances.
He then makes his way towards 'headquarters,' presumably his home, to report on the day's accomplishments or the completion of his task.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Tom said to himself that it was not such a hollow world, after all.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The boy mused awhile over the substantial change which had taken place in his worldly circumstances, and then wended toward headquarters to report.

events.text_segment:
Tom said to himself that it was not such a hollow world, after all. He had discovered a great law of human action, without knowing it—namely, that in order to make a man or a boy covet a thing, it is only necessary to make the thing difficult to attain. If he had been a great and wise philosopher, like the writer of this book, he would now have comprehended that Work consists of whatever a body is obliged to do, and that Play consists of whatever a body is not obliged to do. And this would help him to understand why constructing artificial flowers or performing on a tread-mill is work, while rolling ten-pins or climbing Mont Blanc is only amusement. There are wealthy gentlemen in England who drive four-horse passenger-coaches twenty or thirty miles on a daily line, in the summer, because the privilege costs them considerable money; but if they were offered wages for the service, that would turn it into work and then they would resign.
The boy mused awhile over the substantial change which had taken place in his worldly circumstances, and then wended toward headquarters to report.

events.title: Tom's Whitewashing Triumph and Cunning Reward
detailed_summary: Tom approached Aunt Polly, who was resting by an open window, surrounded by the peaceful atmosphere of a summer day.
Aunt Polly, who had assumed Tom had long since abandoned his chore, was surprised by his appearance and his claim that he was ready to play.
When Tom asserted that the fence whitewashing was entirely completed, Aunt Polly expressed her disbelief and warned him against lying.
Still skeptical, Aunt Polly went to inspect the fence herself, expecting to find only a small portion of the work done.
She was profoundly astonished to discover the entire fence not only whitewashed but meticulously coated multiple times, with even the ground showing signs of thoroughness.
Impressed, she acknowledged Tom's capability to work diligently when he set his mind to it, though she remarked on the rarity of such occasions.
Overcome by his achievement, she took him to the closet, gave him a choice apple, and delivered a lecture on the enhanced satisfaction of rewards earned through virtuous effort.
While Aunt Polly concluded her lecture with a scriptural reference, Tom slyly pilfered a doughnut.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Tom presented himself before Aunt Polly, who was sitting by an open window in a pleasant rearward apartment, which was bedroom, breakfast-room, dining-room, and library, combined.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And while she closed with a happy Scriptural flourish, he “hooked” a doughnut.

events.text_segment:
Tom presented himself before Aunt Polly, who was sitting by an open window in a pleasant rearward apartment, which was bedroom, breakfast-room, dining-room, and library, combined. The balmy summer air, the restful quiet, the odor of the flowers, and the drowsing murmur of the bees had had their effect, and she was nodding over her knitting—for she had no company but the cat, and it was asleep in her lap. Her spectacles were propped up on her gray head for safety. She had thought that of course Tom had deserted long ago, and she wondered at seeing him place himself in her power again in this intrepid way. He said: “Mayn’t I go and play now, aunt?”
“What, a’ready? How much have you done?”
“It’s all done, aunt.”
“Tom, don’t lie to me—I can’t bear it.”
“I ain’t, aunt; it is all done.”
Aunt Polly placed small trust in such evidence. She went out to see for herself; and she would have been content to find twenty per cent. of Tom’s statement true. When she found the entire fence white-washed, and not only whitewashed but elaborately coated and recoated, and even a streak added to the ground, her astonishment was almost unspeakable. She said:
“Well, I never! There’s no getting round it, you can work when you’re a mind to, Tom.” And then she diluted the compliment by adding, “But it’s powerful seldom you’re a mind to, I’m bound to say. Well, go ’long and play; but mind you get back some time in a week, or I’ll tan you.”
She was so overcome by the splendor of his achievement that she took him into the closet and selected a choice apple and delivered it to him, along with an improving lecture upon the added value and flavor a treat took to itself when it came without sin through virtuous effort. And while she closed with a happy Scriptural flourish, he “hooked” a doughnut.

The air was filled with the scent of flowers and the hum of bees, and Aunt Polly, with her spectacles on her nose and the cat in her lap, was dozing in the warm summer sunlight. She was surprised to see Tom, who had been gone so long, and even more so when he declared that he was ready to play. Aunt Polly looked at him with a mixture of suspicion and affection, and asked if he had finished his whitewashing. Tom, with a confident grin, said he had, and that the fence was all done. Aunt Polly, expecting to find only a small patch, rose and went out to inspect. To her astonishment, she found the entire fence not only whitewashed but coated several times, with the ground around it also showing signs of thorough work. She looked at Tom with a mixture of admiration and mild reproach, saying, 'Well, I do believe you can work when you set your mind to it, Tom.' Then she took him to the closet, gave him a choice apple, and said, 'Now, Tom, you’ve earned this, and I hope you’ll remember that honest work is its own reward.' As she concluded her lecture with a scriptural reference, Tom, with a sly look, reached out and pilfered a doughnut from the jar, slipping it into his pocket unnoticed.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
He looked as innocent as possible, with his hands behind his back and a bright, eager smile on his face. Aunt Polly, a stout woman with a kind but firm face, scrutinized him carefully. She had a way of knowing when Tom was up to something, and today was no exception. Tom shifted his weight from one foot to the other, trying to appear as if he had done nothing wrong.

"Well, Tom," she said, her voice gentle but firm, "what have you been up to today?"

Tom hesitated for a moment, then decided to tell the truth, or at least part of it. "I was just exploring the woods, Aunt Polly. I found a new place to play."

Aunt Polly raised an eyebrow. "Exploring the woods, eh? Did you stay out of trouble?"

"Yes, ma'am," Tom replied quickly, though he knew he was not entirely truthful.

She looked at him with a mixture of affection and suspicion. "You know, Tom, I can always tell when you're hiding something."

Tom's eyes darted around the room, searching for a way out of the conversation. He knew he had to be careful. Aunt Polly was wise and kind, but she also had a sharp eye for mischief.

"I didn't mean to cause any trouble," Tom said, trying to sound sincere. "I just wanted to see if I could find some treasure or something interesting."

Aunt Polly chuckled softly. "Well, Tom, the only treasure I want you to find is your good manners and honesty. Now, go wash up for breakfast."

Tom nodded eagerly and scampered off, already planning his next adventure. As he left the room, he couldn't help but feel a thrill of excitement, knowing that the day was still young and full of possibilities.

events.title: Retaliation against Sid and Military Victory
detailed_summary: After leaving Aunt Polly, Tom spotted Sid on an outside stairway.
He quickly gathered clods of earth and launched an assault on Sid, pelting him vigorously.
Before Aunt Polly could react to the commotion and come to Sid's aid, Tom had landed several clods and vaulted over the fence to escape.
He bypassed the gate, as he often did when in a hurry, feeling a sense of peace now that he had retaliated against Sid for getting him into trouble earlier.
Tom then made his way to the village's public square where two rival companies of boys were scheduled to engage in a mock battle.
Tom served as the General for one army, while his close friend, Joe Harper, commanded the other.
The two generals did not participate directly in the fighting but supervised the conflict from a higher vantage point, issuing orders through their aides.
Tom's army emerged victorious after a prolonged and intense struggle.
Following the battle, casualties were tallied, prisoners were exchanged, and arrangements were made for their next confrontation, after which the armies marched off and Tom headed home alone.

events.text_segment:
Then he skipped out, and saw Sid just starting up the outside stairway that led to the back rooms on the second floor. Clods were handy and the air was full of them in a twinkling. They raged around Sid like a hail-storm; and before Aunt Polly could collect her surprised faculties and sally to the rescue, six or seven clods had taken personal effect, and Tom was over the fence and gone. There was a gate, but as a general thing he was too crowded for time to make use of it. His soul was at peace, now that he had settled with Sid for calling attention to his black thread and getting him into trouble.
Tom skirted the block, and came round into a muddy alley that led by the back of his aunt’s cow-stable. He presently got safely beyond the reach of capture and punishment, and hastened toward the public square of the village, where two “military” companies of boys had met for conflict, according to previous appointment. Tom was General of one of these armies, Joe Harper (a bosom friend) General of the other. These two great commanders did not condescend to fight in person—that being better suited to the still smaller fry—but sat together on an eminence and conducted the field operations by orders delivered through aides-de-camp. Tom’s army won a great victory, after a long and hard-fought battle. Then the dead were counted, prisoners exchanged, the terms of the next disagreement agreed upon, and the day for the necessary battle appointed; after which the armies fell into line and marched away, and Tom turned homeward alone.

events.title: Encounter with a New Girl and Instant Infatuation
detailed_summary: As Tom passed by Jeff Thatcher's house, he saw an unfamiliar girl in the garden.
He was immediately struck by her appearance: she had blue eyes, yellow hair in two long braids, and was wearing a white summer dress with embroidered pantalettes.
The sight of this new girl caused Tom, the recent military hero, to fall instantly in love.
In that moment, any memory or affection for Amy Lawrence completely vanished from his heart.
He had previously believed himself to be deeply in love with Amy, considering his feelings an adoration, but now recognized it as a mere fleeting partiality.

Despite having spent months winning Amy's affection, culminating in her confession of love just a week prior and making him feel like the happiest boy alive, she was now erased from his affections as if she were a casual acquaintance.

The fresh-crowned hero fell without firing a shot. A certain Amy Lawrence vanished out of his heart and left not even a memory of herself behind. He had thought he loved her to distraction; he had regarded his passion as adoration; and behold it was only a poor little evanescent partiality. He had been months winning her; she had confessed hardly a week ago; he had been the happiest and the proudest boy in the world only seven short days, and here in one instant of time she had gone out of his heart like a casual stranger whose visit is done.

events.title: Tom's Awkward Courtship and a Floral Token
detailed_summary: Tom secretly admired the new girl until he realized she had noticed him.
He then pretended not to be aware of her presence and began to conspicuously show off through various exaggerated, boyish actions, hoping to gain her admiration.
He persisted in these absurd displays for some time.
While in the middle of a particularly daring gymnastic feat, he glanced aside and saw the girl walking towards her house.
Feeling a pang of disappointment, Tom went to the fence and leaned on it, hoping she might linger a little longer.
She paused for a moment on the steps before moving towards the door.
As she was about to enter, Tom sighed heavily, but his expression brightened immediately when she tossed a pansy over the fence to him just before disappearing inside.

Tom came up to the fence and leaned on it, grieving, and hoping she would tarry yet awhile longer. She halted a moment on the steps and then moved toward the door. Tom heaved a great sigh as she put her foot on the threshold. But his face lit up, right away, for she tossed a pansy over the fence a moment before she disappeared.

events.title: Securing the Pansy and Lingering Hope
detailed_summary: Tom approached the spot where the pansy landed, then feigned distraction by looking down the street as if something interesting were happening there.
He picked up a straw and began trying to balance it on his nose, tilting his head back, and subtly edged closer to the flower with each movement.
Eventually, he positioned his bare foot over the pansy, curled his toes around it, and hopped away with his newfound treasure, disappearing around a corner.
He was gone only briefly, just long enough to secure the flower inside his jacket, near his heart—or possibly his stomach, as his anatomical knowledge was limited.
He then returned to the vicinity of the fence and continued his
showing off
antics until nightfall.
The girl did not reappear, though Tom consoled himself with the possibility that she might have been watching him from a window and noticed his efforts.
Finally, he reluctantly headed home, his mind filled with visions of the new girl.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Finally he strode home reluctantly, with his poor head full of visions.

events.text_segment:
The boy ran around and stopped within a foot or two of the flower, and then shaded his eyes with his hand and began to look down street as if he had discovered something of interest going on in that direction. Presently he picked up a straw and began trying to balance it on his nose, with his head tilted far back; and as he moved from side to side, in his efforts, he edged nearer and nearer toward the pansy; finally his bare foot rested upon it, his pliant toes closed upon it, and he hopped away with the treasure and disappeared round the corner. But only for a minute—only while he could button the flower inside his jacket, next his heart—or next his stomach, possibly, for he was not much posted in anatomy, and not hypercritical, anyway.
He returned, now, and hung about the fence till nightfall, “showing off,” as before; but the girl never exhibited herself again, though Tom comforted himself a little with the hope that she had been near some window, meantime, and been aware of his attentions. Finally he strode home reluctantly, with his poor head full of visions.

Eventually, he positioned his bare foot over the pansy, curled his toes around it, and hopped away with his newfound treasure, disappearing around a corner. He was gone only briefly, just long enough to secure the flower inside his jacket, near his heart—or possibly his stomach, as his anatomical knowledge was limited. He then returned to the vicinity of the fence and continued his showing off antics until nightfall. The girl did not reappear, though Tom consoled himself with the possibility that she might have been watching him from a window and noticed his efforts. Finally, he reluctantly headed home, his mind filled with visions of the new girl.

events.title: Supper Antics, Scolding, and Sid's Sugar Bowl Mishap
detailed_summary: During supper, Tom's exuberant mood was so noticeable that Aunt Polly wondered about its cause.
He received a scolding for pelting Sid with clods earlier but seemed entirely unbothered by it.
He then attempted to sneak some sugar right under Aunt Polly's watch and received a rap on his knuckles for his audacity.
Tom pointed out that Sid was not punished for taking sugar.
Aunt Polly responded that Sid did not cause trouble the way Tom did and that Tom would constantly be into the sugar if not watched.
Shortly after, Aunt Polly went to the kitchen.
Sid, enjoying his perceived immunity and perhaps trying to gloat over Tom, reached for the sugar-bowl.
However, Sid's fingers slipped, and the sugar bowl fell and broke, much to Tom's delight as he foresaw Sid being blamed.

events.text_segment:
All through supper his spirits were so high that his aunt wondered “what had got into the child.” He took a good scolding about clodding Sid, and did not seem to mind it in the least. He tried to steal sugar under his aunt’s very nose, and got his knuckles rapped for it. He said:
“Aunt, you don’t whack Sid when he takes it.”
“Well, Sid don’t torment a body the way you do. You’d be always into that sugar if I warn’t watching you.”
Presently she stepped into the kitchen, and Sid, happy in his immunity, reached for the sugar-bowl—a sort of glorying over Tom which was wellnigh unbearable. But Sid’s fingers slipped and the bowl dropped and broke. Tom was in ecstasies. In such ecstasies that he even controlled his tongue and was silent. He said to himself that he would not speak a word, even when his aunt came in, but would sit perfectly still till she asked who did the mischief; and then he would tell, and there would be nothing so good in the world as to see that pet model “catch it.” He was so brimful of exultation that he could hardly hold himself when the old lady came back and stood above the wreck discharging lightnings of wrath from over her spectacles.

events.title: Misplaced Blame, Aunt Polly's Dilemma, and Tom's Melodramatic Sulk
detailed_summary: Tom eagerly anticipated Aunt Polly's return, planning to remain silent until asked and then reveal Sid as the one who broke the sugar bowl.
When Aunt Polly returned and saw the shattered bowl, her anger flared.
To Tom's utter dismay, she immediately blamed him and struck him, causing him to sprawl on the floor.
As she raised her hand to strike again, Tom cried out that Sid was the culprit.
Aunt Polly paused, looking perplexed, while Tom hoped for her sympathy.
However, she dismissed his plea, stating that he likely deserved the punishment for some other unobserved mischief.
Her conscience pricked her, and she felt a desire to say something kind, but she refrained, believing it would be seen as an admission of error and would undermine discipline.

Tom retreated to a corner to sulk, indulging in dramatic fantasies of his suffering, imagining himself dying while Aunt Polly begged for his forgiveness, or being brought home drowned, to her immense sorrow and regret.
These thoughts moved him to tears, and he relished the tragic nature of his imagined plight.
When his cousin Mary entered cheerfully, her joy clashing with his somber mood, Tom got up and left the room, enveloped in his own gloom.

events.text_segment:
He said to himself, “Now it’s coming!” And the next instant he was sprawling on the floor! The potent palm was uplifted to strike again when Tom cried out:
“Hold on, now, what ’er you belting me for?—Sid broke it!”
Aunt Polly paused, perplexed, and Tom looked for healing pity. But when she got her tongue again, she only said:
“Umf! Well, you didn’t get a lick amiss, I reckon. You been into some other audacious mischief when I wasn’t around, like enough.”
Then her conscience reproached her, and she yearned to say something kind and loving; but she judged that this would be construed into a confession that she had been in the wrong, and discipline forbade that. So she kept silence, and went about her affairs with a troubled heart. Tom sulked in a corner and exalted his woes. He knew that in her heart his aunt was on her knees to him, and he was morosely gratified by the consciousness of it. He would hang out no signals, he would take notice of none. He knew that a yearning glance fell upon him, now and then, through a film of tears, but he refused recognition of it. He pictured himself lying sick unto death and his aunt bending over him beseeching one little forgiving word, but he would turn his face to the wall, and die with that word unsaid. Ah, how would she feel then? And he pictured himself brought home from the river, dead, with his curls all wet, and his sore heart at rest. How she would throw herself upon him, and how her tears would fall like rain, and her lips pray God to give her back her boy and she would never, never abuse him any more! But he would lie there cold and white and make no sign—a poor little sufferer, whose griefs were at an end. He so worked upon his feelings with the pathos of these dreams, that he had to keep swallowing, he was so like to choke; and his eyes swam in a blur of water, which overflowed when he winked, and ran down and trickled from the end of his nose. And such a luxury to him was this petting of his sorrows, that he could not bear to have any worldly cheeriness or any grating delight intrude upon it; it was too sacred for such contact; and so, presently, when his cousin Mary danced in, all alive with the joy of seeing home again after an age-long visit of one week to the country, he got up and moved in clouds and darkness out at one door as she brought song and sunshine in at the other.
