events.title: Tom's Romantic Despair and Riverbank Contemplation
detailed_summary: Tom wandered away from his usual play areas, seeking out desolate locations that resonated with his melancholic state.
He found a log raft on the river and sat on its edge, gazing at the dreary expanse of water, wishing he could drown suddenly and without discomfort.
He then remembered the flower the girl had given him. He took it out; it was rumpled and wilted.
The sight of the flower greatly amplified his sorrowful yet strangely satisfying mood.
He wondered if the girl would feel pity for him if she knew of his suffering.
He imagined whether she would cry and wish she could comfort him, or if she would, like the rest of the unfeeling world, turn away coldly.
This vision of
pleasurable suffering
captivated him so much that he replayed it in his mind repeatedly, exploring different variations, until the idea became worn out.
Finally, sighing, he rose and walked off into the darkness.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He wandered far from the accustomed haunts of boys, and sought desolate places that were in harmony with his spirit.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: At last he rose up sighing and departed in the darkness.

events.text_segment: He wandered far from the accustomed haunts of boys, and sought desolate places that were in harmony with his spirit. A log raft in the river invited him, and he seated himself on its outer edge and contemplated the dreary vastness of the stream, wishing, the while, that he could only be drowned, all at once and unconsciously, without undergoing the uncomfortable routine devised by nature. Then he thought of his flower. He got it out, rumpled and wilted, and it mightily increased his dismal felicity. He wondered if she would pity him if she knew? Would she cry, and wish that she had a right to put her arms around his neck and comfort him? Or would she turn coldly away like all the hollow world? This picture brought such an agony of pleasurable suffering that he worked it over and over again in his mind and set it up in new and varied lights, till he wore it threadbare. At last he rose up sighing and departed in the darkness.

events.title: Nocturnal Vigil, Tragic Fantasies, and a Drenching Interruption
detailed_summary: Around nine-thirty or ten o'clock at night, Tom walked along the deserted street to the house where the girl he admired lived.
He paused, listening for any sound, and noticed a faint candlelight glowing through a curtain in a second-story window, wondering if she was inside.
He climbed the fence, moved stealthily through the plants, and positioned himself directly under the window.
He looked up at it for a long time with deep emotion.
Then, he lay down on his back on the ground beneath the window, hands clasped on his chest, holding the wilted pansy.
He imagined himself dying there in the cold, homeless and uncared for, with no one to comfort him in his final moments.
He envisioned the girl discovering his lifeless body in the morning and perhaps shedding a tear for his tragic, untimely demise.
Suddenly, the window above him opened, and a maid-servant's harsh voice shattered the quiet.
A large amount of water was thrown from the window, drenching Tom where he lay.

events.text_segment:
About half-past nine or ten o’clock he came along the deserted street to where the Adored Unknown lived; he paused a moment; no sound fell upon his listening ear; a candle was casting a dull glow upon the curtain of a second-story window. Was the sacred presence there? He climbed the fence, threaded his stealthy way through the plants, till he stood under that window; he looked up at it long, and with emotion; then he laid him down on the ground under it, disposing himself upon his back, with his hands clasped upon his breast and holding his poor wilted flower. And thus he would die—out in the cold world, with no shelter over his homeless head, no friendly hand to wipe the death-damps from his brow, no loving face to bend pityingly over him when the great agony came. And thus she would see him when she looked out upon the glad morning, and oh! would she drop one little tear upon his poor, lifeless form, would she heave one little sigh to see a bright young life so rudely blighted, so untimely cut down?
The window went up, a maid-servant’s discordant voice profaned the holy calm, and a deluge of water drenched the prone martyr’s remains!

Tom turned in without the added vexation of prayers, and Sid made mental note of the omission.

events.title: Tom's Struggle with Bible Verses and a Prized Reward
detailed_summary: The day commenced with Aunt Polly conducting family worship, which involved a prayer constructed from Scriptural quotes and a reading from the Mosaic Law.
Tom then faced the task of memorizing his Bible verses, a chore Sid had accomplished days prior.
He chose five verses from the Sermon on the Mount for their brevity but struggled to focus, his mind drifting and his hands engaged in other activities.
Mary tried to assist him with his recitation, but Tom fumbled through the lines, needing constant prompting.
After expressing frustration and accusing Mary of being unkind, she gently encouraged him, offering a desirable reward for his success.
Spurred by curiosity and the promise of a prize, Tom applied himself earnestly and managed to learn the verses.
As a reward, Mary presented him with a new Barlow knife, valued at twelve and a half cents, which filled Tom with immense joy.
Despite the knife's poor cutting ability, Tom treasured it as a genuine Barlow, perceiving great value in it, and began to use it on furniture before being called to get ready for Sunday-school.

events.text_segment:
The sun rose upon a tranquil world, and beamed down upon the peaceful village like a benediction. Breakfast over, Aunt Polly had family worship: it began with a prayer built from the ground up of solid courses of Scriptural quotations, welded together with a thin mortar of originality; and from the summit of this she delivered a grim chapter of the Mosaic Law, as from Sinai.
Then Tom girded up his loins, so to speak, and went to work to “get his verses.” Sid had learned his lesson days before. Tom bent all his energies to the memorizing of five verses, and he chose part of the Sermon on the Mount, because he could find no verses that were shorter. At the end of half an hour Tom had a vague general idea of his lesson, but no more, for his mind was traversing the whole field of human thought, and his hands were busy with distracting recreations. Mary took his book to hear him recite, and he tried to find his way through the fog:
“Blessed are the—a—a—”
“Poor”—
“Yes—poor; blessed are the poor—a—a—”
“In spirit—”
“In spirit; blessed are the poor in spirit, for they—they—”
“Theirs—”
“For theirs. Blessed are the poor in spirit, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven. Blessed are they that mourn, for they—they—”
“Sh—”
“For they—a—”
“S, H, A—”
“For they S, H—Oh, I don’t know what it is!”
“Shall!”
“Oh, shall! for they shall—for they shall—a—a—shall mourn—a—a—blessed are they that shall—they that—a—they that shall mourn, for they shall—a—shall what? Why don’t you tell me, Mary?—what do you want to be so mean for?”
“Oh, Tom, you poor thick-headed thing, I’m not teasing you. I wouldn’t do that. You must go and learn it again. Don’t you be discouraged, Tom, you’ll manage it—and if you do, I’ll give you something ever so nice. There, now, that’s a good boy.”
“All right! What is it, Mary, tell me what it is.”
“Never you mind, Tom. You know if I say it’s nice, it is nice.”
“You bet you that’s so, Mary. All right, I’ll tackle it again.”
And he did “tackle it again”—and under the double pressure of curiosity and prospective gain he did it with such spirit that he accomplished a shining success. Mary gave him a brand-new “Barlow” knife worth twelve and a half cents; and the convulsion of delight that swept his system shook him to his foundations. True, the knife would not cut anything, but it was a “sure-enough” Barlow, and there was inconceivable grandeur in that—though where the Western boys ever got the idea that such a weapon could possibly be counterfeited to its injury is an imposing mystery and will always remain so, perhaps. Tom contrived to scarify the cupboard with it, and was arranging to begin on the bureau, when he was called off to dress for Sunday-school.

In the midst of this serenity, Tom Sawyer awoke with a start, his eyes gleaming with the mischief that was his hallmark. Today was a day filled with promise and adventure, and he could hardly contain his excitement. As he swung his legs over the side of his bed, he thought of the endless possibilities that awaited him. Perhaps he would explore the mysterious island beyond the river, or maybe he would outwit the town's most cunning boys in a game of pirates and treasure.

Tom's room was a cluttered testament to his lively spirit—books, toys, and bits of string lay scattered about, each telling a story of his recent escapades. He hurriedly dressed, donning his old trousers and a shirt that had seen better days, eager to seize the day. Outside, the village was already stirring; Mrs. Thatcher was calling her children to breakfast, and the blacksmith's forge was sending up plumes of smoke.

As Tom stepped outside, he was greeted by the warm embrace of the morning sun and the cheerful chirping of birds. He ran to the riverbank, where he often found solace and inspiration. The water shimmered like a mirror, reflecting the clear blue sky and the fluffy clouds drifting lazily above. Tom's mind raced with ideas—perhaps he would find a hidden cave, or stumble upon a buried treasure.

He remembered the stories of pirates and explorers he had read in his favorite books, and his heart beat faster at the thought of adventure. With a quick glance around to ensure no one was watching, he slipped a small knife into his pocket—just in case. He was determined to make this day unforgettable.

Suddenly, a shout broke the peaceful morning. It was Huck Finn, waving from across the street, beckoning Tom to join him. Without hesitation, Tom sprinted towards his friend, eager to share his plans. Together, they plotted their next move, their imaginations transforming the mundane into the extraordinary.

As the sun climbed higher, casting golden hues over the village, Tom and Huck set off towards the woods, their hearts pounding with excitement. Little did they know that today would bring them face to face with a real adventure—one that would test their courage and friendship, and become a story they would tell for years to come.

events.title: Tom's Reluctant Sunday School Preparations
detailed_summary: Mary provided Tom with a basin of water and soap for washing.
Tom attempted to evade a thorough washing by merely going through the motions and then drying his face in the kitchen.
Mary caught his deception, refilled the basin, and insisted he wash properly, reminding him that water is not harmful.
After some hesitation, Tom washed his face, emerging with soap and water as evidence but with a clear demarcation line at his chin and neck, leaving the lower areas unwashed.
Mary intervened and completed his grooming, ensuring he was clean all over, and his wet hair was neatly brushed into curls.
Tom, disliking curls which he considered effeminate, secretly tried to flatten his hair.
Mary then laid out his Sunday suit, referred to as his "other clothes," indicating his limited wardrobe.

After Tom dressed, Mary made final adjustments, buttoning his roundabout, arranging his collar, brushing him, and placing his hat on his head, resulting in an improved but uncomfortable appearance for Tom.
Tom felt constrained by the cleanliness and formal attire and hoped Mary would forget his shoes, but she polished them with tallow and presented them.
He expressed his irritation at being forced to do things he disliked, but Mary's persuasive appeal led him to put on the shoes grudgingly.
Soon after, Mary, Tom, and Sid departed for Sunday-school, an institution Tom deeply disliked, unlike his siblings.

events.text_segment:
Mary gave him a tin basin of water and a piece of soap, and he went outside the door and set the basin on a little bench there; then he dipped the soap in the water and laid it down; turned up his sleeves; poured out the water on the ground, gently, and then entered the kitchen and began to wipe his face diligently on the towel behind the door. But Mary removed the towel and said:
“Now ain’t you ashamed, Tom. You mustn’t be so bad. Water won’t hurt you.”
Tom was a trifle disconcerted. The basin was refilled, and this time he stood over it a little while, gathering resolution; took in a big breath and began. When he entered the kitchen presently, with both eyes shut and groping for the towel with his hands, an honorable testimony of suds and water was dripping from his face. But when he emerged from the towel, he was not yet satisfactory, for the clean territory stopped short at his chin and his jaws, like a mask; below and beyond this line there was a dark expanse of unirrigated soil that spread downward in front and backward around his neck. Mary took him in hand, and when she was done with him he was a man and a brother, without distinction of color, and his saturated hair was neatly brushed, and its short curls wrought into a dainty and symmetrical general effect. [He privately smoothed out the curls, with labor and difficulty, and plastered his hair close down to his head; for he held curls to be effeminate, and his own filled his life with bitterness.] Then Mary got out a suit of his clothing that had been used only on Sundays during two years—they were simply called his “other clothes”—and so by that we know the size of his wardrobe. The girl “put him to rights” after he had dressed himself; she buttoned his neat roundabout up to his chin, turned his vast shirt collar down over his shoulders, brushed him off and crowned him with his speckled straw hat. He now looked exceedingly improved and uncomfortable. He was fully as uncomfortable as he looked; for there was a restraint about whole clothes and cleanliness that galled him. He hoped that Mary would forget his shoes, but the hope was blighted; she coated them thoroughly with tallow, as was the custom, and brought them out. He lost his temper and said he was always being made to do everything he didn’t want to do. But Mary said, persuasively:
“Please, Tom—that’s a good boy.”
So he got into the shoes snarling. Mary was soon ready, and the three children set out for Sunday-school—a place that Tom hated with his whole heart; but Sid and Mary were fond of it.

events.title: Tom's Ticket Trading and Misbehavior in Sunday School
detailed_summary: Sunday-school sessions were scheduled from nine to ten-thirty, followed by church service, which Sid and Mary attended voluntarily, while Tom attended for other reasons.
The church itself was a modest building with uncomfortable pews.
Upon arriving at the Sunday-school, Tom immediately engaged in trading with a classmate, Billy, exchanging a piece of licorice and a fish-hook for a yellow ticket.
He continued to acquire more tickets of various colors—red and blue—by bartering with other boys for about ten to fifteen minutes.
Tom then joined a crowd of children entering the church, found his seat, and promptly started a dispute with a nearby boy.
His disruptive behavior continued as he pulled another boy's hair and stuck a pin in a third, feigning innocence when confronted, and earning reprimands from the elderly teacher.
Tom's entire class was depicted as similarly restless and ill-behaved, with none knowing their Bible verses perfectly during recitation, requiring constant prompting.
Despite their poor performance, each student received small blue tickets as rewards for their recited verses, with a system where blue tickets could be exchanged for red, and red for yellow.
Ten yellow tickets could be redeemed for a plainly bound Bible, a feat rarely achieved due to the immense effort of memorizing two thousand verses.
The narrative mentions Mary's diligence in earning two Bibles and a German boy who won several, though the latter suffered mentally from the strain.
Winning a Bible was a significant event, bringing temporary fame and inspiring ambition in other students, and Tom, while not necessarily wanting the Bible itself, craved the associated glory.

events.text_segment:
Sabbath-school hours were from nine to half-past ten; and then church service. Two of the children always remained for the sermon voluntarily, and the other always remained too—for stronger reasons. The church’s high-backed, uncushioned pews would seat about three hundred persons; the edifice was but a small, plain affair, with a sort of pine board tree-box on top of it for a steeple. At the door Tom dropped back a step and accosted a Sunday-dressed comrade:
“Say, Billy, got a yaller ticket?”
“Yes.”
“What’ll you take for her?”
“What’ll you give?”
“Piece of lickrish and a fish-hook.”
“Less see ’em.”
Tom exhibited. They were satisfactory, and the property changed hands. Then Tom traded a couple of white alleys for three red tickets, and some small trifle or other for a couple of blue ones. He waylaid other boys as they came, and went on buying tickets of various colors ten or fifteen minutes longer. He entered the church, now, with a swarm of clean and noisy boys and girls, proceeded to his seat and started a quarrel with the first boy that came handy. The teacher, a grave, elderly man, interfered; then turned his back a moment and Tom pulled a boy’s hair in the next bench, and was absorbed in his book when the boy turned around; stuck a pin in another boy, presently, in order to hear him say “Ouch!” and got a new reprimand from his teacher. Tom’s whole class were of a pattern—restless, noisy, and troublesome. When they came to recite their lessons, not one of them knew his verses perfectly, but had to be prompted all along. However, they worried through, and each got his reward—in small blue tickets, each with a passage of Scripture on it; each blue ticket was pay for two verses of the recitation. Ten blue tickets equalled a red one, and could be exchanged for it; ten red tickets equalled a yellow one; for ten yellow tickets the superintendent gave a very plainly bound Bible (worth forty cents in those easy times) to the pupil. How many of my readers would have the industry and application to memorize two thousand verses, even for a Doré Bible? And yet Mary had acquired two Bibles in this way—it was the patient work of two years—and a boy of German parentage had won four or five. He once recited three thousand verses without stopping; but the strain upon his mental faculties was too great, and he was little better than an idiot from that day forth—a grievous misfortune for the school, for on great occasions, before company, the superintendent (as Tom expressed it) had always made this boy come out and “spread himself.” Only the older pupils managed to keep their tickets and stick to their tedious work long enough to get a Bible, and so the delivery of one of these prizes was a rare and noteworthy circumstance; the successful pupil was so great and conspicuous for that day that on the spot every scholar’s heart was fired with a fresh ambition that often lasted a couple of weeks. It is possible that Tom’s mental stomach had never really hungered for one of those prizes, but unquestionably his entire being had for many a day longed for the glory and the eclat that came with it.

events.title: Superintendent's Speech and the Arrival of Distinguished Visitors
detailed_summary: The superintendent, Mr. Walters, a slim man of thirty-five with distinctive features and attire, rose to address the Sunday-school, holding a hymn-book as a prop.
He was known for adopting a peculiar, solemn tone of voice specifically for his Sunday-school duties.
Mr. Walters delivered a standard speech, encouraging the children to be attentive and good, expressing his pleasure at seeing their clean faces ready to learn righteousness.
The latter part of his oration was disturbed by the children's renewed restlessness, fighting, and whispering, which subsided abruptly when he finished speaking.
The children's whispering had also been fueled by the arrival of visitors: Lawyer Thatcher, an elderly man, a distinguished middle-aged gentleman with his wife, and a child led by the lady.
Tom, who had been feeling restless and conscience-stricken, unable to meet Amy Lawrence's gaze, was instantly captivated by the sight of the newcomer, a young girl.

This new infatuation began to erase the memory of a previous humiliation related to this new girl.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: His exaltation had but one alloy—the memory of his humiliation in this angel’s garden—and that record in sand was fast washing out, under the waves of happiness that were sweeping over it now.

events.text_segment:
In due course the superintendent stood up in front of the pulpit, with a closed hymn-book in his hand and his forefinger inserted between its leaves, and commanded attention. When a Sunday-school superintendent makes his customary little speech, a hymn-book in the hand is as necessary as is the inevitable sheet of music in the hand of a singer who stands forward on the platform and sings a solo at a concert—though why, is a mystery: for neither the hymn-book nor the sheet of music is ever referred to by the sufferer. This superintendent was a slim creature of thirty-five, with a sandy goatee and short sandy hair; he wore a stiff standing-collar whose upper edge almost reached his ears and whose sharp points curved forward abreast the corners of his mouth—a fence that compelled a straight lookout ahead, and a turning of the whole body when a side view was required; his chin was propped on a spreading cravat which was as broad and as long as a bank-note, and had fringed ends; his boot toes were turned sharply up, in the fashion of the day, like sleigh-runners—an effect patiently and laboriously produced by the young men by sitting with their toes pressed against a wall for hours together. Mr. Walters was very earnest of mien, and very sincere and honest at heart; and he held sacred things and places in such reverence, and so separated them from worldly matters, that unconsciously to himself his Sunday-school voice had acquired a peculiar intonation which was wholly absent on week-days. He began after this fashion:
“Now, children, I want you all to sit up just as straight and pretty as you can and give me all your attention for a minute or two. There—that is it. That is the way good little boys and girls should do. I see one little girl who is looking out of the window—I am afraid she thinks I am out there somewhere—perhaps up in one of the trees making a speech to the little birds. [Applausive titter.] I want to tell you how good it makes me feel to see so many bright, clean little faces assembled in a place like this, learning to do right and be good.” And so forth and so on. It is not necessary to set down the rest of the oration. It was of a pattern which does not vary, and so it is familiar to us all.
The latter third of the speech was marred by the resumption of fights and other recreations among certain of the bad boys, and by fidgetings and whisperings that extended far and wide, washing even to the bases of isolated and incorruptible rocks like Sid and Mary. But now every sound ceased suddenly, with the subsidence of Mr. Walters’ voice, and the conclusion of the speech was received with a burst of silent gratitude.
A good part of the whispering had been occasioned by an event which was more or less rare—the entrance of visitors: lawyer Thatcher, accompanied by a very feeble and aged man; a fine, portly, middle-aged gentleman with iron-gray hair; and a dignified lady who was doubtless the latter’s wife. The lady was leading a child. Tom had been restless and full of chafings and repinings; conscience-smitten, too—he could not meet Amy Lawrence’s eye, he could not brook her loving gaze. But when he saw this small newcomer his soul was all ablaze with bliss in a moment. The next moment he was “showing off” with all his might—cuffing boys, pulling hair, making faces—in a word, using every art that seemed likely to fascinate a girl and win her applause. His exaltation had but one alloy—the memory of his humiliation in this angel’s garden—and that record in sand was fast washing out, under the waves of happiness that were sweeping over it now.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: He looked over the congregation with a grave and earnest expression, and then began to speak. His voice was clear and steady, carrying across the hushed assembly. 'My friends,' he said, 'we are gathered here today to reflect upon the importance of virtue and the dangers of vice. It is our duty to guide the young and to set a good example for all. Let us remember that our actions speak louder than words, and that the character we build now will follow us through life.' As he spoke, the children listened intently, their eyes wide with curiosity and respect. Tom Sawyer, sitting near the front, felt a mixture of boredom and mischief stirring within him. He was more interested in the crack in the ceiling or the way the sunlight danced on the floor than in the sermon. Yet, he knew better than to show his disinterest openly, for he was aware of the watchful eyes of Aunt Polly and the other adults. The superintendent continued, 'We must strive to be honest, kind, and diligent in all our pursuits. Temptations are many, and the path of virtue is often difficult, but it is the only true way to happiness and peace.' At this, Tom's mind wandered again, and he began to think about the adventures he longed for—fights, treasure hunts, and escapades that would make his life exciting. He wondered if he could find a way to slip away unnoticed and join Huck Finn and Joe in their latest scheme. The preacher's voice brought him back to the present. 'Remember, children, that honesty is the best policy. Do not be tempted by falsehoods or shortcuts, for they lead only to trouble.' Tom shifted in his seat, trying to suppress a yawn. He glanced around and saw Becky Thatcher sitting beside him, her face attentive and bright. He felt a flutter in his chest, a mixture of admiration and nervousness. Becky was the prettiest girl in school, and Tom was secretly in love with her. He hoped she would notice him, perhaps smile at him, or better yet, talk to him. The sermon was nearing its end, and Tom's thoughts drifted again to the fun he could be having outside. He imagined himself sneaking away from the church, running to the river, and joining Huck and Joe in their latest adventure. Just then, the superintendent concluded his speech with a prayer, asking for guidance and protection for all the children. The congregation responded with a chorus of 'Amen,' and the service drew to a close. As the people began to file out, Tom lingered for a moment, contemplating whether to stay or to make a quick exit. He decided to wait until the crowd thinned, then slip away quietly. Aunt Polly approached him, her face kind but firm. 'Tom, you must pay attention during the sermon,' she said softly. 'It's important to learn good lessons.' Tom nodded obediently, though his mind was already elsewhere. Once outside, the fresh air and the bright sunlight invigorated him. He ran to the riverbank, where Huck Finn was waiting with a mischievous grin. 'Well, Tom,' Huck said, 'are you ready for some real fun?' Tom grinned back, feeling the thrill of the impending adventure. He knew that today would be another story to tell, another memory to cherish. As they set off towards the woods, Tom thought about the lessons of the day—the importance of honesty, the value of virtue—but he also knew that his true happiness lay in the daring escapades that awaited him beyond the bounds of the church and the town.

events.title: The Impact of Judge Thatcher's Presence and Widespread 'Showing Off'
detailed_summary: The newly arrived visitors were given the most prominent seats.
After his speech, Mr. Walters introduced them, revealing the portly gentleman to be the esteemed county judge, Judge Thatcher, which awed the children.
The children were impressed that the Judge was from Constantinople, a town twelve miles away, and had seen the county court-house.
Jeff Thatcher, a local boy, eagerly went forward to interact with the Judge, hoping to be envied by his peers.
This prompted a wave of ostentatious behavior, or "showing off," throughout the Sunday-school.
Mr. Walters bustled about with official activities, the librarian scurried with books, and the young lady teachers adopted sweet demeanors towards their pupils.
Young gentlemen teachers also engaged in minor displays of authority.
Many teachers found reasons to be near the pulpit and library, often repeating tasks unnecessarily.
The little girls and boys also participated in this display, with the boys creating a commotion with paper wads and scuffling.
Presiding over this scene, Judge Thatcher himself appeared to enjoy the attention, beaming majestically.

events.text_segment:
The visitors were given the highest seat of honor, and as soon as Mr. Walters’ speech was finished, he introduced them to the school. The middle-aged man turned out to be a prodigious personage—no less a one than the county judge—altogether the most august creation these children had ever looked upon—and they wondered what kind of material he was made of—and they half wanted to hear him roar, and were half afraid he might, too. He was from Constantinople, twelve miles away—so he had travelled, and seen the world—these very eyes had looked upon the county court-house—which was said to have a tin roof. The awe which these reflections inspired was attested by the impressive silence and the ranks of staring eyes. This was the great Judge Thatcher, brother of their own lawyer. Jeff Thatcher immediately went forward, to be familiar with the great man and be envied by the school. It would have been music to his soul to hear the whisperings:
“Look at him, Jim! He’s a going up there. Say—look! he’s a going to shake hands with him—he is shaking hands with him! By jings, don’t you wish you was Jeff?”
Mr. Walters fell to “showing off,” with all sorts of official bustlings and activities, giving orders, delivering judgments, discharging directions here, there, everywhere that he could find a target. The librarian “showed off”—running hither and thither with his arms full of books and making a deal of the splutter and fuss that insect authority delights in. The young lady teachers “showed off”—bending sweetly over pupils that were lately being boxed, lifting pretty warning fingers at bad little boys and patting good ones lovingly. The young gentlemen teachers “showed off” with small scoldings and other little displays of authority and fine attention to discipline—and most of the teachers, of both sexes, found business up at the library, by the pulpit; and it was business that frequently had to be done over again two or three times (with much seeming vexation). The little girls “showed off” in various ways, and the little boys “showed off” with such diligence that the air was thick with paper wads and the murmur of scufflings. And above it all the great man sat and beamed a majestic judicial smile upon all the house, and warmed himself in the sun of his own grandeur—for he was “showing off,” too.

The school was a simple, one-room building with a high ceiling and large windows that let in plenty of light. The children sat on benches, their faces bright with curiosity and excitement. Tom, sitting near the front, was especially interested in the visitors, who seemed to be important people from the town.

After Mr. Walters finished his speech, he called for the visitors to stand and be introduced. The principal of the school, a kind-looking man with a gentle voice, stepped forward and announced each visitor's name. The visitors nodded and smiled, acknowledging the warm welcome from the school and the town.

Tom watched intently as the visitors were introduced. He was particularly fascinated by a tall gentleman who wore a fine suit and had a friendly smile. Tom wondered who he was and what he did. The visitors then took their seats, and the schoolmaster resumed his role, explaining the different subjects taught and the importance of education.

As the day went on, Tom's mind wandered to the stories he had heard about the visitors. Some said they were wealthy merchants, while others believed they were government officials. Tom's imagination ran wild with ideas of adventures and treasures that might be hidden away in their pockets.

During the recess, Tom and his friends gathered around, whispering excitedly about the visitors. They speculated about what kind of gifts they might bring or what secrets they might reveal. Tom, always eager for excitement, thought about how he could impress the visitors with his cleverness.

The school day ended with a sense of pride and curiosity. The visitors had left a lasting impression on the children, who now looked forward to the next time they might see such important guests. Tom, in particular, felt inspired to be brave and clever, dreaming of the adventures that awaited him beyond the school walls.

events.title: Tom's Astonishing Bible Claim and Amy Lawrence's Distress
detailed_summary: Mr. Walters longed for an opportunity to award a Bible prize and showcase a star pupil, but found no one with enough yellow tickets despite his inquiries.
He particularly wished for the return of the mentally sound German boy who had previously excelled.
At this moment of despair for Mr. Walters, Tom Sawyer unexpectedly came forward with nine yellow, nine red, and ten blue tickets, demanding a Bible.
This claim astonished Mr. Walters, who had not anticipated such an achievement from Tom for at least another decade.
However, the tickets were legitimate, and Tom was consequently honored by being seated with Judge Thatcher and other dignitaries.
The announcement of Tom's achievement was a major surprise, elevating him to a status comparable to the Judge, giving the school two marvels to admire.

The other boys were consumed with envy, especially those who realized they had unwittingly contributed to Tom's success by trading their tickets to him for items he obtained from his whitewashing venture.
These boys felt they had been tricked by a clever schemer.

Mr. Walters presented the Bible to Tom with as much enthusiasm as he could muster, though he intuitively sensed something suspicious about Tom's sudden accumulation of Scriptural knowledge, doubting Tom's capacity to memorize so many verses.
Amy Lawrence initially felt proud and happy for Tom, trying to catch his eye, but he avoided her gaze.
Her feelings shifted to unease, then suspicion, and finally, upon a furtive glance from Tom, her heart broke with jealousy, anger, and tears, leading her to hate everyone, especially Tom.

events.text_segment:
There was only one thing wanting to make Mr. Walters’ ecstasy complete, and that was a chance to deliver a Bible-prize and exhibit a prodigy. Several pupils had a few yellow tickets, but none had enough—he had been around among the star pupils inquiring. He would have given worlds, now, to have that German lad back again with a sound mind.
And now at this moment, when hope was dead, Tom Sawyer came forward with nine yellow tickets, nine red tickets, and ten blue ones, and demanded a Bible. This was a thunderbolt out of a clear sky. Walters was not expecting an application from this source for the next ten years. But there was no getting around it—here were the certified checks, and they were good for their face. Tom was therefore elevated to a place with the Judge and the other elect, and the great news was announced from headquarters. It was the most stunning surprise of the decade, and so profound was the sensation that it lifted the new hero up to the judicial one’s altitude, and the school had two marvels to gaze upon in place of one. The boys were all eaten up with envy—but those that suffered the bitterest pangs were those who perceived too late that they themselves had contributed to this hated splendor by trading tickets to Tom for the wealth he had amassed in selling whitewashing privileges. These despised themselves, as being the dupes of a wily fraud, a guileful snake in the grass.
The prize was delivered to Tom with as much effusion as the superintendent could pump up under the circumstances; but it lacked somewhat of the true gush, for the poor fellow’s instinct taught him that there was a mystery here that could not well bear the light, perhaps; it was simply preposterous that this boy had warehoused two thousand sheaves of Scriptural wisdom on his premises—a dozen would strain his capacity, without a doubt.
Amy Lawrence was proud and glad, and she tried to make Tom see it in her face—but he wouldn’t look. She wondered; then she was just a grain troubled; next a dim suspicion came and went—came again; she watched; a furtive glance told her worlds—and then her heart broke, and she was jealous, and angry, and the tears came and she hated everybody. Tom most of all (she thought).

events.title: Tom's Moment of Glory Turns to Humiliation Before Judge Thatcher
detailed_summary: Tom was formally introduced to Judge Thatcher, but found himself overcome with nervousness, his tongue tied and heart pounding, largely because the Judge was the father of the new girl he admired.
He felt an urge to revere the Judge, if only it could be done privately.
Judge Thatcher placed a hand on Tom's head, called him a fine little man, and asked for his name.
Tom managed to stammer out "Tom," which was then corrected to "Thomas."
The Judge, after confirming his full name as "Thomas Sawyer—sir" with Mr. Walters' prompting for manners, praised him extensively.

He lauded Tom for learning two thousand verses, emphasizing the enduring value of knowledge and predicting Tom would become a great and good man, attributing this future success to his Sunday-school upbringing, teachers, and the superintendent who gave him the Bible.
The Judge then expressed his confidence that Tom would be happy to share some of his learning and asked him to name the first two disciples appointed.
Tom became visibly uncomfortable, blushing and looking down, while Mr. Walters grew increasingly anxious, fearing Tom could not answer even this simple question.
Mr. Walters urged Tom to answer, trying to reassure him.
The Judge's wife also gently prompted Tom for the names.
In response to the question about the first two disciples, Tom confidently but incorrectly answered, "David and Goliah!"
The narrator concludes the chapter by stating an intention to mercifully skip over the remainder of this embarrassing scene.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Tom was introduced to the Judge; but his tongue was tied, his breath would hardly come, his heart quaked—partly because of the awful greatness of the man, but mainly because he was her parent.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Let us draw the curtain of charity over the rest of the scene.

events.text_segment:
Tom was introduced to the Judge; but his tongue was tied, his breath would hardly come, his heart quaked—partly because of the awful greatness of the man, but mainly because he was her parent. He would have liked to fall down and worship him, if it were in the dark. The Judge put his hand on Tom’s head and called him a fine little man, and asked him what his name was. The boy stammered, gasped, and got it out:
“Tom.”
“Oh, no, not Tom—it is—”
“Thomas.”
“Ah, that’s it. I thought there was more to it, maybe. That’s very well. But you’ve another one I daresay, and you’ll tell it to me, won’t you?”
“Tell the gentleman your other name, Thomas,” said Walters, “and say sir. You mustn’t forget your manners.”
“Thomas Sawyer—sir.”
“That’s it! That’s a good boy. Fine boy. Fine, manly little fellow. Two thousand verses is a great many—very, very great many. And you never can be sorry for the trouble you took to learn them; for knowledge is worth more than anything there is in the world; it’s what makes great men and good men; you’ll be a great man and a good man yourself, some day, Thomas, and then you’ll look back and say, It’s all owing to the precious Sunday-school privileges of my boyhood—it’s all owing to my dear teachers that taught me to learn—it’s all owing to the good superintendent, who encouraged me, and watched over me, and gave me a beautiful Bible—a splendid elegant Bible—to keep and have it all for my own, always—it’s all owing to right bringing up! That is what you will say, Thomas—and you wouldn’t take any money for those two thousand verses—no indeed you wouldn’t. And now you wouldn’t mind telling me and this lady some of the things you’ve learned—no, I know you wouldn’t—for we are proud of little boys that learn. Now, no doubt you know the names of all the twelve disciples. Won’t you tell us the names of the first two that were appointed?”
Tom was tugging at a button-hole and looking sheepish. He blushed, now, and his eyes fell. Mr. Walters’ heart sank within him. He said to himself, it is not possible that the boy can answer the simplest question—why did the Judge ask him? Yet he felt obliged to speak up and say:
“Answer the gentleman, Thomas—don’t be afraid.”
Tom still hung fire.
“Now I know you’ll tell me,” said the lady. “The names of the first two disciples were—”
“David and Goliah!”
Let us draw the curtain of charity over the rest of the scene.

The Judge, placing a kindly hand on Tom's head, looked down at him with a gentle smile. "Well, my little man," he said, "what's your name?" Tom managed to stammer, "Tom." "Thomas," corrected the Judge, with a nod. Then Mr. Walters, eager to teach manners, prompted, "His full name, sir?" "Thomas Sawyer—sir," Tom replied, trying to sound proud. The Judge nodded approvingly. "A fine boy! I hear you've learned two thousand verses," he continued. "That’s a good start. Knowledge is a treasure that no one can take from you. I believe you'll grow up to be a great and good man, thanks to your Sunday-school and your teachers, especially the superintendent who gave you the Bible." Tom listened, blushing, feeling both proud and shy. The Judge then asked, "Can you tell me the first two disciples appointed?" Tom, now visibly uncomfortable, looked down and hesitated. Mr. Walters, growing anxious, urged him, "Go on, Tom, you can do it." The lady, gentle and encouraging, added, "Tell us, dear." Tom, trying to answer confidently but incorrectly, said, "David and Goliah!" The room fell silent for a moment, and the narrator concludes that, to spare Tom further embarrassment, he would mercifully skip the rest of this scene.

Tom Sawyer felt a mixture of awe and nervousness as he stood before the Judge. The room was filled with a quiet hum of conversation, but to Tom, it seemed as if the world had fallen silent. His mind raced, trying to find the right words to say, but his tongue refused to cooperate. The Judge's stern gaze seemed to pierce through him, making his cheeks flush with embarrassment.

He remembered the stories he had heard about the Judge—how just and kind he was, yet how formidable in his authority. Tom's heart pounded in his chest, a tumult of fear and respect. He knew that the Judge held the power to decide his fate, and the weight of that responsibility pressed heavily on him.

As he hesitated, a gentle smile appeared on the Judge's face, softening his stern features. It was a look of understanding, of patience. The Judge's eyes seemed to say, "Take your time, boy." Encouraged by this, Tom took a deep breath, trying to steady his trembling voice.

He looked down briefly, gathering his thoughts, then met the Judge's gaze again. With a shaky but clear voice, he began to speak, telling the truth about his actions and feelings. The words came slowly at first, but as he continued, his confidence grew. He realized that honesty was the best course, and that the Judge was listening with kindness.

Throughout the encounter, Tom's mind wandered to his mother, who was watching from the sidelines. He knew she was proud of him for facing his fears, even if he was scared stiff. Her presence gave him strength, and he felt a surge of courage.

By the end of the conversation, Tom felt a sense of relief. The Judge's demeanor had softened even more, and he nodded approvingly. Tom knew that he had been given a chance to make amends and to learn from his mistakes. As he left the courtroom, he carried with him a newfound respect for authority and a deeper understanding of himself.

That day, Tom Sawyer learned that bravery isn't the absence of fear, but the willingness to face it. And he also learned that sometimes, the greatest strength lies in honesty and humility.

events.title: The Congregation Gathers: Notable Figures and Tom's Observations
detailed_summary: The church bell signaled the commencement of the morning sermon, drawing the townsfolk.
Sunday-school children settled into pews with their parents for supervision.
Aunt Polly arrived accompanied by Tom, Sid, and Mary. Tom was strategically placed near the aisle, distant from the allure of the window and summer scenes.
A procession of notable community members entered: the aging postmaster, the mayor and his wife, the justice of the peace, and the esteemed Widow Douglas, known for her generosity and grand home.
Other significant attendees included Major and Mrs. Ward, and a newly arrived lawyer, Mr. Riverson.
The village's most attractive young woman made her entrance, trailed by a group of admiring young men.
Finally, Willie Mufferson, the epitome of a 'Model Boy,' entered, attentively caring for his mother, a display that earned him adult admiration but the disdain of his peers.
Willie's customary display of a white handkerchief from his pocket, perceived as accidental, further fueled Tom's view of such boys as snobbish, especially since Tom himself lacked a handkerchief.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: About half-past ten the cracked bell of the small church began to ring, and presently the people began to gather for the morning sermon.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Tom had no handkerchief, and he looked upon boys who had as snobs.

events.text_segment: About half-past ten the cracked bell of the small church began to ring, and presently the people began to gather for the morning sermon. The Sunday-school children distributed themselves about the house and occupied pews with their parents, so as to be under supervision. Aunt Polly came, and Tom and Sid and Mary sat with her—Tom being placed next the aisle, in order that he might be as far away from the open window and the seductive outside summer scenes as possible. The crowd filed up the aisles: the aged and needy postmaster, who had seen better days; the mayor and his wife—for they had a mayor there, among other unnecessaries; the justice of the peace; the widow Douglas, fair, smart, and forty, a generous, good-hearted soul and well-to-do, her hill mansion the only palace in the town, and the most hospitable and much the most lavish in the matter of festivities that St. Petersburg could boast; the bent and venerable Major and Mrs. Ward; lawyer Riverson, the new notable from a distance; next the belle of the village, followed by a troop of lawn-clad and ribbon-decked young heart-breakers; then all the young clerks in town in a body—for they had stood in the vestibule sucking their cane-heads, a circling wall of oiled and simpering admirers, till the last girl had run their gantlet; and last of all came the Model Boy, Willie Mufferson, taking as heedful care of his mother as if she were cut glass. He always brought his mother to church, and was the pride of all the matrons. The boys all hated him, he was so good. And besides, he had been “thrown up to them” so much. His white handkerchief was hanging out of his pocket behind, as usual on Sundays—accidentally. Tom had no handkerchief, and he looked upon boys who had as snobs.

events.title: Service Preliminaries: Choir's Whispers, Hymn Reading, and Lengthy Notices
detailed_summary: Once the congregation was fully assembled, a final bell toll signaled the start, followed by a profound silence, punctuated only by the choir's continuous tittering from the gallery.
The narrator dryly remarks on the typical ill-breeding of church choirs, recalling a well-behaved one from a distant memory, possibly in a foreign land.
The minister announced the hymn and read it with a distinctive, much-admired vocal style that ascended to an emphatic high point before dramatically descending.
His reading prowess was renowned, often leading to requests for him to read poetry at social events, where his performance would deeply move the female attendees.
Following the hymn, Rev. Mr. Sprague delivered a lengthy series of announcements for meetings and societies, a custom the narrator finds peculiar yet enduring in America.
The narrator muses that the less justification a tradition has, the more difficult it often is to abandon.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The congregation being fully assembled, now, the bell rang once more, to warn laggards and stragglers, and then a solemn hush fell upon the church which was only broken by the tittering and whispering of the choir in the gallery.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Often, the less there is to justify a traditional custom, the harder it is to get rid of it.

events.text_segment:
The congregation being fully assembled, now, the bell rang once more, to warn laggards and stragglers, and then a solemn hush fell upon the church which was only broken by the tittering and whispering of the choir in the gallery. The choir always tittered and whispered all through service. There was once a church choir that was not ill-bred, but I have forgotten where it was, now. It was a great many years ago, and I can scarcely remember anything about it, but I think it was in some foreign country.
The minister gave out the hymn, and read it through with a relish, in a peculiar style which was much admired in that part of the country. His voice began on a medium key and climbed steadily up till it reached a certain point, where it bore with strong emphasis upon the topmost word and then plunged down as if from a spring-board:
Shall I be car-ri-ed toe the skies, on flow’ry beds
of ease,
Whilst others fight to win the prize, and sail thro’ blood
-y seas?
He was regarded as a wonderful reader. At church “sociables” he was always called upon to read poetry; and when he was through, the ladies would lift up their hands and let them fall helplessly in their laps, and “wall” their eyes, and shake their heads, as much as to say, “Words cannot express it; it is too beautiful, TOO beautiful for this mortal earth.”
After the hymn had been sung, the Rev. Mr. Sprague turned himself into a bulletin-board, and read off “notices” of meetings and societies and things till it seemed that the list would stretch out to the crack of doom—a queer custom which is still kept up in America, even in cities, away here in this age of abundant newspapers. Often, the less there is to justify a traditional custom, the harder it is to get rid of it.

The congregation being fully assembled, now, the bell rang once more, to warn laggards and stragglers, and then a solemn hush fell upon the church which was only broken by the tittering and whispering of the choir in the gallery. The choir, as usual, was in a state of perpetual giggling, their voices rising and falling in a kind of nervous chatter that seemed to mock the solemnity of the occasion. The narrator, observing this, could not help but recall a time in a distant land when the choir was well-behaved, attentive, and truly devout.

Then the minister, Rev. Mr. Sprague, stepped forward and announced the hymn. His voice, known for its distinctive and admired style, would ascend to an emphatic high note before descending dramatically, a technique that always drew admiration. As he read the hymn, his voice soared and dipped with a kind of theatrical flair, quoting lines that seemed to lift the congregation’s spirits.

His reading was so powerful that it often moved the female members of the congregation to tears, and requests for him to read poetry at social gatherings became common. After the hymn, Rev. Mr. Sprague proceeded to deliver a lengthy series of announcements for various meetings and societies—a custom that the narrator found peculiar, yet it persisted in America. The narrator mused that the less justification a tradition has, the more difficult it is to abandon, and so these customs endured, much to the amusement and sometimes the bemusement of those present.

events.title: The Minister's Expansive Prayer and Tom's Fly Distraction
detailed_summary: The minister commenced a comprehensive and far-reaching prayer.

The prayer addressed the local church, its children, other village churches, the village, county, state, national government officials, sailors, oppressed populations under foreign rule, those spiritually blind, and heathens in distant lands.
It concluded with a plea for his upcoming sermon to be received favorably and yield positive results.
After the prayer, the standing congregation sat down.
Tom Sawyer found the prayer tedious, merely tolerating it without genuine attention.
He mentally noted the prayer's familiar structure, resenting any deviations or additions as unfair.
During the prayer, a fly landed on the pew ahead of Tom, capturing his attention with its meticulous grooming.
Tom was deeply tempted to catch the fly but refrained, believing it would endanger his soul to do so during prayer.
The moment the prayer concluded with "Amen," Tom swiftly captured the fly.
His aunt observed his action and compelled him to release the insect.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: And now the minister prayed.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: His aunt detected the act and made him let it go.

events.text_segment:
And now the minister prayed. A good, generous prayer it was, and went into details: it pleaded for the church, and the little children of the church; for the other churches of the village; for the village itself; for the county; for the State; for the State officers; for the United States; for the churches of the United States; for Congress; for the President; for the officers of the Government; for poor sailors, tossed by stormy seas; for the oppressed millions groaning under the heel of European monarchies and Oriental despotisms; for such as have the light and the good tidings, and yet have not eyes to see nor ears to hear withal; for the heathen in the far islands of the sea; and closed with a supplication that the words he was about to speak might find grace and favor, and be as seed sown in fertile ground, yielding in time a grateful harvest of good. Amen.
There was a rustling of dresses, and the standing congregation sat down. The boy whose history this book relates did not enjoy the prayer, he only endured it—if he even did that much. He was restive all through it; he kept tally of the details of the prayer, unconsciously—for he was not listening, but he knew the ground of old, and the clergyman’s regular route over it—and when a little trifle of new matter was interlarded, his ear detected it and his whole nature resented it; he considered additions unfair, and scoundrelly. In the midst of the prayer a fly had lit on the back of the pew in front of him and tortured his spirit by calmly rubbing its hands together, embracing its head with its arms, and polishing it so vigorously that it seemed to almost part company with the body, and the slender thread of a neck was exposed to view; scraping its wings with its hind legs and smoothing them to its body as if they had been coat-tails; going through its whole toilet as tranquilly as if it knew it was perfectly safe. As indeed it was; for as sorely as Tom’s hands itched to grab for it they did not dare—he believed his soul would be instantly destroyed if he did such a thing while the prayer was going on. But with the closing sentence his hand began to curve and steal forward; and the instant the “Amen” was out the fly was a prisoner of war. His aunt detected the act and made him let it go.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text: And now the minister prayed. He began with a long, comprehensive prayer, addressing the Lord and then mentioning the church and its children, praying for their growth and happiness. He moved on to pray for the other churches in the village, asking for their prosperity and spiritual strength. Then he prayed for the village itself, for its peace and well-being. Next, he lifted up the county, the state, and the nation, praying for wise leaders and just laws. He prayed for the officials of the government, for sailors and travelers, for oppressed peoples under foreign rule, and for those who were spiritually blind or heathens in distant lands. The prayer was lengthy and detailed, covering every conceivable need and concern, and it seemed to go on and on. The minister concluded with a plea that his upcoming sermon would be received favorably and would bring good results. As he finished, he said, 'Amen,' and the congregation sat down. Tom Sawyer sat quietly, feeling the prayer was tedious and long, just tolerating it without paying much attention. He mentally noted the familiar pattern of the prayer, resenting any deviations or additions, which he thought were unfair. During the prayer, a fly landed on the pew ahead of Tom. It was a common fly, and it began grooming itself meticulously, first rubbing its front legs together, then cleaning its face with its forelegs, and then turning its head from side to side, grooming its wings and body with careful, deliberate movements. The fly seemed to be perfectly at ease, safe from harm, and completely absorbed in its grooming. Tom was deeply tempted to catch the fly, but he believed that doing so during prayer would be a sin, a danger to his soul. He watched the fly with fascination, feeling a strong impulse to catch it, but he restrained himself. The prayer ended with a loud 'Amen,' and immediately Tom reached out and caught the fly. His aunt, sitting nearby, saw what he did and quickly reached over, pinched his arm, and told him to let the fly go.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: And now the minister prayed. His voice was steady and clear, filling the little church with a sense of solemnity and hope. The congregation listened intently, their heads bowed in reverence. As he spoke, Tom Sawyer sat quietly, his eyes fixed on the altar, feeling a mixture of curiosity and reverence. The prayer seemed to lift the spirits of everyone present, bringing a peaceful hush over the room. When the prayer concluded, the minister nodded softly, and the congregation responded with an 'Amen.' Tom felt a strange warmth in his chest, a feeling he couldn't quite understand but knew was good. After the prayer, the service continued with hymns and scripture readings, each word resonating deeply within him. As the service drew to a close, Tom looked around at the familiar faces, feeling a sense of belonging and community. He thought about the stories his Aunt Polly had told him about faith and kindness, and he wondered if he could find that same comfort in his own heart. Walking out of the church, Tom felt lighter, as if a burden had been lifted. The sunlight streamed through the trees, casting dappled shadows on the ground, and he took a deep breath, savoring the fresh air. He knew that this moment, simple as it was, was part of something bigger—something that connected everyone in that small town. As he made his way home, Tom's mind wandered to the adventures awaiting him, but he carried with him the quiet strength of the prayer he had just heard. It was a reminder that even in the simplest acts—like praying—there was a profound power to bring people together and give them hope. Tom resolved to remember this feeling, to hold onto the sense of peace and community it brought him. Perhaps, he thought, there was more to life than just mischief and fun; maybe there was a purpose in these moments of reflection and faith. With that thought, he hurried home, eager to share his day with Aunt Polly and to carry the spirit of the prayer with him into whatever adventures lay ahead.

events.title: Monotonous Sermon and Tom's Fleeting Fascination
detailed_summary: The minister announced his sermon text and began a monotonous, prosaic argument, despite its themes of eternal damnation and the very few chosen for salvation, causing many congregants to doze off.
Tom, as was his habit, counted the sermon's pages, typically remembering little else about its content.
However, he experienced a brief flicker of interest when the minister described the millennial gathering where a lion and lamb would coexist peacefully under a child's guidance.
The profound meaning and moral of this spectacle were lost on Tom; he was instead captivated by the idea of being that prominent child, especially if the lion was tame.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The minister gave out his text and droned along monotonously through an argument that was so prosy that many a head by and by began to nod—and yet it was an argument that dealt in limitless fire and brimstone and thinned the predestined elect down to a company so small as to be hardly worth the saving.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But the pathos, the lesson, the moral of the great spectacle were lost upon the boy; he only thought of the conspicuousness of the principal character before the on-looking nations; his face lit with the thought, and he said to himself that he wished he could be that child, if it was a tame lion.

events.text_segment: The minister gave out his text and droned along monotonously through an argument that was so prosy that many a head by and by began to nod—and yet it was an argument that dealt in limitless fire and brimstone and thinned the predestined elect down to a company so small as to be hardly worth the saving. Tom counted the pages of the sermon; after church he always knew how many pages there had been, but he seldom knew anything else about the discourse. However, this time he was really interested for a little while. The minister made a grand and moving picture of the assembling together of the world’s hosts at the millennium when the lion and the lamb should lie down together and a little child should lead them. But the pathos, the lesson, the moral of the great spectacle were lost upon the boy; he only thought of the conspicuousness of the principal character before the on-looking nations; his face lit with the thought, and he said to himself that he wished he could be that child, if it was a tame lion.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Tom Sawyer, sitting in the back pew, was more interested in the fluttering of a fly on the window than in the minister's fiery words. His mind wandered to the adventures he longed for, the treasure he hoped to find, and the mischief he could get into. The sermon dragged on, and Tom's eyelids grew heavy, but he kept his ears open just enough to catch the mention of salvation and the elect. Suddenly, he thought of Huck Finn, his wild friend, and wondered if Huck was among the chosen. The church was warm and stuffy, and Tom fought to stay awake, dreaming of the freedom outside, where the river called to him with its endless possibilities. The preacher's voice faded into the background as Tom's thoughts drifted to the adventures awaiting him beyond the church walls.

events.title: Tom's Pinchbug and the Poodle's Chaotic Interruption
detailed_summary: As the sermon continued its dry course, Tom's boredom intensified.
He retrieved a prized possession: a large black beetle with strong jaws, which he called a "pinchbug," kept in a percussion-cap box.
The beetle immediately bit Tom's finger, causing him to flick it into the aisle, where it landed on its back, struggling.
Tom longed to retrieve it, but it was out of reach; other disinterested congregants also noticed the beetle.
A stray poodle, looking melancholic and weary, wandered into the church.
The poodle spotted the beetle, its interest piqued. It cautiously approached, sniffed, and then began to playfully bat at the insect.
Eventually, the poodle lay down with the beetle between its paws, but then, growing drowsy, its chin touched the beetle, which bit it.
The poodle yelped sharply, flinging the beetle some distance away; Tom and other onlookers found this amusing.
Feeling resentful, the dog renewed its attack on the beetle, jumping and snapping at it.
Tiring of this, the poodle tried to entertain itself with a fly and an ant, but then, forgetting the beetle, accidentally sat on it.
A piercing yelp of agony followed as the poodle shot up the aisle, its cries echoing through the church.
It raced frantically around the building, past the altar and down the aisles, a furry blur of motion and distress.
Finally, the distraught dog leaped into its master's lap, who promptly threw it out of a window, its cries fading in the distance.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: At last the frantic sufferer sheered from its course, and sprang into its master’s lap; he flung it out of the window, and the voice of distress quickly thinned away and died in the distance.

events.text_segment: Now he lapsed into suffering again, as the dry argument was resumed. Presently he bethought him of a treasure he had and got it out. It was a large black beetle with formidable jaws—a “pinchbug,” he called it. It was in a percussion-cap box. The first thing the beetle did was to take him by the finger. A natural fillip followed, the beetle went floundering into the aisle and lit on its back, and the hurt finger went into the boy’s mouth. The beetle lay there working its helpless legs, unable to turn over. Tom eyed it, and longed for it; but it was safe out of his reach. Other people uninterested in the sermon found relief in the beetle, and they eyed it too. Presently a vagrant poodle dog came idling along, sad at heart, lazy with the summer softness and the quiet, weary of captivity, sighing for change. He spied the beetle; the drooping tail lifted and wagged. He surveyed the prize; walked around it; smelt at it from a safe distance; walked around it again; grew bolder, and took a closer smell; then lifted his lip and made a gingerly snatch at it, just missing it; made another, and another; began to enjoy the diversion; subsided to his stomach with the beetle between his paws, and continued his experiments; grew weary at last, and then indifferent and absent-minded. His head nodded, and little by little his chin descended and touched the enemy, who seized it. There was a sharp yelp, a flirt of the poodle’s head, and the beetle fell a couple of yards away, and lit on its back once more. The neighboring spectators shook with a gentle inward joy, several faces went behind fans and hand-kerchiefs, and Tom was entirely happy. The dog looked foolish, and probably felt so; but there was resentment in his heart, too, and a craving for revenge. So he went to the beetle and began a wary attack on it again; jumping at it from every point of a circle, lighting with his fore-paws within an inch of the creature, making even closer snatches at it with his teeth, and jerking his head till his ears flapped again. But he grew tired once more, after a while; tried to amuse himself with a fly but found no relief; followed an ant around, with his nose close to the floor, and quickly wearied of that; yawned, sighed, forgot the beetle entirely, and sat down on it. Then there was a wild yelp of agony and the poodle went sailing up the aisle; the yelps continued, and so did the dog; he crossed the house in front of the altar; he flew down the other aisle; he crossed before the doors; he clamored up the home-stretch; his anguish grew with his progress, till presently he was but a woolly comet moving in its orbit with the gleam and the speed of light. At last the frantic sufferer sheered from its course, and sprang into its master’s lap; he flung it out of the window, and the voice of distress quickly thinned away and died in the distance.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: He listened with a distracted air, his thoughts wandering far away from the dull debate that raged around him. The room was filled with the hum of voices, each trying to outdo the other in their verbosity, but Tom Sawyer's mind was elsewhere. He thought of the adventures he had dreamed of, the rivers he longed to explore, and the treasures he yearned to find. The arguments continued, but to Tom, they were mere background noise, like the distant murmur of a brook he once knew. His eyes drifted to the window, where the sunlight danced on the leaves, and he felt a pang of longing for the freedom of the outdoors. The dry argument was resumed, but Tom's attention was elsewhere, caught up in the vivid images of his own imagination. He wondered what it would be like to run away and live among the pirates or to discover a hidden cave filled with gold. The monotony of the discussion was almost unbearable, yet he sat quietly, pretending to listen, while his mind plotted the next escapade. Suddenly, a loud voice snapped him back to the present, and he realized that the argument was reaching a climax. He sighed inwardly, knowing that soon it would be over, and he could slip away unnoticed. As the debate concluded, Tom quickly excused himself, eager to escape the confines of the room and return to the world of adventure that beckoned him outside. He slipped out through the door, feeling a thrill of excitement as he stepped into the fresh air. The sun was shining brightly, and the birds were singing their cheerful songs. Tom ran down the street, his heart pounding with anticipation. He thought of the old island in the river, where he and Huck had once played pirates, and he decided to visit it again. As he approached the riverbank, he saw Huck sitting on a log, whittling a stick and whistling a tune. "Hello, Huck!" Tom called out, grinning from ear to ear. Huck looked up and grinned back. "Hello, Tom! What are you up to?" Tom shrugged. "Just getting away from that boring argument. I need some adventure." Huck nodded knowingly. "Me too. Let's go exploring. Maybe we'll find some treasure or a secret cave." The boys set off along the river, their spirits high. They imagined themselves as brave explorers, uncovering hidden riches and battling pirates. The world outside was full of possibilities, and Tom felt more alive than he had in days. As they reached the old island, they began to search for signs of hidden treasure or secret passages. They climbed trees, looked under rocks, and dug in the sand. Though they found nothing but shells and old bottles, their imaginations turned every ordinary object into a treasure. Hours passed quickly, and the sun started to dip toward the horizon. Tom and Huck sat on the shore, tired but happy. They talked about their dreams and plans for the future, feeling a sense of freedom and adventure that the dry argument in the room could never provide. As they headed back home, Tom thought about how much he preferred the wild, unpredictable life of a boy to the dull, endless debates of grown-up society. He knew that tomorrow would bring more adventures, more stories to tell, and more memories to cherish. With a smile on his face, he looked forward to the next day, eager to see what new escapades awaited him in the great, wide world.

events.title: Sermon Disrupted and Congregation's Relief at Dismissal
detailed_summary: The poodle's dramatic exit left the entire church congregation red-faced and struggling to suppress their laughter, bringing the sermon to an abrupt halt.
When the minister attempted to continue, his discourse was compromised, lacking any possibility of its former impressiveness.
Even his most serious statements were met with stifled bursts of laughter from various pews, as if he had unintentionally said something humorous.
The remainder of the service felt like an ordeal, and there was widespread relief when it finally concluded with the benediction.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: By this time the whole church was red-faced and suffocating with suppressed laughter, and the sermon had come to a dead standstill.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It was a genuine relief to the whole congregation when the ordeal was over and the benediction pronounced.

events.text_segment: By this time the whole church was red-faced and suffocating with suppressed laughter, and the sermon had come to a dead standstill. The discourse was resumed presently, but it went lame and halting, all possibility of impressiveness being at an end; for even the gravest sentiments were constantly being received with a smothered burst of unholy mirth, under cover of some remote pew-back, as if the poor parson had said a rarely facetious thing. It was a genuine relief to the whole congregation when the ordeal was over and the benediction pronounced.

The remainder of the service felt like an ordeal, with the congregation eager for it to end. At last, the benediction was pronounced, and the congregation hurried out, still trying to suppress their laughter.

events.title: Tom's Monday Morning Misery and Sickness Ploy
detailed_summary: Tom Sawyer wakes up on Monday feeling miserable about the upcoming school week.
He considers feigning illness to avoid school, hoping for a day off.
He mentally cycles through possible ailments, such as colicky symptoms, which quickly fade.
He discovers a loose upper front tooth, but worries his aunt would pull it, causing pain, so he keeps it as a backup plan.

Unsure of the specific symptoms, he decides to risk it and begins groaning with great effort.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Monday morning found Tom Sawyer miserable.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: However, it seemed well worth while to chance it, so he fell to groaning with considerable spirit.

events.text_segment:
Monday morning found Tom Sawyer miserable. Monday morning always found him so—because it began another week’s slow suffering in school. He generally began that day with wishing he had had no intervening holiday, it made the going into captivity and fetters again so much more odious.
Tom lay thinking. Presently it occurred to him that he wished he was sick; then he could stay home from school. Here was a vague possibility. He canvassed his system. No ailment was found, and he investigated again. This time he thought he could detect colicky symptoms, and he began to encourage them with considerable hope. But they soon grew feeble, and presently died wholly away. He reflected further. Suddenly he discovered something. One of his upper front teeth was loose. This was lucky; he was about to begin to groan, as a “starter,” as he called it, when it occurred to him that if he came into court with that argument, his aunt would pull it out, and that would hurt. So he thought he would hold the tooth in reserve for the present, and seek further. Nothing offered for some little time, and then he remembered hearing the doctor tell about a certain thing that laid up a patient for two or three weeks and threatened to make him lose a finger. So the boy eagerly drew his sore toe from under the sheet and held it up for inspection. But now he did not know the necessary symptoms. However, it seemed well worth while to chance it, so he fell to groaning with considerable spirit.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Monday morning found Tom Sawyer miserable. He lay in bed, contemplating the dreadful prospect of going to school. He thought about pretending to be sick, hoping to stay home. His mind raced through various ailments—colicky pains, stomach aches—that would convince his aunt he was unwell. Suddenly, he noticed a loose upper front tooth. He hesitated, knowing that if he told his aunt, she might pull it out, causing him pain. So he decided to keep it as a backup plan. Then, recalling a story a doctor once told about a severe toe infection, Tom decided to fake a sore toe. He drew the covers aside and examined his toe, unsure of the exact symptoms but determined to make it convincing. With a deep breath, he began to groan loudly, trying to imitate the pain he hoped would keep him from school.

events.title: Tom's Dramatic Performance and Alarming the Household
detailed_summary: Tom's brother, Sid, remains asleep despite Tom's initial groans.
Tom increases the intensity of his groans, imagining he genuinely feels pain in his toe.
After more effort, he resorts to shaking Sid awake.
Tom launches into a dramatic performance, moaning and asking Sid not to joggle him.
He initially tells Sid not to call anyone, then implies his imminent demise, stating he has been suffering for hours.
Tom
forgives
Sid for past transgressions and begins to
bequeath
his possessions, including his window-sash and one-eyed cat to a new girl in town.
Sid, thoroughly alarmed by Tom's act, rushes downstairs, crying out that Tom is dying.
Aunt Polly, though expressing disbelief, hurries upstairs with Sid and Mary, her face growing pale and her lip trembling with concern.
Upon reaching Tom's bedside, she anxiously demands to know what is wrong with him.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: But Sid slept on unconscious.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence:
When she reached the bedside she gasped out:
“You, Tom! Tom, what’s the matter with you?”

events.text_segment:
But Sid slept on unconscious.
Tom groaned louder, and fancied that he began to feel pain in the toe.
No result from Sid.
Tom was panting with his exertions by this time. He took a rest and then swelled himself up and fetched a succession of admirable groans.
Sid snored on.
Tom was aggravated. He said, “Sid, Sid!” and shook him. This course worked well, and Tom began to groan again. Sid yawned, stretched, then brought himself up on his elbow with a snort, and began to stare at Tom. Tom went on groaning. Sid said:
“Tom! Say, Tom!” [No response.] “Here, Tom! TOM! What is the matter, Tom?” And he shook him and looked in his face anxiously.
Tom moaned out:
“Oh, don’t, Sid. Don’t joggle me.”
“Why, what’s the matter, Tom? I must call auntie.”
“No—never mind. It’ll be over by and by, maybe. Don’t call anybody.”
“But I must! Don’t groan so, Tom, it’s awful. How long you been this way?”
“Hours. Ouch! Oh, don’t stir so, Sid, you’ll kill me.”
“Tom, why didn’t you wake me sooner? Oh, Tom, don’t! It makes my flesh crawl to hear you. Tom, what is the matter?”
“I forgive you everything, Sid. [Groan.] Everything you’ve ever done to me. When I’m gone—”
“Oh, Tom, you ain’t dying, are you? Don’t, Tom—oh, don’t. Maybe—”
“I forgive everybody, Sid. [Groan.] Tell ’em so, Sid. And Sid, you give my window-sash and my cat with one eye to that new girl that’s come to town, and tell her—”
But Sid had snatched his clothes and gone. Tom was suffering in reality, now, so handsomely was his imagination working, and so his groans had gathered quite a genuine tone.
Sid flew downstairs and said:
“Oh, Aunt Polly, come! Tom’s dying!”
“Dying!”
“Yes’m. Don’t wait—come quick!”
“Rubbage! I don’t believe it!”
But she fled upstairs, nevertheless, with Sid and Mary at her heels. And her face grew white, too, and her lip trembled. When she reached the bedside she gasped out:
“You, Tom! Tom, what’s the matter with you?”
