From that moment, Tom resolved to be more honest and to face his mistakes head-on, understanding that secrets and guilt only made life harder. As the day went on, Tom felt lighter, knowing he had taken a step toward honesty, and he promised himself to be better in the future.

events.title: Tom's Aversion to Mock Inquests and Sid's Continued Observation
detailed_summary: Tom felt that his schoolmates would never cease conducting mock inquests on deceased cats, which served as a constant painful reminder of his predicament.
Sid observed that Tom, who typically led new activities, never served as coroner in these mock trials.
Sid also noted, with surprise, that Tom never acted as a witness in these games.
Furthermore, Sid did not fail to notice Tom's pronounced dislike for these inquests and his efforts to avoid them whenever possible.
Sid was intrigued by this change but refrained from commenting.
Eventually, however, the fad of holding mock inquests subsided, providing Tom relief from that particular source of mental anguish.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: However, even inquests went out of vogue at last, and ceased to torture Tom’s conscience.

events.text_segment: It seemed to Tom that his schoolmates never would get done holding inquests on dead cats, and thus keeping his trouble present to his mind. Sid noticed that Tom never was coroner at one of these inquiries, though it had been his habit to take the lead in all new enterprises; he noticed, too, that Tom never acted as a witness—and that was strange; and Sid did not overlook the fact that Tom even showed a marked aversion to these inquests, and always avoided them when he could. Sid marvelled, but said nothing. However, even inquests went out of vogue at last, and ceased to torture Tom’s conscience.

events.title: Tom's Secret Aid to Potter and Public Sentiment Towards Injun Joe
detailed_summary: Throughout this sorrowful time, Tom would regularly find opportunities to visit the small, barred window of the jail and pass whatever small comforts he could find to Muff Potter.
The jail was a modest brick structure located in a marshy area at the village outskirts, lacking guards and infrequently occupied.
These small offerings significantly helped to alleviate Tom's guilty conscience.
The villagers strongly wished to tar-and-feather Injun Joe and parade him on a rail as punishment for body-snatching.
However, Injun Joe's imposing nature was such that no one was willing to spearhead the effort, so the matter was ultimately dropped.

He had prudently begun both of his statements at the inquest by describing the fight, without admitting to the grave-robbery that occurred beforehand, leading to a decision that it was best not to pursue a court case at that time.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He had been careful to begin both of his inquest-statements with the fight, without confessing the grave-robbery that preceded it; therefore it was deemed wisest not to try the case in the courts at present.

events.text_segment:
Every day or two, during this time of sorrow, Tom watched his opportunity and went to the little grated jail-window and smuggled such small comforts through to the “murderer” as he could get hold of. The jail was a trifling little brick den that stood in a marsh at the edge of the village, and no guards were afforded for it; indeed, it was seldom occupied. These offerings greatly helped to ease Tom’s conscience.
The villagers had a strong desire to tar-and-feather Injun Joe and ride him on a rail, for body-snatching, but so formidable was his character that nobody could be found who was willing to take the lead in the matter, so it was dropped. He had been careful to begin both of his inquest-statements with the fight, without confessing the grave-robbery that preceded it; therefore it was deemed wisest not to try the case in the courts at present.

events.title: Tom's Lovesickness and Aunt Polly's Medical Enthusiasms
detailed_summary: Tom's melancholy deepened due to Becky Thatcher's prolonged absence from school because of illness.
He lost all interest in his typical pastimes like war games and piracy, finding life dreary and joyless, which led him to neglect his playthings.
His aunt, observing his despondent state, grew concerned and decided to intervene with various remedies.
The narrative describes Aunt Polly as someone deeply captivated by patent medicines and novel health practices, constantly seeking new methods to treat ailments.
She was an avid experimenter, always eager to try new health products on others rather than herself, as she was rarely ill.
Aunt Polly subscribed to numerous health journals and followed phrenological theories, accepting their often contradictory and ill-informed advice as gospel.
Despite her good intentions and simple-hearted nature, her reliance on quack remedies is portrayed metaphorically as her unknowingly dispensing harm.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: One of the reasons why Tom’s mind had drifted away from its secret troubles was, that it had found a new and weighty matter to interest itself about.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But she never suspected that she was not an angel of healing and the balm of Gilead in disguise, to the suffering neighbors.

events.text_segment: One of the reasons why Tom’s mind had drifted away from its secret troubles was, that it had found a new and weighty matter to interest itself about. Becky Thatcher had stopped coming to school. Tom had struggled with his pride a few days, and tried to “whistle her down the wind,” but failed. He began to find himself hanging around her father’s house, nights, and feeling very miserable. She was ill. What if she should die! There was distraction in the thought. He no longer took an interest in war, nor even in piracy. The charm of life was gone; there was nothing but dreariness left. He put his hoop away, and his bat; there was no joy in them any more. His aunt was concerned. She began to try all manner of remedies on him. She was one of those people who are infatuated with patent medicines and all new-fangled methods of producing health or mending it. She was an inveterate experimenter in these things. When something fresh in this line came out she was in a fever, right away, to try it; not on herself, for she was never ailing, but on anybody else that came handy. She was a subscriber for all the “Health” periodicals and phrenological frauds; and the solemn ignorance they were inflated with was breath to her nostrils. All the “rot” they contained about ventilation, and how to go to bed, and how to get up, and what to eat, and what to drink, and how much exercise to take, and what frame of mind to keep one’s self in, and what sort of clothing to wear, was all gospel to her, and she never observed that her health-journals of the current month customarily upset everything they had recommended the month before. She was as simple-hearted and honest as the day was long, and so she was an easy victim. She gathered together her quack periodicals and her quack medicines, and thus armed with death, went about on her pale horse, metaphorically speaking, with “hell following after.” But she never suspected that she was not an angel of healing and the balm of Gilead in disguise, to the suffering neighbors.

His usual zest for war games and piracy, which once filled his days with joy, now seemed dull and meaningless. He lost all interest in his playthings, and his spirits sank lower and lower. Aunt Polly, observing his despondency, grew increasingly concerned. She was a woman of simple tastes but a great believer in patent medicines and new health practices. She was always eager to try some new remedy, often experimenting on others rather than herself, for she was rarely ill. Her house was filled with health journals, and she followed phrenological theories with earnest belief, accepting their advice, no matter how contradictory or unfounded, as gospel. Despite her good intentions, her reliance on quack remedies was portrayed as her unwittingly doing harm, a metaphor for her well-meaning but misguided efforts to cure Tom's melancholy.

events.title: Aunt Polly Implements the Rigorous Water Cure
detailed_summary: Aunt Polly viewed Tom's dejected state as a perfect chance to implement a newly discovered water treatment.
Each morning, she subjected Tom to an ordeal in the woodshed, drenching him with cold water.
After the cold-water deluge, she would vigorously scrub him with a towel that felt as rough as a file.
He was then enveloped in a damp sheet and covered with blankets, a process intended to make him sweat until, as Tom put it, his soul was cleansed and its impurities visibly extracted.
Despite this regimen, Tom's condition worsened; he became increasingly melancholic, pale, and dejected.
In response, Aunt Polly intensified the hydrotherapy, introducing hot baths, sitz baths, shower baths, and plunges.
She also supplemented these water treatments with a restrictive oatmeal diet and blister-plasters, meticulously dosing him with an array of dubious cure-alls.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The water treatment was new, now, and Tom’s low condition was a windfall to her.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She calculated his capacity as she would a jug’s, and filled him up every day with quack cure-alls.

events.text_segment:
The water treatment was new, now, and Tom’s low condition was a windfall to her. She had him out at daylight every morning, stood him up in the wood-shed and drowned him with a deluge of cold water; then she scrubbed him down with a towel like a file, and so brought him to; then she rolled him up in a wet sheet and put him away under blankets till she sweated his soul clean and “the yellow stains of it came through his pores”—as Tom said.
Yet notwithstanding all this, the boy grew more and more melancholy and pale and dejected. She added hot baths, sitz baths, shower baths, and plunges. The boy remained as dismal as a hearse. She began to assist the water with a slim oatmeal diet and blister-plasters. She calculated his capacity as she would a jug’s, and filled him up every day with quack cure-alls.

events.title: The Introduction of Pain-killer and Tom's Cunning Plan
detailed_summary: Tom's growing indifference to Aunt Polly's treatments caused her great alarm, making her determined to rouse him from his apathy.
She discovered a new remedy called Pain-killer and promptly acquired a supply.
After tasting the medicine and finding its fiery potency impressive, she abandoned all previous treatments and placed her complete trust in Pain-killer.
A spoonful given to Tom had an immediate and dramatic effect, visibly breaking his indifference, which greatly relieved Aunt Polly.
Tom, weary of the endless experimentation, decided to feign fondness for Pain-killer as a strategy to avoid further diverse treatments.
He began requesting the medicine so often that his aunt, exasperated, permitted him to administer it himself.
Suspicious of Tom, she clandestinely monitored the medicine bottle, noticing a decrease in its contents, unaware that Tom was using it to fill a crack in the sitting-room floor.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Tom had become indifferent to persecution by this time.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She found that the medicine did really diminish, but it did not occur to her that the boy was mending the health of a crack in the sitting-room floor with it.

events.text_segment:
Tom had become indifferent to persecution by this time. This phase filled the old lady’s heart with consternation. This indifference must be broken up at any cost. Now she heard of Pain-killer for the first time. She ordered a lot at once. She tasted it and was filled with gratitude. It was simply fire in a liquid form. She dropped the water treatment and everything else, and pinned her faith to Pain-killer. She gave Tom a teaspoonful and watched with the deepest anxiety for the result. Her troubles were instantly at rest, her soul at peace again; for the “indifference” was broken up. The boy could not have shown a wilder, heartier interest, if she had built a fire under him.
Tom felt that it was time to wake up; this sort of life might be romantic enough, in his blighted condition, but it was getting to have too little sentiment and too much distracting variety about it. So he thought over various plans for relief, and finally hit upon that of professing to be fond of Pain-killer. He asked for it so often that he became a nuisance, and his aunt ended by telling him to help himself and quit bothering her. If it had been Sid, she would have had no misgivings to alloy her delight; but since it was Tom, she watched the bottle clandestinely. She found that the medicine did really diminish, but it did not occur to her that the boy was mending the health of a crack in the sitting-room floor with it.

When she tasted it, she found it fiery and potent, and decided to abandon all her previous treatments, trusting only in Pain-killer. She gave Tom a spoonful, and the effect was immediate—his indifference broke, and he showed signs of revival, much to Aunt Polly's relief.

Tom, tired of the endless experimenting, decided to pretend he liked Pain-killer so he wouldn't have to endure more treatments. Unbeknownst to her, Tom was using the medicine to fill a crack in the sitting-room floor, cleverly disguising his actions.

events.title: Peter the Cat's Dramatic Reaction to Pain-killer
detailed_summary: As Tom was administering Pain-killer to the floor crack, his aunt's yellow cat, Peter, approached, showing keen interest in the teaspoon.
Tom cautioned Peter that he might not enjoy the medicine, but the cat persisted in its apparent desire for a taste.
Asserting his lack of malice, Tom opened Peter's mouth and poured in the Pain-killer.

Peter's reaction was immediate and violent: he leaped high, emitted a loud cry, and began racing frantically around the room, colliding with furniture and knocking over flower-pots, creating utter chaos.
The cat then rose on its hind legs, prancing in a state of apparent ecstasy, vocalizing its extreme excitement.
It resumed its destructive tear through the house, spreading disorder.
Aunt Polly arrived just as Peter performed several somersaults, let out a final powerful yowl, and launched himself through an open window, taking the remaining flower-pots along.
The old lady was left dumbfounded by the sight, while Tom was doubled over with laughter.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: One day Tom was in the act of dosing the crack when his aunt’s yellow cat came along, purring, eyeing the teaspoon avariciously, and begging for a taste.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Tom lay on the floor expiring with laughter.

events.text_segment:
One day Tom was in the act of dosing the crack when his aunt’s yellow cat came along, purring, eyeing the teaspoon avariciously, and begging for a taste. Tom said:
“Don’t ask for it unless you want it, Peter.”
But Peter signified that he did want it.
“You better make sure.”
Peter was sure.
“Now you’ve asked for it, and I’ll give it to you, because there ain’t anything mean about me; but if you find you don’t like it, you mustn’t blame anybody but your own self.”
Peter was agreeable. So Tom pried his mouth open and poured down the Pain-killer. Peter sprang a couple of yards in the air, and then delivered a war-whoop and set off round and round the room, banging against furniture, upsetting flower-pots, and making general havoc. Next he rose on his hind feet and pranced around, in a frenzy of enjoyment, with his head over his shoulder and his voice proclaiming his unappeasable happiness. Then he went tearing around the house again spreading chaos and destruction in his path. Aunt Polly entered in time to see him throw a few double summersets, deliver a final mighty hurrah, and sail through the open window, carrying the rest of the flower-pots with him. The old lady stood petrified with astonishment, peering over her glasses; Tom lay on the floor expiring with laughter.

events.title: Confrontation, Justification, and Aunt Polly's Remorse
detailed_summary: Aunt Polly, bewildered, questioned Tom about the cause of the cat's extraordinary behavior.
Tom initially feigned ignorance, suggesting that cats always behave so wildly when they are enjoying themselves.
Aunt Polly's tone grew suspicious, making Tom anxious.
She then noticed the incriminating teaspoon handle visible beneath the bed-valance, confirming her suspicions about Tom's involvement.
Aunt Polly reprimanded Tom, pulling his ear and rapping his head with her thimble, demanding to know why he had treated the cat so cruelly.
Tom cleverly defended himself by claiming he acted out of pity, because Peter, unlike himself, didn't have an aunt to subject him to harsh treatments, thereby subtly critiquing her own methods.
This comparison made Aunt Polly reflect, and she felt a pang of remorse, realizing that what was cruel to a cat could also be cruel to a boy.
Her demeanor softened, and she admitted her intentions were good, also noting that the medicine did seem to benefit Tom.
Tom, with a hint of a smile, acknowledged her good intentions and mirrored them regarding Peter, adding that the cat also seemed to benefit from the experience.
Aunt Polly, wishing to end the discussion, told Tom to behave and that he would not need to take any more medicine.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Tom, what on earth ails that cat?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And you try and see if you can’t be a good boy, for once, and you needn’t take any more medicine.”

events.text_segment:
“Tom, what on earth ails that cat?”
“I don’t know, aunt,” gasped the boy.
“Why, I never see anything like it. What did make him act so?”
“Deed I don’t know, Aunt Polly; cats always act so when they’re having a good time.”
“They do, do they?” There was something in the tone that made Tom apprehensive.
“Yes’m. That is, I believe they do.”
“You do?”
“Yes’m.”
The old lady was bending down, Tom watching, with interest emphasized by anxiety. Too late he divined her “drift.” The handle of the telltale tea-spoon was visible under the bed-valance. Aunt Polly took it, held it up. Tom winced, and dropped his eyes. Aunt Polly raised him by the usual handle—his ear—and cracked his head soundly with her thimble.
“Now, sir, what did you want to treat that poor dumb beast so, for?”
“I done it out of pity for him—because he hadn’t any aunt.”
“Hadn’t any aunt!—you numskull. What has that got to do with it?”
“Heaps. Because if he’d had one she’d a burnt him out herself! She’d a roasted his bowels out of him ’thout any more feeling than if he was a human!”
Aunt Polly felt a sudden pang of remorse. This was putting the thing in a new light; what was cruelty to a cat might be cruelty to a boy, too. She began to soften; she felt sorry. Her eyes watered a little, and she put her hand on Tom’s head and said gently:
“I was meaning for the best, Tom. And, Tom, it did do you good.”
Tom looked up in her face with just a perceptible twinkle peeping through his gravity.
“I know you was meaning for the best, aunty, and so was I with Peter. It done him good, too. I never see him get around so since—”
“Oh, go ’long with you, Tom, before you aggravate me again. And you try and see if you can’t be a good boy, for once, and you needn’t take any more medicine.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
"Tom, what on earth ails that cat?" Aunt Polly asked, bewildered, as she observed the animal's strange behavior.

Tom, feigning ignorance, suggested, "Cats always act so wildly when they're having a good time, Aunt Polly."

Aunt Polly's suspicion grew, and she looked more closely. Her eyes fell upon the handle of a teaspoon peeking out from beneath the bed-valance, confirming her suspicions about Tom's involvement.

She scolded him sharply, pulling his ear and rapping his head with her thimble, demanding to know why he had treated the cat so cruelly.

Tom, quick-witted, defended himself by saying, "I only did it out of pity. You see, Peter, unlike me, doesn't have an aunt to give him such harsh treatments."

This remark made Aunt Polly pause and reflect. She felt a pang of remorse, realizing that what was cruel to a cat could also be cruel to a boy.

Her demeanor softened, and she admitted, "My intentions were good, Tom. And the medicine I gave you does seem to be helping."

Tom, with a slight smile, acknowledged her good intentions and added, "The cat seems to have benefited from it too, Aunt Polly."

Wishing to end the discussion, she told Tom to behave and assured him he would not need to take any more medicine.

events.title: Tom's Desperate Attempts to Win Becky's Attention at School
detailed_summary: Tom arrived at school unusually early, a behavior that had become common for him recently.

Instead of joining his peers in play, he lingered by the schoolyard gate, claiming to feel unwell and appearing so, all the while feigning to look elsewhere but actually watching down the road for Becky.
When Jeff Thatcher appeared, Tom's face brightened, but he quickly feigned disinterest after a brief glance.
Tom approached Jeff and cautiously tried to steer the conversation towards Becky, but Jeff failed to notice Tom's subtle inquiries.
He continued to watch anxiously for Becky, feeling disappointment each time another girl appeared.
Upon Becky's eventual arrival, Tom's spirits lifted dramatically, and he immediately began an extravagant display of acrobatics and daring feats to capture her attention.
He performed handsprings, stood on his head, leaped over fences, and generally created a spectacle, all while surreptitiously checking if Becky was noticing.
However, Becky seemed entirely unaware of his presence or his elaborate performance, never once looking his way.
In a final, desperate attempt, Tom caused a commotion directly in front of her, nearly making her stumble.
Becky, with an air of disdain, turned away and commented aloud that some people are conceited and always showing off.
Mortified, Tom's cheeks burned, and he retreated, feeling utterly crushed and disheartened.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Tom reached school ahead of time.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He gathered himself up and sneaked off, crushed and crestfallen.

events.text_segment:
Tom reached school ahead of time. It was noticed that this strange thing had been occurring every day latterly. And now, as usual of late, he hung about the gate of the schoolyard instead of playing with his comrades. He was sick, he said, and he looked it. He tried to seem to be looking everywhere but whither he really was looking—down the road. Presently Jeff Thatcher hove in sight, and Tom’s face lighted; he gazed a moment, and then turned sorrowfully away. When Jeff arrived, Tom accosted him; and “led up” warily to opportunities for remark about Becky, but the giddy lad never could see the bait. Tom watched and watched, hoping whenever a frisking frock came in sight, and hating the owner of it as soon as he saw she was not the right one. At last frocks ceased to appear, and he dropped hopelessly into the dumps; he entered the empty schoolhouse and sat down to suffer. Then one more frock passed in at the gate, and Tom’s heart gave a great bound. The next instant he was out, and “going on” like an Indian; yelling, laughing, chasing boys, jumping over the fence at risk of life and limb, throwing handsprings, standing on his head—doing all the heroic things he could conceive of, and keeping a furtive eye out, all the while, to see if Becky Thatcher was noticing. But she seemed to be unconscious of it all; she never looked. Could it be possible that she was not aware that he was there? He carried his exploits to her immediate vicinity; came war-whooping around, snatched a boy’s cap, hurled it to the roof of the schoolhouse, broke through a group of boys, tumbling them in every direction, and fell sprawling, himself, under Becky’s nose, almost upsetting her—and she turned, with her nose in the air, and he heard her say: “Mf! some people think they’re mighty smart—always showing off!”
Tom’s cheeks burned. He gathered himself up and sneaked off, crushed and crestfallen.

As the teacher started the lesson, Tom's thoughts drifted to the adventures awaiting him after school. He knew that the day would pass quickly, and soon he would be free to explore the woods, fish in the river, or perhaps even find some trouble to get into. Despite the strict rules and the lessons he was supposed to learn, Tom's mind was always on the possibility of fun and excitement. He was a boy full of energy and imagination, always dreaming of daring escapades and hidden treasures. As the morning wore on, Tom's anticipation grew, and he couldn't help but wonder what the rest of the day would bring. Would he find a new hiding spot? Would he outsmart the schoolmaster? Whatever happened, Tom was ready for whatever adventures lay ahead, eager to make the most of his childhood in the small town of St. Petersburg.

events.title: Tom's Desperate Resolve for a Life of Crime
detailed_summary: Tom Sawyer feels utterly forsaken, friendless, and unloved, believing that everyone wishes him gone.
He rationalizes that his impending actions are forced upon him and that others will feel remorse when they realize the extent of his desperation.
Convinced that his attempts to live a good life have been thwarted, he concludes that a life of crime is his only remaining path.
The distant sound of the school bell evokes a wave of sorrow, as he reflects on never hearing it again, a hardship he feels is imposed on him.
Despite his bitterness, he claims to forgive those who have driven him to this state, even as his sobs become more intense.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Tom’s mind was made up now.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then the sobs came thick and fast.

events.text_segment:
Tom’s mind was made up now. He was gloomy and desperate. He was a forsaken, friendless boy, he said; nobody loved him; when they found out what they had driven him to, perhaps they would be sorry; he had tried to do right and get along, but they would not let him; since nothing would do them but to be rid of him, let it be so; and let them blame him for the consequences—why shouldn’t they? What right had the friendless to complain? Yes, they had forced him to it at last: he would lead a life of crime. There was no choice.
By this time he was far down Meadow Lane, and the bell for school to “take up” tinkled faintly upon his ear. He sobbed, now, to think he should never, never hear that old familiar sound any more—it was very hard, but it was forced on him; since he was driven out into the cold world, he must submit—but he forgave them. Then the sobs came thick and fast.

The distant chime of the school bell echoed through his mind, filling him with a deep sorrow as he thought he would never hear it again—a hardship he believed was unfairly imposed on him. Despite his bitterness, he claimed to forgive those who had driven him to this point, even as his sobs grew more intense, overwhelmed by the pain of his solitude.

events.title: A Pact of Misery: Tom and Joe Decide to Become Pirates
detailed_summary: Tom encounters Joe Harper, who appears equally distressed and resolute.
Tom, tearfully, shares his decision to escape his unsympathetic home environment and seek a life of adventure, expressing a hope that Joe will not forget him.
It turns out Joe was on a similar mission, intending to make the same request of Tom.
Joe recounts being unjustly punished by his mother for drinking cream he never touched, leading him to believe she wants him to leave.
He expresses a somber acceptance of his fate, hoping his mother will be happy without him and eventually regret driving him away to suffer.
The two boys pledge to be like brothers, supporting each other until death frees them from their woes.
They begin to formulate their plans; Joe initially proposes becoming a hermit, living a life of austerity and sorrow in a cave.
However, after Tom outlines the exciting aspects of a criminal life, Joe is convinced and agrees to become a pirate instead.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Just at this point he met his soul’s sworn comrade, Joe Harper—hard-eyed, and with evidently a great and dismal purpose in his heart.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Joe was for being a hermit, and living on crusts in a remote cave, and dying, some time, of cold and want and grief; but after listening to Tom, he conceded that there were some conspicuous advantages about a life of crime, and so he consented to be a pirate.

events.text_segment:
Just at this point he met his soul’s sworn comrade, Joe Harper—hard-eyed, and with evidently a great and dismal purpose in his heart. Plainly here were “two souls with but a single thought.” Tom, wiping his eyes with his sleeve, began to blubber out something about a resolution to escape from hard usage and lack of sympathy at home by roaming abroad into the great world never to return; and ended by hoping that Joe would not forget him.
But it transpired that this was a request which Joe had just been going to make of Tom, and had come to hunt him up for that purpose. His mother had whipped him for drinking some cream which he had never tasted and knew nothing about; it was plain that she was tired of him and wished him to go; if she felt that way, there was nothing for him to do but succumb; he hoped she would be happy, and never regret having driven her poor boy out into the unfeeling world to suffer and die.
As the two boys walked sorrowing along, they made a new compact to stand by each other and be brothers and never separate till death relieved them of their troubles. Then they began to lay their plans. Joe was for being a hermit, and living on crusts in a remote cave, and dying, some time, of cold and want and grief; but after listening to Tom, he conceded that there were some conspicuous advantages about a life of crime, and so he consented to be a pirate.

To Tom’s surprise, Joe revealed he was on a similar mission, intending to ask Tom the same thing. Joe recounted how he had been unjustly punished by his mother for drinking cream he never touched, leading him to believe she wanted him to leave. He expressed a somber acceptance of his fate, wishing his mother happiness without him and hoping she would regret driving him away to suffer. The boys vowed to be like brothers, supporting each other until death freed them from their woes. They began to plan; Joe first suggested becoming a hermit, living austerely and sorrowfully in a cave. But after Tom described the exciting life of a pirate, Joe was convinced and agreed to become a pirate instead.

events.title: Choosing a Hideout and Recruiting Huckleberry Finn
detailed_summary: The boys select Jackson's Island, a long, wooded, and uninhabited isle in the Mississippi River, as their future hideout.
The island's isolation, situated far across the river from St. Petersburg and near a sparsely populated forest, makes it an attractive choice.
The practical detail of whom they would target with their piracy does not cross their minds.
They then seek out Huckleberry Finn, who, being indifferent to various occupations, promptly agrees to join their pirate band.
The trio arranges to convene at a secluded location on the riverbank, two miles from the village, at the adventurous hour of midnight.
Their plan includes commandeering a small log raft they know is there.
Each boy is tasked with bringing fishing gear and any provisions he can acquire through surreptitious, outlaw-like means.
Before the day concludes, they manage to spread cryptic hints throughout the town, suggesting that significant news would soon emerge, cautioning informants to remain silent and expectant.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Three miles below St. Petersburg, at a point where the Mississippi River was a trifle over a mile wide, there was a long, narrow, wooded island, with a shallow bar at the head of it, and this offered well as a rendezvous.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: All who got this vague hint were cautioned to “be mum and wait.”

events.text_segment: Three miles below St. Petersburg, at a point where the Mississippi River was a trifle over a mile wide, there was a long, narrow, wooded island, with a shallow bar at the head of it, and this offered well as a rendezvous. It was not inhabited; it lay far over toward the further shore, abreast a dense and almost wholly unpeopled forest. So Jackson’s Island was chosen. Who were to be the subjects of their piracies was a matter that did not occur to them. Then they hunted up Huckleberry Finn, and he joined them promptly, for all careers were one to him; he was indifferent. They presently separated to meet at a lonely spot on the river-bank two miles above the village at the favorite hour—which was midnight. There was a small log raft there which they meant to capture. Each would bring hooks and lines, and such provision as he could steal in the most dark and mysterious way—as became outlaws. And before the afternoon was done, they had all managed to enjoy the sweet glory of spreading the fact that pretty soon the town would “hear something.” All who got this vague hint were cautioned to “be mum and wait.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Three miles below St. Petersburg, at a point where the Mississippi River was a trifle over a mile wide, there was a long, narrow, wooded island, with a shallow bar at the head of it, and this offered well as a rendezvous. The boys, Tom Sawyer, Joe Harper, and Huckleberry Finn, had chosen this secluded spot for their secret plans. They decided to meet at midnight, each bringing along fishing gear and provisions, and to commandeer a small log raft they knew was moored nearby. Their scheme was simple: to become pirates for a night, free from the watchful eyes of the town, and to enjoy the thrill of adventure on the uninhabited island, far across the river from St. Petersburg.

events.title: Midnight Rendezvous and Pirate Personas
detailed_summary: Around midnight, Tom reaches the meeting spot carrying a boiled ham and a few other items, concealing himself in dense bushes on a bluff overlooking the river.
The night is still and starlit, the vast river appearing calm like a resting ocean.
Tom listens briefly, hearing nothing, then emits a distinct, low whistle.
His signal is answered from beneath the bluff.
After two more whistle exchanges, a guarded voice inquires his identity.
Tom dramatically announces himself as "Tom Sawyer, the Black Avenger of the Spanish Main."
Huck and Joe respond with their newly assigned pirate titles, "Huck Finn the Red-Handed" and "Joe Harper the Terror of the Seas," names Tom had supplied from his adventure books.
They complete the ritual by simultaneously whispering the password, "Blood!"
Tom then casts his ham over the bluff and descends after it, scraping his skin and tearing his clothes, deliberately choosing this hazardous route over an easier path to embody the pirate spirit.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: About midnight Tom arrived with a boiled ham and a few trifles, and stopped in a dense undergrowth on a small bluff overlooking the meeting-place.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: There was an easy, comfortable path along the shore under the bluff, but it lacked the advantages of difficulty and danger so valued by a pirate.

events.text_segment:
About midnight Tom arrived with a boiled ham and a few trifles, and stopped in a dense undergrowth on a small bluff overlooking the meeting-place. It was starlight, and very still. The mighty river lay like an ocean at rest. Tom listened a moment, but no sound disturbed the quiet. Then he gave a low, distinct whistle. It was answered from under the bluff. Tom whistled twice more; these signals were answered in the same way. Then a guarded voice said:
“Who goes there?”
“Tom Sawyer, the Black Avenger of the Spanish Main. Name your names.”
“Huck Finn the Red-Handed, and Joe Harper the Terror of the Seas.” Tom had furnished these titles, from his favorite literature.
“’Tis well. Give the countersign.”
Two hoarse whispers delivered the same awful word simultaneously to the brooding night:
“Blood!”
Then Tom tumbled his ham over the bluff and let himself down after it, tearing both skin and clothes to some extent in the effort. There was an easy, comfortable path along the shore under the bluff, but it lacked the advantages of difficulty and danger so valued by a pirate.

events.title: Gathering Supplies and Embarking with Pirate Theatrics
detailed_summary: Joe Harper, now "The Terror of the Seas," arrives with a side of bacon, visibly tired from the effort of transporting it.
Huckleberry Finn, "The Red-Handed," contributes a skillet, a supply of partially cured tobacco leaves, and a few corn-cobs for making pipes, as he is the only one among them who uses tobacco.
Tom, "The Black Avenger of the Spanish Main," wisely points out their need for fire, noting that matches were not readily available.
They spot a smoldering fire on a large raft further up the river and stealthily procure a burning piece of wood.

This act of acquiring fire is turned into a grand adventure, with the boys using hushed interjections like "Hist!", halting dramatically with fingers on lips, feigning to grasp imaginary daggers, and issuing whispered orders to attack any perceived "foe" because "dead men tell no tales."
They perform this charade despite knowing the raftsmen were likely absent, enjoying themselves in the village.
Soon after, they push off on their raft, with Tom in command, Huck at the rear oar, and Joe at the front.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The Terror of the Seas had brought a side of bacon, and had about worn himself out with getting it there.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Steady it is, sir!”

events.text_segment:
The Terror of the Seas had brought a side of bacon, and had about worn himself out with getting it there. Finn the Red-Handed had stolen a skillet and a quantity of half-cured leaf tobacco, and had also brought a few corn-cobs to make pipes with. But none of the pirates smoked or “chewed” but himself. The Black Avenger of the Spanish Main said it would never do to start without some fire. That was a wise thought; matches were hardly known there in that day. They saw a fire smouldering upon a great raft a hundred yards above, and they went stealthily thither and helped themselves to a chunk. They made an imposing adventure of it, saying, “Hist!” every now and then, and suddenly halting with finger on lip; moving with hands on imaginary dagger-hilts; and giving orders in dismal whispers that if “the foe” stirred, to “let him have it to the hilt,” because “dead men tell no tales.” They knew well enough that the raftsmen were all down at the village laying in stores or having a spree, but still that was no excuse for their conducting this thing in an unpiratical way.
They shoved off, presently, Tom in command, Huck at the after oar and Joe at the forward. Tom stood amidships, gloomy-browed, and with folded arms, and gave his orders in a low, stern whisper:
“Luff, and bring her to the wind!”
“Aye-aye, sir!”
“Steady, steady-y-y-y!”
“Steady it is, sir!”

events.title: The Solemn Journey to Jackson's Island and Establishing Camp
detailed_summary: As the raft moves past the river's midpoint, the boys align its course correctly and then rest on their oars.
The river wasn't high, resulting in a gentle current of about two or three miles per hour.
For the next forty-five minutes, very little is spoken as the raft glides past the distant, sleeping town, identifiable by a few faint lights across the vast, star-dusted water.

Tom, in his persona as the Black Avenger, stands silently with folded arms, taking a symbolic "last look" at the place of his past happiness and recent misery, wishing "she" could witness his current bravery as he faces danger and death on the wild waters.
He mentally adjusts the perceived distance to Jackson's Island to amplify the dramatic sense of his departure, feeling a mixture of sorrow and satisfaction.
The other two pirates also engage in their own solemn "last looks," becoming so absorbed that they nearly allow the current to carry them beyond the island.
They realize their predicament just in time and manage to steer towards it.
Around two in the morning, the raft runs aground on a sandbar near the island's head, prompting them to wade back and forth to unload their supplies.

Among their raft's equipment is an old sail, which they utilize to fashion a makeshift tent over some bushes to protect their provisions, while they themselves plan to sleep in the open, true to their outlaw status.

events.text_segment: The raft drew beyond the middle of the river; the boys pointed her head right, and then lay on their oars. The river was not high, so there was not more than a two or three mile current. Hardly a word was said during the next three-quarters of an hour. Now the raft was passing before the distant town. Two or three glimmering lights showed where it lay, peacefully sleeping, beyond the vague vast sweep of star-gemmed water, unconscious of the tremendous event that was happening. The Black Avenger stood still with folded arms, “looking his last” upon the scene of his former joys and his later sufferings, and wishing “she” could see him now, abroad on the wild sea, facing peril and death with dauntless heart, going to his doom with a grim smile on his lips. It was but a small strain on his imagination to remove Jackson’s Island beyond eye-shot of the village, and so he “looked his last” with a broken and satisfied heart. The other pirates were looking their last, too; and they all looked so long that they came near letting the current drift them out of the range of the island. But they discovered the danger in time, and made shift to avert it. About two o’clock in the morning the raft grounded on the bar two hundred yards above the head of the island, and they waded back and forth until they had landed their freight. Part of the little raft’s belongings consisted of an old sail, and this they spread over a nook in the bushes for a tent to shelter their provisions; but they themselves would sleep in the open air in good weather, as became outlaws.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The raft drew beyond the middle of the river; the boys pointed her head right, and then lay on their oars. The current was swift, and the water sparkled in the sunlight like a thousand diamonds. Tom Sawyer sat at the bow, his eyes bright with excitement, while Huck Finn leaned back, whistling softly. They had been planning this trip for days, eager to escape the dullness of school and the watchful eyes of Aunt Polly. As they drifted further downstream, the scenery changed from the lush green banks to rocky outcroppings and overhanging trees. Tom felt a thrill of adventure coursing through him. Suddenly, Huck pointed to a shadow beneath the water. "Look at that!" he exclaimed. Tom peered over the side and saw a large fish darting away. The boys giggled, their fears and worries temporarily forgotten. They decided to stop and explore an island they saw ahead. As they approached, Tom's mind raced with possibilities—treasure, pirates, or perhaps a secret hideout. They tied the raft to a tree and stepped onto the sandy shore. The island was quiet, save for the chirping of birds and the rustling of leaves. Huck suggested they build a fort, while Tom imagined finding buried treasure. They spent the afternoon exploring, dreaming of adventures, and making plans for the next day. As the sun began to set, they returned to their raft, feeling more like explorers than boys. The river carried them back toward home, but their minds were already filled with new stories to tell.

events.title: First Night's Feast and Debating the Merits of Piracy
detailed_summary: The boys construct a fire near a large log deep within the forest.
They cook bacon and consume some of their corn bread for dinner, reveling in the liberating experience of feasting in the untouched wilderness of an uninhabited island, far from human society.
They passionately declare their intention never to go back to civilization.
The dancing flames illuminate their faces and the surrounding trees, creating an atmosphere akin to a forest temple.
After finishing their meal, they stretch out on the grass, filled with deep contentment, choosing the romantic warmth of the campfire over a potentially cooler resting spot.
Joe and Tom express their sheer delight with their new pirate lifestyle.
Huckleberry affirms his own satisfaction, especially valuing the abundance of food and the absence of harassment.

Tom praises the pirate's life for its freedom from daily chores like waking up early, attending school, and washing, contrasting it with the perceived obligations of a hermit, who must pray frequently and lacks companionship and fun.
Joe concurs, admitting he hadn't fully considered the downsides of hermit life and now much prefers being a pirate.
Tom further argues that pirates command respect, unlike hermits in modern times, who are expected to endure discomforts like sleeping on hard surfaces and wearing sackcloth and ashes.
Huck questions the rationale behind wearing sackcloth and ashes, to which Tom can only reply that it's a traditional requirement for hermits.
Huck firmly states he would refuse such a practice and would run away, prompting Tom to call him a potentially disgraceful hermit.

events.text_segment:
They built a fire against the side of a great log twenty or thirty steps within the sombre depths of the forest, and then cooked some bacon in the frying-pan for supper, and used up half of the corn “pone” stock they had brought. It seemed glorious sport to be feasting in that wild, free way in the virgin forest of an unexplored and uninhabited island, far from the haunts of men, and they said they never would return to civilization. The climbing fire lit up their faces and threw its ruddy glare upon the pillared tree-trunks of their forest temple, and upon the varnished foliage and festooning vines.
When the last crisp slice of bacon was gone, and the last allowance of corn pone devoured, the boys stretched themselves out on the grass, filled with contentment. They could have found a cooler place, but they would not deny themselves such a romantic feature as the roasting campfire.
“Ain’t it gay?” said Joe.
“It’s nuts!” said Tom. “What would the boys say if they could see us?”
“Say? Well, they’d just die to be here—hey, Hucky!”
“I reckon so,” said Huckleberry; “anyways, I’m suited. I don’t want nothing better’n this. I don’t ever get enough to eat, gen’ally—and here they can’t come and pick at a feller and bullyrag him so.”
“It’s just the life for me,” said Tom. “You don’t have to get up, mornings, and you don’t have to go to school, and wash, and all that blame foolishness. You see a pirate don’t have to do anything, Joe, when he’s ashore, but a hermit he has to be praying considerable, and then he don’t have any fun, anyway, all by himself that way.”
“Oh yes, that’s so,” said Joe, “but I hadn’t thought much about it, you know. I’d a good deal rather be a pirate, now that I’ve tried it.”
“You see,” said Tom, “people don’t go much on hermits, nowadays, like they used to in old times, but a pirate’s always respected. And a hermit’s got to sleep on the hardest place he can find, and put sackcloth and ashes on his head, and stand out in the rain, and—”
“What does he put sackcloth and ashes on his head for?” inquired Huck.
“I dono. But they’ve got to do it. Hermits always do. You’d have to do that if you was a hermit.”
“Dern’d if I would,” said Huck.
“Well, what would you do?”
“I dono. But I wouldn’t do that.”
“Why, Huck, you’d have to. How’d you get around it?”
“Why, I just wouldn’t stand it. I’d run away.”
“Run away! Well, you would be a nice old slouch of a hermit. You’d be a disgrace.”

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
They built a fire against the side of a great log twenty or thirty steps within the sombre depths of the forest, and then cooked some bacon in the frying-pan for supper, and used up half of the corn “pone” stock they had brought. The flames danced and flickered, casting a warm glow on their eager faces and the surrounding trees, creating an atmosphere that felt almost sacred—a forest temple of their own making. After their meal, they stretched out on the soft grass, feeling a deep sense of contentment and freedom. They reveled in the joy of their independence, far from the constraints of civilization, and declared with enthusiasm that they would never go back.

Joe and Tom expressed their delight with their new pirate lifestyle, while Huck, satisfied with the abundance of food and the absence of harassment, nodded in agreement. Tom extolled the virtues of the pirate life, contrasting it with the drudgery of everyday chores—waking early, attending school, washing, and the burdens of a hermit’s life, which involved frequent prayers and lacked companionship and fun.

“Pirates don’t have to get up early, nor go to school, nor wash,” said Tom. “And they don’t have to pray all the time, like hermits do. Hermits are always praying and they don’t have any fun, and they have to sleep on hard beds and wear sackcloth and ashes.”

“Huh! Sackcloth and ashes!” said Huck. “What’s the use of that? I wouldn’t wear it. I’d run away first.”

“Run away! You’d be a disgraceful hermit,” said Tom, laughing.

Joe looked thoughtful. “I hadn’t thought much about hermits. I guess I’d rather be a pirate.”

“Pirates command respect,” said Tom. “Hermits are just old men who sleep on the floor and wear sackcloth and ashes, and nobody cares for them.”

Huck looked skeptical. “Why do they wear sackcloth and ashes?”

“Because it’s what hermits do,” said Tom. “It’s a tradition.”

“I wouldn’t do it,” said Huck. “I’d run away and be a pirate.”

Tom grinned. “You’d make a fine hermit, Huck.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The boys sat around the fire, their faces glowing in the flickering light, sharing stories and laughter as the night deepened around them. Tom, feeling a rare sense of contentment, looked up at the starry sky through the gaps in the trees. The crackling of the fire and the distant hoot of an owl were the only sounds breaking the silence of the woods. As they finished their meal, Tom's mind wandered to the adventures that awaited them the next day. He was filled with a mixture of excitement and curiosity, eager to explore the mysterious depths of the forest and perhaps find some hidden treasure or secret. Huck and Joe joined in the conversation, their voices low but animated, discussing plans and possibilities. The fire's warmth kept the chill of the evening at bay, and the boys felt a sense of camaraderie and freedom that only such wilderness escapades could bring. After a while, Tom suggested they take a short walk to stretch their legs and enjoy the cool night air. They moved quietly, stepping softly over the fallen leaves and twigs, their shadows dancing on the ground. As they wandered, Tom pointed out different constellations and told stories about the stars, making the night seem even more magical. They returned to their campfire, feeling refreshed and more connected than ever. As the fire dwindled to embers, Tom carefully stoked it back to life, ensuring they would have enough light and warmth for the rest of the night. The boys settled down on the ground, leaning against logs and sharing their hopes for tomorrow. Tom's thoughts drifted to the adventures he dreamed of—perhaps discovering a hidden cave or outwitting the town bullies. The forest around them was alive with sounds, a symphony of nocturnal creatures that added to the thrill of their camping trip. As sleep began to claim them, Tom felt a deep sense of gratitude for these simple pleasures—good friends, a warm fire, and the wild, beautiful woods that stretched endlessly before them. Tomorrow would bring new adventures, but for tonight, they were content to rest under the vast, starry sky, dreaming of the adventures yet to come.

events.title: Pirate Lore, Aspirations, and a Bout of Conscience
detailed_summary: Huckleberry, unfazed by the hermit discussion, fashions a pipe from a corn-cob and a weed stem, fills it with tobacco, and begins to smoke, achieving a state of luxurious contentment.
Tom and Joe observe him with envy, silently resolving to adopt this impressive habit themselves soon.
Huck then inquires about the actual duties and activities of pirates.
Tom describes a thrilling existence involving capturing and burning ships, amassing and burying treasure in eerie, ghost-guarded locations on their island, and forcing captives to walk the plank.
Joe chimes in that pirates also take women to their island, but do not kill them.
Tom agrees, highlighting the pirates' supposed nobility and the invariable beauty of the women they capture.
Joe adds with excitement that pirates wear magnificent clothing adorned with gold, silver, and diamonds.

Huck, looking at his own tattered attire, expresses concern that he isn't suitably dressed for a pirate, but Tom and Joe reassure him that fine clothes will come once their adventures begin, explaining that while wealthy pirates start with proper wardrobes, his current rags are acceptable for starting out.
As their conversation wanes, drowsiness overcomes them. Huck, weary and conscience-free, drops his pipe and falls asleep.
Tom and Joe find it harder to sleep, troubled by their consciences.
They say their prayers privately, having considered skipping them but fearing divine punishment.
A vague fear about the wrongness of running away surfaces, followed by more acute guilt over the stolen meat.
They attempt to rationalize their actions by comparing the theft of ham and bacon to previous instances of taking sweetmeats and apples, which they termed mere "hooking."

However, their consciences are not easily soothed, eventually making them realize that taking valuable provisions was undeniably stealing, an act prohibited by the Bible, unlike the minor offense of "hooking."
They inwardly resolve that for the duration of their pirate careers, they will not tarnish their activities with the crime of actual stealing.
This moral compromise brings them a truce with their consciences, allowing the surprisingly inconsistent pirates to finally fall asleep peacefully.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The Red-Handed made no response, being better employed.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then conscience granted a truce, and these curiously inconsistent pirates fell peacefully to sleep.

events.text_segment:
The Red-Handed made no response, being better employed. He had finished gouging out a cob, and now he fitted a weed stem to it, loaded it with tobacco, and was pressing a coal to the charge and blowing a cloud of fragrant smoke—he was in the full bloom of luxurious contentment. The other pirates envied him this majestic vice, and secretly resolved to acquire it shortly. Presently Huck said:
“What does pirates have to do?”
Tom said:
“Oh, they have just a bully time—take ships and burn them, and get the money and bury it in awful places in their island where there’s ghosts and things to watch it, and kill everybody in the ships—make ’em walk a plank.”
“And they carry the women to the island,” said Joe; “they don’t kill the women.”
“No,” assented Tom, “they don’t kill the women—they’re too noble. And the women’s always beautiful, too.”
“And don’t they wear the bulliest clothes! Oh no! All gold and silver and di’monds,” said Joe, with enthusiasm.
“Who?” said Huck.
“Why, the pirates.”
Huck scanned his own clothing forlornly.
“I reckon I ain’t dressed fitten for a pirate,” said he, with a regretful pathos in his voice; “but I ain’t got none but these.”
But the other boys told him the fine clothes would come fast enough, after they should have begun their adventures. They made him understand that his poor rags would do to begin with, though it was customary for wealthy pirates to start with a proper wardrobe.
Gradually their talk died out and drowsiness began to steal upon the eyelids of the little waifs. The pipe dropped from the fingers of the Red-Handed, and he slept the sleep of the conscience-free and the weary. The Terror of the Seas and the Black Avenger of the Spanish Main had more difficulty in getting to sleep. They said their prayers inwardly, and lying down, since there was nobody there with authority to make them kneel and recite aloud; in truth, they had a mind not to say them at all, but they were afraid to proceed to such lengths as that, lest they might call down a sudden and special thunderbolt from heaven. Then at once they reached and hovered upon the imminent verge of sleep—but an intruder came, now, that would not “down.” It was conscience. They began to feel a vague fear that they had been doing wrong to run away; and next they thought of the stolen meat, and then the real torture came. They tried to argue it away by reminding conscience that they had purloined sweetmeats and apples scores of times; but conscience was not to be appeased by such thin plausibilities; it seemed to them, in the end, that there was no getting around the stubborn fact that taking sweetmeats was only “hooking,” while taking bacon and hams and such valuables was plain simple stealing—and there was a command against that in the Bible. So they inwardly resolved that so long as they remained in the business, their piracies should not again be sullied with the crime of stealing. Then conscience granted a truce, and these curiously inconsistent pirates fell peacefully to sleep.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
The Red-Handed made no response, being better employed.

Huckleberry Finn, unbothered by the talk of hermits, took a corn-cob and a weed stem, fashioned a pipe, filled it with tobacco, and began to smoke, feeling a deep sense of contentment. Tom and Joe watched him with envy, silently resolving to try the same soon. Huck then asked about what pirates actually did.

Tom described a life full of adventure—capturing ships, burning them, hiding treasure on their island guarded by ghosts, and making captives walk the plank. Joe added that pirates also took women to their island but did not kill them. Tom agreed, saying pirates were noble and the women they captured were always beautiful. Joe excitedly mentioned that pirates wore fine clothes decorated with gold, silver, and diamonds.

Huck looked at his torn clothes and worried he wasn't dressed like a pirate, but Tom and Joe reassured him that once they started their adventures, he would have fine clothes. For now, they said, his rags were enough to begin.

As they talked, sleep overtook them. Huck, feeling tired and free of guilt, dropped his pipe and fell asleep. Tom and Joe found it harder to sleep, troubled by their consciences. They privately said their prayers, considering skipping them but fearing divine punishment. A vague fear about the wrongness of running away appeared, then more intense guilt over stealing meat.

They tried to justify their theft, comparing it to previous acts of taking sweets and apples, which they called "hooking." But their consciences told them that stealing ham and bacon was real stealing, which the Bible forbade, unlike "hooking." They inwardly decided that during their pirate careers, they would not commit actual theft, thus making peace with their consciences. This moral compromise allowed the unlikely pirates to finally sleep peacefully.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Tom Sawyer was a boy full of mischief and adventure, always finding himself in the most curious situations. One bright summer day, he and his friend Joe had been wandering along the riverbank, dreaming up schemes and daring each other to daring deeds. As they sat on the sandy shore, Tom's eyes caught sight of a strange, shiny object half-buried in the sand. Curious, he scrambled over and dug it out, revealing a small, ornate box with a rusty latch.

"What do you suppose this is?" Joe asked, peering over Tom's shoulder.

"I don't know," Tom replied, his eyes gleaming with excitement. "But I bet it's something valuable. Maybe treasure!"

They tried to open the box, but it was locked tight. Tom's mind raced with possibilities. Could it be a pirate's loot? A secret message? Or perhaps a hidden stash of gold?

Suddenly, Tom remembered the story of the treasure buried near the old oak tree, and his heart pounded with anticipation. He decided they should take the box to Becky Thatcher, who was known for her cleverness and love of mysteries. Becky examined the box carefully, noting the intricate carvings and the strange symbols etched into its surface.

"It looks like a puzzle," she said thoughtfully. "Maybe if we find the key or figure out how to open it, we'll discover what's inside."

The children spent the afternoon trying different methods to unlock the box, turning it over and examining every inch. As the sun began to set, Tom suddenly remembered an old legend about a secret compartment that could be opened with a specific sequence of symbols.

"Let's try pressing the symbols in the order of the stars," Becky suggested, recalling a story her grandmother had told her.

They carefully pressed the symbols, and with a satisfying click, the latch released. The lid swung open to reveal a collection of old coins, a faded map, and a small, leather-bound journal.

Tom's eyes widened with wonder. "This is better than any treasure I ever imagined!" he exclaimed.

They eagerly examined the contents, realizing that the map might lead to more hidden secrets, and the journal contained stories of a long-lost explorer who had once lived in their town.

Excited by their discovery, Tom, Becky, and Joe decided to follow the map, embarking on a new adventure that would take them through the woods, across the river, and into the heart of their town's history.

As they set off at dawn, Tom couldn't help but feel a thrill of anticipation. The Red-Handed had made no response, being better employed, but their own hands were busy with the promise of discovery, and their hearts were full of the spirit of adventure.

events.title: Awakening in the Wilderness
detailed_summary: Tom awakens feeling disoriented but quickly realizes he is in the woods.
He observes the serene and peaceful early morning atmosphere, noting the deep calm and silence.
Dewdrops are visible on the leaves and grass around him.
The remnants of the previous night's fire are a white layer of ashes with a thin plume of smoke ascending vertically.
His companions, Joe and Huck, are still asleep.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When Tom awoke in the morning, he wondered where he was.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Joe and Huck still slept.

events.text_segment: When Tom awoke in the morning, he wondered where he was. He sat up and rubbed his eyes and looked around. Then he comprehended. It was the cool gray dawn, and there was a delicious sense of repose and peace in the deep pervading calm and silence of the woods. Not a leaf stirred; not a sound obtruded upon great Nature’s meditation. Beaded dewdrops stood upon the leaves and grasses. A white layer of ashes covered the fire, and a thin blue breath of smoke rose straight into the air. Joe and Huck still slept.

The remnants of last night's fire lay in a white bed of ashes, with a thin plume of smoke rising straight up into the clear sky. He looked around and saw that Joe and Huck were still asleep, their faces peaceful in the quiet dawn.

events.title: Tom's Communion with Nature
detailed_summary: The sounds of birds calling and a woodpecker hammering signal the progression of dawn.
As the morning lightens, the sounds of nature multiply, and life becomes more apparent to Tom.
He watches a green worm, interpreting its movements as a form of measurement and believing its journey across his leg signifies he will soon get a new pirate uniform.
A procession of ants appears, one diligently carrying a dead spider much larger than itself up a tree.
Tom interacts with a ladybug, reciting a traditional rhyme and noting its characteristic gullibility regarding fires, a trait he has exploited before.
He observes a tumblebug, which feigns death when he touches it.
The bird activity becomes more vibrant, with a catbird mimicking other birds and a jay curiously inspecting the boys.
Squirrels also approach, observing the unfamiliar humans with a mixture of curiosity and caution.
The forest is now fully awake, with sunlight filtering through the leaves and butterflies fluttering by.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Now, far away in the woods a bird called; another answered; presently the hammering of a woodpecker was heard.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: All Nature was wide awake and stirring, now; long lances of sunlight pierced down through the dense foliage far and near, and a few butterflies came fluttering upon the scene.

events.text_segment: Now, far away in the woods a bird called; another answered; presently the hammering of a woodpecker was heard. Gradually the cool dim gray of the morning whitened, and as gradually sounds multiplied and life manifested itself. The marvel of Nature shaking off sleep and going to work unfolded itself to the musing boy. A little green worm came crawling over a dewy leaf, lifting two-thirds of his body into the air from time to time and “sniffing around,” then proceeding again—for he was measuring, Tom said; and when the worm approached him, of its own accord, he sat as still as a stone, with his hopes rising and falling, by turns, as the creature still came toward him or seemed inclined to go elsewhere; and when at last it considered a painful moment with its curved body in the air and then came decisively down upon Tom’s leg and began a journey over him, his whole heart was glad—for that meant that he was going to have a new suit of clothes—without the shadow of a doubt a gaudy piratical uniform. Now a procession of ants appeared, from nowhere in particular, and went about their labors; one struggled manfully by with a dead spider five times as big as itself in its arms, and lugged it straight up a tree-trunk. A brown spotted lady-bug climbed the dizzy height of a grass blade, and Tom bent down close to it and said, “Lady-bug, lady-bug, fly away home, your house is on fire, your children’s alone,” and she took wing and went off to see about it—which did not surprise the boy, for he knew of old that this insect was credulous about conflagrations, and he had practised upon its simplicity more than once. A tumblebug came next, heaving sturdily at its ball, and Tom touched the creature, to see it shut its legs against its body and pretend to be dead. The birds were fairly rioting by this time. A catbird, the Northern mocker, lit in a tree over Tom’s head, and trilled out her imitations of her neighbors in a rapture of enjoyment; then a shrill jay swept down, a flash of blue flame, and stopped on a twig almost within the boy’s reach, cocked his head to one side and eyed the strangers with a consuming curiosity; a gray squirrel and a big fellow of the “fox” kind came skurrying along, sitting up at intervals to inspect and chatter at the boys, for the wild things had probably never seen a human being before and scarcely knew whether to be afraid or not. All Nature was wide awake and stirring, now; long lances of sunlight pierced down through the dense foliage far and near, and a few butterflies came fluttering upon the scene.

A procession of ants appeared, one carrying a dead spider much larger than itself up a tree. Tom recited a rhyme to a ladybug, noting how gullible it was about fires, a trick he had played before. Squirrels approached cautiously, observing the strange humans. The forest was now fully awake, sunlight filtering through the leaves, and butterflies fluttered by, completing the lively scene.

As the dawn grew brighter, the sounds of birds and insects increased, and the woods seemed to wake up. Tom watched a green worm crawling along his leg, moving slowly and pausing now and then, as if measuring his limb. He thought that when the worm reached the end of his leg, he would get a new pirate uniform, and he watched eagerly. The worm paused, then started again, and Tom felt a little thrill of hope. Suddenly, the worm stopped and turned, and Tom was delighted when it crawled onto his hand, as if it had chosen him. He believed that this was a sign he would soon be dressed as a pirate. From the ground, a line of ants appeared, one carrying a dead spider much larger than itself, climbing up a tree with determined effort. Tom watched a ladybug climb a blade of grass, and he recited a rhyme about ladybugs being gullible about fires, which he had used to trick the bugs before. The ladybug reached a leaf, then took a little rest. Nearby, a tumblebug was rolling its ball, and when Tom touched it, it played dead, lying still on the ground. The bird activity grew more lively; a catbird mimicked the calls of other birds, and a jay, bright and curious, came close to inspect the boys, its crest raised and eyes bright. Squirrels approached cautiously, chattering and pausing to observe the strange visitors. The forest was now fully alive, sunlight filtering through the leaves, casting dappled shadows, and butterflies fluttered by, adding to the vibrant scene.

events.title: Morning Swim and Symbolic Loss of Raft
detailed_summary: Tom wakes up Joe and Huck with a shout.
The three boys eagerly run to the sandbar, strip off their clothes, and enjoy a playful swim in the shallow water.
They feel no desire to return to their village, which is visible in the distance.
They discover that their raft has been carried away by the river's current or a rise in water level.
The loss of the raft pleases them, as they see it as a symbolic severing of their ties to civilized society.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: A vagrant current or a slight rise in the river had carried off their raft, but this only gratified them, since its going was something like burning the bridge between them and civilization.

events.text_segment: Tom stirred up the other pirates and they all clattered away with a shout, and in a minute or two were stripped and chasing after and tumbling over each other in the shallow limpid water of the white sandbar. They felt no longing for the little village sleeping in the distance beyond the majestic waste of water. A vagrant current or a slight rise in the river had carried off their raft, but this only gratified them, since its going was something like burning the bridge between them and civilization.

events.title: A Pirate's Breakfast of Freshly Caught Fish
detailed_summary: The boys return to their camp feeling invigorated, cheerful, and extremely hungry.
They quickly get the campfire burning again.
Huck discovers a nearby spring of clear, cold water.
The boys fashion cups from large leaves and find the spring water, enhanced by the wilderness setting, a satisfactory replacement for coffee.
While Joe is preparing bacon for breakfast, Tom and Huck decide to try fishing in a promising spot by the riverbank.
They quickly catch several fish, including bass, sun-perch, and a small catfish, enough for a substantial meal.
They cook the fish with the bacon and are astonished by its delicious taste.
The narrative notes their unawareness that the freshness of the fish and the context of their outdoor activities contribute significantly to the meal's appeal.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: They did not know that the quicker a fresh-water fish is on the fire after he is caught the better he is; and they reflected little upon what a sauce open-air sleeping, open-air exercise, bathing, and a large ingredient of hunger make, too.

events.text_segment: They came back to camp wonderfully refreshed, glad-hearted, and ravenous; and they soon had the camp-fire blazing up again. Huck found a spring of clear cold water close by, and the boys made cups of broad oak or hickory leaves, and felt that water, sweetened with such a wildwood charm as that, would be a good enough substitute for coffee. While Joe was slicing bacon for breakfast, Tom and Huck asked him to hold on a minute; they stepped to a promising nook in the river-bank and threw in their lines; almost immediately they had reward. Joe had not had time to get impatient before they were back again with some handsome bass, a couple of sun-perch and a small catfish—provisions enough for quite a family. They fried the fish with the bacon, and were astonished; for no fish had ever seemed so delicious before. They did not know that the quicker a fresh-water fish is on the fire after he is caught the better he is; and they reflected little upon what a sauce open-air sleeping, open-air exercise, bathing, and a large ingredient of hunger make, too.

events.title: Island Exploration and the Onset of Homesickness
detailed_summary: After their meal, and while Huck smokes, the boys embark on an exploratory expedition through the woods.
They happily traverse the island, navigating over fallen logs, through dense undergrowth, and among towering trees adorned with grapevines.
They encounter many pleasing sights, such as grassy nooks decorated with flowers, but nothing that truly astounds them.
They ascertain the island's dimensions—approximately three miles long and a quarter of a mile wide—and note its proximity to the mainland, separated by a narrow channel.
They take frequent swims throughout the day, returning to their camp around mid-afternoon.
Too famished to fish again, they eat cold ham and then settle down to talk.
However, their conversation soon fades, and the pervasive stillness and solemnity of the forest, combined with a growing sense of isolation, begin to weigh on their spirits.
An indistinct yearning starts to affect them, gradually materializing as homesickness.
Even Huck, portrayed as the most rugged, finds himself thinking of home.
Despite this shared feeling, they are all ashamed of what they perceive as weakness and do not voice their thoughts.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: They lay around in the shade, after breakfast, while Huck had a smoke, and then went off through the woods on an exploring expedition.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But they were all ashamed of their weakness, and none was brave enough to speak his thought.

events.text_segment:
They lay around in the shade, after breakfast, while Huck had a smoke, and then went off through the woods on an exploring expedition. They tramped gayly along, over decaying logs, through tangled underbrush, among solemn monarchs of the forest, hung from their crowns to the ground with a drooping regalia of grape-vines. Now and then they came upon snug nooks carpeted with grass and jeweled with flowers.
They found plenty of things to be delighted with, but nothing to be astonished at. They discovered that the island was about three miles long and a quarter of a mile wide, and that the shore it lay closest to was only separated from it by a narrow channel hardly two hundred yards wide. They took a swim about every hour, so it was close upon the middle of the afternoon when they got back to camp. They were too hungry to stop to fish, but they fared sumptuously upon cold ham, and then threw themselves down in the shade to talk. But the talk soon began to drag, and then died. The stillness, the solemnity that brooded in the woods, and the sense of loneliness, began to tell upon the spirits of the boys. They fell to thinking. A sort of undefined longing crept upon them. This took dim shape, presently—it was budding homesickness. Even Finn the Red-Handed was dreaming of his doorsteps and empty hogsheads. But they were all ashamed of their weakness, and none was brave enough to speak his thought.

events.title: The Mysterious Booming and Ferryboat Activity
detailed_summary: The boys become acutely aware of a strange, distant sound that they had been subconsciously noticing.
This mysterious sound grows louder, demanding their attention.
They listen intently, and after a prolonged silence, a deep, somber booming noise reaches them.
Joe whispers, questioning the sound's origin, and Tom echoes his curiosity.
Huck correctly identifies that the sound is not thunder.
Tom instructs them to remain silent and listen carefully.
The muffled boom is heard again after what feels like a very long time.
They decide to investigate the source of the sound.
They quickly rise and hurry towards the shore in the direction of the town.
Parting the bushes, they look out over the water and spot the small steam ferryboat about a mile downstream from the village, its deck appearing crowded.
Numerous skiffs are moving around the ferryboat, but the boys cannot discern what the people in them are doing.
Suddenly, a large plume of white smoke erupts from the side of the ferryboat, and as it dissipates, the same dull, booming sound is heard once more.

events.text_segment:
For some time, now, the boys had been dully conscious of a peculiar sound in the distance, just as one sometimes is of the ticking of a clock which he takes no distinct note of. But now this mysterious sound became more pronounced, and forced a recognition. The boys started, glanced at each other, and then each assumed a listening attitude. There was a long silence, profound and unbroken; then a deep, sullen boom came floating down out of the distance.
“What is it!” exclaimed Joe, under his breath.
“I wonder,” said Tom in a whisper.
“’Tain’t thunder,” said Huckleberry, in an awed tone, “becuz thunder—”
“Hark!” said Tom. “Listen—don’t talk.”
They waited a time that seemed an age, and then the same muffled boom troubled the solemn hush.
“Let’s go and see.”
They sprang to their feet and hurried to the shore toward the town. They parted the bushes on the bank and peered out over the water. The little steam ferry-boat was about a mile below the village, drifting with the current. Her broad deck seemed crowded with people. There were a great many skiffs rowing about or floating with the stream in the neighborhood of the ferryboat, but the boys could not determine what the men in them were doing. Presently a great jet of white smoke burst from the ferryboat’s side, and as it expanded and rose in a lazy cloud, that same dull throb of sound was borne to the listeners again.
