segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The group loitered away, still recalling memories of the lost heroes, in awed voices.

events.text_segment:
Then quite a group of boys and girls—playmates of Tom’s and Joe’s—came by, and stood looking over the paling fence and talking in reverent tones of how Tom did so-and-so the last time they saw him, and how Joe said this and that small trifle (pregnant with awful prophecy, as they could easily see now!)—and each speaker pointed out the exact spot where the lost lads stood at the time, and then added something like “and I was a-standing just so—just as I am now, and as if you was him—I was as close as that—and he smiled, just this way—and then something seemed to go all over me, like—awful, you know—and I never thought what it meant, of course, but I can see now!”
Then there was a dispute about who saw the dead boys last in life, and many claimed that dismal distinction, and offered evidences, more or less tampered with by the witness; and when it was ultimately decided who did see the departed last, and exchanged the last words with them, the lucky parties took upon themselves a sort of sacred importance, and were gaped at and envied by all the rest. One poor chap, who had no other grandeur to offer, said with tolerably manifest pride in the remembrance:
“Well, Tom Sawyer he licked me once.”
But that bid for glory was a failure. Most of the boys could say that, and so that cheapened the distinction too much. The group loitered away, still recalling memories of the lost heroes, in awed voices.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
Certainly! Based on your detailed guidance, here's a more faithful reconstruction that emphasizes the scene's setting, the sequential recounting, physical gestures, collective emotion, and the nuanced social dynamics:

---

**CHAPTER XVII**

Then quite a group of boys and girls—playmates of Tom’s and Joe’s—came by, and stood looking over the paling fence, talking in reverent tones of how Tom did so-and-so the last time they saw him, and how Joe said this and that small trifle (pregnant with awful prophecy, as they could easily see now!)—and each speaker pointed out the exact spot where the lost lads stood at the time. Some of them would imitate the very posture, the way Tom smiled, or how Joe looked when he spoke. One boy would say, “I was just standing right here—just as I am now—and Tom was over there, just like that—see?” and he would point. Then another would add, “And I was a-standing just so—just as I am now—and Joe was just the same—just as if he was right here with us!”

As they spoke, a strange, awful feeling seemed to go all over them, like a chill or a shiver, and they would pause, looking at each other with wide eyes. Some of the children would try to imitate the very gestures or expressions of the boys, as if to bring back the moment, to see if they could understand what it all meant. They would whisper, “He smiled just this way,” or “He looked just so—like he was glad, but kind of sad, too.”

A little dispute arose among them about who had the last chance to see Tom and Joe, who had spoken to them last, or who had been closest when they parted. Some claimed they had been the last to see Tom, others insisted they had seen Joe last. They argued, each trying to prove their story, and some even exaggerated, saying they had been right beside the boys, or that they had heard them say something special. But everyone knew, deep down, that no one could be sure—each story was a little different, a little exaggerated, and all of it was tinged with awe and reverence.

Finally, after a while, the group grew quiet, each child lost in their own thoughts, remembering the last moments with the boys. They looked over the fence one last time, then slowly dispersed, still whispering about the 'lost heroes'—their memories now tinged with a strange, awful prophecy that they could not understand at the time but now saw clearly.

---

events.title: The Funeral Service Commences
detailed_summary: The Sunday morning church bell tolled mournfully, a departure from its usual ringing, signaling the funeral.
The Sabbath was exceptionally still, and the sad sound of the bell complemented the somber atmosphere.
Villagers gathered, whispering about the tragedy in the church vestibule before entering.
Inside the church, a profound silence was broken only by the rustling of women's dresses as they took their seats.
The church was unusually packed, more so than anyone could remember.
After a moment of expectant silence, Aunt Polly, Sid, Mary, and the Harper family, all in mourning attire, entered.
The entire congregation, including the minister, rose respectfully until the grieving families were seated in the front pew.
Another hush, punctuated by muffled sobs, fell before the minister began the service with a prayer.
A touching hymn was sung, followed by the minister announcing the text for the sermon: “I am the Resurrection and the Life.”

events.text_segment: When the Sunday-school hour was finished, the next morning, the bell began to toll, instead of ringing in the usual way. It was a very still Sabbath, and the mournful sound seemed in keeping with the musing hush that lay upon nature. The villagers began to gather, loitering a moment in the vestibule to converse in whispers about the sad event. But there was no whispering in the house; only the funereal rustling of dresses as the women gathered to their seats disturbed the silence there. None could remember when the little church had been so full before. There was finally a waiting pause, an expectant dumbness, and then Aunt Polly entered, followed by Sid and Mary, and they by the Harper family, all in deep black, and the whole congregation, the old minister as well, rose reverently and stood until the mourners were seated in the front pew. There was another communing silence, broken at intervals by muffled sobs, and then the minister spread his hands abroad and prayed. A moving hymn was sung, and the text followed: “I am the Resurrection and the Life.”

detailed_summary: The clergyman delivered a eulogy praising the lost boys' virtues, charm, and bright futures.

The minister shared poignant stories from the boys' lives, highlighting their kind and generous natures.
The townspeople now recognized the nobility and beauty in these past incidents, which they had previously dismissed as mere mischief deserving punishment.

Ultimately, the entire assembly, including the minister who wept in the pulpit, broke down in a shared chorus of sorrowful sobs with the bereaved families.

events.title: The 'Dead' Boys Make a Dramatic Appearance
detailed_summary: A slight noise from the church gallery went unnoticed by the grieving congregation.
A moment later, the church door creaked open.
The minister, his eyes wet with tears, looked up and became frozen in astonishment.
Gradually, the rest of the congregation followed the minister's gaze.
Almost simultaneously, everyone rose to their feet and stared as Tom Sawyer, Joe Harper, and Huckleberry Finn marched up the aisle.
Tom was in the lead, Joe followed him, and Huck, clad in tattered rags, trailed sheepishly at the rear.
It was revealed that the three boys had been concealed in the unused gallery, secretly listening to their own funeral sermon.

They had been hid in the unused gallery listening to their own funeral sermon!

events.title: Joyful Reunion and Huck's Awkward Welcome
detailed_summary: Aunt Polly, Mary, and the Harpers emotionally embraced their returned boys, covering them with kisses and expressing heartfelt gratitude.
Huck, however, stood apart, feeling embarrassed and awkward, uncertain of what to do or where to look amidst many unwelcoming stares.
He hesitated and started to sneak away, but Tom stopped him.
Tom declared to Aunt Polly that it wasn't fair for Huck to be ignored and that someone should be happy to see him.
Aunt Polly agreed, stating she was glad to see Huck, calling him a 'poor motherless thing.'
The affectionate attention Aunt Polly then showered upon Huck paradoxically made him feel even more uncomfortable than before.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Aunt Polly, Mary, and the Harpers threw themselves upon their restored ones, smothered them with kisses and poured out thanksgivings, while poor Huck stood abashed and uncomfortable, not knowing exactly what to do or where to hide from so many unwelcoming eyes.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And the loving attentions Aunt Polly lavished upon him were the one thing capable of making him more uncomfortable than he was before.

events.text_segment:
Aunt Polly, Mary, and the Harpers threw themselves upon their restored ones, smothered them with kisses and poured out thanksgivings, while poor Huck stood abashed and uncomfortable, not knowing exactly what to do or where to hide from so many unwelcoming eyes. He wavered, and started to slink away, but Tom seized him and said:
“Aunt Polly, it ain’t fair. Somebody’s got to be glad to see Huck.”
“And so they shall. I’m glad to see him, poor motherless thing!” And the loving attentions Aunt Polly lavished upon him were the one thing capable of making him more uncomfortable than he was before.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Aunt Polly, Mary, and the Harpers threw themselves upon their restored ones, smothered them with kisses and poured out thanksgivings, while poor Huck stood abashed and uncomfortable, not knowing exactly what to do or where to hide from so many unwelcoming eyes. Huck felt out of place, a stranger among friends, and the warmth of their embraces only heightened his sense of awkwardness. Just as he was about to slip away, Tom caught his arm.

"Huck, you ain't going to run off now, are you?" Tom said, with a grin.

"No," Huck mumbled, looking down.

Tom turned to Aunt Polly. "It ain't fair for Huck to be left out. Someone ought to be glad to see him, too."

Aunt Polly nodded, her eyes shining. "Of course, I am glad to see Huck. He's a poor motherless thing, and I always liked him."

Huck, overwhelmed by the attention, felt even more uncomfortable than before, wishing he could disappear.

events.title: Triumphant Celebration and Tom's Proudest Moment
detailed_summary: The minister exuberantly urged the congregation to sing 'Praise God from whom all blessings flow' with genuine feeling.
The congregation responded with immense enthusiasm, and the hymn 'Old Hundred' filled the church with a triumphant and powerful sound that seemed to vibrate through the building.
While the hymn was being sung, Tom Sawyer, self-styled as 'the Pirate,' observed the envious looks from other youngsters around him.
He privately acknowledged that this was the most glorious and proud moment of his life.

As the congregation, who had been 'sold' or tricked by the boys' reappearance, filed out, they remarked that they would almost endure being made foolish again to experience such a heartfelt rendition of 'Old Hundred' once more.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: As the “sold” congregation trooped out they said they would almost be willing to be made ridiculous again to hear Old Hundred sung like that once more.

events.text_segment:
Suddenly the minister shouted at the top of his voice: “Praise God from whom all blessings flow—sing!—and put your hearts in it!”
And they did. Old Hundred swelled up with a triumphant burst, and while it shook the rafters Tom Sawyer the Pirate looked around upon the envying juveniles about him and confessed in his heart that this was the proudest moment of his life.
As the “sold” congregation trooped out they said they would almost be willing to be made ridiculous again to hear Old Hundred sung like that once more.

events.title: The Pirates' Return and Aunt Polly's Gentle Reproach
detailed_summary: The narrative reveals Tom's elaborate plan with his friends to return from their feigned deaths to attend their own funerals.
They accomplished this by paddling to the Missouri shore on a log, hiding in the woods, and then sleeping in the church gallery.
On Monday morning, Aunt Polly and Mary treat Tom with exceptional affection and concern.
Aunt Polly, while acknowledging the cleverness of the joke, expresses her deep hurt over the week of suffering Tom caused her.
She points out that Tom could have found a way to let her know he was alive, just as he found a way to attend his funeral.
Mary concurs, believing Tom would have shown such consideration if it had occurred to him.
Tom hesitates, then admits that revealing his survival would have ruined their grand scheme.
Aunt Polly voices her disappointment, wishing Tom had at least cared enough to think of her feelings, even if he didn't act.
Mary attempts to excuse Tom's behavior as his usual thoughtless impetuosity.
Aunt Polly contrasts Tom with Sid, whom she believes would have both thought of her and acted to alleviate her suffering, warning Tom he'll regret his lack of care.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: That was Tom’s great secret—the scheme to return home with his brother pirates and attend their own funerals.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Tom, you’ll look back, some day, when it’s too late, and wish you’d cared a little more for me when it would have cost you so little.”

events.text_segment:
That was Tom’s great secret—the scheme to return home with his brother pirates and attend their own funerals. They had paddled over to the Missouri shore on a log, at dusk on Saturday, landing five or six miles below the village; they had slept in the woods at the edge of the town till nearly daylight, and had then crept through back lanes and alleys and finished their sleep in the gallery of the church among a chaos of invalided benches.
At breakfast, Monday morning, Aunt Polly and Mary were very loving to Tom, and very attentive to his wants. There was an unusual amount of talk. In the course of it Aunt Polly said:
“Well, I don’t say it wasn’t a fine joke, Tom, to keep everybody suffering ’most a week so you boys had a good time, but it is a pity you could be so hard-hearted as to let me suffer so. If you could come over on a log to go to your funeral, you could have come over and give me a hint some way that you warn’t dead, but only run off.”
“Yes, you could have done that, Tom,” said Mary; “and I believe you would if you had thought of it.”
“Would you, Tom?” said Aunt Polly, her face lighting wistfully. “Say, now, would you, if you’d thought of it?”
“I—well, I don’t know. ’Twould ’a’ spoiled everything.”
“Tom, I hoped you loved me that much,” said Aunt Polly, with a grieved tone that discomforted the boy. “It would have been something if you’d cared enough to think of it, even if you didn’t do it.”
“Now, auntie, that ain’t any harm,” pleaded Mary; “it’s only Tom’s giddy way—he is always in such a rush that he never thinks of anything.”
“More’s the pity. Sid would have thought. And Sid would have come and done it, too. Tom, you’ll look back, some day, when it’s too late, and wish you’d cared a little more for me when it would have cost you so little.”

simple_agent_extraction_refined_2.text:
That was Tom’s great secret—the scheme to return home with his brother pirates and attend their own funerals. The boys had paddled across the river on a log, landing at the Missouri shore about three miles below the village, and then they had hidden in the woods, sleeping at the edge of town. They kept watch until nearly daylight, then crept into the church gallery, where the chaos of invalided benches and the dim light made it a perfect hiding place.

On Monday morning, as the first light crept into the sky, Aunt Polly and Mary sat at the breakfast table, their faces full of concern. Aunt Polly looked at Tom with a mixture of love and pain. "Tom, you could have let me know you were alive, just as you found a way to attend your funeral," she said softly.

Mary nodded in agreement. "Tom, if it had occurred to you, you would have thought of us."

Tom hesitated, then said, "I didn't tell because it would have spoiled everything."

Aunt Polly sighed deeply. "You might have cared enough to think of me, even if you didn't act."

Mary tried to comfort him. "It's just Tom's usual thoughtless impetuosity."

Aunt Polly looked at Tom with a gentle but wistful expression. "Sid would have thought of me and tried to ease my pain. You’ll regret this someday, Tom."

Tom felt a twinge of guilt and looked down, realizing how much he had hurt her.

events.title: Tom's "Prophetic" Dream Deception
detailed_summary: Tom attempts to soothe Aunt Polly by asserting his affection and claiming he dreamt about her.
Aunt Polly initially dismisses the dream as insignificant.
Tom begins to recount a vivid 'dream' from Wednesday night, accurately describing the family's arrangement in the room as they mourned.
Aunt Polly confirms these details, her interest piqued.
He then 'dreams' of Joe Harper's mother being present, another fact Aunt Polly validates.
Tom feigns difficulty remembering more, then 'recalls' specific details: the wind blowing out a candle, Aunt Polly remarking on an open door, and her instructing Sid to close it.
Aunt Polly is amazed by the dream's precision, vowing to share this proof against superstition with Sereny Harper.
Tom continues, 'remembering' Aunt Polly describing him as mischievous rather than wicked, and then her subsequent tears.
He further 'dreams' of Mrs. Harper crying over Joe, regretting a past punishment for spilled cream she herself had discarded; Aunt Polly exclaims Tom was 'prophesying.'
Tom includes a 'dreamt' comment from Sid about hoping Tom was better off, which Aunt Polly confirms verbatim, and her sharp retort to Sid.
He adds details about Mrs. Harper discussing Joe's firecracker incident and Aunt Polly recalling Peter and the Pain-killer, all verified by Aunt Polly.
Tom's 'dream' also covers discussions about dragging the river, the planned Sunday funeral, and a tearful embrace between Aunt Polly and Mrs. Harper.

As a final touch, Tom claims he 'dreamt' Aunt Polly prayed for him, that he saw and heard her, and then wrote a note on sycamore bark stating 'We ain’t dead—we are only off being pirates,' placing it by her candle. He concludes by 'dreaming' he kissed her on the lips as she slept.
Overwhelmed by this 'dreamt' kiss, Aunt Polly forgives Tom completely, embracing him so forcefully that Tom feels immense guilt.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Now, auntie, you know I do care for you,” said Tom.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And she seized the boy in a crushing embrace that made him feel like the guiltiest of villains.

events.text_segment:
“Now, auntie, you know I do care for you,” said Tom.
“I’d know it better if you acted more like it.”
“I wish now I’d thought,” said Tom, with a repentant tone; “but I dreamt about you, anyway. That’s something, ain’t it?”
“It ain’t much—a cat does that much—but it’s better than nothing. What did you dream?”
“Why, Wednesday night I dreamt that you was sitting over there by the bed, and Sid was sitting by the woodbox, and Mary next to him.”
“Well, so we did. So we always do. I’m glad your dreams could take even that much trouble about us.”
“And I dreamt that Joe Harper’s mother was here.”
“Why, she was here! Did you dream any more?”
“Oh, lots. But it’s so dim, now.”
“Well, try to recollect—can’t you?”
“Somehow it seems to me that the wind—the wind blowed the—the—”
“Try harder, Tom! The wind did blow something. Come!”
Tom pressed his fingers on his forehead an anxious minute, and then said:
“I’ve got it now! I’ve got it now! It blowed the candle!”
“Mercy on us! Go on, Tom—go on!”
“And it seems to me that you said, ‘Why, I believe that that door—’”
“Go on, Tom!”
“Just let me study a moment—just a moment. Oh, yes—you said you believed the door was open.”
“As I’m sitting here, I did! Didn’t I, Mary! Go on!”
“And then—and then—well I won’t be certain, but it seems like as if you made Sid go and—and—”
“Well? Well? What did I make him do, Tom? What did I make him do?”
“You made him—you—Oh, you made him shut it.”
“Well, for the land’s sake! I never heard the beat of that in all my days! Don’t tell me there ain’t anything in dreams, any more. Sereny Harper shall know of this before I’m an hour older. I’d like to see her get around this with her rubbage ’bout superstition. Go on, Tom!”
“Oh, it’s all getting just as bright as day, now. Next you said I warn’t bad, only mischeevous and harum-scarum, and not any more responsible than—than—I think it was a colt, or something.”
“And so it was! Well, goodness gracious! Go on, Tom!”
“And then you began to cry.”
“So I did. So I did. Not the first time, neither. And then—”
“Then Mrs. Harper she began to cry, and said Joe was just the same, and she wished she hadn’t whipped him for taking cream when she’d throwed it out her own self—”
“Tom! The sperrit was upon you! You was a prophesying—that’s what you was doing! Land alive, go on, Tom!”
“Then Sid he said—he said—”
“I don’t think I said anything,” said Sid.
“Yes you did, Sid,” said Mary.
“Shut your heads and let Tom go on! What did he say, Tom?”
“He said—I think he said he hoped I was better off where I was gone to, but if I’d been better sometimes—”
“There, d’you hear that! It was his very words!”
“And you shut him up sharp.”
“I lay I did! There must ’a’ been an angel there. There was an angel there, somewheres!”
“And Mrs. Harper told about Joe scaring her with a firecracker, and you told about Peter and the Pain-killer—”
“Just as true as I live!”
“And then there was a whole lot of talk ’bout dragging the river for us, and ’bout having the funeral Sunday, and then you and old Miss Harper hugged and cried, and she went.”
“It happened just so! It happened just so, as sure as I’m a-sitting in these very tracks. Tom, you couldn’t told it more like if you’d ’a’ seen it! And then what? Go on, Tom!”
“Then I thought you prayed for me—and I could see you and hear every word you said. And you went to bed, and I was so sorry that I took and wrote on a piece of sycamore bark, ‘We ain’t dead—we are only off being pirates,’ and put it on the table by the candle; and then you looked so good, laying there asleep, that I thought I went and leaned over and kissed you on the lips.”
“Did you, Tom, did you! I just forgive you everything for that!” And she seized the boy in a crushing embrace that made him feel like the guiltiest of villains.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
“Now, auntie, you know I do care for you,” said Tom.

Aunt Polly looked at him, her face softening a little, but she still shook her head.

“Tom,” she said, “I don’t believe you’ve had a dream at all. You’re just trying to fool me.”

But Tom was eager to prove his sincerity.

“Last Wednesday night,” he began, “I dreamt I was in the room with you and Mary and Sid, and we were all mourning. I saw Joe Harper’s mother there, too. She was crying and seemed very sorry.”

Aunt Polly’s eyes widened.

“Go on,” she said, her voice trembling.

“Then I saw the wind blow out a candle, and I heard you say, ‘Close that door, Sid,’ and you did. I remember it all very well.”

Aunt Polly was listening intently now.

“Mrs. Harper was crying because she wished she hadn’t punished Joe for spilling the cream, which she had thrown away herself,” Tom continued. “And she said she wished she could undo it. I think I was prophesying, Aunt Polly.”

Aunt Polly’s face was full of wonder.

“Tom,” she exclaimed, “you’re telling the truth! I’ll tell Sereny Harper about this. She’ll believe it.”

Tom pressed on.

“I remember you said I was mischievous, not wicked, and then I saw you crying, Aunt Polly.”

“Go on,” she urged.

“Mrs. Harper was crying over Joe, and she said she wished she hadn’t punished him so harshly. She talked about the firecracker he set off and how she wished she’d been kinder.”

Aunt Polly nodded.

“Then I saw you and Mrs. Harper by the river, talking about dragging it, and about the Sunday funeral. I saw you hug her, and she cried, and you cried, too.”

Tom’s voice grew softer.

“And I dreamt I saw you praying for me, Aunt Polly, and I saw and heard you. I even wrote a note on a piece of bark that said, ‘We ain’t dead—we are only off being pirates,’ and I placed it by your candle.”

He paused, then added shyly, “And I dreamt I kissed you on the lips as you slept.”

Aunt Polly’s eyes filled with tears.

“Oh, Tom,” she whispered, “I believe you. I believe every word. You’ve made me see that dreams can be true sometimes.”

She embraced him tightly, her heart full of love and forgiveness, and Tom felt a great weight lift from his shoulders.

events.title: Aunt Polly's Forgiveness, Sid's Skepticism, and School Departure
detailed_summary: Sid subtly expresses his skepticism about Tom's 'dream' by remarking on its kindness, even if only a dream.
Aunt Polly quickly defends the dream's significance, asserting that dream actions mirror waking intentions.
She gives Tom a special Milum apple she had saved, then urges the children to head to school.
Aunt Polly offers a heartfelt prayer of thanks for Tom's return, acknowledging God's mercy despite her own unworthiness.
She then dismisses the children, stating they have delayed her long enough.
The children depart for school, while Aunt Polly plans to visit Mrs. Harper to share the story of Tom's marvelous dream and counter Mrs. Harper's skepticism.
Sid, perceptive as ever, leaves the house silently musing on the improbability of such a long and flawless dream.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “It was very kind, even though it was only a—dream,” Sid soliloquized just audibly.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It was this: “Pretty thin—as long a dream as that, without any mistakes in it!”

events.text_segment:
“It was very kind, even though it was only a—dream,” Sid soliloquized just audibly.
“Shut up, Sid! A body does just the same in a dream as he’d do if he was awake. Here’s a big Milum apple I’ve been saving for you, Tom, if you was ever found again—now go ’long to school. I’m thankful to the good God and Father of us all I’ve got you back, that’s long-suffering and merciful to them that believe on Him and keep His word, though goodness knows I’m unworthy of it, but if only the worthy ones got His blessings and had His hand to help them over the rough places, there’s few enough would smile here or ever enter into His rest when the long night comes. Go ’long Sid, Mary, Tom—take yourselves off—you’ve hendered me long enough.”
The children left for school, and the old lady to call on Mrs. Harper and vanquish her realism with Tom’s marvellous dream. Sid had better judgment than to utter the thought that was in his mind as he left the house. It was this: “Pretty thin—as long a dream as that, without any mistakes in it!”

events.title: Tom's Schoolyard Glory and Hero Status
detailed_summary: Tom is now a celebrated hero, and he carries himself with a new, dignified swagger appropriate for a pirate in the public eye.
He pretends not to notice the admiring looks and comments from passersby, but they secretly delight him.
Younger boys eagerly follow him, proud to be associated with him.
Boys of his own age affect indifference to his return but are consumed with envy for his sun-tanned appearance and thrilling notoriety.
Tom highly values his newfound fame and appearance.
At school, Tom and Joe are inundated with admiration from their peers, which quickly makes them insufferably conceited.
They begin recounting their adventures to captivated audiences, their tales likely to be endless due to their vivid imaginations.
The pinnacle of their glory is reached when they casually light up their pipes and smoke in the schoolyard.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: What a hero Tom was become, now!
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And finally, when they got out their pipes and went serenely puffing around, the very summit of glory was reached.

events.text_segment:
What a hero Tom was become, now! He did not go skipping and prancing, but moved with a dignified swagger as became a pirate who felt that the public eye was on him. And indeed it was; he tried not to seem to see the looks or hear the remarks as he passed along, but they were food and drink to him. Smaller boys than himself flocked at his heels, as proud to be seen with him, and tolerated by him, as if he had been the drummer at the head of a procession or the elephant leading a menagerie into town. Boys of his own size pretended not to know he had been away at all; but they were consuming with envy, nevertheless. They would have given anything to have that swarthy sun-tanned skin of his, and his glittering notoriety; and Tom would not have parted with either for a circus.
At school the children made so much of him and of Joe, and delivered such eloquent admiration from their eyes, that the two heroes were not long in becoming insufferably “stuck-up.” They began to tell their adventures to hungry listeners—but they only began; it was not a thing likely to have an end, with imaginations like theirs to furnish material. And finally, when they got out their pipes and went serenely puffing around, the very summit of glory was reached.

The height of their glory was reached when they casually lit their pipes and smoked, as if it were the most natural thing in the world, in the midst of their admiring friends.

events.title: Tom's Calculated Indifference and Becky's Distress
detailed_summary: Buoyed by his current glory, Tom decides he no longer needs Becky Thatcher and resolves to act indifferent if she seeks reconciliation.
When Becky arrives at school, Tom pointedly ignores her, engaging instead with a group of other children.
Becky attempts to capture his attention by playfully chasing schoolmates near him, her face flushed and eyes bright, occasionally glancing his way.
Her efforts only inflate Tom's vanity, and he becomes more determined to show he is unaware of her presence.
Becky's spirits fall; she becomes visibly disheartened, sighing and casting wistful looks towards Tom.
She then notices Tom focusing his attention on Amy Lawrence, which causes her a sharp pang of jealousy and unease.
Drawn despite herself, Becky approaches the group and, with forced cheerfulness, initiates a conversation with Mary Austin about Sunday school.
She then loudly announces plans for her own picnic, specifying that she can invite anyone she wishes, and proceeds to invite many girls, all while glancing furtively at Tom.
Tom deliberately continues his animated conversation with Amy, detailing a dramatic storm on the island, completely ignoring Becky's overtures.
After all the girls in the group except Amy have solicited invitations, Tom coolly turns away, still talking, and walks off with Amy.
Becky is devastated; her lips tremble, and tears well in her eyes. She masks her pain with forced gaiety but feels crushed.
She soon excuses herself to cry in private and remains moody and prideful until the school bell rings, at which point she resolves with a vindictive look that she knows what she will do.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Tom decided that he could be independent of Becky Thatcher now.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She roused up, now, with a vindictive cast in her eye, and gave her plaited tails a shake and said she knew what she’d do.

events.text_segment:
Tom decided that he could be independent of Becky Thatcher now. Glory was sufficient. He would live for glory. Now that he was distinguished, maybe she would be wanting to “make up.” Well, let her—she should see that he could be as indifferent as some other people. Presently she arrived. Tom pretended not to see her. He moved away and joined a group of boys and girls and began to talk. Soon he observed that she was tripping gayly back and forth with flushed face and dancing eyes, pretending to be busy chasing schoolmates, and screaming with laughter when she made a capture; but he noticed that she always made her captures in his vicinity, and that she seemed to cast a conscious eye in his direction at such times, too. It gratified all the vicious vanity that was in him; and so, instead of winning him, it only “set him up” the more and made him the more diligent to avoid betraying that he knew she was about. Presently she gave over skylarking, and moved irresolutely about, sighing once or twice and glancing furtively and wistfully toward Tom. Then she observed that now Tom was talking more particularly to Amy Lawrence than to any one else. She felt a sharp pang and grew disturbed and uneasy at once. She tried to go away, but her feet were treacherous, and carried her to the group instead. She said to a girl almost at Tom’s elbow—with sham vivacity:
“Why, Mary Austin! you bad girl, why didn’t you come to Sunday-school?”
“I did come—didn’t you see me?”
“Why, no! Did you? Where did you sit?”
“I was in Miss Peters’ class, where I always go. I saw you.”
“Did you? Why, it’s funny I didn’t see you. I wanted to tell you about the picnic.”
“Oh, that’s jolly. Who’s going to give it?”
“My ma’s going to let me have one.”
“Oh, goody; I hope she’ll let me come.”
“Well, she will. The picnic’s for me. She’ll let anybody come that I want, and I want you.”
“That’s ever so nice. When is it going to be?”
“By and by. Maybe about vacation.”
“Oh, won’t it be fun! You going to have all the girls and boys?”
“Yes, every one that’s friends to me—or wants to be”; and she glanced ever so furtively at Tom, but he talked right along to Amy Lawrence about the terrible storm on the island, and how the lightning tore the great sycamore tree “all to flinders” while he was “standing within three feet of it.”
“Oh, may I come?” said Grace Miller.
“Yes.”
“And me?” said Sally Rogers.
“Yes.”
“And me, too?” said Susy Harper. “And Joe?”
“Yes.”
And so on, with clapping of joyful hands till all the group had begged for invitations but Tom and Amy. Then Tom turned coolly away, still talking, and took Amy with him. Becky’s lips trembled and the tears came to her eyes; she hid these signs with a forced gayety and went on chattering, but the life had gone out of the picnic, now, and out of everything else; she got away as soon as she could and hid herself and had what her sex call “a good cry.” Then she sat moody, with wounded pride, till the bell rang. She roused up, now, with a vindictive cast in her eye, and gave her plaited tails a shake and said she knew what she’d do.

events.title: Tom's Jealousy Provoked by Becky and Alfred
detailed_summary: During recess, Tom ostentatiously flirts with Amy Lawrence, deriving satisfaction from the belief that he is making Becky suffer.
He actively seeks out Becky to ensure she witnesses his performance.
His confidence plummets when he finally spots Becky sitting comfortably with Alfred Temple behind the schoolhouse, both deeply absorbed in a picture-book, their heads close together.
A wave of intense jealousy washes over Tom. He berates himself for rejecting Becky's earlier, implicit offer of reconciliation, calling himself a fool.
He is so vexed he feels like crying. Amy's cheerful chatter continues, unheard by Tom, whose mind is elsewhere.
When Amy pauses for a response, Tom can only manage awkward, often inappropriate, assents.
He repeatedly finds himself drawn to the back of the schoolhouse, torturing himself with the sight of Becky and Alfred.
It infuriates him to think Becky is completely unaware of his presence, though, in reality, she sees him and knows her tactic is working, enjoying his evident suffering as she had suffered earlier.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At recess Tom continued his flirtation with Amy with jubilant self-satisfaction.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And he hastened away, hating her for it.

events.text_segment:
At recess Tom continued his flirtation with Amy with jubilant self-satisfaction. And he kept drifting about to find Becky and lacerate her with the performance. At last he spied her, but there was a sudden falling of his mercury. She was sitting cosily on a little bench behind the schoolhouse looking at a picture-book with Alfred Temple—and so absorbed were they, and their heads so close together over the book, that they did not seem to be conscious of anything in the world besides. Jealousy ran red-hot through Tom’s veins. He began to hate himself for throwing away the chance Becky had offered for a reconciliation. He called himself a fool, and all the hard names he could think of. He wanted to cry with vexation. Amy chatted happily along, as they walked, for her heart was singing, but Tom’s tongue had lost its function. He did not hear what Amy was saying, and whenever she paused expectantly he could only stammer an awkward assent, which was as often misplaced as otherwise. He kept drifting to the rear of the schoolhouse, again and again, to sear his eyeballs with the hateful spectacle there. He could not help it. And it maddened him to see, as he thought he saw, that Becky Thatcher never once suspected that he was even in the land of the living. But she did see, nevertheless; and she knew she was winning her fight, too, and was glad to see him suffer as she had suffered.
Amy’s happy prattle became intolerable. Tom hinted at things he had to attend to; things that must be done; and time was fleeting. But in vain—the girl chirped on. Tom thought, “Oh, hang her, ain’t I ever going to get rid of her?” At last he must be attending to those things—and she said artlessly that she would be “around” when school let out. And he hastened away, hating her for it.

events.title: Tom's Frustration, Imaginary Revenge, and Retreat Home
detailed_summary: Tom internally fumes about Alfred Temple, disdainfully thinking of him as a well-dressed 'St. Louis smarty' and vowing to defeat him in a fight again.
He physically acts out an imaginary brawl with Alfred, complete with taunts and blows, until he feels a sense of satisfaction.
Overwhelmed by Amy's cheerful company and his own jealousy regarding Becky, Tom flees home at noon.
Meanwhile, Becky continues her charade with Alfred and the picture book, but her triumph diminishes as Tom fails to appear and witness her supposed happiness.
Her interest fades, replaced by seriousness, absentmindedness, and eventually melancholy; she jumps at footsteps, hoping for Tom, but is disappointed.
She becomes entirely miserable, regretting that she pushed her game too far.
When Alfred, oblivious to the cause of her distress, tries to re-engage her with the pictures, Becky loses patience, snaps at him, bursts into tears, and walks away.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Any other boy!” Tom thought, grating his teeth.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: When poor Alfred, seeing that he was losing her, he did not know how, kept exclaiming: “Oh, here’s a jolly one! look at this!” she lost patience at last, and said, “Oh, don’t bother me! I don’t care for them!” and burst into tears, and got up and walked away.

events.text_segment:
“Any other boy!” Tom thought, grating his teeth. “Any boy in the whole town but that Saint Louis smarty that thinks he dresses so fine and is aristocracy! Oh, all right, I licked you the first day you ever saw this town, mister, and I’ll lick you again! You just wait till I catch you out! I’ll just take and—”
And he went through the motions of thrashing an imaginary boy—pummelling the air, and kicking and gouging. “Oh, you do, do you? You holler ’nough, do you? Now, then, let that learn you!” And so the imaginary flogging was finished to his satisfaction.
Tom fled home at noon. His conscience could not endure any more of Amy’s grateful happiness, and his jealousy could bear no more of the other distress. Becky resumed her picture inspections with Alfred, but as the minutes dragged along and no Tom came to suffer, her triumph began to cloud and she lost interest; gravity and absentmindedness followed, and then melancholy; two or three times she pricked up her ear at a footstep, but it was a false hope; no Tom came. At last she grew entirely miserable and wished she hadn’t carried it so far. When poor Alfred, seeing that he was losing her, he did not know how, kept exclaiming: “Oh, here’s a jolly one! look at this!” she lost patience at last, and said, “Oh, don’t bother me! I don’t care for them!” and burst into tears, and got up and walked away.

events.title: Alfred's Revenge and Becky's Shifting Resolve
detailed_summary: Alfred tries to approach Becky to comfort her after her outburst, but she angrily rebuffs him, telling him to leave her alone and that she hates him.
The boy is left bewildered, as Becky had initially agreed to look at pictures with him for the entire noon break. He wanders into the empty schoolhouse, feeling humiliated and furious.
He quickly deduces that Becky had merely used him as a tool to provoke Tom Sawyer, a realization that intensifies his dislike for Tom.
Alfred looks for a way to get Tom into trouble without implicating himself.
His eyes fall upon Tom's spelling-book, presenting the perfect opportunity.
He gratefully opens the book to the afternoon's lesson and deliberately pours ink over the page.
At that moment, Becky glances in through a window behind Alfred and witnesses his act of vandalism but chooses to move on without revealing her presence.
She starts for home, initially intending to find Tom, inform him about the ink, and thereby achieve a reconciliation.
However, before she gets halfway home, the memory of Tom's cruel treatment of her during her picnic announcement resurfaces, filling her with shame and anger.
She changes her mind, resolving to let Tom face the punishment for the spoiled spelling-book and, furthermore, to hate him indefinitely.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She resolved to let him get whipped on the damaged spelling-book’s account, and to hate him forever, into the bargain.

events.text_segment:
Alfred dropped alongside and was going to try to comfort her, but she said:
“Go away and leave me alone, can’t you! I hate you!”
So the boy halted, wondering what he could have done—for she had said she would look at pictures all through the nooning—and she walked on, crying. Then Alfred went musing into the deserted schoolhouse. He was humiliated and angry. He easily guessed his way to the truth—the girl had simply made a convenience of him to vent her spite upon Tom Sawyer. He was far from hating Tom the less when this thought occurred to him. He wished there was some way to get that boy into trouble without much risk to himself. Tom’s spelling-book fell under his eye. Here was his opportunity. He gratefully opened to the lesson for the afternoon and poured ink upon the page.
Becky, glancing in at a window behind him at the moment, saw the act, and moved on, without discovering herself. She started homeward, now, intending to find Tom and tell him; Tom would be thankful and their troubles would be healed. Before she was half way home, however, she had changed her mind. The thought of Tom’s treatment of her when she was talking about her picnic came scorching back and filled her with shame. She resolved to let him get whipped on the damaged spelling-book’s account, and to hate him forever, into the bargain.

events.title: Aunt Polly's Confrontation and Tom's Initial Remorse
detailed_summary: Tom arrives home in a despondent state, only to be met by his aunt's immediate anger.

Aunt Polly reveals her intention to punish Tom severely, explaining that Sereny Harper informed her that Tom had been present and overheard their entire conversation the night they were mourning the boys.
She expresses deep disappointment that Tom allowed her to make a fool of herself with Sereny by recounting the supposed dream, which she now understands was based on Tom's eavesdropping.
Tom, who had previously been proud of his clever deception, now feels ashamed and recognizes his actions as mean.
He struggles for words before apologizing, claiming he hadn't thought through the consequences.

Aunt Polly rebukes him for his persistent thoughtlessness and selfishness, contrasting his ability to plan a secret return and a fabricated dream with his failure to consider their suffering or offer them comfort.
Tom reiterates that his actions were not intended to be malicious and that he did not return that night to mock their grief.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Tom arrived at home in a dreary mood, and the first thing his aunt said to him showed him that he had brought his sorrows to an unpromising market:
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Auntie, I know now it was mean, but I didn’t mean to be mean. I didn’t, honest. And besides, I didn’t come over here to laugh at you that night.”

events.text_segment:
Tom arrived at home in a dreary mood, and the first thing his aunt said to him showed him that he had brought his sorrows to an unpromising market:
“Tom, I’ve a notion to skin you alive!”
“Auntie, what have I done?”
“Well, you’ve done enough. Here I go over to Sereny Harper, like an old softy, expecting I’m going to make her believe all that rubbage about that dream, when lo and behold you she’d found out from Joe that you was over here and heard all the talk we had that night. Tom, I don’t know what is to become of a boy that will act like that. It makes me feel so bad to think you could let me go to Sereny Harper and make such a fool of myself and never say a word.”
This was a new aspect of the thing. His smartness of the morning had seemed to Tom a good joke before, and very ingenious. It merely looked mean and shabby now. He hung his head and could not think of anything to say for a moment. Then he said:
“Auntie, I wish I hadn’t done it—but I didn’t think.”
“Oh, child, you never think. You never think of anything but your own selfishness. You could think to come all the way over here from Jackson’s Island in the night to laugh at our troubles, and you could think to fool me with a lie about a dream; but you couldn’t ever think to pity us and save us from sorrow.”
“Auntie, I know now it was mean, but I didn’t mean to be mean. I didn’t, honest. And besides, I didn’t come over here to laugh at you that night.”

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
Tom arrived at home in a dreary mood, and the first thing his aunt said to him showed him that he had brought his sorrows to an unpromising market:

"Tom, I am going to punish you severely," she said, her face stern. "Sereny Harper told me that you were there last night, and that you overheard everything we said about the boys."

Tom looked down, feeling ashamed. "I didn't mean to listen," he mumbled.

"And I am disappointed in you," Aunt Polly continued. "You let me make a fool of myself with Sereny by telling her about my dream, which I now see was based on your eavesdropping."

Tom, who had been proud of his cleverness in deceiving her, now felt a deep sense of remorse. "I'm sorry, Aunt Polly," he said, struggling for words. "I didn't think about what it would cause."

"You are always thinking of yourself, Tom," she replied sharply. "You can plan a secret return and a false dream, but you cannot think of others' feelings or offer them comfort."

"I didn't mean to mock their grief," Tom added quickly. "I only wanted to be clever."

Aunt Polly shook her head, her disappointment evident. "You need to learn to be kind and considerate, Tom. That is more important than tricks and schemes."

Tom hung his head, realizing the truth in her words, and promised to do better in the future.

events.title: Tom's Justification and the Revelation of the Kiss
detailed_summary: When Aunt Polly questions his true reason for returning from Jackson's Island that night, Tom asserts he came back to inform her that they were safe and had not drowned.
Aunt Polly expresses profound skepticism, stating she would be immensely thankful if she could believe he possessed such a considerate thought, but she is convinced he didn't.
Tom earnestly insists he is telling the truth, motivated solely by the desire to alleviate her grieving.
Aunt Polly responds that she would give anything to believe him, as it would absolve many of his wrongdoings, but she finds his claim illogical since he ultimately didn't tell her.

Tom explains his silence by saying that when he heard them discussing the funeral, he became captivated by the idea of their dramatic reappearance at the church and couldn't bring himself to spoil the plan, so he kept the piece of bark with his message in his pocket.
He then reveals that he kissed her while she was asleep and moaning, expressing regret that she didn't awaken.
This admission visibly softens Aunt Polly; her stern expression relaxes, and a gentle look appears in her eyes.
She tenderly questions him about the kiss, asking if he is certain he did it and why.
Tom confirms he did, explaining he kissed her out of love and sorrow for her distress.
His words carry the ring of truth, and Aunt Polly, her voice trembling with emotion, asks him for another kiss before sending him off to school, telling him not to bother her further.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “What did you come for, then?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence:
The words sounded like truth. The old lady could not hide a tremor in her voice when she said:
“Kiss me again, Tom!—and be off with you to school, now, and don’t bother me any more.”

events.text_segment:
“What did you come for, then?”
“It was to tell you not to be uneasy about us, because we hadn’t got drownded.”
“Tom, Tom, I would be the thankfullest soul in this world if I could believe you ever had as good a thought as that, but you know you never did—and I know it, Tom.”
“Indeed and ’deed I did, auntie—I wish I may never stir if I didn’t.”
“Oh, Tom, don’t lie—don’t do it. It only makes things a hundred times worse.”
“It ain’t a lie, auntie; it’s the truth. I wanted to keep you from grieving—that was all that made me come.”
“I’d give the whole world to believe that—it would cover up a power of sins, Tom. I’d ’most be glad you’d run off and acted so bad. But it ain’t reasonable; because, why didn’t you tell me, child?”
“Why, you see, when you got to talking about the funeral, I just got all full of the idea of our coming and hiding in the church, and I couldn’t somehow bear to spoil it. So I just put the bark back in my pocket and kept mum.”
“What bark?”
“The bark I had wrote on to tell you we’d gone pirating. I wish, now, you’d waked up when I kissed you—I do, honest.”
The hard lines in his aunt’s face relaxed and a sudden tenderness dawned in her eyes.
“Did you kiss me, Tom?”
“Why, yes, I did.”
“Are you sure you did, Tom?”
“Why, yes, I did, auntie—certain sure.”
“What did you kiss me for, Tom?”
“Because I loved you so, and you laid there moaning and I was so sorry.”
The words sounded like truth. The old lady could not hide a tremor in her voice when she said:
“Kiss me again, Tom!—and be off with you to school, now, and don’t bother me any more.”

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
"What did you come for, then?" Aunt Polly asked sternly.

Tom looked down, fidgeting. "I come back to tell you that we’re all safe and didn’t drown," he said earnestly.

Aunt Polly’s face softened slightly, but her eyes remained skeptical. "I’d be thankful if I could believe that, Tom, but I don’t. I know you didn’t come back just to tell me that."

"I swear I did," Tom insisted. "I only wanted to ease your mind, to let you know we’re all right."

She sighed, her voice trembling. "I’d give anything to believe you, Tom. It would clear away so many of your faults if I could. But it doesn’t make sense—you didn’t tell me the truth."

Tom hesitated, then explained, "When I heard them talking about the funeral, I got caught up in the idea of them coming back at the church, and I didn’t want to spoil it. So I kept the piece of bark with my message in my pocket."

He paused, then added softly, "And I kissed you while you were asleep, moaning. I wish you’d wakened."

Aunt Polly’s stern face softened into a gentle look, her eyes filling with emotion. "Did you really kiss me? Are you sure? Why?"

"Because I love you and I was sorry for your pain," Tom replied, his voice sincere.

Her eyes brimmed with tears as she reached out and gently touched his head. "One more kiss, then, before you go to school. Don’t bother me further," she whispered, her voice trembling with affection.

events.title: Aunt Polly's Internal Debate and the Discovery of the Bark
detailed_summary: Immediately after Tom departs for school, Aunt Polly goes to a closet and takes out the tattered jacket Tom wore during his pirating adventure.
She pauses, holding the jacket, hesitant to check the pocket for the bark Tom mentioned.
She reflects that his story about the kiss might be a lie, but a 'blessed' one due to the comfort it brought her, and she hopes the Lord will forgive him for such a well-intentioned fabrication.
Initially, she decides against looking, not wanting to discover if it's untrue.
She puts the jacket away but finds herself drawn back to it, twice reaching for it before restraining herself.
On her third attempt, she steels herself with the thought that even if it is a lie, it's a 'good lie' and she won't let the truth, if different, distress her.
She then searches the jacket pocket.
A moment later, she is reading Tom's message on the piece of bark, tears streaming down her face, and exclaims that she could now forgive him for a million sins.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: A moment later she was reading Tom’s piece of bark through flowing tears and saying: “I could forgive the boy, now, if he’d committed a million sins!”

events.text_segment:
The moment he was gone, she ran to a closet and got out the ruin of a jacket which Tom had gone pirating in. Then she stopped, with it in her hand, and said to herself:
“No, I don’t dare. Poor boy, I reckon he’s lied about it—but it’s a blessed, blessed lie, there’s such a comfort come from it. I hope the Lord—I know the Lord will forgive him, because it was such good-heartedness in him to tell it. But I don’t want to find out it’s a lie. I won’t look.”
She put the jacket away, and stood by musing a minute. Twice she put out her hand to take the garment again, and twice she refrained. Once more she ventured, and this time she fortified herself with the thought: “It’s a good lie—it’s a good lie—I won’t let it grieve me.” So she sought the jacket pocket. A moment later she was reading Tom’s piece of bark through flowing tears and saying: “I could forgive the boy, now, if he’d committed a million sins!”

events.title: Tom's Rejected Apology and Renewed Feud with Becky
detailed_summary: Aunt Polly's kiss elevates Tom's mood, making him cheerful.
He encounters Becky Thatcher and sincerely apologizes for his previous unkind behavior, promising never to repeat it.
Becky scornfully rejects his apology, declaring she will never speak to him again, and walks away.
Tom is initially stunned, then becomes furious, wishing Becky were a boy so he could physically express his anger.
He later passes Becky in the schoolyard and delivers a sharp insult.
Becky retorts with her own insult, completing the angry break between them.

Filled with resentment, Becky eagerly anticipates school starting so she can see Tom punished for the damaged spelling book, any thought of exposing Alfred Temple now gone due to Tom's latest offense.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: There was something about Aunt Polly’s manner, when she kissed Tom, that swept away his low spirits and made him lighthearted and happy again.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: If she had had any lingering notion of exposing Alfred Temple, Tom’s offensive fling had driven it entirely away.

events.text_segment:
There was something about Aunt Polly’s manner, when she kissed Tom, that swept away his low spirits and made him lighthearted and happy again. He started to school and had the luck of coming upon Becky Thatcher at the head of Meadow Lane. His mood always determined his manner. Without a moment’s hesitation he ran to her and said:
“I acted mighty mean today, Becky, and I’m so sorry. I won’t ever, ever do that way again, as long as ever I live—please make up, won’t you?”
The girl stopped and looked him scornfully in the face:
“I’ll thank you to keep yourself to yourself, Mr. Thomas Sawyer. I’ll never speak to you again.”
She tossed her head and passed on. Tom was so stunned that he had not even presence of mind enough to say “Who cares, Miss Smarty?” until the right time to say it had gone by. So he said nothing. But he was in a fine rage, nevertheless. He moped into the schoolyard wishing she were a boy, and imagining how he would trounce her if she were. He presently encountered her and delivered a stinging remark as he passed. She hurled one in return, and the angry breach was complete. It seemed to Becky, in her hot resentment, that she could hardly wait for school to “take in,” she was so impatient to see Tom flogged for the injured spelling-book. If she had had any lingering notion of exposing Alfred Temple, Tom’s offensive fling had driven it entirely away.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
There was something about Aunt Polly’s manner, when she kissed Tom, that swept away his low spirits and made him lighthearted and happy again. As he trotted along the street, he saw Becky Thatcher approaching, and he felt a sudden desire to make amends. He stopped and looked at her sincerely.

"Becky, I’m sorry for being unkind yesterday," he said. "I promise I’ll never do it again."

Becky looked at him scornfully. "You’re always sorry after you’ve been mean. I’ll never speak to you again," she declared, and she turned on her heel and walked away.

Tom was stunned. Then a fiery anger took hold of him. He wished Becky were a boy so he could punch her. Later, he saw her in the schoolyard and, in a burst of spite, called her a name.

Becky shot back with her own insult, and their quarrel was complete. Filled with resentment, Becky looked forward to school starting so she could see Tom punished for the damage to her spelling book. Any thought of exposing Alfred Temple was gone, now that Tom had insulted her again.

events.title: Becky's Forbidden Glimpse and the Torn Anatomy Book
detailed_summary: The narrative introduces the schoolmaster, Mr. Dobbins, whose unfulfilled ambition was to be a doctor, and who possessed a mysterious book he kept locked and read daily.
All the students were intensely curious about this secret book.
As Becky passes Mr. Dobbins' desk, she discovers the key left in the lock.
Finding herself alone, she seizes the chance and takes the book.
She opens it to find it's an anatomy book, and her eyes fall upon a detailed, colored illustration of a completely naked human figure.
At that very moment, Tom Sawyer enters the room and catches a glimpse of the picture.
Startled and flustered, Becky snatches at the book to close it, accidentally tearing the illustrated page significantly.
She quickly shoves the book back into the desk, turns the key, and bursts into tears from shame and vexation.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Poor girl, she did not know how fast she was nearing trouble herself.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She thrust the volume into the desk, turned the key, and burst out crying with shame and vexation.

events.text_segment: Poor girl, she did not know how fast she was nearing trouble herself. The master, Mr. Dobbins, had reached middle age with an unsatisfied ambition. The darling of his desires was, to be a doctor, but poverty had decreed that he should be nothing higher than a village schoolmaster. Every day he took a mysterious book out of his desk and absorbed himself in it at times when no classes were reciting. He kept that book under lock and key. There was not an urchin in school but was perishing to have a glimpse of it, but the chance never came. Every boy and girl had a theory about the nature of that book; but no two theories were alike, and there was no way of getting at the facts in the case. Now, as Becky was passing by the desk, which stood near the door, she noticed that the key was in the lock! It was a precious moment. She glanced around; found herself alone, and the next instant she had the book in her hands. The titlepage—Professor Somebody’s Anatomy—carried no information to her mind; so she began to turn the leaves. She came at once upon a handsomely engraved and colored frontispiece—a human figure, stark naked. At that moment a shadow fell on the page and Tom Sawyer stepped in at the door and caught a glimpse of the picture. Becky snatched at the book to close it, and had the hard luck to tear the pictured page half down the middle. She thrust the volume into the desk, turned the key, and burst out crying with shame and vexation.

events.title: Becky's Accusation and Tom's Callous Resolve
detailed_summary: Becky angrily accuses Tom of being mean for sneaking up and seeing what she was looking at.
Tom feigns ignorance, asking how he could have known she was looking at anything.
Distraught, Becky exclaims that Tom should be ashamed and will surely tell on her, leading to her being whipped for the first time in school.
She stamps her foot, calls Tom hateful, and exits in another fit of tears.
Tom, somewhat flustered by her outburst, reflects to himself on what he considers the overly sensitive nature of girls, dismissing the severity of a school licking.
He internally decides not to inform Mr. Dobbins about Becky tearing the book, believing there are less 'mean' ways to get even with her.
He reasons that Mr. Dobbins will likely discover Becky's guilt anyway, as girls' faces tend to betray them.
Concluding that Becky is in a tight spot with no escape, and recalling she would likely enjoy seeing him in a similar predicament, he resolves to let her endure the consequences.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Tom Sawyer, you are just as mean as you can be, to sneak up on a person and look at what they’re looking at.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Tom conned the thing a moment longer, and then added: “All right, though; she’d like to see me in just such a fix—let her sweat it out!”

events.text_segment:
“Tom Sawyer, you are just as mean as you can be, to sneak up on a person and look at what they’re looking at.”
“How could I know you was looking at anything?”
“You ought to be ashamed of yourself, Tom Sawyer; you know you’re going to tell on me, and oh, what shall I do, what shall I do! I’ll be whipped, and I never was whipped in school.”
Then she stamped her little foot and said:
“Be so mean if you want to! I know something that’s going to happen. You just wait and you’ll see! Hateful, hateful, hateful!”—and she flung out of the house with a new explosion of crying.
Tom stood still, rather flustered by this onslaught. Presently he said to himself:
“What a curious kind of a fool a girl is! Never been licked in school! Shucks! What’s a licking! That’s just like a girl—they’re so thin-skinned and chicken-hearted. Well, of course I ain’t going to tell old Dobbins on this little fool, because there’s other ways of getting even on her, that ain’t so mean; but what of it? Old Dobbins will ask who it was tore his book. Nobody’ll answer. Then he’ll do just the way he always does—ask first one and then t’other, and when he comes to the right girl he’ll know it, without any telling. Girls’ faces always tell on them. They ain’t got any backbone. She’ll get licked. Well, it’s a kind of a tight place for Becky Thatcher, because there ain’t any way out of it.” Tom conned the thing a moment longer, and then added: “All right, though; she’d like to see me in just such a fix—let her sweat it out!”

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
“Tom Sawyer, you are just as mean as you can be, to sneak up on a person and look at what they’re looking at.” Becky’s voice was trembling with anger as she turned on Tom, her cheeks flushed and her eyes bright with tears. Tom, caught off guard, raised his hands in a defensive gesture.

"I didn't mean to spy, Becky," he said, feigning innocence. "How could I have known you were looking at anything?"

Becky’s face twisted with hurt and frustration. "You’re just hateful, Tom! You’ll tell on me, I just know you will!" Her voice cracked as she stamped her foot, then burst into tears and hurried away.

Tom watched her go, feeling a strange mixture of guilt and annoyance. He thought to himself that girls were too sensitive, that a school licking was nothing to get upset about. He decided that he wouldn’t tell Mr. Dobbins about Becky tearing the book, reasoning that there were less mean ways to get even.

He also figured that Mr. Dobbins would probably find out anyway, because girls’ faces always betrayed them. With a sigh, Tom concluded that Becky was in a tight spot and that she’d probably enjoy seeing him in trouble just as much as he enjoyed seeing her upset. So, he resolved to let her face the music, knowing that the consequences would be inevitable.

events.title: Tom's Punishment and Becky's Silent Dilemma
detailed_summary: Tom joins the other students outside before school begins.
Once school is in session, Tom finds his attention drawn to Becky's troubled face, and despite his intentions, he feels pity for her.
He cannot muster any genuine satisfaction from her distress.
The matter of the ink-stained spelling book is brought up, and Tom's own problems temporarily occupy his full attention.
Becky, momentarily roused from her distress, watches the proceedings with interest, correctly assuming Tom's denial of spilling the ink will only worsen his situation.
She attempts to feel pleased by this but finds herself uncertain of her true feelings.

As Tom faces his punishment, Becky feels a strong impulse to reveal Alfred Temple's culpability but restrains herself, reasoning that if she speaks up, Tom will surely expose her for tearing the anatomy book page.
Tom endures his whipping without being particularly upset, considering it possible he might have accidentally spilled the ink himself, having denied it mainly for show and out of habit.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Tom joined the mob of skylarking scholars outside.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Tom took his whipping and went back to his seat not at all broken-hearted, for he thought it was possible that he had unknowingly upset the ink on the spelling-book himself, in some skylarking bout—he had denied it for form’s sake and because it was custom, and had stuck to the denial from principle.

events.text_segment:
Tom joined the mob of skylarking scholars outside. In a few moments the master arrived and school “took in.” Tom did not feel a strong interest in his studies. Every time he stole a glance at the girls’ side of the room Becky’s face troubled him. Considering all things, he did not want to pity her, and yet it was all he could do to help it. He could get up no exultation that was really worthy the name. Presently the spelling-book discovery was made, and Tom’s mind was entirely full of his own matters for a while after that. Becky roused up from her lethargy of distress and showed good interest in the proceedings. She did not expect that Tom could get out of his trouble by denying that he spilt the ink on the book himself; and she was right. The denial only seemed to make the thing worse for Tom. Becky supposed she would be glad of that, and she tried to believe she was glad of it, but she found she was not certain. When the worst came to the worst, she had an impulse to get up and tell on Alfred Temple, but she made an effort and forced herself to keep still—because, said she to herself, “he’ll tell about me tearing the picture sure. I wouldn’t say a word, not to save his life!”
Tom took his whipping and went back to his seat not at all broken-hearted, for he thought it was possible that he had unknowingly upset the ink on the spelling-book himself, in some skylarking bout—he had denied it for form’s sake and because it was custom, and had stuck to the denial from principle.

As Tom faced his punishment, Becky felt a strong impulse to reveal that Alfred Temple was responsible, but she restrained herself, reasoning that if she spoke up, Tom would surely expose her for tearing the anatomy book page. Tom endured his whipping without being particularly upset, considering that he might have accidentally spilled the ink himself, and that his denial was mainly for show and out of habit.

events.title: The Master Discovers the Damage and Begins Interrogation
detailed_summary: An hour passes with the master dozing and the students quietly studying.
Mr. Dobbins awakens, unlocks his desk, and retrieves his special book.
Most students glance up idly, but Tom and Becky watch his every move with focused, anxious eyes.
Mr. Dobbins handles the book for a moment, then settles in to read it.
Tom sees Becky's expression, likening it to that of a trapped rabbit facing a hunter, and his anger towards her vanishes.
He feels an urgent need to act but is momentarily paralyzed by the immediacy of the crisis; a plan to snatch the book and flee forms but the opportunity passes as the master opens the volume.
Tom feels it's too late to help Becky.
The master confronts the school, his gaze instilling fear even in the innocent, and after a tense silence, he demands to know who tore his book.
The silence continues as he scrutinizes the students' faces.
He begins questioning the boys: Benjamin Rogers denies it, followed by Joseph Harper.
Tom's distress mounts with each denial.
The master then turns to the girls, questioning Amy Lawrence, then Gracie Miller, and then Susan Harper, each of whom indicates her innocence.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: A whole hour drifted by, the master sat nodding in his throne, the air was drowsy with the hum of study.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Another negative.

events.text_segment:
A whole hour drifted by, the master sat nodding in his throne, the air was drowsy with the hum of study. By and by, Mr. Dobbins straightened himself up, yawned, then unlocked his desk, and reached for his book, but seemed undecided whether to take it out or leave it. Most of the pupils glanced up languidly, but there were two among them that watched his movements with intent eyes. Mr. Dobbins fingered his book absently for a while, then took it out and settled himself in his chair to read! Tom shot a glance at Becky. He had seen a hunted and helpless rabbit look as she did, with a gun levelled at its head. Instantly he forgot his quarrel with her. Quick—something must be done! done in a flash, too! But the very imminence of the emergency paralyzed his invention. Good!—he had an inspiration! He would run and snatch the book, spring through the door and fly. But his resolution shook for one little instant, and the chance was lost—the master opened the volume. If Tom only had the wasted opportunity back again! Too late. There was no help for Becky now, he said. The next moment the master faced the school. Every eye sank under his gaze. There was that in it which smote even the innocent with fear. There was silence while one might count ten—the master was gathering his wrath. Then he spoke: “Who tore this book?”
There was not a sound. One could have heard a pin drop. The stillness continued; the master searched face after face for signs of guilt.
“Benjamin Rogers, did you tear this book?”
A denial. Another pause.
“Joseph Harper, did you?”
Another denial. Tom’s uneasiness grew more and more intense under the slow torture of these proceedings. The master scanned the ranks of boys—considered a while, then turned to the girls:
“Amy Lawrence?”
A shake of the head.
“Gracie Miller?”
The same sign.
“Susan Harper, did you do this?”
Another negative.

events.title: Tom's Unexpected Confession and Heroic Sacrifice
detailed_summary: Becky Thatcher is the next student to be questioned.
Tom observes Becky, who is pale with terror, trembling as Mr. Dobbins addresses her directly.
Mr. Dobbins insists Becky look him in the face as he asks if she tore the book; her hands rise in a desperate, appealing gesture.
An idea flashes through Tom's mind.
He suddenly leaps to his feet and shouts, “I done it!”
The entire school stares in disbelief at his seemingly foolish confession.

Tom pauses to compose himself, and as he steps forward to receive his punishment, the look of profound surprise, gratitude, and adoration in Becky's eyes feels like a worthy reward for any number of floggings.

Inspired by the grandeur of his own sacrifice, Tom endures the harshest whipping Mr. Dobbins had ever given without a sound, and also accepts an additional two-hour detention after school with indifference, knowing Becky would wait for him.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The next girl was Becky Thatcher.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Inspired by the splendor of his own act, he took without an outcry the most merciless flaying that even Mr. Dobbins had ever administered; and also received with indifference the added cruelty of a command to remain two hours after school should be dismissed—for he knew who would wait for him outside till his captivity was done, and not count the tedious time as loss, either.

events.text_segment:
The next girl was Becky Thatcher. Tom was trembling from head to foot with excitement and a sense of the hopelessness of the situation.
“Rebecca Thatcher” [Tom glanced at her face—it was white with terror]—“did you tear—no, look me in the face” [her hands rose in appeal]—“did you tear this book?”
A thought shot like lightning through Tom’s brain. He sprang to his feet and shouted—“I done it!”
The school stared in perplexity at this incredible folly. Tom stood a moment, to gather his dismembered faculties; and when he stepped forward to go to his punishment the surprise, the gratitude, the adoration that shone upon him out of poor Becky’s eyes seemed pay enough for a hundred floggings. Inspired by the splendor of his own act, he took without an outcry the most merciless flaying that even Mr. Dobbins had ever administered; and also received with indifference the added cruelty of a command to remain two hours after school should be dismissed—for he knew who would wait for him outside till his captivity was done, and not count the tedious time as loss, either.

events.title: Reconciliation and Becky's Admiration for Noble Tom
detailed_summary: That evening, Tom initially considers how to get revenge on Alfred Temple.
Becky, feeling ashamed and repentant, has confessed everything to Tom, including her own earlier treacherous behavior.
However, Tom's desire for vengeance soon fades, replaced by more pleasant thoughts.
He drifts off to sleep with Becky's words praising his nobility replaying in his mind.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Tom went to bed that night planning vengeance against Alfred Temple; for with shame and repentance Becky had told him all, not forgetting her own treachery; but even the longing for vengeance had to give way, soon, to pleasanter musings, and he fell asleep at last with Becky’s latest words lingering dreamily in his ear—
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Tom, how could you be so noble!”

events.title: The Schoolmaster's Pre-Examination Tyranny and the Boys' Revenge Plot
detailed_summary: As the vacation period drew near, Mr. Dobbins, the schoolmaster, intensified his already strict demeanor, driven by the desire for his school to excel on the upcoming "Examination" day.

He frequently employed his rod and ferule for discipline, primarily targeting the younger students, while older pupils and young women aged eighteen to twenty were generally exempt from these physical punishments.
Mr. Dobbins, though bald under his wig, was a man in his middle years with undiminished physical strength, enabling him to administer very forceful lashings.
With the approach of the significant day, his inherent tyrannical tendencies became more pronounced, and he appeared to derive a spiteful satisfaction from penalizing even the slightest infractions.
Consequently, the younger boys endured their school days in a state of fear and distress, using their nights to concoct schemes for revenge.
They seized every chance to cause trouble for the master, but he consistently outmaneuvered them.
Each successful act of vengeance by the boys was met with such comprehensive and severe retribution that they invariably ended up defeated.
Ultimately, they collaborated on a plan they believed would lead to a spectacular triumph, securing the assistance of the signpainter's son after confiding their scheme to him.
The signpainter's son was enthusiastic about participating, having his own grievances against the master who lodged with his family and had given the boy ample reason for animosity.

The plan was timed to coincide with the master's wife's upcoming trip to the countryside, ensuring no interference. It also capitalized on the master's habit of becoming significantly intoxicated before important events.

The signpainter's son assured the boys that once the schoolmaster reached the desired level of inebriation on Examination Evening, he would carry out the prank while the master napped in his chair, subsequently ensuring he was awakened and dispatched to the school at the appropriate moment.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Vacation was approaching.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: then he would have him awakened at the right time and hurried away to school.

events.text_segment: Vacation was approaching. The schoolmaster, always severe, grew severer and more exacting than ever, for he wanted the school to make a good showing on “Examination” day. His rod and his ferule were seldom idle now—at least among the smaller pupils. Only the biggest boys, and young ladies of eighteen and twenty, escaped lashing. Mr. Dobbins’ lashings were very vigorous ones, too; for although he carried, under his wig, a perfectly bald and shiny head, he had only reached middle age, and there was no sign of feebleness in his muscle. As the great day approached, all the tyranny that was in him came to the surface; he seemed to take a vindictive pleasure in punishing the least shortcomings. The consequence was, that the smaller boys spent their days in terror and suffering and their nights in plotting revenge. They threw away no opportunity to do the master a mischief. But he kept ahead all the time. The retribution that followed every vengeful success was so sweeping and majestic that the boys always retired from the field badly worsted. At last they conspired together and hit upon a plan that promised a dazzling victory. They swore in the signpainter’s boy, told him the scheme, and asked his help. He had his own reasons for being delighted, for the master boarded in his father’s family and had given the boy ample cause to hate him. The master’s wife would go on a visit to the country in a few days, and there would be nothing to interfere with the plan; the master always prepared himself for great occasions by getting pretty well fuddled, and the signpainter’s boy said that when the dominie had reached the proper condition on Examination Evening he would “manage the thing” while he napped in his chair; then he would have him awakened at the right time and hurried away to school.
