simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
Vacation was approaching. As the time drew near, Mr. Dobbins, the schoolmaster, grew more severe and tyrannical, eager to have his school perform well on the upcoming Examination day. He was known for his strict discipline, often wielding his rod and ferule to punish the younger boys, while the older pupils and young ladies of about eighteen to twenty years of age were generally spared such treatment. Mr. Dobbins, though bald beneath his wig, was a man in his middle years with a robust frame, capable of administering very forceful lashings.

As the big day approached, his natural harshness intensified, and he seemed to take a malicious pleasure in punishing even the slightest faults. The younger boys endured their days in fear and distress, often plotting revenge during the nights. They seized every opportunity to cause trouble for their master, but he was always quick to outwit them. Each act of retaliation was met with such severe and comprehensive punishment that the boys usually ended up defeated.

Finally, they conspired together, believing they had devised a plan that would bring about a spectacular victory. They enlisted the help of the signpainter’s boy, with whom they shared grievances against the master, who lodged with his family and had given the boy ample reasons for resentment. The plan was carefully timed to coincide with the master’s wife’s trip to the countryside, ensuring no interference. It also relied on the master’s habit of becoming heavily intoxicated before important events.

The signpainter’s son was enthusiastic about participating, having his own reasons for dislike, and assured the boys that once the schoolmaster was sufficiently drunk on Examination Evening, he would carry out the prank while the master was napping in his chair, and then make sure he was awakened and sent to the school at the right moment.

events.title: The Examination Evening Commences: Setting and Initial Student Recitations
characters: scholars (small boys, big boys, girls, young ladies)
detailed_summary: The anticipated Examination Evening eventually took place.
By eight o'clock that evening, the schoolhouse was aglow with lights and festively decorated with wreaths and garlands of greenery and blossoms.
The schoolmaster, appearing reasonably mellow, occupied his large chair on an elevated platform, with his blackboard positioned behind him.
Rows of benches flanking him on three sides and extending for six rows in front were filled by prominent town members and the students' parents.
To his left, behind the citizens' seating, a large temporary stage held the students scheduled to participate in the evening's program.

This group included rows of young boys, scrubbed clean and dressed in uncomfortably formal attire; rows of awkward older boys; and a large contingent of girls and young women in light-colored dresses, very aware of their exposed arms, heirloom jewelry, ribbons, and hair flowers.
The remainder of the building was occupied by students not taking part in the performances.
The program commenced with a very small boy who nervously recited a poem, his delivery marked by precise yet jerky gestures, as if performed by a slightly malfunctioning automaton.
Despite his evident terror, he managed to complete his piece successfully, earning a significant round of applause upon making his rehearsed bow and exiting.

Following him, a slightly embarrassed young girl recited "Mary had a little lamb," executed a curtsy that evoked sympathy, received her share of applause, and returned to her seat, flushed and pleased.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: In the fulness of time the interesting occasion arrived.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: A little shamefaced girl lisped, “Mary had a little lamb,” etc., performed a compassion-inspiring curtsy, got her meed of applause, and sat down flushed and happy.

events.text_segment:
In the fulness of time the interesting occasion arrived. At eight in the evening the schoolhouse was brilliantly lighted, and adorned with wreaths and festoons of foliage and flowers. The master sat throned in his great chair upon a raised platform, with his blackboard behind him. He was looking tolerably mellow. Three rows of benches on each side and six rows in front of him were occupied by the dignitaries of the town and by the parents of the pupils. To his left, back of the rows of citizens, was a spacious temporary platform upon which were seated the scholars who were to take part in the exercises of the evening; rows of small boys, washed and dressed to an intolerable state of discomfort; rows of gawky big boys; snowbanks of girls and young ladies clad in lawn and muslin and conspicuously conscious of their bare arms, their grandmothers’ ancient trinkets, their bits of pink and blue ribbon and the flowers in their hair. All the rest of the house was filled with non-participating scholars.
The exercises began. A very little boy stood up and sheepishly recited, “You’d scarce expect one of my age to speak in public on the stage,” etc.—accompanying himself with the painfully exact and spasmodic gestures which a machine might have used—supposing the machine to be a trifle out of order. But he got through safely, though cruelly scared, and got a fine round of applause when he made his manufactured bow and retired.
A little shamefaced girl lisped, “Mary had a little lamb,” etc., performed a compassion-inspiring curtsy, got her meed of applause, and sat down flushed and happy.

events.title: Tom Sawyer's Public Speaking Failure
detailed_summary: Tom Sawyer came to the stage with an air of self-assuredness, launching into the famous "Give me liberty or give me death" speech with exaggerated passion and wild movements, but he faltered in the middle of it.
He was overcome by a terrible case of stage fright, causing his legs to tremble and making him feel as though he might suffocate.
While he clearly had the audience's sympathy, their ensuing silence was even more distressing to him than their pity.
The schoolmaster's frown deepened Tom's predicament.
Tom made an effort to continue for a short while but ultimately gave up and left the stage, utterly vanquished.
A faint attempt at applause quickly subsided.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Tom Sawyer stepped forward with conceited confidence and soared into the unquenchable and indestructible “Give me liberty or give me death” speech, with fine fury and frantic gesticulation, and broke down in the middle of it.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: There was a weak attempt at applause, but it died early.

events.text_segment: Tom Sawyer stepped forward with conceited confidence and soared into the unquenchable and indestructible “Give me liberty or give me death” speech, with fine fury and frantic gesticulation, and broke down in the middle of it. A ghastly stage-fright seized him, his legs quaked under him and he was like to choke. True, he had the manifest sympathy of the house but he had the house’s silence, too, which was even worse than its sympathy. The master frowned, and this completed the disaster. Tom struggled awhile and then retired, utterly defeated. There was a weak attempt at applause, but it died early.

events.title: Young Ladies' Compositions: Themes, Stylistic Critique, and Sermonizing
detailed_summary: Performances of "The Boy Stood on the Burning Deck," "The Assyrian Came Down," and other dramatic recitation pieces followed Tom's attempt.
The program also included reading exercises and a spelling competition.
The small group of students studying Latin delivered their recitations with distinction.
The highlight of the evening, the original "compositions" by the young ladies, was next on the agenda.

Each young woman, when it was her turn, would walk to the front of the platform, clear her throat, present her manuscript tied with a delicate ribbon, and read, paying deliberate attention to "expression" and punctuation.
The themes of these compositions were consistently the same ones that their mothers, grandmothers, and likely all their female forebears dating back to the Crusades had explored on similar occasions.

Common topics included "Friendship," "Memories of Other Days," "Religion in History," "Dream Land," "The Advantages of Culture," "Forms of Political Government Compared and Contrasted," "Melancholy," "Filial Love," and "Heart Longings."
A frequently observed characteristic in these essays was a cultivated and cherished sense of melancholy.
Another was an extravagant and profuse outpouring of sophisticated vocabulary.
There was also a tendency to unnaturally insert particularly favored words and phrases until they lost all impact through overuse.
A distinct and detrimental peculiarity that marked these compositions was the habitual and unbearable sermon that concluded each and every one.
Regardless of the composition's subject, a strenuous effort was made to twist it into a form that could be contemplated with moral and religious benefit.
The obvious lack of sincerity in these sermons did not lead to their disappearance from schools, and the narrator suggests this trend persists and likely always will.

The narrator notes that in every school, young ladies feel compelled to end their compositions with a sermon, and often the most superficial and least religious girl produces the longest and most ardently pious one.
The narrator concludes this critique by remarking that unembellished truths are often hard to accept.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “The Boy Stood on the Burning Deck” followed; also “The Assyrian Came Down,” and other declamatory gems.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But enough of this. Homely truth is unpalatable.

events.text_segment:
“The Boy Stood on the Burning Deck” followed; also “The Assyrian Came Down,” and other declamatory gems. Then there were reading exercises, and a spelling fight. The meagre Latin class recited with honor. The prime feature of the evening was in order, now—original “compositions” by the young ladies. Each in her turn stepped forward to the edge of the platform, cleared her throat, held up her manuscript (tied with dainty ribbon), and proceeded to read, with labored attention to “expression” and punctuation. The themes were the same that had been illuminated upon similar occasions by their mothers before them, their grandmothers, and doubtless all their ancestors in the female line clear back to the Crusades. “Friendship” was one; “Memories of Other Days”; “Religion in History”; “Dream Land”; “The Advantages of Culture”; “Forms of Political Government Compared and Contrasted”; “Melancholy”; “Filial Love”; “Heart Longings,” etc., etc.
A prevalent feature in these compositions was a nursed and petted melancholy; another was a wasteful and opulent gush of “fine language”; another was a tendency to lug in by the ears particularly prized words and phrases until they were worn entirely out; and a peculiarity that conspicuously marked and marred them was the inveterate and intolerable sermon that wagged its crippled tail at the end of each and every one of them. No matter what the subject might be, a brainracking effort was made to squirm it into some aspect or other that the moral and religious mind could contemplate with edification. The glaring insincerity of these sermons was not sufficient to compass the banishment of the fashion from the schools, and it is not sufficient today; it never will be sufficient while the world stands, perhaps. There is no school in all our land where the young ladies do not feel obliged to close their compositions with a sermon; and you will find that the sermon of the most frivolous and the least religious girl in the school is always the longest and the most relentlessly pious. But enough of this. Homely truth is unpalatable.

The sermon was often a crippled tail, a sort of moral appendage that was awkwardly tacked on, and it was always delivered with a kind of forced piety that was almost comic. This sermon, with its moral and religious moral, was never banished from the schools, and the narrator suggests that it never will be, while the world stands, perhaps. In every school, young ladies feel compelled to end their compositions with a sermon, and the most superficial and least religious girl often produces the longest and most ardently pious one. The narrator concludes that unembellished truths are often hard to swallow, and that the habit of ending with a sermon is a tradition that will probably never die out.

events.title: Exemplary Compositions: Melodrama, Poetry, and the Prize-Winning Sermon
characters: A young lady (author of "Is this, then, Life?")
a slim, melancholy girl (author of "A MISSOURI MAIDEN’S FAREWELL TO ALABAMA")
a dark-complexioned young lady (author of the prize-winning composition)
detailed_summary: The narrative shifts back to the "Examination" itself, beginning with an excerpt from a composition named "Is this, then, Life?".
The passage describes a young mind's eager anticipation of festive scenes, imagining herself as the center of attention at a joyous dance.

It continues by depicting her entry into this dreamlike world, where everything initially seems magical, but eventually reveals itself as hollow vanity, leading to disillusionment and the realization that worldly pleasures cannot satisfy the soul.

During the reading of this piece, the audience murmured their appreciation with comments like "How sweet!" and "So true!", and it received enthusiastic applause, especially after its particularly sorrowful concluding sermon.
Next, a slender, melancholic young woman, whose pallor suggested a reliance on pills and digestive issues, presented a poem.
Two stanzas of her poem, "A MISSOURI MAIDEN’S FAREWELL TO ALABAMA," are shared, expressing sorrow at leaving Alabama and cherished memories of its natural beauty and streams.
Although few in the audience understood the meaning of "tête," the poem was deemed quite satisfactory.
Following this, a young lady with dark hair and eyes took the stage, paused dramatically, adopted a tragic demeanor, and began to read in a slow, serious voice.
Her composition depicted a dark, stormy night, a yearning for human connection, and the arrival of a beautiful, comforting female figure.
This lengthy piece, about ten pages of manuscript, concluded with a sermon so vehemently anti-non-Presbyterian that it earned the first prize.
This composition was regarded as the finest work of the evening.
The village mayor, in awarding the prize, delivered a heartfelt speech, declaring it the most "eloquent" piece he had ever heard and suggesting even Daniel Webster would have admired it.

The narrator adds an observation that the frequency of overused words like "beauteous" and references to human experience as "life's page" in these compositions was consistent with the usual standard.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Let us return to the “Examination.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It may be remarked, in passing, that the number of compositions in which the word “beauteous” was over-fondled, and human experience referred to as “life’s page,” was up to the usual average.

events.text_segment:
Let us return to the “Examination.” The first composition that was read was one entitled “Is this, then, Life?” Perhaps the reader can endure an extract from it:
“In the common walks of life, with what delightful emotions does the youthful mind look forward to some anticipated scene of festivity! Imagination is busy sketching rose-tinted pictures of joy. In fancy, the voluptuous votary of fashion sees herself amid the festive throng, ‘the observed of all observers.’ Her graceful form, arrayed in snowy robes, is whirling through the mazes of the joyous dance; her eye is brightest, her step is lightest in the gay assembly.
“In such delicious fancies time quickly glides by, and the welcome hour arrives for her entrance into the Elysian world, of which she has had such bright dreams. How fairy-like does everything appear to her enchanted vision! Each new scene is more charming than the last. But after a while she finds that beneath this goodly exterior, all is vanity, the flattery which once charmed her soul, now grates harshly upon her ear; the ballroom has lost its charms; and with wasted health and imbittered heart, she turns away with the conviction that earthly pleasures cannot satisfy the longings of the soul!”
And so forth and so on. There was a buzz of gratification from time to time during the reading, accompanied by whispered ejaculations of “How sweet!” “How eloquent!” “So true!” etc., and after the thing had closed with a peculiarly afflicting sermon the applause was enthusiastic.
Then arose a slim, melancholy girl, whose face had the “interesting” paleness that comes of pills and indigestion, and read a “poem.” Two stanzas of it will do:
“A MISSOURI MAIDEN’S FAREWELL TO ALABAMA
“Alabama, goodbye! I love thee well!
    But yet for a while do I leave thee now!
Sad, yes, sad thoughts of thee my heart doth swell,
    And burning recollections throng my brow!
For I have wandered through thy flowery woods;
    Have roamed and read near Tallapoosa’s stream;
Have listened to Tallassee’s warring floods,
    And wooed on Coosa’s side Aurora’s beam.

“Yet shame I not to bear an o’erfull heart,
    Nor blush to turn behind my tearful eyes;
’Tis from no stranger land I now must part,
    ’Tis to no strangers left I yield these sighs.
Welcome and home were mine within this State,
    Whose vales I leave—whose spires fade fast from me
And cold must be mine eyes, and heart, and tête,
    When, dear Alabama! they turn cold on thee!”
There were very few there who knew what “tête” meant, but the poem was very satisfactory, nevertheless.
Next appeared a dark-complexioned, black-eyed, black-haired young lady, who paused an impressive moment, assumed a tragic expression, and began to read in a measured, solemn tone:
Dark and tempestuous was night. Around the throne on high not a single star quivered; but the deep intonations of the heavy thunder constantly vibrated upon the ear; whilst the terrific lightning revelled in angry mood through the cloudy chambers of heaven, seeming to scorn the power exerted over its terror by the illustrious Franklin! Even the boisterous winds unanimously came forth from their mystic homes, and blustered about as if to enhance by their aid the wildness of the scene.
At such a time, so dark, so dreary, for human sympathy my very spirit sighed; but instead thereof,
 ‘My dearest friend, my counsellor, my comforter and guide—
        My joy in grief, my second bliss in joy,’ came to my side.
She moved like one of those bright beings pictured in the sunny walks of fancy’s Eden by the romantic and young, a queen of beauty unadorned save by her own transcendent loveliness. So soft was her step, it failed to make even a sound, and but for the magical thrill imparted by her genial touch, as other unobtrusive beauties, she would have glided away unperceived—unsought. A strange sadness rested upon her features, like icy tears upon the robe of December, as she pointed to the contending elements without, and bade me contemplate the two beings presented.
This nightmare occupied some ten pages of manuscript and wound up with a sermon so destructive of all hope to non-Presbyterians that it took the first prize. This composition was considered to be the very finest effort of the evening. The mayor of the village, in delivering the prize to the author of it, made a warm speech in which he said that it was by far the most “eloquent” thing he had ever listened to, and that Daniel Webster himself might well be proud of it.
It may be remarked, in passing, that the number of compositions in which the word “beauteous” was over-fondled, and human experience referred to as “life’s page,” was up to the usual average.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
Let us return to the “Examination.” The first piece was a composition entitled “Is this, then, Life?” written by a young lady who was the author of that well-known poem. It was a vivid, glowing description of a young girl’s anticipation of a dance, her dreams of being the center of attraction, and her entrance into a world of joy and splendor. The piece painted a picture of a scene so enchanting that the audience murmured their approval, whispering “How sweet!” and “So true!” as they listened. When the young lady reached the sorrowful conclusion, her words touched the hearts of all present, and the applause was enthusiastic, especially after the final, tearful sermon that closed her reading.

Next, a slender, melancholy girl, whose pallor suggested she relied on pills and suffered from digestive troubles, stepped forward. She read a poem titled “A Missouri Maiden’s Farewell to Alabama,” which expressed her sorrow at leaving the land of her childhood, her fond memories of its streams and natural beauty. Though many in the audience did not understand the word “tête,” they found her poem quite satisfactory, and her delivery was earnest.

Then, a dark-haired young lady took the stage. She paused dramatically, adopting a tragic expression, and began to read in a slow, serious tone. Her composition depicted a dark, stormy night, a longing for human companionship, and the arrival of a beautiful, comforting female figure. This lengthy piece, about ten pages of manuscript, culminated in a vehement sermon against non-Presbyterian denominations, which earned her the first prize. It was regarded as the finest work of the evening.

The village mayor, in awarding the prize, delivered a heartfelt speech, declaring that it was the most “eloquent” piece he had ever heard, and that even Daniel Webster would have admired it. The narrator notes that the frequent use of words like “beauteous” and references to “life’s page” as a symbol of human experience were typical of such compositions, reflecting the standard of the time.

events.title: The Cat, the Wig, and the Gilded Pate: The Boys' Revenge Fulfilled
detailed_summary: The schoolmaster, now very relaxed and almost friendly, moved his chair, turned away from the audience, and started to draw a map of America on the blackboard for a geography class exercise.
However, his unsteady hand resulted in a poorly executed drawing, prompting quiet laughter to spread through the audience.
He recognized the problem and attempted to correct it by erasing and redrawing lines, but this only made the distortions worse, and the laughter grew more noticeable.
He then concentrated entirely on his work, seemingly resolved not to be deterred by the amusement.
He sensed all eyes on him and believed he was improving, yet the tittering persisted and even intensified.
The reason for the increasing amusement was a cat being lowered through a hatch in the ceiling directly above him, suspended by a string around its hindquarters.
The cat had a cloth tied around its head and jaw to prevent it from meowing.
As it slowly descended, it arched its body upwards, clawing at the string, then swung downwards, clawing at the empty air.
The laughter grew louder as the cat came within inches of the engrossed teacher's head.
Suddenly, the cat descended further, grabbed the master's wig with its claws, held onto it, and was swiftly pulled back up into the attic, still holding its trophy.
The light then brightly illuminated the master's bald scalp, which, it was revealed, the signpainter's son had gilded.
This event brought the meeting to an immediate and chaotic end.
The boys had successfully exacted their revenge.
Vacation had arrived.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Now the master, mellow almost to the verge of geniality, put his chair aside, turned his back to the audience, and began to draw a map of America on the blackboard, to exercise the geography class upon.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: That broke up the meeting. The boys were avenged. Vacation had come.

events.text_segment:
Now the master, mellow almost to the verge of geniality, put his chair aside, turned his back to the audience, and began to draw a map of America on the blackboard, to exercise the geography class upon. But he made a sad business of it with his unsteady hand, and a smothered titter rippled over the house. He knew what the matter was, and set himself to right it. He sponged out lines and remade them; but he only distorted them more than ever, and the tittering was more pronounced. He threw his entire attention upon his work, now, as if determined not to be put down by the mirth. He felt that all eyes were fastened upon him; he imagined he was succeeding, and yet the tittering continued; it even manifestly increased. And well it might. There was a garret above, pierced with a scuttle over his head; and down through this scuttle came a cat, suspended around the haunches by a string; she had a rag tied about her head and jaws to keep her from mewing; as she slowly descended she curved upward and clawed at the string, she swung downward and clawed at the intangible air. The tittering rose higher and higher—the cat was within six inches of the absorbed teacher’s head—down, down, a little lower, and she grabbed his wig with her desperate claws, clung to it, and was snatched up into the garret in an instant with her trophy still in her possession! And how the light did blaze abroad from the master’s bald pate—for the signpainter’s boy had gilded it!
That broke up the meeting. The boys were avenged. Vacation had come.

events.title: Tom's Short-Lived Temperance and the Judge's Demise
detailed_summary: Tom Sawyer enrolled in the Cadets of Temperance, drawn by the attractiveness of their official attire.
He committed to refraining from smoking, chewing tobacco, and using swear words for the duration of his membership.
He soon realized that making a promise not to do something was the most effective way to create an urge to do that specific thing.
Tom found himself increasingly plagued by a powerful desire to drink and use profanity.
The only thing preventing him from leaving the order was the hope of an opportunity to show off his red sash.
The Fourth of July was approaching, but he quickly abandoned that hope, within forty-eight hours of joining, and instead focused on Judge Frazer, a justice of the peace.
Judge Frazer appeared to be near death, and Tom anticipated a large public funeral due to the Judge's high official status, which would be an occasion to wear his regalia.
Over three days, Tom was intensely preoccupied with the Judge's health and eager for updates.
Sometimes his optimism soared, prompting him to take out his uniform and practice poses in the mirror.
However, the Judge's condition had a very frustrating pattern of improvement and decline.
Eventually, the Judge was reported to be improving and then recovering.
Tom was thoroughly annoyed and felt personally aggrieved by this development.
He immediately tendered his resignation from the Cadets.
On that very same night, the Judge experienced a sudden worsening of his condition and died.
Tom made a firm decision never to place his trust in such an unpredictable individual again.
The funeral was a grand affair.
The Cadets marched in a manner seemingly intended to make the late Judge Frazer envious.
Tom, however, was once again free from his temperance commitments, which brought him a sense of relief.
He discovered, to his own astonishment, that he no longer had the inclination to drink or swear.
The mere fact that he was permitted to do so had eliminated the desire and the appeal of these activities.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Tom joined the new order of Cadets of Temperance, being attracted by the showy character of their “regalia.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The simple fact that he could, took the desire away, and the charm of it.

events.text_segment:
Tom joined the new order of Cadets of Temperance, being attracted by the showy character of their “regalia.” He promised to abstain from smoking, chewing, and profanity as long as he remained a member. Now he found out a new thing—namely, that to promise not to do a thing is the surest way in the world to make a body want to go and do that very thing. Tom soon found himself tormented with a desire to drink and swear; the desire grew to be so intense that nothing but the hope of a chance to display himself in his red sash kept him from withdrawing from the order. Fourth of July was coming; but he soon gave that up—gave it up before he had worn his shackles over forty-eight hours—and fixed his hopes upon old Judge Frazer, justice of the peace, who was apparently on his deathbed and would have a big public funeral, since he was so high an official. During three days Tom was deeply concerned about the Judge’s condition and hungry for news of it. Sometimes his hopes ran high—so high that he would venture to get out his regalia and practise before the looking-glass. But the Judge had a most discouraging way of fluctuating. At last he was pronounced upon the mend—and then convalescent. Tom was disgusted; and felt a sense of injury, too. He handed in his resignation at once—and that night the Judge suffered a relapse and died. Tom resolved that he would never trust a man like that again.
The funeral was a fine thing. The Cadets paraded in a style calculated to kill the late member with envy. Tom was a free boy again, however—there was something in that. He could drink and swear, now—but found to his surprise that he did not want to. The simple fact that he could, took the desire away, and the charm of it.

Soon, he discovered that promising not to do something only heightened his desire to do it, and he found himself increasingly tempted to drink and curse. The only thing that kept him in the order was the hope of a chance to wear his bright red sash at a public event.

As the Fourth of July approached, Tom's hopes for a grand display faded within forty-eight hours of joining, and he turned his attention instead to Judge Frazer, a justice of the peace who was gravely ill. Tom anticipated that the Judge's funeral would be a large public occasion, perfect for displaying his regalia. Over the next three days, Tom was obsessed with the Judge's health, eagerly awaiting news, sometimes feeling optimistic enough to practice poses in front of a mirror, imagining himself in his uniform.

However, the Judge's condition fluctuated—improving at times, then worsening. At last, reports came that the Judge was recovering, which deeply annoyed Tom, who felt personally slighted by this turn of events. He immediately resigned from the Cadets. That very night, the Judge's condition suddenly worsened, and he died.

This experience led Tom to a firm resolve never to trust such an unpredictable person again. The funeral was a grand affair, with the Cadets marching in a manner that seemed designed to make the late Judge Frazer envious. Once again, Tom was free from his temperance vows, which brought him relief. simple_agent_extraction_refined_2.text:
Tom joined the new order of Cadets of Temperance, being attracted by the showy character of their "regalia." He promised to abstain from smoking, chewing tobacco, and using swear words while he was a member. But he soon found that making a promise not to do something only increased his desire to do it, and he was more and more troubled by a strong wish to drink and swear. The only thing that kept him in the order was the hope of an opportunity to wear his bright red sash at a public event.

He gave up hope of that happening on the Fourth of July, within forty-eight hours of joining, and instead turned his attention to Judge Frazer, a justice of the peace who was very ill. Tom thought the Judge might die, and he looked forward to a big public funeral, which would be a fine occasion to wear his regalia. Over three days, Tom was very anxious about the Judge’s health, eagerly waiting for news. Sometimes he felt hopeful enough to take out his uniform and practice poses in front of a mirror.

But the Judge’s condition kept changing—improving and then worsening. At last, reports said he was getting better and then recovering. Tom was very annoyed and felt personally hurt by this. He immediately handed in his resignation from the Cadets. That very night, the Judge’s condition suddenly worsened, and he died.

Tom decided he would never trust a man like the Judge again. The funeral was a grand affair. The Cadets marched in a way that seemed meant to make the late Judge Frazer envious. Tom, however, was once again free from his temperance vows, which made him feel relieved. To his surprise, he found that he no longer had the desire to drink or swear. The fact that he was allowed to do these things had taken away their appeal and desire.

events.title: Vacation Disappointments and Failed Distractions
detailed_summary: Tom soon found that his eagerly awaited vacation was becoming somewhat boring and uneventful.
He made an attempt to keep a diary, but nothing of interest occurred for three days, leading him to abandon the effort.
The town's very first negro minstrel show arrived, creating a significant stir and excitement.
In response, Tom and Joe Harper organized their own group of performers, enjoying this activity for two days.
Even the anticipated Glorious Fourth of July turned out to be somewhat of a letdown due to heavy rainfall, which led to the cancellation of the procession.
Furthermore, Mr. Benton, a genuine United States Senator whom Tom had imagined to be an immense figure, was a major disappointment as he was not nearly twenty-five feet tall, nor even close to it.

A circus came to town, inspiring the boys to play circus for the following three days in makeshift tents constructed from rag carpeting; admission was set at three pins for boys and two for girls, after which this activity was also discontinued.
A phrenologist and a mesmerizer visited the town but soon departed, leaving the village feeling even more lackluster and depressing than before.
There were a few parties attended by both boys and girls, but these events were so infrequent and enjoyable that they only served to make the periods of emptiness between them feel more acute.
Becky Thatcher had traveled to her family's home in Constantinople for the vacation, meaning there was no source of happiness or brightness in Tom's life.
The terrible secret concerning the murder was a persistent source of distress for Tom, like a chronic and painful disease.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It was a very cancer for permanency and pain.

events.text_segment:
Tom presently wondered to find that his coveted vacation was beginning to hang a little heavily on his hands.
He attempted a diary—but nothing happened during three days, and so he abandoned it.
The first of all the negro minstrel shows came to town, and made a sensation. Tom and Joe Harper got up a band of performers and were happy for two days.
Even the Glorious Fourth was in some sense a failure, for it rained hard, there was no procession in consequence, and the greatest man in the world (as Tom supposed), Mr. Benton, an actual United States Senator, proved an overwhelming disappointment—for he was not twenty-five feet high, nor even anywhere in the neighborhood of it.
A circus came. The boys played circus for three days afterward in tents made of rag carpeting—admission, three pins for boys, two for girls—and then circusing was abandoned.
A phrenologist and a mesmerizer came—and went again and left the village duller and drearier than ever.
There were some boys-and-girls’ parties, but they were so few and so delightful that they only made the aching voids between ache the harder.
Becky Thatcher was gone to her Constantinople home to stay with her parents during vacation—so there was no bright side to life anywhere.
The dreadful secret of the murder was a chronic misery. It was a very cancer for permanency and pain.

events.title: Tom's Illness and the Town's Religious Revival
detailed_summary: Following these events, Tom fell ill with the measles.
For two extended weeks, Tom was confined as a prisoner by his illness, completely cut off from the world and its activities, feeling extremely unwell and uninterested in anything.
When he finally regained enough strength to get out of bed and walk feebly into the downtown area, he discovered that a gloomy transformation had affected everything and everyone.
A religious 'revival' had occurred in the town, and virtually everyone had 'found religion.'
This spiritual awakening had touched not only the adults but also the children, including both boys and girls.
Tom wandered about, clinging to a faint hope of seeing a familiar, unrepentant face, but he encountered disappointment everywhere he looked.
He discovered Joe Harper deeply absorbed in studying a Testament, a sight that caused Tom to turn away with sadness.
He then looked for Ben Rogers, only to find him engaged in charitable activities, distributing religious pamphlets to the poor.
He managed to find Jim Hollis, who pointed to Tom's recent illness as a significant and divine warning.
Every boy Tom met seemed to add to his growing despair.
In a state of utter desperation, he sought comfort from Huckleberry Finn, but Huck greeted him with a quotation from Scripture.
This final interaction was devastating for Tom; his heart felt broken, and he retreated home to bed, convinced that he was the only person in the entire town who was irredeemably lost.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Then came the measles.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Every boy he encountered added another ton to his depression; and when, in desperation, he flew for refuge at last to the bosom of Huckleberry Finn and was received with a Scriptural quotation, his heart broke and he crept home and to bed realizing that he alone of all the town was lost, forever and forever.

events.text_segment:
Then came the measles.
During two long weeks Tom lay a prisoner, dead to the world and its happenings. He was very ill, he was interested in nothing. When he got upon his feet at last and moved feebly downtown, a melancholy change had come over everything and every creature. There had been a “revival,” and everybody had “got religion,” not only the adults, but even the boys and girls. Tom went about, hoping against hope for the sight of one blessed sinful face, but disappointment crossed him everywhere. He found Joe Harper studying a Testament, and turned sadly away from the depressing spectacle. He sought Ben Rogers, and found him visiting the poor with a basket of tracts. He hunted up Jim Hollis, who called his attention to the precious blessing of his late measles as a warning. Every boy he encountered added another ton to his depression; and when, in desperation, he flew for refuge at last to the bosom of Huckleberry Finn and was received with a Scriptural quotation, his heart broke and he crept home and to bed realizing that he alone of all the town was lost, forever and forever.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text: Then came the measles. For two long weeks, Tom Sawyer was confined to his bed, a prisoner to his illness, cut off from the world and its lively pursuits. When at last he felt strong enough to rise and venture into the town, he found that everything had changed. A gloom had settled over the place; a religious revival had swept through the community. Almost everyone, from the oldest to the youngest, had found religion. Tom wandered about, hoping to see some familiar face that had not been touched by the revival. He looked for Joe Harper, who was deeply engrossed in studying a Testament, and felt a pang of sadness. He sought Ben Rogers, who was busy distributing religious pamphlets to the poor, and then found Jim Hollis, who pointed to Tom’s recent illness as a divine warning. Every boy he met seemed to deepen his despair. In his desperation, Tom sought out Huck Finn, who greeted him with a quotation from Scripture. That final encounter broke Tom’s heart; he felt utterly lost and retreated home to his bed, convinced that he was the only one in town beyond redemption.

events.title: The Great Storm and Tom's Existential Dread
detailed_summary: On that very night, a ferocious storm began, featuring torrential rain, terrifying claps of thunder, and blinding flashes of lightning.
Tom concealed himself under his bedclothes, waiting in a state of horrified anticipation for what he believed was his certain doom.
He was completely convinced that the entire chaotic weather event was specifically about him.
He believed he had strained the patience of the divine powers to the breaking point and that this storm was the direct consequence.

While it might generally be considered an excessive use of resources to eliminate a tiny creature with heavy artillery, Tom saw nothing illogical about such an elaborate thunderstorm being orchestrated to eradicate an insignificant being like himself.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: And that night there came on a terrific storm, with driving rain, awful claps of thunder and blinding sheets of lightning.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It might have seemed to him a waste of pomp and ammunition to kill a bug with a battery of artillery, but there seemed nothing incongruous about the getting up such an expensive thunderstorm as this to knock the turf from under an insect like himself.

events.text_segment: And that night there came on a terrific storm, with driving rain, awful claps of thunder and blinding sheets of lightning. He covered his head with the bedclothes and waited in a horror of suspense for his doom; for he had not the shadow of a doubt that all this hubbub was about him. He believed he had taxed the forbearance of the powers above to the extremity of endurance and that this was the result. It might have seemed to him a waste of pomp and ammunition to kill a bug with a battery of artillery, but there seemed nothing incongruous about the getting up such an expensive thunderstorm as this to knock the turf from under an insect like himself.

events.title: Tom's Relapse and the Return of His 'Sinful' Companions
detailed_summary: After some time, the storm exhausted its energy and ended without achieving what Tom perceived as its goal.
Tom's first instinct was to feel thankful and to decide to change his ways for the better.
His second thought, however, was to pause and reconsider, as there might not be any more such storms.
The next day, the doctors were called back; Tom had experienced a relapse of his illness.
The three weeks he spent confined to his bed this time felt like an entire lifetime.
When he was finally able to go out again, he felt hardly any gratitude for having been spared, recalling how isolated his situation was and how utterly alone and dejected he felt.

He wandered dejectedly down the street and came across Jim Hollis acting as a judge in a children's make-believe court that was trying a cat for the murder of a bird, with the bird's body present as evidence.
He then found Joe Harper and Huckleberry Finn in an alley, engaged in eating a stolen melon.
Tom realized that these unfortunate boys, much like himself, had also experienced a 'relapse' from their recent religious piety.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: By and by the tempest spent itself and died without accomplishing its object.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Poor lads! they—like Tom—had suffered a relapse.

events.text_segment:
By and by the tempest spent itself and died without accomplishing its object. The boy’s first impulse was to be grateful, and reform. His second was to wait—for there might not be any more storms.
The next day the doctors were back; Tom had relapsed. The three weeks he spent on his back this time seemed an entire age. When he got abroad at last he was hardly grateful that he had been spared, remembering how lonely was his estate, how companionless and forlorn he was. He drifted listlessly down the street and found Jim Hollis acting as judge in a juvenile court that was trying a cat for murder, in the presence of her victim, a bird. He found Joe Harper and Huck Finn up an alley eating a stolen melon. Poor lads! they—like Tom—had suffered a relapse.

events.title: Tom and Huck Reaffirm Their Secret Oath Amidst Trial Anxiety
detailed_summary: The commencement of the murder trial stirs the village, making it the dominant topic of conversation.
Tom is deeply unsettled by any mention of the murder, fearing that references to it are subtle attempts to gauge his knowledge.
Despite not understanding how he could be suspected, Tom lives in a constant state of anxiety.
He seeks out Huck in a private location to discuss their shared secret and alleviate some of his distress.
Tom's primary concern is to confirm that Huck has not revealed anything about what they witnessed.
Huck firmly reassures Tom that he has never spoken a word about the incident.
Huck underscores the grave danger they would face if their knowledge became public, stating they wouldn't survive long.
Feeling somewhat more at ease, Tom presses further, asking Huck if anyone could coerce him into confessing.
Huck emphatically states that only a desire for Injun Joe to kill him would make him tell, asserting there's no other way he'd reveal the truth.
Tom agrees that their safety lies in silence, and they decide to renew their vow of secrecy with solemn oaths for extra assurance.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At last the sleepy atmosphere was stirred—and vigorously: the murder trial came on in the court.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So they swore again with dread solemnities.

events.text_segment:
At last the sleepy atmosphere was stirred—and vigorously: the murder trial came on in the court. It became the absorbing topic of village talk immediately. Tom could not get away from it. Every reference to the murder sent a shudder to his heart, for his troubled conscience and fears almost persuaded him that these remarks were put forth in his hearing as “feelers”; he did not see how he could be suspected of knowing anything about the murder, but still he could not be comfortable in the midst of this gossip. It kept him in a cold shiver all the time. He took Huck to a lonely place to have a talk with him. It would be some relief to unseal his tongue for a little while; to divide his burden of distress with another sufferer. Moreover, he wanted to assure himself that Huck had remained discreet.
“Huck, have you ever told anybody about—that?”
“’Bout what?”
“You know what.”
“Oh—’course I haven’t.”
“Never a word?”
“Never a solitary word, so help me. What makes you ask?”
“Well, I was afeard.”
“Why, Tom Sawyer, we wouldn’t be alive two days if that got found out. You know that.”
Tom felt more comfortable. After a pause:
“Huck, they couldn’t anybody get you to tell, could they?”
“Get me to tell? Why, if I wanted that halfbreed devil to drownd me they could get me to tell. They ain’t no different way.”
“Well, that’s all right, then. I reckon we’re safe as long as we keep mum. But let’s swear again, anyway. It’s more surer.”
“I’m agreed.”
So they swore again with dread solemnities.

events.title: Boys' Guilt, Potter's Gratitude, and a Jailhouse Visit
detailed_summary: Tom inquires about the prevalent village talk, which Huck confirms is entirely focused on Muff Potter, causing Huck continuous anxiety.
Tom shares that he experiences similar discomfort and expresses his belief that Potter is doomed, questioning Huck if he ever feels sympathy for him.
Huck admits to frequently feeling sorry for Potter, acknowledging Potter's lack of social standing but also his harmless nature and past acts of kindness, such as sharing food and offering support.
Tom reciprocates, recalling how Potter mended his kites and helped with his fishing line, and expresses a wish to free Potter from jail.
Huck dismisses the idea of freeing Potter as futile, believing he would inevitably be recaptured.
Both boys express their dismay at hearing Potter so harshly condemned for a crime they know he didn't commit.
They discuss the villagers' harsh judgment, including remarks about Potter's villainous appearance and threats of lynching if he were freed.
Their long conversation provides little comfort, and as twilight descends, they find themselves lingering near the isolated jail, perhaps with a vague hope for a miraculous resolution.
Following a familiar routine, the boys approach Potter's cell grating to give him tobacco and matches, as he is on the ground floor without guards.
Potter's gratitude for their offerings has always troubled their consciences, but this time it affects them more profoundly.
They feel intensely cowardly and treacherous when Potter thanks them, calling them his only true friends in town and promising not to forget their loyalty.
Potter acknowledges his wrongdoing, attributing it to being drunk and crazed, and accepts that he must face the consequences, hoping it is for the best.
He implores the boys never to get drunk, so they avoid his fate, and expresses how much comfort their friendly faces bring him in his isolation.
Potter asks to touch their hands through the bars, remarking on their smallness but acknowledging the significant help they've provided and would provide if they could.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “What is the talk around, Huck? I’ve heard a power of it.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Little hands, and weak—but they’ve helped Muff Potter a power, and they’d help him more if they could.”

events.text_segment:
“What is the talk around, Huck? I’ve heard a power of it.”
“Talk? Well, it’s just Muff Potter, Muff Potter, Muff Potter all the time. It keeps me in a sweat, constant, so’s I want to hide som’ers.”
“That’s just the same way they go on round me. I reckon he’s a goner. Don’t you feel sorry for him, sometimes?”
“Most always—most always. He ain’t no account; but then he hain’t ever done anything to hurt anybody. Just fishes a little, to get money to get drunk on—and loafs around considerable; but lord, we all do that—leastways most of us—preachers and such like. But he’s kind of good—he give me half a fish, once, when there warn’t enough for two; and lots of times he’s kind of stood by me when I was out of luck.”
“Well, he’s mended kites for me, Huck, and knitted hooks on to my line. I wish we could get him out of there.”
“My! we couldn’t get him out, Tom. And besides, ’twouldn’t do any good; they’d ketch him again.”
“Yes—so they would. But I hate to hear ’em abuse him so like the dickens when he never done—that.”
“I do too, Tom. Lord, I hear ’em say he’s the bloodiest looking villain in this country, and they wonder he wasn’t ever hung before.”
“Yes, they talk like that, all the time. I’ve heard ’em say that if he was to get free they’d lynch him.”
“And they’d do it, too.”
The boys had a long talk, but it brought them little comfort. As the twilight drew on, they found themselves hanging about the neighborhood of the little isolated jail, perhaps with an undefined hope that something would happen that might clear away their difficulties. But nothing happened; there seemed to be no angels or fairies interested in this luckless captive.
The boys did as they had often done before—went to the cell grating and gave Potter some tobacco and matches. He was on the ground floor and there were no guards.
His gratitude for their gifts had always smote their consciences before—it cut deeper than ever, this time. They felt cowardly and treacherous to the last degree when Potter said:
“You’ve been mighty good to me, boys—better’n anybody else in this town. And I don’t forget it, I don’t. Often I says to myself, says I, ‘I used to mend all the boys’ kites and things, and show ’em where the good fishin’ places was, and befriend ’em what I could, and now they’ve all forgot old Muff when he’s in trouble; but Tom don’t, and Huck don’t—they don’t forget him,’ says I, ‘and I don’t forget them.’ Well, boys, I done an awful thing—drunk and crazy at the time—that’s the only way I account for it—and now I got to swing for it, and it’s right. Right, and best, too, I reckon—hope so, anyway. Well, we won’t talk about that. I don’t want to make you feel bad; you’ve befriended me. But what I want to say, is, don’t you ever get drunk—then you won’t ever get here. Stand a litter furder west—so—that’s it; it’s a prime comfort to see faces that’s friendly when a body’s in such a muck of trouble, and there don’t none come here but yourn. Good friendly faces—good friendly faces. Git up on one another’s backs and let me touch ’em. That’s it. Shake hands—yourn’ll come through the bars, but mine’s too big. Little hands, and weak—but they’ve helped Muff Potter a power, and they’d help him more if they could.”

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
"What is the talk around, Huck? I’ve heard a power of it," Tom began, his voice low and serious.

Huck looked uneasy. "It’s all about Muff Potter, Tom. The folks are saying he’s a villain, and they’re talking about hanging him. It’s got me all in a tremble."

Tom nodded, sharing Huck’s discomfort. "I feel the same. I believe Potter’s a doomed man. Do you ever feel sorry for him?"

Huck hesitated, then admitted, "Sometimes I do. He’s not much of a man, but he’s harmless enough, and he’s helped me out a time or two—shared his food, and once he even helped me with my fishing line."

Tom sighed. "I remember how he mended my kites and helped me fix my boat. I wish we could do something to help him. Maybe we could get him out of jail."

Huck shook his head. "It’s no use, Tom. They’d catch him again, and it’d be worse for him."

They both looked toward the darkening sky, feeling the weight of the injustice. As they lingered near the lonely jail, they hesitated, perhaps hoping for a miracle.

Then, as usual, they approached the jail grating, slipping in tobacco and matches for Muff Potter, who was on the ground floor without guards.

Potter’s face lit up with gratitude, and as he took the offerings, he looked at the boys with a mixture of affection and remorse. "You’re my only friends in this town," he said softly. "Don’t forget me."

He looked at them with tears in his eyes. "I was drunk and crazy. I didn’t mean to do wrong. I suppose I have to face the music now. But I wish I could be free."

He reached out through the bars, touching their small hands. "You’re good boys. If only I could help you, I would."

The boys felt a surge of cowardice and guilt, but they promised to remember Muff Potter and to stay true to their friendship, no matter what.

events.title: The Trial's Climax Approaches: Courtroom Drama Unfolds
detailed_summary: Tom returns home profoundly distressed, and his sleep is plagued by horrific nightmares.
Over the subsequent two days, both Tom and Huck feel an irresistible compulsion to be near the courtroom but actively avoid entering and each other.
They drift away periodically, only to be drawn back by a grim fascination with the proceedings.
Tom listens intently to comments from idlers exiting the courtroom, consistently hearing distressing updates about Potter's worsening situation.
By the close of the second day, the prevailing sentiment in the village is that Injun Joe's testimony against Potter is irrefutable and the jury's guilty verdict is a foregone conclusion.
Tom arrives home late that night in a state of extreme agitation and finds it difficult to sleep for hours.
The next morning, the entire village population throngs to the courthouse, anticipating it as the pivotal day of the trial.
The courtroom is densely packed with an audience comprising roughly equal numbers of men and women.
Following a significant wait, the jury members file in and take their seats.
Shortly thereafter, Muff Potter, appearing pale, gaunt, timid, and devoid of hope, is brought in, bound in chains, and seated where he is the focus of all curious gazes.
Injun Joe is also present, maintaining his usual impassive demeanor.
Another pause ensues before the judge arrives, and the sheriff formally opens the court session.
The customary hushed conversations among lawyers and the rustling of papers follow, contributing to an atmosphere of preparation that is both impressive and captivating.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Tom went home miserable, and his dreams that night were full of horrors.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: These details and accompanying delays worked up an atmosphere of preparation that was as impressive as it was fascinating.

events.text_segment:
Tom went home miserable, and his dreams that night were full of horrors. The next day and the day after, he hung about the courtroom, drawn by an almost irresistible impulse to go in, but forcing himself to stay out. Huck was having the same experience. They studiously avoided each other. Each wandered away, from time to time, but the same dismal fascination always brought them back presently. Tom kept his ears open when idlers sauntered out of the courtroom, but invariably heard distressing news—the toils were closing more and more relentlessly around poor Potter. At the end of the second day the village talk was to the effect that Injun Joe’s evidence stood firm and unshaken, and that there was not the slightest question as to what the jury’s verdict would be.
Tom was out late, that night, and came to bed through the window. He was in a tremendous state of excitement. It was hours before he got to sleep. All the village flocked to the courthouse the next morning, for this was to be the great day. Both sexes were about equally represented in the packed audience. After a long wait the jury filed in and took their places; shortly afterward, Potter, pale and haggard, timid and hopeless, was brought in, with chains upon him, and seated where all the curious eyes could stare at him; no less conspicuous was Injun Joe, stolid as ever. There was another pause, and then the judge arrived and the sheriff proclaimed the opening of the court. The usual whisperings among the lawyers and gathering together of papers followed. These details and accompanying delays worked up an atmosphere of preparation that was as impressive as it was fascinating.

Tom went home miserable, and his dreams that night were full of horrors. He lay awake for hours, tossing and turning, until exhaustion finally claimed him. Over the next two days, Tom and Huck felt an almost magnetic pull toward the courthouse, yet they kept their distance from each other and avoided entering the building. They drifted away from the crowds, only to be drawn back again and again, unable to resist the grim fascination of the trial proceedings.

Tom listened carefully to the comments of idlers leaving the courtroom, hearing distressing reports about Muff Potter's worsening condition. By the end of the second day, everyone in the village believed that Injun Joe's testimony was irrefutable, and the verdict of guilty was all but certain.

Late that night, Tom returned home in a state of agitation, his mind racing, and he found it difficult to sleep for hours. The following morning, the entire village gathered at the courthouse, eager for what was expected to be the decisive day of the trial. The courtroom was densely packed with men and women, roughly equal in number, all eager to witness the proceedings.

After a long wait, the jury entered and took their seats. Muff Potter, looking pale, gaunt, and timid, was brought in, chained and seated where all could see him. Injun Joe was also present, maintaining his usual impassive demeanor. There was a brief pause before the judge arrived, and the sheriff formally opened the court.

The lawyers exchanged hushed words, and the rustling of papers filled the air as everyone prepared for the trial to begin. The atmosphere was tense, filled with anticipation and a sense of mounting drama, as the villagers watched closely, eager to see justice unfold.

events.title: Prosecution Builds Case as Defense Remains Passive
detailed_summary: A witness is called who recounts finding Muff Potter washing in a brook early on the morning the murder was discovered, noting Potter's hurried departure. Potter's lawyer declines to cross-examine.
The subsequent witness testifies about the knife found near the corpse. Again, Potter's counsel states he has no questions.
A third witness swears to having often seen the specific knife in Potter's possession. Potter's lawyer once more declines to question him.
The audience begins to show signs of irritation, questioning if Potter's attorney intends to passively allow his client's conviction.
Several more witnesses testify regarding Potter's guilty-seeming behavior when he was brought to the scene of the crime. None are cross-examined.
Every incriminating detail from the events in the graveyard, well-remembered by those present, is presented by credible witnesses, yet Potter's lawyer refrains from cross-examining any of them.
The growing confusion and dissatisfaction in the courtroom manifest as murmurs, prompting a reprimand from the judge.
The counsel for the prosecution concludes their case, asserting that the testimony from trustworthy citizens has unequivocally established Potter's guilt.
A despairing groan escapes Muff Potter; he covers his face with his hands and sways gently, while a tense silence fills the courtroom.
Many men in the audience are visibly affected, and numerous women express their compassion through tears.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Now a witness was called who testified that he found Muff Potter washing in the brook, at an early hour of the morning that the murder was discovered, and that he immediately sneaked away.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Many men were moved, and many women’s compassion testified itself in tears.

events.text_segment:
Now a witness was called who testified that he found Muff Potter washing in the brook, at an early hour of the morning that the murder was discovered, and that he immediately sneaked away. After some further questioning, counsel for the prosecution said:
“Take the witness.”
The prisoner raised his eyes for a moment, but dropped them again when his own counsel said:
“I have no questions to ask him.”
The next witness proved the finding of the knife near the corpse. Counsel for the prosecution said:
“Take the witness.”
“I have no questions to ask him,” Potter’s lawyer replied.
A third witness swore he had often seen the knife in Potter’s possession.
“Take the witness.”
Counsel for Potter declined to question him. The faces of the audience began to betray annoyance. Did this attorney mean to throw away his client’s life without an effort?
Several witnesses deposed concerning Potter’s guilty behavior when brought to the scene of the murder. They were allowed to leave the stand without being cross-questioned.
Every detail of the damaging circumstances that occurred in the graveyard upon that morning which all present remembered so well was brought out by credible witnesses, but none of them were cross-examined by Potter’s lawyer. The perplexity and dissatisfaction of the house expressed itself in murmurs and provoked a reproof from the bench. Counsel for the prosecution now said:
“By the oaths of citizens whose simple word is above suspicion, we have fastened this awful crime, beyond all possibility of question, upon the unhappy prisoner at the bar. We rest our case here.”
A groan escaped from poor Potter, and he put his face in his hands and rocked his body softly to and fro, while a painful silence reigned in the courtroom. Many men were moved, and many women’s compassion testified itself in tears.

events.title: A Shocking Turn: Defense Calls Tom Sawyer as Witness
detailed_summary: The counsel for the defense stands and announces a change in their intended strategy, stating they will no longer argue that their client committed the act under the influence of delirium caused by alcohol, as previously suggested.
He then addresses the clerk, delivering a stunning directive: to call Thomas Sawyer to the stand.
This unexpected development causes a stir of bewildered amazement throughout the courtroom, affecting everyone present, including Muff Potter himself.
All eyes turn with intense, wondering interest towards Tom as he gets up and moves to the witness stand.
The boy appears visibly frightened and disheveled.
The oath is then formally administered to Tom.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Counsel for the defence rose and said:
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The oath was administered.

events.text_segment:
Counsel for the defence rose and said:
“Your honor, in our remarks at the opening of this trial, we foreshadowed our purpose to prove that our client did this fearful deed while under the influence of a blind and irresponsible delirium produced by drink. We have changed our mind. We shall not offer that plea.” [Then to the clerk:] “Call Thomas Sawyer!”
A puzzled amazement awoke in every face in the house, not even excepting Potter’s. Every eye fastened itself with wondering interest upon Tom as he rose and took his place upon the stand. The boy looked wild enough, for he was badly scared. The oath was administered.

events.title: Tom's Testimony Reveals the Truth, Injun Joe Escapes
detailed_summary: The lawyer begins by asking Tom his location around midnight on June seventeenth.
Tom, unnerved by Injun Joe's steely gaze, finds his voice failing him initially, while the courtroom audience listens with rapt attention.
After a few moments, Tom regains some composure and manages to audibly state he was "In the graveyard!"
The lawyer encourages him to speak more loudly and without fear, prompting Tom to repeat, "In the graveyard."
A disdainful smile briefly appears on Injun Joe's face.
Tom confirms he was near Horse Williams' grave, as close as his current distance to the lawyer.
He admits he was hidden behind the elm trees at the edge of the grave.
Injun Joe exhibits a barely noticeable startle.
Tom acknowledges he was accompanied but is instructed by the lawyer to withhold his companion's name for now, as that person will be produced later.
When questioned about what he carried with him, Tom hesitates, looking confused.
The lawyer encourages him to speak truthfully, reminding him that truth is always respectable, before Tom reveals he took "Only a—a—dead cat."
A ripple of amusement passes through the courtroom but is quickly suppressed by the court.
The lawyer states they will produce the cat's skeleton and then instructs Tom to recount everything that occurred, in his own words, without omitting any details or succumbing to fear.
Tom begins his testimony, initially with hesitation, but his words start to flow more easily as he gets into his narrative.

Soon, the only sound in the courtroom is Tom's voice; every eye is fixed on him, and the audience, with parted lips and held breath, hangs on his every word, completely absorbed in the horrifying tale.
The emotional strain reaches its peak when Tom declares, "—and as the doctor fetched the board around and Muff Potter fell, Injun Joe jumped with the knife and—"
At that precise moment, a crash is heard; Injun Joe, with lightning speed, lunges for a window, forcefully breaks through any opposition, and vanishes.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Thomas Sawyer, where were you on the seventeenth of June, about the hour of midnight?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Crash! Quick as lightning the halfbreed sprang for a window, tore his way through all opposers, and was gone!

events.text_segment:
“Thomas Sawyer, where were you on the seventeenth of June, about the hour of midnight?”
Tom glanced at Injun Joe’s iron face and his tongue failed him. The audience listened breathless, but the words refused to come. After a few moments, however, the boy got a little of his strength back, and managed to put enough of it into his voice to make part of the house hear:
“In the graveyard!”
“A little bit louder, please. Don’t be afraid. You were—”
“In the graveyard.”
A contemptuous smile flitted across Injun Joe’s face.
“Were you anywhere near Horse Williams’ grave?”
“Yes, sir.”
“Speak up—just a trifle louder. How near were you?”
“Near as I am to you.”
“Were you hidden, or not?”
“I was hid.”
“Where?”
“Behind the elms that’s on the edge of the grave.”
Injun Joe gave a barely perceptible start.
“Any one with you?”
“Yes, sir. I went there with—”
“Wait—wait a moment. Never mind mentioning your companion’s name. We will produce him at the proper time. Did you carry anything there with you.”
Tom hesitated and looked confused.
“Speak out, my boy—don’t be diffident. The truth is always respectable. What did you take there?”
“Only a—a—dead cat.”
There was a ripple of mirth, which the court checked.
“We will produce the skeleton of that cat. Now, my boy, tell us everything that occurred—tell it in your own way—don’t skip anything, and don’t be afraid.”
Tom began—hesitatingly at first, but as he warmed to his subject his words flowed more and more easily; in a little while every sound ceased but his own voice; every eye fixed itself upon him; with parted lips and bated breath the audience hung upon his words, taking no note of time, rapt in the ghastly fascinations of the tale. The strain upon pent emotion reached its climax when the boy said:
“—and as the doctor fetched the board around and Muff Potter fell, Injun Joe jumped with the knife and—”
Crash! Quick as lightning the halfbreed sprang for a window, tore his way through all opposers, and was gone!

Thomas Sawyer, where were you on the seventeenth of June, about the hour of midnight?" asked the lawyer.

Tom, looking nervously at the stern face of Injun Joe, hesitated and then stammered, "In the graveyard!"

"Louder, Tom," said the lawyer kindly. "Speak up."

Tom took a deep breath and repeated, "In the graveyard!"

A faint smile of contempt crossed Injun Joe's face.

"And where exactly were you?" continued the lawyer.

"Near Horse Williams' grave," said Tom, "as close as I am to you now."

"And what were you doing there?"

"I was hiding behind the elm trees at the edge of the graveyard."

Injun Joe started slightly, but he kept his composure.

"Did anyone accompany you?" asked the lawyer.

"Yes," said Tom, but he was told to withhold the name for the present, as the person would be produced later.

"What did you carry with you?" inquired the lawyer.

Tom looked confused and hesitated.

"Speak the truth, Tom," said the lawyer gently. "Truth is always respectable."

"Only a—a—dead cat," said Tom.

A ripple of amusement ran through the courtroom, but it was quickly suppressed.

"We will produce the skeleton of the cat," said the lawyer. "Now, Tom, tell everything that happened, just as it occurred, without fear or omission."

Tom began to speak, his voice trembling at first, but gradually gaining strength.

Soon, every eye in the courtroom was fixed on him, and the audience, with parted lips and held breath, listened intently.

"And as the doctor fetched the board around and Muff Potter fell, Injun Joe jumped with the knife and—"

At that moment, a loud crash was heard. Injun Joe, with lightning speed, lunged for a window, broke through the opposition, and disappeared.

events.title: A Hero's Acclaim and a Community's Redemption
detailed_summary: Tom Sawyer's public image soared once again, making him a cherished figure among adults and an object of envy for younger people.
His recent actions were widely celebrated, with the village newspaper even publishing an exaggerated account of his heroism.
Some members of the community began to speculate that Tom might achieve a high political office, such as the presidency, assuming he could avoid a criminal's end.
The community, known for its shifting allegiances, wholeheartedly embraced Muff Potter, showing him as much affection as they had previously shown him disdain.
This tendency for public opinion to reverse itself is presented as a commendable aspect of human nature, not something to be criticized.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Tom was a glittering hero once more—the pet of the old, the envy of the young.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But that sort of conduct is to the world’s credit; therefore it is not well to find fault with it.

events.text_segment:
Tom was a glittering hero once more—the pet of the old, the envy of the young. His name even went into immortal print, for the village paper magnified him. There were some that believed he would be President, yet, if he escaped hanging.
As usual, the fickle, unreasoning world took Muff Potter to its bosom and fondled him as lavishly as it had abused him before. But that sort of conduct is to the world’s credit; therefore it is not well to find fault with it.

events.title: Daytime Glory, Night-time Terrors: Tom and Huck's Shared Dread
detailed_summary: While Tom's days were filled with public admiration and personal triumph, his nights were dominated by intense fear.
He was persistently troubled by nightmares featuring Injun Joe, who always appeared with a threatening demeanor.
This deep-seated fear made Tom extremely unwilling to go outside after dark.
Huck Finn was experiencing a similar state of profound misery and terror.
This shared fear stemmed from Tom having revealed the complete story of the murder to the lawyer on the night before the trial.
Huck was terrified that his own participation in the events might be discovered, even though Injun Joe's escape had absolved Huck of the need to testify in court.
Although Huck had obtained a promise of secrecy from the attorney, his trust in such assurances had been severely undermined.
Tom, compelled by his troubled conscience, had broken their most solemn and binding oath by confessing to the lawyer, which led Huck to lose nearly all faith in the reliability of people.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Tom’s days were days of splendor and exultation to him, but his nights were seasons of horror.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Since Tom’s harassed conscience had managed to drive him to the lawyer’s house by night and wring a dread tale from lips that had been sealed with the dismalest and most formidable of oaths, Huck’s confidence in the human race was wellnigh obliterated.

events.text_segment: Tom’s days were days of splendor and exultation to him, but his nights were seasons of horror. Injun Joe infested all his dreams, and always with doom in his eye. Hardly any temptation could persuade the boy to stir abroad after nightfall. Poor Huck was in the same state of wretchedness and terror, for Tom had told the whole story to the lawyer the night before the great day of the trial, and Huck was sore afraid that his share in the business might leak out, yet, notwithstanding Injun Joe’s flight had saved him the suffering of testifying in court. The poor fellow had got the attorney to promise secrecy, but what of that? Since Tom’s harassed conscience had managed to drive him to the lawyer’s house by night and wring a dread tale from lips that had been sealed with the dismalest and most formidable of oaths, Huck’s confidence in the human race was wellnigh obliterated.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
Tom’s days were days of splendor and exultation to him, but his nights were seasons of horror. While he basked in the admiration of the town and reveled in his personal triumphs, his sleep was haunted by nightmares of Injun Joe, who appeared with a threatening and menacing demeanor. These terrifying visions made Tom extremely unwilling to venture outside after dark, and he was often paralyzed by fear at the thought of Injun Joe lurking in the shadows.

Huck Finn was suffering a similar torment. He was overwhelmed by misery and terror, stemming from the knowledge that Tom had revealed the full story of the murder to the lawyer on the night before the trial. Huck feared that his own involvement in the events might be uncovered, even though Injun Joe’s escape had seemingly freed him from the obligation to testify in court. Despite having obtained a promise of secrecy from the attorney, Huck’s trust in such assurances was severely shaken.

Tom, driven by his troubled conscience, had broken their most solemn and binding oath by confessing to the lawyer, which caused Huck to lose nearly all faith in the reliability of people. The weight of guilt and fear pressed heavily upon both boys, casting a pall over their nights and filling their hearts with dread of the consequences that might follow.

events.title: Tom's Conflicted Conscience and the Fruitless Hunt for Injun Joe
detailed_summary: Muff Potter's daily expressions of gratitude made Tom feel that his decision to reveal the truth had been correct.
However, each night, Tom found himself wishing he had kept the secret.
Tom was caught in a cycle of conflicting anxieties: at times he feared Injun Joe would never be apprehended, and at other times he feared that he would be.
He felt a profound conviction that he would never be able to live without fear until Injun Joe was dead, and he had personally seen the evidence.
Rewards were publicized for Injun Joe's capture, and the surrounding countryside was thoroughly searched, yet he remained elusive.
A detective, described as an omniscient and awe-inspiring figure, arrived from St. Louis to investigate.
This detective meticulously went about his work, giving an impression of profound wisdom, but ultimately achieved the kind of limited success typical of his profession.
He announced he had found a “clew,” but such a piece of evidence was insufficient to secure a murder conviction.
Consequently, after the detective concluded his investigation and returned home, Tom's sense of insecurity remained as strong as before.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Daily Muff Potter’s gratitude made Tom glad he had spoken; but nightly he wished he had sealed up his tongue.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: That is to say, he “found a clew.” But you can’t hang a “clew” for murder, and so after that detective had got through and gone home, Tom felt just as insecure as he was before.

events.text_segment:
Daily Muff Potter’s gratitude made Tom glad he had spoken; but nightly he wished he had sealed up his tongue.
Half the time Tom was afraid Injun Joe would never be captured; the other half he was afraid he would be. He felt sure he never could draw a safe breath again until that man was dead and he had seen the corpse.
Rewards had been offered, the country had been scoured, but no Injun Joe was found. One of those omniscient and awe-inspiring marvels, a detective, came up from St. Louis, moused around, shook his head, looked wise, and made that sort of astounding success which members of that craft usually achieve. That is to say, he “found a clew.” But you can’t hang a “clew” for murder, and so after that detective had got through and gone home, Tom felt just as insecure as he was before.
