events.title: Tom Investigates the Taverns for 'Number Two'
detailed_summary: Tom instructed Huck to wait for him while he went to investigate the taverns, as he preferred not to have Huck's company in public establishments.
He returned after about half an hour.
His investigation revealed that in the more upscale tavern, Room No. 2 had been continuously occupied by a young lawyer for a considerable time.
However, in the less pretentious tavern, Room No. 2 was an enigma.
The tavern-keeper's young son informed Tom that this particular Room No. 2 was kept locked at all times.
The boy reported that he never witnessed anyone entering or exiting the room, except occasionally at night.
He was unaware of any specific reason for this secrecy and possessed only a mild curiosity about it.
He had amused himself by imagining that the room was 'haunted'.
Crucially, the boy mentioned having seen a light emanating from that room on the preceding night.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: You stay here, Huck, till I come.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: had noticed that there was a light in there the night before.

events.text_segment:
You stay here, Huck, till I come.”
Tom was off at once. He did not care to have Huck’s company in public places. He was gone half an hour. He found that in the best tavern, No. 2 had long been occupied by a young lawyer, and was still so occupied. In the less ostentatious house, No. 2 was a mystery. The tavern-keeper’s young son said it was kept locked all the time, and he never saw anybody go into it or come out of it except at night; he did not know any particular reason for this state of things; had had some little curiosity, but it was rather feeble; had made the most of the mystery by entertaining himself with the idea that that room was “ha’nted”; had noticed that there was a light in there the night before.

events.title: Tom and Huck Devise a Plan for Room No. 2 and Injun Joe
detailed_summary: Tom conveyed his findings to Huck, concluding that the mysterious Room No. 2 at the second tavern was their target.
Huck concurred with Tom's deduction.
After a lengthy period of thought, Tom outlined his plan.
He explained that the back door of this Room No. 2 opened into a small, confined alley situated between the tavern and an old, dilapidated brick store.
He proposed that both he and Huck should gather all the door keys they could find; Tom would take his aunt's keys.
Their strategy was to go there on the first dark night and attempt to open the door with the collected keys.
Tom also stressed the importance of keeping a lookout for Injun Joe, reminding Huck of Joe's threat to return to town to seek revenge.
If Huck spotted Injun Joe, he was to follow him discreetly to see if he went to that particular Room No. 2, as this would confirm it was the correct location.
Huck expressed significant apprehension, stating he did not want to follow Injun Joe by himself.
Tom attempted to reassure him, suggesting that since it would be nighttime, Injun Joe might not even see him, or if he did, might not think anything of it.
Huck hesitantly agreed to try tracking him if the conditions were dark enough.
Tom then asserted that he too would follow Injun Joe if it were dark, positing that Joe might have abandoned his revenge plans and be pursuing the money instead.
This encouraged Huck, who then enthusiastically committed to following Injun Joe.
Tom praised Huck's renewed determination and urged him to maintain his resolve, promising to do the same.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: That’s what I’ve found out, Huck.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Now you’re talking! Don’t you ever weaken, Huck, and I won’t.”

events.text_segment:
That’s what I’ve found out, Huck. I reckon that’s the very No. 2 we’re after.”
“I reckon it is, Tom. Now what you going to do?”
“Lemme think.”
Tom thought a long time. Then he said:
“I’ll tell you. The back door of that No. 2 is the door that comes out into that little close alley between the tavern and the old rattle trap of a brick store. Now you get hold of all the doorkeys you can find, and I’ll nip all of auntie’s, and the first dark night we’ll go there and try ’em. And mind you, keep a lookout for Injun Joe, because he said he was going to drop into town and spy around once more for a chance to get his revenge. If you see him, you just follow him; and if he don’t go to that No. 2, that ain’t the place.”
“Lordy, I don’t want to foller him by myself!”
“Why, it’ll be night, sure. He mightn’t ever see you—and if he did, maybe he’d never think anything.”
“Well, if it’s pretty dark I reckon I’ll track him. I dono—I dono. I’ll try.”
“You bet I’ll follow him, if it’s dark, Huck. Why, he might ’a’ found out he couldn’t get his revenge, and be going right after that money.”
“It’s so, Tom, it’s so. I’ll foller him; I will, by jingoes!”
“Now you’re talking! Don’t you ever weaken, Huck, and I won’t.”

events.title: Initial Night Vigil and Frustration
detailed_summary: Tom and Huck initiated their plan by observing the tavern vicinity, anticipating the appearance of the 'Spaniard'.
They established a surveillance system, with one watching the alley and the other the tavern entrance.
Their watch proved fruitless as no one matching the description or using the alley was seen.
Tom had arranged a signal with Huck: Huck was to 'maow' if conditions became dark enough for Tom to attempt using the keys to enter a specific location.
However, the night remained clear, and around midnight, Huck abandoned his post and went to sleep in an unoccupied sugar hogshead, their initial efforts unrewarded.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: That night Tom and Huck were ready for their adventure.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But the night remained clear, and Huck closed his watch and retired to bed in an empty sugar hogshead about twelve.

events.text_segment: That night Tom and Huck were ready for their adventure. They hung about the neighborhood of the tavern until after nine, one watching the alley at a distance and the other the tavern door. Nobody entered the alley or left it; nobody resembling the Spaniard entered or left the tavern door. The night promised to be a fair one; so Tom went home with the understanding that if a considerable degree of darkness came on, Huck was to come and “maow,” whereupon he would slip out and try the keys. But the night remained clear, and Huck closed his watch and retired to bed in an empty sugar hogshead about twelve.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text: That night Tom and Huck were ready for their adventure. They had watched the tavern and its surroundings, waiting for the Spaniard to appear. Tom had arranged a signal with Huck: if it grew dark enough, Huck was to 'maow' to let Tom know he could try to get in with the keys. They took their positions—one watching the alley, the other the tavern door—hoping to catch their man. But the night remained clear, and no sign of the Spaniard or anyone matching his description showed up. As midnight approached, Huck, tired of waiting, gave up his post and went to sleep in an empty sugar hogshead, their plan unfulfilled for that night.

events.title: Renewed Surveillance and Ominous Anticipation
detailed_summary: The boys experienced similar disappointment on Tuesday and Wednesday, with no sign of their target.
Thursday night, however, seemed more promising for their endeavor.
Tom equipped himself with his aunt's old tin lantern and a large towel to obscure its light when necessary.
He carefully hid the lantern in Huck's sugar hogshead, and the two resumed their watch.
An hour before midnight, the tavern ceased operations for the night, and its lights, the only ones in the immediate area, were extinguished, plunging the surroundings into darkness.

Despite the seemingly ideal conditions—no Spaniard sighted, no activity in the alley, profound darkness, and an eerie stillness broken only by the distant rumbling of thunder—their primary target remained elusive.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Tuesday the boys had the same ill luck.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The blackness of darkness reigned, the perfect stillness was interrupted only by occasional mutterings of distant thunder.

events.text_segment: Tuesday the boys had the same ill luck. Also Wednesday. But Thursday night promised better. Tom slipped out in good season with his aunt’s old tin lantern, and a large towel to blindfold it with. He hid the lantern in Huck’s sugar hogshead and the watch began. An hour before midnight the tavern closed up and its lights (the only ones thereabouts) were put out. No Spaniard had been seen. Nobody had entered or left the alley. Everything was auspicious. The blackness of darkness reigned, the perfect stillness was interrupted only by occasional mutterings of distant thunder.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text: Tuesday the boys had the same ill luck. They watched and waited, but no sign of the Spaniard or any activity in the alley. Wednesday brought no better fortune; their hopes were dashed again. Thursday night, however, seemed more promising. Tom took his aunt's old tin lantern and a large towel to hide its light when needed. He carefully hid the lantern in Huck's sugar hogshead, and they resumed their vigil. About an hour before midnight, the tavern shut down for the night, and its lights, the only ones nearby, were extinguished, leaving everything in darkness. Despite the perfect conditions—no Spaniard seen, no movement in the alley, complete darkness, and a strange stillness broken only by distant thunder—their target remained unseen.

events.title: Tom's Perilous Exploration and Urgent Escape
detailed_summary: Tom retrieved the lantern, lit it inside the hogshead, and carefully wrapped it in the towel to conceal its glow.
The two adventurers then stealthily made their way towards the tavern under the cover of darkness.
Huck took up a sentry position while Tom cautiously navigated his way into the alley.
An agonizing period of waiting ensued for Huck, his anxiety mounting with each passing moment, fearing the worst for Tom.
As time stretched on without any signal, Huck's dread intensified, leading him to imagine terrible scenarios and to unconsciously drift closer to the alley entrance, expecting an imminent disaster.
Suddenly, a brief flash of light emanated from the alley, and Tom burst out, urgently shouting for Huck to run for his life.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Tom got his lantern, lit it in the hogshead, wrapped it closely in the towel, and the two adventurers crept in the gloom toward the tavern.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Run!” said he; “run, for your life!”

events.text_segment: Tom got his lantern, lit it in the hogshead, wrapped it closely in the towel, and the two adventurers crept in the gloom toward the tavern. Huck stood sentry and Tom felt his way into the alley. Then there was a season of waiting anxiety that weighed upon Huck’s spirits like a mountain. He began to wish he could see a flash from the lantern—it would frighten him, but it would at least tell him that Tom was alive yet. It seemed hours since Tom had disappeared. Surely he must have fainted; maybe he was dead; maybe his heart had burst under terror and excitement. In his uneasiness Huck found himself drawing closer and closer to the alley; fearing all sorts of dreadful things, and momentarily expecting some catastrophe to happen that would take away his breath. There was not much to take away, for he seemed only able to inhale it by thimblefuls, and his heart would soon wear itself out, the way it was beating. Suddenly there was a flash of light and Tom came tearing by him: “Run!” said he; “run, for your life!”

events.title: Narrow Escape and Shocking Discovery of Injun Joe
detailed_summary: Huck immediately fled at Tom's warning, the two boys running at top speed until they found refuge in a dilapidated slaughter-house at the village's edge.
Just as they reached cover, a fierce storm broke, and rain began to pour down heavily.
Once Tom regained his breath, he began to recount the harrowing details of his experience inside.
He described how he cautiously tried two keys in the lock, but they made a startling amount of noise and failed to turn.
To his astonishment, upon impulsively trying the doorknob, he discovered the door was unlocked, and it swung open easily.
Stepping inside and removing the towel from the lantern, Tom was horrified to find he had almost stepped directly on Injun Joe, who was lying fast asleep on the floor.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He needn’t have repeated it; once was enough; Huck was making thirty or forty miles an hour before the repetition was uttered.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Yes! He was lying there, sound asleep on the floor, with his old patch on his eye and his arms spread out.”

events.text_segment:
He needn’t have repeated it; once was enough; Huck was making thirty or forty miles an hour before the repetition was uttered. The boys never stopped till they reached the shed of a deserted slaughter-house at the lower end of the village. Just as they got within its shelter the storm burst and the rain poured down. As soon as Tom got his breath he said:
“Huck, it was awful! I tried two of the keys, just as soft as I could; but they seemed to make such a power of racket that I couldn’t hardly get my breath I was so scared. They wouldn’t turn in the lock, either. Well, without noticing what I was doing, I took hold of the knob, and open comes the door! It warn’t locked! I hopped in, and shook off the towel, and, Great Caesar’s Ghost!”
“What!—what’d you see, Tom?”
“Huck, I most stepped onto Injun Joe’s hand!”
“No!”
“Yes! He was lying there, sound asleep on the floor, with his old patch on his eye and his arms spread out.”

events.title: The 'Whiskey-Haunted' Room and Cautious Reassessment
detailed_summary: Huck anxiously inquired if Injun Joe had awakened, but Tom confirmed he remained asleep, likely due to intoxication.
Tom explained his immediate reaction was to grab the towel and flee, partly motivated by the fear of his aunt's displeasure if he lost it.
He admitted he hadn't seen the treasure box or any cross, his attention fixed on Injun Joe and the surrounding indicators of alcohol: a bottle, a tin cup, two barrels, and numerous other bottles.
Tom then wryly theorized that the 'ha'nted room' was actually haunted by whiskey, jokingly suggesting that perhaps all Temperance Taverns concealed similar secrets.
Huck, seizing on Injun Joe's drunken state, proposed it was an opportune moment to retrieve the box.

However, both boys quickly dismissed the idea as too perilous; Tom reasoned that a single bottle beside Injun Joe wasn't sufficient guarantee of his incapacitation, suggesting three bottles would make him feel safer to attempt it.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Lordy, what did you do? Did he wake up?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: If there’d been three, he’d be drunk enough and I’d do it.”

events.text_segment:
“Lordy, what did you do? Did he wake up?”
“No, never budged. Drunk, I reckon. I just grabbed that towel and started!”
“I’d never ’a’ thought of the towel, I bet!”
“Well, I would. My aunt would make me mighty sick if I lost it.”
“Say, Tom, did you see that box?”
“Huck, I didn’t wait to look around. I didn’t see the box, I didn’t see the cross. I didn’t see anything but a bottle and a tin cup on the floor by Injun Joe; yes, I saw two barrels and lots more bottles in the room. Don’t you see, now, what’s the matter with that ha’nted room?”
“How?”
“Why, it’s ha’nted with whiskey! Maybe all the Temperance Taverns have got a ha’nted room, hey, Huck?”
“Well, I reckon maybe that’s so. Who’d ’a’ thought such a thing? But say, Tom, now’s a mighty good time to get that box, if Injun Joe’s drunk.”
“It is, that! You try it!”
Huck shuddered.
“Well, no—I reckon not.”
“And I reckon not, Huck. Only one bottle alongside of Injun Joe ain’t enough. If there’d been three, he’d be drunk enough and I’d do it.”

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
Lordy, what did you do? Did he wake up?"

"No, he’s still asleep," Tom said, with a cautious glance at Injun Joe, who was lying there, evidently drunk, with a bottle and a tin cup beside him. "I just grabbed the towel and made a run for it, mostly because I was afraid Aunt Polly would be mad if I lost it."

"Did you see the treasure box or any cross?" Huck asked eagerly.

"No, I didn’t see anything but Injun Joe and the bottles—there’s a bottle, a tin cup, two barrels, and a lot of other bottles around."

Tom chuckled softly. "I reckon that’s what’s haunted in that room—whiskey. Maybe all Temperance Taverns hide secrets like this."

Huck’s eyes sparkled. "Now’s our chance! Injun Joe’s drunk—he’s as helpless as a baby. We could grab the box while he’s out cold."

"Hold on," Tom said, shaking his head. "One bottle beside him isn’t enough. He might just be tipsy. We’d need three bottles to feel safe enough to try it."

They both looked at Injun Joe, contemplating the risk and the reward, their hearts pounding with the thrill of the secret they were about to uncover.

events.title: New Surveillance Plan and Huck's Living Arrangements
detailed_summary: After a period of reflection, Tom proposed a new strategy: they should avoid further attempts to enter the room until they were certain Injun Joe was absent.
He suggested they maintain a nightly watch to observe Injun Joe leaving, at which point they could quickly seize the treasure box.
Huck readily agreed to undertake the all-night surveillance every night, provided Tom would handle the retrieval of the box.
Tom consented to this division of labor and established a signaling system: Huck was to go to Hooper Street and 'maow', or if Tom was asleep, throw gravel at his window.
With the storm having passed, Tom announced his intention to return home as daylight was approaching.
Huck reaffirmed his commitment to watch the tavern vigilantly every night, planning to sleep during the daytime.

He explained his sleeping arrangements in Ben Rogers' hayloft, a privilege granted by Ben and his father's enslaved man, Uncle Jake, with whom Huck had a friendly rapport based on mutual respect and small exchanges of service for food.
Tom assured Huck he wouldn't disturb him during the day and reminded him of the 'maow' signal for any nighttime developments.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Any time you see something’s up, in the night, just skip right around and maow.”

events.text_segment:
There was a long pause for reflection, and then Tom said:
“Lookyhere, Huck, less not try that thing any more till we know Injun Joe’s not in there. It’s too scary. Now, if we watch every night, we’ll be dead sure to see him go out, some time or other, and then we’ll snatch that box quicker’n lightning.”
“Well, I’m agreed. I’ll watch the whole night long, and I’ll do it every night, too, if you’ll do the other part of the job.”
“All right, I will. All you got to do is to trot up Hooper Street a block and maow—and if I’m asleep, you throw some gravel at the window and that’ll fetch me.”
“Agreed, and good as wheat!”
“Now, Huck, the storm’s over, and I’ll go home. It’ll begin to be daylight in a couple of hours. You go back and watch that long, will you?”
“I said I would, Tom, and I will. I’ll ha’nt that tavern every night for a year! I’ll sleep all day and I’ll stand watch all night.”
“That’s all right. Now, where you going to sleep?”
“In Ben Rogers’ hayloft. He lets me, and so does his pap’s nigger man, Uncle Jake. I tote water for Uncle Jake whenever he wants me to, and any time I ask him he gives me a little something to eat if he can spare it. That’s a mighty good nigger, Tom. He likes me, becuz I don’t ever act as if I was above him. Sometime I’ve set right down and eat with him. But you needn’t tell that. A body’s got to do things when he’s awful hungry he wouldn’t want to do as a steady thing.”
“Well, if I don’t want you in the daytime, I’ll let you sleep. I won’t come bothering around. Any time you see something’s up, in the night, just skip right around and maow.”

events.title: Picnic Anticipation and Tom's Disappointment
detailed_summary: Tom was delighted to learn of the Thatcher family's return, momentarily overshadowing his thoughts of Injun Joe and the treasure.
His primary focus shifted to Becky Thatcher.
He encountered Becky, and they, along with other schoolmates, enjoyed games like "hispy" and "gully-keeper."
The day culminated with Becky successfully persuading her mother to schedule the long-awaited picnic for the following day.
Becky's joy was immense, and Tom shared her enthusiasm.
Invitations were dispatched before evening, throwing the village's young people into a flurry of preparation and eager anticipation.
Tom's excitement kept him awake late into the night, hoping to hear Huck's signal so he could impress Becky and the others with the treasure, but no signal came.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: No signal came that night.

events.text_segment: The first thing Tom heard on Friday morning was a glad piece of news—Judge Thatcher’s family had come back to town the night before. Both Injun Joe and the treasure sunk into secondary importance for a moment, and Becky took the chief place in the boy’s interest. He saw her and they had an exhausting good time playing “hispy” and “gully-keeper” with a crowd of their schoolmates. The day was completed and crowned in a peculiarly satisfactory way: Becky teased her mother to appoint the next day for the long-promised and long-delayed picnic, and she consented. The child’s delight was boundless; and Tom’s not more moderate. The invitations were sent out before sunset, and straightway the young folks of the village were thrown into a fever of preparation and pleasurable anticipation. Tom’s excitement enabled him to keep awake until a pretty late hour, and he had good hopes of hearing Huck’s “maow,” and of having his treasure to astonish Becky and the picnickers with, next day; but he was disappointed. No signal came that night.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
The first thing Tom heard on Friday morning was a glad piece of news—Judge Thatcher’s family had come back to town the night before. This news filled Tom with delight, momentarily overshadowing his thoughts of Injun Joe and the treasure. His mind quickly shifted to Becky Thatcher, and soon he was on his way to school, eager to see her.

At school, Tom encountered Becky, and together with their classmates, they enjoyed playing games like "hispy" and "gully-keeper." The day passed quickly, and Becky, full of joy, managed to persuade her mother to allow a picnic the next day—a long-anticipated event. Becky’s happiness was contagious, and Tom shared her excitement.

Before evening, invitations were sent out, and the village’s young people buzzed with preparations and eager anticipation. That night, Tom lay awake late, hoping to hear Huck’s signal so he could impress Becky and the others with the treasure, but no signal came, and he drifted into sleep, dreaming of the adventures to come.

events.title: Picnic Departure and Tom's Secret Plan with Becky
detailed_summary: By late morning the next day, a cheerful group had assembled at Judge Thatcher's residence, ready for the picnic.
It was customary for older adults not to join, with the children being supervised by a few young women and men.
An old steam ferry-boat was hired for the excursion, and the group, carrying food baskets, paraded up the main street.
Sid was unwell and couldn't attend, so Mary stayed home to care for him.
Mrs. Thatcher advised Becky that she might return late and suggested she stay overnight with a friend near the ferry landing.
Becky decided she would stay with Susy Harper.
Mrs. Thatcher agreed, reminding Becky to behave well.
While walking, Tom proposed to Becky that instead of going to Joe Harper's, they should visit the Widow Douglas, who often had plenty of ice cream and would be pleased to see them.
Becky thought it sounded enjoyable but then expressed concern about her mother's potential disapproval.
Tom reassured her, arguing her mother wouldn't find out and would likely have approved if she'd considered it, as her main concern was Becky's safety.
The allure of the Widow Douglas's hospitality and Tom's persuasion convinced Becky, and they agreed to keep their evening plans a secret.
Tom then considered the possibility of Huck signaling that night, which dampened his excitement somewhat.
However, he reasoned that since no signal came the previous night, it was unlikely to come this night, and decided the definite fun at Widow Douglas's outweighed the uncertain treasure.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The sure fun of the evening outweighed the uncertain treasure; and, boy-like, he determined to yield to the stronger inclination and not allow himself to think of the box of money another time that day.

events.text_segment:
Morning came, eventually, and by ten or eleven o’clock a giddy and rollicking company were gathered at Judge Thatcher’s, and everything was ready for a start. It was not the custom for elderly people to mar the picnics with their presence. The children were considered safe enough under the wings of a few young ladies of eighteen and a few young gentlemen of twenty-three or thereabouts. The old steam ferry-boat was chartered for the occasion; presently the gay throng filed up the main street laden with provision-baskets. Sid was sick and had to miss the fun; Mary remained at home to entertain him. The last thing Mrs. Thatcher said to Becky, was:
“You’ll not get back till late. Perhaps you’d better stay all night with some of the girls that live near the ferry-landing, child.”
“Then I’ll stay with Susy Harper, mamma.”
“Very well. And mind and behave yourself and don’t be any trouble.”
Presently, as they tripped along, Tom said to Becky:
“Say—I’ll tell you what we’ll do. ’Stead of going to Joe Harper’s we’ll climb right up the hill and stop at the Widow Douglas’. She’ll have ice-cream! She has it most every day—dead loads of it. And she’ll be awful glad to have us.”
“Oh, that will be fun!”
Then Becky reflected a moment and said:
“But what will mamma say?”
“How’ll she ever know?”
The girl turned the idea over in her mind, and said reluctantly:
“I reckon it’s wrong—but—”
“But shucks! Your mother won’t know, and so what’s the harm? All she wants is that you’ll be safe; and I bet you she’d ’a’ said go there if she’d ’a’ thought of it. I know she would!”
The Widow Douglas’ splendid hospitality was a tempting bait. It and Tom’s persuasions presently carried the day. So it was decided to say nothing to anybody about the night’s programme. Presently it occurred to Tom that maybe Huck might come this very night and give the signal. The thought took a deal of the spirit out of his anticipations. Still he could not bear to give up the fun at Widow Douglas’. And why should he give it up, he reasoned—the signal did not come the night before, so why should it be any more likely to come tonight? The sure fun of the evening outweighed the uncertain treasure; and, boy-like, he determined to yield to the stronger inclination and not allow himself to think of the box of money another time that day.

events.title: Arrival at the Hollow and Initial Cave Exploration
detailed_summary: The ferryboat journeyed three miles downstream and docked at the entrance of a forested valley.
The group disembarked, and their lively shouts and laughter soon filled the woods and echoed off the nearby cliffs.
After engaging in various activities that left them hot and tired, the picnickers returned to their camp with hearty appetites and began to enjoy the food.
Following the meal, they relaxed and chatted in the shade of large oak trees.
Soon, someone proposed exploring the nearby cave.
The idea was met with universal enthusiasm, and after obtaining bundles of candles, everyone hurried up the hill towards the cave.
The cave's entrance was high on the hillside, shaped like the letter 'A', with its large oak door open.
Inside, a small chamber felt as cold as an icehouse, its limestone walls damp with condensation.
The atmosphere was initially perceived as romantic and mysterious, looking out from the darkness into the sunlit valley.
However, this solemn mood quickly dissipated, and playful activities resumed.
Lighting a candle would trigger a friendly scuffle for it, often resulting in the candle being knocked over or extinguished, followed by laughter and more chasing.
Eventually, the group formed a procession and descended into the main passage of the cave, their flickering lights casting dim illumination on the high rock walls.
This primary passage was relatively narrow, with even narrower crevices branching off frequently.
McDougal's cave was known as a vast, interconnected labyrinth with no discernible end, where one could wander for days without finding an exit.
It was said that no one truly knew the entirety of the cave.
While most young men were familiar with a section of it, they rarely ventured beyond that known area. Tom Sawyer's knowledge of the cave was comparable to anyone else's.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Three miles below town the ferryboat stopped at the mouth of a woody hollow and tied up.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Tom Sawyer knew as much of the cave as any one.

events.text_segment:
Three miles below town the ferryboat stopped at the mouth of a woody hollow and tied up. The crowd swarmed ashore and soon the forest distances and craggy heights echoed far and near with shoutings and laughter. All the different ways of getting hot and tired were gone through with, and by-and-by the rovers straggled back to camp fortified with responsible appetites, and then the destruction of the good things began. After the feast there was a refreshing season of rest and chat in the shade of spreading oaks. By-and-by somebody shouted:
“Who’s ready for the cave?”
Everybody was. Bundles of candles were procured, and straightway there was a general scamper up the hill. The mouth of the cave was up the hillside—an opening shaped like a letter A. Its massive oaken door stood unbarred. Within was a small chamber, chilly as an icehouse, and walled by Nature with solid limestone that was dewy with a cold sweat. It was romantic and mysterious to stand here in the deep gloom and look out upon the green valley shining in the sun. But the impressiveness of the situation quickly wore off, and the romping began again. The moment a candle was lighted there was a general rush upon the owner of it; a struggle and a gallant defence followed, but the candle was soon knocked down or blown out, and then there was a glad clamor of laughter and a new chase. But all things have an end. By-and-by the procession went filing down the steep descent of the main avenue, the flickering rank of lights dimly revealing the lofty walls of rock almost to their point of junction sixty feet overhead. This main avenue was not more than eight or ten feet wide. Every few steps other lofty and still narrower crevices branched from it on either hand—for McDougal’s cave was but a vast labyrinth of crooked aisles that ran into each other and out again and led nowhere. It was said that one might wander days and nights together through its intricate tangle of rifts and chasms, and never find the end of the cave; and that he might go down, and down, and still down, into the earth, and it was just the same—labyrinth under labyrinth, and no end to any of them. No man “knew” the cave. That was an impossible thing. Most of the young men knew a portion of it, and it was not customary to venture much beyond this known portion. Tom Sawyer knew as much of the cave as any one.

events.title: Cave Games, Late Return, and Ferry Departure
detailed_summary: The group advanced about three-quarters of a mile along the main passage of the cave.
Then, smaller groups and pairs began to venture into the side passages, navigating the dark corridors and playfully surprising each other where paths rejoined.
They managed to evade one another for up to half an hour without going beyond the commonly known sections of the cave.
Gradually, one group after another made their way back to the cave entrance, out of breath, joyful, covered in candle wax and clay, and thoroughly pleased with their day's adventure.
They were surprised to discover they had lost track of time and that evening was approaching.
The ferryboat's bell had been ringing for half an hour to summon them.
Nevertheless, they found this conclusion to their day's adventures to be romantic and pleasing.
As the ferryboat, carrying its exuberant passengers, moved into the river, only the boat's captain was concerned about the time spent; the others were unbothered.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The procession moved along the main avenue some three-quarters of a mile, and then groups and couples began to slip aside into branch avenues, fly along the dismal corridors, and take each other by surprise at points where the corridors joined again.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: When the ferryboat with her wild freight pushed into the stream, nobody cared sixpence for the wasted time but the captain of the craft.

events.text_segment:
The procession moved along the main avenue some three-quarters of a mile, and then groups and couples began to slip aside into branch avenues, fly along the dismal corridors, and take each other by surprise at points where the corridors joined again. Parties were able to elude each other for the space of half an hour without going beyond the “known” ground.
By-and-by, one group after another came straggling back to the mouth of the cave, panting, hilarious, smeared from head to foot with tallow drippings, daubed with clay, and entirely delighted with the success of the day. Then they were astonished to find that they had been taking no note of time and that night was about at hand. The clanging bell had been calling for half an hour. However, this sort of close to the day’s adventures was romantic and therefore satisfactory. When the ferryboat with her wild freight pushed into the stream, nobody cared sixpence for the wasted time but the captain of the craft.

events.title: Huck's Lonely Vigil and Diminishing Hope
detailed_summary: Huck was already at his observation post when he saw the lights of the ferryboat passing the wharf.
He noticed the silence from the boat, attributing it to the passengers being extremely tired.
He briefly wondered about the boat and why it didn't dock, then dismissed it to focus on his task.
The night was becoming overcast and dark.

At ten o'clock, vehicular sounds ceased, lights in houses started going out, and people walking about disappeared; the village settled into sleep, leaving Huck alone with the quiet and his thoughts of ghosts.
When eleven o'clock arrived, the tavern lights were extinguished, plunging everything into darkness.
Huck waited for what felt like an extremely long and tedious period, but nothing occurred.
His confidence began to wane, and he questioned the utility of his vigil, contemplating whether to abandon it and go to sleep.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Huck was already upon his watch when the ferryboat’s lights went glinting past the wharf.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Why not give it up and turn in?

events.text_segment: Huck was already upon his watch when the ferryboat’s lights went glinting past the wharf. He heard no noise on board, for the young people were as subdued and still as people usually are who are nearly tired to death. He wondered what boat it was, and why she did not stop at the wharf—and then he dropped her out of his mind and put his attention upon his business. The night was growing cloudy and dark. Ten o’clock came, and the noise of vehicles ceased, scattered lights began to wink out, all straggling foot-passengers disappeared, the village betook itself to its slumbers and left the small watcher alone with the silence and the ghosts. Eleven o’clock came, and the tavern lights were put out; darkness everywhere, now. Huck waited what seemed a weary long time, but nothing happened. His faith was weakening. Was there any use? Was there really any use? Why not give it up and turn in?

events.title: Huck Spots Injun Joe and Follows the Villains
detailed_summary: A sound suddenly caught Huck's attention.
He became instantly alert as he heard an alley door close quietly.
He quickly hid behind the corner of a brick store.
Moments later, two men walked past him, one appearing to carry something under his arm, which Huck assumed was the treasure box.
He concluded they were moving the treasure and decided against calling Tom, believing it would be futile as the men would escape.
Instead, he resolved to follow them, relying on the darkness to remain unseen.
Huck silently trailed the men as they walked up river street for three blocks, then turned left onto a cross-street.
They continued straight until they reached the path leading up Cardiff Hill, which they took.
They passed the old Welshman's house halfway up the hill without stopping and kept climbing.
Huck thought they might be heading to bury the treasure in the old quarry.
However, they passed the quarry and continued towards the summit.
They entered a narrow path between tall sumach bushes, disappearing into the darkness.
Huck moved closer, confident they wouldn't see him.
He trotted for a bit, then slowed, worried he was approaching too quickly, and eventually stopped to listen.
He heard no sound except what he thought was his own heartbeat, and then the ominous hoot of an owl.
With no sound of footsteps, he feared he had lost them and was about to rush forward when a man cleared his throat just a few feet away.
Huck's heart leaped, but he regained composure, though he stood there trembling intensely, feeling so weak he thought he might collapse.
He realized his location: within a few steps of the stile leading into Widow Douglas's property, and thought they might bury the treasure there, making it easy to find.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: A noise fell upon his ear.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Very well, he thought, let them bury it there; it won’t be hard to find.

events.text_segment:
A noise fell upon his ear. He was all attention in an instant. The alley door closed softly. He sprang to the corner of the brick store. The next moment two men brushed by him, and one seemed to have something under his arm. It must be that box! So they were going to remove the treasure. Why call Tom now? It would be absurd—the men would get away with the box and never be found again. No, he would stick to their wake and follow them; he would trust to the darkness for security from discovery. So communing with himself, Huck stepped out and glided along behind the men, cat-like, with bare feet, allowing them to keep just far enough ahead not to be invisible.
They moved up the river street three blocks, then turned to the left up a crossstreet. They went straight ahead, then, until they came to the path that led up Cardiff Hill; this they took. They passed by the old Welshman’s house, halfway up the hill, without hesitating, and still climbed upward. Good, thought Huck, they will bury it in the old quarry. But they never stopped at the quarry. They passed on, up the summit. They plunged into the narrow path between the tall sumach bushes, and were at once hidden in the gloom. Huck closed up and shortened his distance, now, for they would never be able to see him. He trotted along awhile; then slackened his pace, fearing he was gaining too fast; moved on a piece, then stopped altogether; listened; no sound; none, save that he seemed to hear the beating of his own heart. The hooting of an owl came over the hill—ominous sound! But no footsteps. Heavens, was everything lost! He was about to spring with winged feet, when a man cleared his throat not four feet from him! Huck’s heart shot into his throat, but he swallowed it again; and then he stood there shaking as if a dozen agues had taken charge of him at once, and so weak that he thought he must surely fall to the ground. He knew where he was. He knew he was within five steps of the stile leading into Widow Douglas’ grounds. Very well, he thought, let them bury it there; it won’t be hard to find.

A moment later, two men passed by, one carrying something under his arm—Huck guessed it was the treasure box. He decided they were moving the treasure and that calling Tom would be useless; the men would escape before help arrived. Instead, Huck resolved to follow them, trusting the darkness to conceal him.

He trailed silently as they walked up River Street for three blocks, then turned left onto a cross-street. They kept straight until reaching the path leading up Cardiff Hill, which they ascended. They passed the old Welshman's house halfway up without stopping and continued climbing. Huck thought they might be heading to bury the treasure in the old quarry, but they passed it and kept going toward the summit.

They entered a narrow path between tall sumach bushes and vanished into the darkness. Huck moved closer, confident they wouldn't see him. He trotted a bit, then slowed, worried he was approaching too quickly, and finally stopped to listen. All he heard was his own heartbeat and the distant hoot of an owl. No footsteps—he feared he had lost them—and was about to rush forward when a man cleared his throat just a few feet away.

Huck's heart leaped into his throat, but he steadied himself, though he trembled intensely, feeling so weak he thought he might faint. He realized his position: just a few steps from the stile leading into Widow Douglas's property. He thought they might bury the treasure there, making it easy to find.

events.title: Huck Overhears Injun Joe's Horrifying Revenge Plan
detailed_summary: Huck then heard a very quiet voice, which he recognized as Injun Joe's, remarking about lights at Widow Douglas's house despite the late hour.
Another voice, that of the stranger from the haunted house, replied that he couldn't see any lights.
A sudden chill struck Huck as he understood that this was the "revenge" Injun Joe had spoken of.
His first instinct was to run, but then he recalled Widow Douglas's past kindness to him and worried that the men intended to murder her.
He wished he had the courage to warn her but knew he was too afraid, as they might catch him.
Injun Joe then directed the stranger's attention, saying a bush was obstructing his view, and pointed out the lights.
The stranger acknowledged the lights and suggested they abandon their plan due to the company.

Injun Joe vehemently refused, stating he was about to leave the country permanently and might not get another chance. He reiterated that he didn't care about her money, which the stranger could have, but was driven by revenge against her late husband.
He recounted how her husband, as justice of the peace, had imprisoned him for vagrancy and, most significantly, had him publicly horsewhipped, an indignity he could not forget.
The stranger begged Injun Joe not to kill the Widow.
Injun Joe clarified his intent was not murder but disfigurement; he planned to slit her nostrils and notch her ears as a form of revenge on a woman.
When the stranger started to object, Injun Joe warned him to keep his opinions to himself for his own safety.
He detailed his plan to tie her to the bed, indifferent to whether she bled to death, and asserted that the stranger must assist him.
He threatened to kill the stranger if he hesitated, and then the Widow as well, ensuring no one would know who committed the crime.
The terrified stranger reluctantly agreed, urging to get it over with quickly.
Injun Joe, however, decided against immediate action due to the lights indicating company, opting to wait until the lights were extinguished.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Now there was a voice—a very low voice—Injun Joe’s:
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: No—we’ll wait till the lights are out—there’s no hurry.

events.text_segment:
Now there was a voice—a very low voice—Injun Joe’s:
“Damn her, maybe she’s got company—there’s lights, late as it is.”
“I can’t see any.”
This was that stranger’s voice—the stranger of the haunted house. A deadly chill went to Huck’s heart—this, then, was the “revenge” job! His thought was, to fly. Then he remembered that the Widow Douglas had been kind to him more than once, and maybe these men were going to murder her. He wished he dared venture to warn her; but he knew he didn’t dare—they might come and catch him. He thought all this and more in the moment that elapsed between the stranger’s remark and Injun Joe’s next—which was—
“Because the bush is in your way. Now—this way—now you see, don’t you?”
“Yes. Well, there is company there, I reckon. Better give it up.”
“Give it up, and I just leaving this country forever! Give it up and maybe never have another chance. I tell you again, as I’ve told you before, I don’t care for her swag—you may have it. But her husband was rough on me—many times he was rough on me—and mainly he was the justice of the peace that jugged me for a vagrant. And that ain’t all. It ain’t a millionth part of it! He had me horsewhipped!—horsewhipped in front of the jail, like a nigger!—with all the town looking on! Horsewhipped!—do you understand? He took advantage of me and died. But I’ll take it out of her.”
“Oh, don’t kill her! Don’t do that!”
“Kill? Who said anything about killing? I would kill him if he was here; but not her. When you want to get revenge on a woman you don’t kill her—bosh! you go for her looks. You slit her nostrils—you notch her ears like a sow!”
“By God, that’s—”
“Keep your opinion to yourself! It will be safest for you. I’ll tie her to the bed. If she bleeds to death, is that my fault? I’ll not cry, if she does. My friend, you’ll help me in this thing—for my sake—that’s why you’re here—I mightn’t be able alone. If you flinch, I’ll kill you. Do you understand that? And if I have to kill you, I’ll kill her—and then I reckon nobody’ll ever know much about who done this business.”
“Well, if it’s got to be done, let’s get at it. The quicker the better—I’m all in a shiver.”
“Do it now? And company there? Look here—I’ll get suspicious of you, first thing you know. No—we’ll wait till the lights are out—there’s no hurry.

Now there was a voice—a very low voice—Injun Joe’s: “Did you see the lights at Widow Douglas’s house?”

Another voice, that of the Stranger, replied, “No, I can’t see any lights.”

Huck shivered as he understood that this was the revenge Injun Joe had spoken of. His first impulse was to run, but he remembered Widow Douglas’s past kindness to him and feared they might be planning to murder her.

He wished he had the courage to warn her, but he was too afraid they might catch him.

Injun Joe then pointed out a bush that was obstructing the stranger’s view and said, “There, you see the lights now.”

The Stranger acknowledged the lights and suggested they abandon their plan because of the company.

Injun Joe, vehement, refused, saying, “I’m about to leave the country for good, and I might not get another chance. I don’t care about her money—she can have that—but I want revenge for what her late husband did to me.”

He recounted how her husband, as justice of the peace, had imprisoned him for vagrancy and, most humiliating, had horsewhipped him in public, an insult he could never forget.

The Stranger begged Injun Joe not to kill the Widow.

Injun Joe clarified that his plan was not murder but disfigurement; he intended to slit her nostrils and notch her ears as a form of revenge.

When the Stranger hesitated, Injun Joe warned him to keep his opinions to himself for his own safety.

He detailed his plan to tie her to the bed, indifferent whether she bled to death, and insisted that the Stranger must help him.

He threatened to kill the Stranger if he hesitated, and then the Widow herself, so no one would know who committed the crime.

The Stranger, terrified, agreed reluctantly, urging to get it over with quickly.

Injun Joe, however, decided to wait until the lights went out, as they indicated company was still present.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_2.text:
Now there was a voice—a very low voice—Injun Joe’s: “Did you see the lights at Widow Douglas’s house?”

Another voice, that of the Stranger, replied, “No, I can’t see any lights.”

Huck’s heart gave a leap. He knew then that this was the revenge Injun Joe had spoken of. His first thought was to run, but he remembered Widow Douglas’s kindness to him and feared they might be planning to kill her.

He wished he had the courage to warn her, but he was too afraid they might catch him.

Injun Joe then pointed out a bush that was blocking the stranger’s view and said, “There, you see the lights now.”

The Stranger acknowledged the lights and said, “Well, I reckon we’d better leave it alone; there’s company there.”

Injun Joe’s eyes flashed with fury. “No,” he said, “I’m about to leave the country for good, and I might not get another chance. I don’t care about her money—she can have that—but I want revenge for what her late husband did to me.”

He recounted how her husband, as justice of the peace, had imprisoned him for vagrancy and, most humiliating, had horsewhipped him in public, an insult he could never forget.

The Stranger begged him, “Don’t do anything rash, Injun Joe. Don’t kill the Widow.”

Injun Joe’s face twisted with rage. “It’s not murder I’m after,” he said, “but disfigurement. I’ll slit her nostrils and notch her ears—she’ll remember me then.”

The Stranger started to object, but Injun Joe cut him off. “Keep your opinions to yourself,” he warned. “If you value your skin, you’ll help me. Tie her to the bed, and I’ll do the rest. I don’t care if she bleeds to death. And if you hesitate, I’ll kill you too—and the Widow after that, so no one will ever know who did it.”

The Stranger, trembling, nodded quickly. “All right, let’s get it over with.”

Injun Joe paused, then decided to wait until the lights went out, for they still had company, and he didn’t want to be caught in the act.

events.title: Huck's Daring Escape and Warning to the Welshman
detailed_summary: Anticipating a dreadful silence, Huck began to retreat with extreme caution, balancing precariously with each step.
He took several careful steps back when a twig snapped under his foot.
He froze, holding his breath, but heard no reaction from the men; the stillness was complete, and he was immensely grateful.
He then turned carefully, like a ship maneuvering, and moved quickly but cautiously along the path.
Upon reaching the quarry, he felt safer and ran as fast as he could down the hill until he arrived at the Welshman's house.
He knocked urgently on the door, and soon the old man and his two strong sons appeared at the windows demanding to know who was there and what they wanted.
Huck identified himself and pleaded to be let in quickly, promising to explain everything.
The Welshman, remarking that Huckleberry Finn was not a name that usually opened doors, nevertheless instructed his sons to let him in to see what the matter was.

Once inside, Huck's first words were a plea for them never to reveal that he was the one who told them, expressing fear of being killed, but stating he had to tell because the widow had been kind to him.
The old man, convinced by Huck's earnestness that he had something important to say, promised that no one there would betray him.
Three minutes later, the Welshman and his sons, armed, were heading up the hill, entering the sumach path stealthily with weapons ready. Huck did not go further with them.
He concealed himself behind a large boulder and listened intently.
After a period of tense silence, there was a sudden sound of gunfire and a shout.
Huck did not stay to learn more; he immediately ran away, speeding down the hill as fast as his legs could take him.

events.text_segment:
Huck felt that a silence was going to ensue—a thing still more awful than any amount of murderous talk; so he held his breath and stepped gingerly back; planted his foot carefully and firmly, after balancing, one-legged, in a precarious way and almost toppling over, first on one side and then on the other. He took another step back, with the same elaboration and the same risks; then another and another, and—a twig snapped under his foot! His breath stopped and he listened. There was no sound—the stillness was perfect. His gratitude was measureless. Now he turned in his tracks, between the walls of sumach bushes—turned himself as carefully as if he were a ship—and then stepped quickly but cautiously along. When he emerged at the quarry he felt secure, and so he picked up his nimble heels and flew. Down, down he sped, till he reached the Welshman’s. He banged at the door, and presently the heads of the old man and his two stalwart sons were thrust from windows.
“What’s the row there? Who’s banging? What do you want?”
“Let me in—quick! I’ll tell everything.”
“Why, who are you?”
“Huckleberry Finn—quick, let me in!”
“Huckleberry Finn, indeed! It ain’t a name to open many doors, I judge! But let him in, lads, and let’s see what’s the trouble.”
“Please don’t ever tell I told you,” were Huck’s first words when he got in. “Please don’t—I’d be killed, sure—but the widow’s been good friends to me sometimes, and I want to tell—I will tell if you’ll promise you won’t ever say it was me.”
“By George, he has got something to tell, or he wouldn’t act so!” exclaimed the old man; “out with it and nobody here’ll ever tell, lad.”
Three minutes later the old man and his sons, well armed, were up the hill, and just entering the sumach path on tiptoe, their weapons in their hands. Huck accompanied them no further. He hid behind a great bowlder and fell to listening. There was a lagging, anxious silence, and then all of a sudden there was an explosion of firearms and a cry.
Huck waited for no particulars. He sprang away and sped down the hill as fast as his legs could carry him.

events.title: Huck's Arrival and Account of the Failed Capture
detailed_summary: Huck Finn arrives at the Welshman's house at dawn, seeking entry.
He is warmly welcomed, an unfamiliar and pleasant experience for him.
The Welshman and his sons quickly dress, offering Huck breakfast and a place to rest.
Huck recounts his fear during the previous night's gunfire, explaining he fled a long distance and returned to learn what happened, careful to avoid the criminals.
The Welshman explains their attempt to capture the villains, detailing how a sneeze alerted the criminals, leading to an exchange of gunfire and the villains' escape into the woods.
He mentions that authorities are now searching the woods and riverbank.
Huck provides a description of the two men, identifying one as an old deaf and dumb Spaniard and the other as a ragged individual.
The Welshman recognizes the description, recalling a previous encounter, and immediately sends his sons to inform the sheriff.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: As the earliest suspicion of dawn appeared on Sunday morning, Huck came groping up the hill and rapped gently at the old Welshman’s door.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Off with you, boys, and tell the sheriff—get your breakfast tomorrow morning!”

events.text_segment:
As the earliest suspicion of dawn appeared on Sunday morning, Huck came groping up the hill and rapped gently at the old Welshman’s door. The inmates were asleep, but it was a sleep that was set on a hair-trigger, on account of the exciting episode of the night. A call came from a window:
“Who’s there!”
Huck’s scared voice answered in a low tone:
“Please let me in! It’s only Huck Finn!”
“It’s a name that can open this door night or day, lad!—and welcome!”
These were strange words to the vagabond boy’s ears, and the pleasantest he had ever heard. He could not recollect that the closing word had ever been applied in his case before. The door was quickly unlocked, and he entered. Huck was given a seat and the old man and his brace of tall sons speedily dressed themselves.
“Now, my boy, I hope you’re good and hungry, because breakfast will be ready as soon as the sun’s up, and we’ll have a piping hot one, too—make yourself easy about that! I and the boys hoped you’d turn up and stop here last night.”
“I was awful scared,” said Huck, “and I run. I took out when the pistols went off, and I didn’t stop for three mile. I’ve come now becuz I wanted to know about it, you know; and I come before daylight becuz I didn’t want to run across them devils, even if they was dead.”
“Well, poor chap, you do look as if you’d had a hard night of it—but there’s a bed here for you when you’ve had your breakfast. No, they ain’t dead, lad—we are sorry enough for that. You see we knew right where to put our hands on them, by your description; so we crept along on tiptoe till we got within fifteen feet of them—dark as a cellar that sumach path was—and just then I found I was going to sneeze. It was the meanest kind of luck! I tried to keep it back, but no use—’twas bound to come, and it did come! I was in the lead with my pistol raised, and when the sneeze started those scoundrels a-rustling to get out of the path, I sung out, ‘Fire boys!’ and blazed away at the place where the rustling was. So did the boys. But they were off in a jiffy, those villains, and we after them, down through the woods. I judge we never touched them. They fired a shot apiece as they started, but their bullets whizzed by and didn’t do us any harm. As soon as we lost the sound of their feet we quit chasing, and went down and stirred up the constables. They got a posse together, and went off to guard the river bank, and as soon as it is light the sheriff and a gang are going to beat up the woods. My boys will be with them presently. I wish we had some sort of description of those rascals—’twould help a good deal. But you couldn’t see what they were like, in the dark, lad, I suppose?”
“Oh yes; I saw them downtown and follered them.”
“Splendid! Describe them—describe them, my boy!”
“One’s the old deaf and dumb Spaniard that’s ben around here once or twice, and t’other’s a mean-looking, ragged—”
“That’s enough, lad, we know the men! Happened on them in the woods back of the widow’s one day, and they slunk away. Off with you, boys, and tell the sheriff—get your breakfast tomorrow morning!”

events.title: Huck's Plea for Secrecy and Revelation of Injun Joe
detailed_summary: As the Welshman's sons leave, Huck urgently requests that his involvement in exposing the criminals not be revealed.
The Welshman agrees to keep Huck's role a secret but questions his desire for anonymity.
Huck explains his fear, stating that one of the men would kill him if his knowledge became known.
The Welshman probes Huck about how he came to follow the suspicious men.

Huck fabricates a story about insomnia and restlessness leading him to wander at midnight, where he fortuitously observed the two men near the Temperance Tavern, identifying them when they lit cigars.
He claims he followed them to the widow's stile and overheard their malicious plans.
Huck inadvertently slips up, mentioning the 'deaf and dumb' Spaniard speaking, a mistake he tries to retract.
The Welshman, seeing through Huck's attempts to cover his error, gently coaxes the truth from him, assuring Huck of his protection.
Huck confides in a whisper that the supposed Spaniard is actually Injun Joe.
The Welshman is startled but finds Huck's earlier embellishments about the criminals' violent intentions now make sense, attributing such revenge to an 'Injun'.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The Welshman’s sons departed at once.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But an Injun! That’s a different matter altogether.”

events.text_segment:
The Welshman’s sons departed at once. As they were leaving the room Huck sprang up and exclaimed:
“Oh, please don’t tell anybody it was me that blowed on them! Oh, please!”
“All right if you say it, Huck, but you ought to have the credit of what you did.”
“Oh no, no! Please don’t tell!”
When the young men were gone, the old Welshman said:
“They won’t tell—and I won’t. But why don’t you want it known?”
Huck would not explain, further than to say that he already knew too much about one of those men and would not have the man know that he knew anything against him for the whole world—he would be killed for knowing it, sure.
The old man promised secrecy once more, and said:
“How did you come to follow these fellows, lad? Were they looking suspicious?”
Huck was silent while he framed a duly cautious reply. Then he said:
“Well, you see, I’m a kind of a hard lot,—least everybody says so, and I don’t see nothing agin it—and sometimes I can’t sleep much, on account of thinking about it and sort of trying to strike out a new way of doing. That was the way of it last night. I couldn’t sleep, and so I come along upstreet ’bout midnight, a-turning it all over, and when I got to that old shackly brick store by the Temperance Tavern, I backed up agin the wall to have another think. Well, just then along comes these two chaps slipping along close by me, with something under their arm, and I reckoned they’d stole it. One was a-smoking, and t’other one wanted a light; so they stopped right before me and the cigars lit up their faces and I see that the big one was the deaf and dumb Spaniard, by his white whiskers and the patch on his eye, and t’other one was a rusty, ragged-looking devil.”
“Could you see the rags by the light of the cigars?”
This staggered Huck for a moment. Then he said:
“Well, I don’t know—but somehow it seems as if I did.”
“Then they went on, and you—”
“Follered ’em—yes. That was it. I wanted to see what was up—they sneaked along so. I dogged ’em to the widder’s stile, and stood in the dark and heard the ragged one beg for the widder, and the Spaniard swear he’d spile her looks just as I told you and your two—”
“What! The deaf and dumb man said all that!”
Huck had made another terrible mistake! He was trying his best to keep the old man from getting the faintest hint of who the Spaniard might be, and yet his tongue seemed determined to get him into trouble in spite of all he could do. He made several efforts to creep out of his scrape, but the old man’s eye was upon him and he made blunder after blunder. Presently the Welshman said:
“My boy, don’t be afraid of me. I wouldn’t hurt a hair of your head for all the world. No—I’d protect you—I’d protect you. This Spaniard is not deaf and dumb; you’ve let that slip without intending it; you can’t cover that up now. You know something about that Spaniard that you want to keep dark. Now trust me—tell me what it is, and trust me—I won’t betray you.”
Huck looked into the old man’s honest eyes a moment, then bent over and whispered in his ear:
“’Tain’t a Spaniard—it’s Injun Joe!”
The Welshman almost jumped out of his chair. In a moment he said:
“It’s all plain enough, now. When you talked about notching ears and slitting noses I judged that that was your own embellishment, because white men don’t take that sort of revenge. But an Injun! That’s a different matter altogether.”

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
The Welshman’s sons departed at once. Huck, in a low voice, begged him not to tell what he knew about the criminals. The Welshman promised to keep his secret but looked at Huck with a questioning eye.

"You needn’t worry," Huck said hurriedly. "I don’t want no one to know I was mixed up in it. If they find out I saw them, one of them would kill me."

The Welshman leaned in a little. "How come you was following them?"

"Oh, I couldn’t sleep, and I was restless, so I got up and wandered around. It was midnight, and I just happened to see them near the Temperance Tavern. I saw them light cigars, and I followed them to the widow’s stile. I overheard their plans—bad plans, I tell you."

Huck hesitated, then added, "And I saw the deaf and dumb Spaniard speaking to them."

The Welshman looked surprised. "You saw him?"

"Yes, and I heard him talk. But I guess I made a mistake about him being deaf and dumb."

The Welshman smiled gently. "You’re a brave boy, Huck. I believe you. But tell me, what did they say?"

Huck whispered, "They’re planning to do harm to someone. I don’t know who, but it’s bad."

The Welshman nodded thoughtfully. "That Injun Joe, he’s a dangerous man. I’ve heard of him."

Huck looked at him anxiously. "You won’t tell, will you?"

"No, Huck. Your secret’s safe with me."

Huck felt a little relief. "Thanks, sir. I just wanted to make sure."

The Welshman patted him on the shoulder. "You did right to tell me. Now go home and be careful."

Huck turned and hurried away, his mind racing with the dangerous news he had uncovered.

events.title: The Mysterious Bundle and Huck's Misplaced Fear
detailed_summary: Over breakfast, the Welshman mentions that he and his sons found no blood at the stile but did discover a substantial bundle.
Huck reacts with extreme alarm, his face paling and breath catching, as he awaits the description of the bundle's contents.
The Welshman, after a pause, reveals the bundle contained burglar's tools.
Huck visibly relaxes, overcome with relief.
The Welshman, noticing Huck's strong reaction, questions what he had expected them to find.
Under pressure, Huck feebly suggests he thought they might have found Sunday-school books.
The Welshman laughs heartily at Huck's absurd answer, remarking on Huck's pale and worn-out appearance.

Huck feels foolish for his overreaction, realizing the bundle was not the treasure, as he had initially feared after hearing talk at the widow's stile. He is now certain the treasure remains in 'No. 2' and feels optimistic about retrieving it soon.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: During breakfast the talk went on, and in the course of it the old man said that the last thing which he and his sons had done, before going to bed, was to get a lantern and examine the stile and its vicinity for marks of blood.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: In fact, everything seemed to be drifting just in the right direction, now; the treasure must be still in No. 2, the men would be captured and jailed that day, and he and Tom could seize the gold that night without any trouble or any fear of interruption.

events.text_segment:
During breakfast the talk went on, and in the course of it the old man said that the last thing which he and his sons had done, before going to bed, was to get a lantern and examine the stile and its vicinity for marks of blood. They found none, but captured a bulky bundle of—
“Of what?”
If the words had been lightning they could not have leaped with a more stunning suddenness from Huck’s blanched lips. His eyes were staring wide, now, and his breath suspended—waiting for the answer. The Welshman started—stared in return—three seconds—five seconds—ten—then replied:
“Of burglar’s tools. Why, what’s the matter with you?”
Huck sank back, panting gently, but deeply, unutterably grateful. The Welshman eyed him gravely, curiously—and presently said:
“Yes, burglar’s tools. That appears to relieve you a good deal. But what did give you that turn? What were you expecting we’d found?”
Huck was in a close place—the inquiring eye was upon him—he would have given anything for material for a plausible answer—nothing suggested itself—the inquiring eye was boring deeper and deeper—a senseless reply offered—there was no time to weigh it, so at a venture he uttered it—feebly:
“Sunday-school books, maybe.”
Poor Huck was too distressed to smile, but the old man laughed loud and joyously, shook up the details of his anatomy from head to foot, and ended by saying that such a laugh was money in a-man’s pocket, because it cut down the doctor’s bill like everything. Then he added:
“Poor old chap, you’re white and jaded—you ain’t well a bit—no wonder you’re a little flighty and off your balance. But you’ll come out of it. Rest and sleep will fetch you out all right, I hope.”
Huck was irritated to think he had been such a goose and betrayed such a suspicious excitement, for he had dropped the idea that the parcel brought from the tavern was the treasure, as soon as he had heard the talk at the widow’s stile. He had only thought it was not the treasure, however—he had not known that it wasn’t—and so the suggestion of a captured bundle was too much for his self-possession. But on the whole he felt glad the little episode had happened, for now he knew beyond all question that that bundle was not the bundle, and so his mind was at rest and exceedingly comfortable. In fact, everything seemed to be drifting just in the right direction, now; the treasure must be still in No. 2, the men would be captured and jailed that day, and he and Tom could seize the gold that night without any trouble or any fear of interruption.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text: During breakfast the talk went on, and in the course of it the old man said that the last thing which he and his sons had done, before going to bed, was to get a lantern and examine the stile and its vicinity for marks of blood. The Welshman added that they found no blood, but they did find a large bundle. Huck's face went pale and his breath caught in his throat as he waited to hear what was in the bundle. After a pause, the Welshman said it was burglar's tools. Huck relaxed visibly, feeling a great relief. The Welshman, noticing Huck's reaction, asked what he had expected to find. Huck, feebly, said he thought they might have found Sunday-school books. The Welshman burst out laughing at Huck's answer, remarking on how pale and worn out Huck looked. Huck felt foolish for overreacting, realizing the bundle was not the treasure he feared after hearing talk at the widow's stile. Now he was sure the treasure was still in No. 2, and he felt hopeful about getting it soon.

events.title: Community Gathers, News Spreads, and a New Alarm for Tom and Becky
detailed_summary: A knock at the door startles Huck, who hides to avoid any connection with the recent events.
The Welshman admits several visitors, including the Widow Douglas, as townspeople gather near the stile, indicating the news has spread.
The Welshman recounts the night's events to the visitors, and the Widow Douglas expresses her gratitude for her rescue.
He hints at an unnamed hero responsible for their timely arrival, piquing immense curiosity but refusing to reveal Huck's identity.
The Widow Douglas wonders why she wasn't awakened during the commotion.
The Welshman explains they didn't want to frighten her, especially since the culprits were unlikely to return without their tools, and her servants guarded the house.
Later, at church, the attempted burglary is the main topic of conversation, with no sign of the villains found.
A new concern arises when Mrs. Thatcher asks Mrs. Harper about Becky, realizing Becky didn't stay with her.
Aunt Polly arrives, looking for Tom, assuming he stayed with either Mrs. Thatcher or Mrs. Harper and is now avoiding church.
Both Mrs. Thatcher and Mrs. Harper deny Tom stayed with them, leading to growing anxiety for Aunt Polly.
Joe Harper cannot confirm when he last saw Tom.
Whispers spread through the church as people realize Tom and Becky are missing, and no one recalls seeing them on the ferry; a young man voices the fear that they are still in the cave.
Mrs. Thatcher faints, and Aunt Polly becomes distraught.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Just as breakfast was completed there was a knock at the door.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Aunt Polly fell to crying and wringing her hands.

events.text_segment:
Just as breakfast was completed there was a knock at the door. Huck jumped for a hiding-place, for he had no mind to be connected even remotely with the late event. The Welshman admitted several ladies and gentlemen, among them the Widow Douglas, and noticed that groups of citizens were climbing up the hill—to stare at the stile. So the news had spread. The Welshman had to tell the story of the night to the visitors. The widow’s gratitude for her preservation was outspoken.
“Don’t say a word about it, madam. There’s another that you’re more beholden to than you are to me and my boys, maybe, but he don’t allow me to tell his name. We wouldn’t have been there but for him.”
Of course this excited a curiosity so vast that it almost belittled the main matter—but the Welshman allowed it to eat into the vitals of his visitors, and through them be transmitted to the whole town, for he refused to part with his secret. When all else had been learned, the widow said:
“I went to sleep reading in bed and slept straight through all that noise. Why didn’t you come and wake me?”
“We judged it warn’t worth while. Those fellows warn’t likely to come again—they hadn’t any tools left to work with, and what was the use of waking you up and scaring you to death? My three negro men stood guard at your house all the rest of the night. They’ve just come back.”
More visitors came, and the story had to be told and retold for a couple of hours more.
There was no Sabbath-school during day-school vacation, but everybody was early at church. The stirring event was well canvassed. News came that not a sign of the two villains had been yet discovered. When the sermon was finished, Judge Thatcher’s wife dropped alongside of Mrs. Harper as she moved down the aisle with the crowd and said:
“Is my Becky going to sleep all day? I just expected she would be tired to death.”
“Your Becky?”
“Yes,” with a startled look—“didn’t she stay with you last night?”
“Why, no.”
Mrs. Thatcher turned pale, and sank into a pew, just as Aunt Polly, talking briskly with a friend, passed by. Aunt Polly said:
“Goodmorning, Mrs. Thatcher. Goodmorning, Mrs. Harper. I’ve got a boy that’s turned up missing. I reckon my Tom stayed at your house last night—one of you. And now he’s afraid to come to church. I’ve got to settle with him.”
Mrs. Thatcher shook her head feebly and turned paler than ever.
“He didn’t stay with us,” said Mrs. Harper, beginning to look uneasy. A marked anxiety came into Aunt Polly’s face.
“Joe Harper, have you seen my Tom this morning?”
“No’m.”
“When did you see him last?”
Joe tried to remember, but was not sure he could say. The people had stopped moving out of church. Whispers passed along, and a boding uneasiness took possession of every countenance. Children were anxiously questioned, and young teachers. They all said they had not noticed whether Tom and Becky were on board the ferryboat on the homeward trip; it was dark; no one thought of inquiring if any one was missing. One young man finally blurted out his fear that they were still in the cave! Mrs. Thatcher swooned away. Aunt Polly fell to crying and wringing her hands.

events.title: Town's Frantic Search for Missing Children and Huck's Illness
detailed_summary: The news of Tom and Becky's disappearance spreads rapidly, causing widespread panic and overshadowing the recent burglary attempt.
The town quickly mobilizes a large search party, with men on horses and boats heading towards the cave.
The village feels deserted as the search continues through the afternoon.
Many women visit and console Aunt Polly and Mrs. Thatcher.
The town anxiously awaits news throughout the night, but the only message by morning is a request for more candles and food for the searchers.
Judge Thatcher sends encouraging messages from the cave, but they offer little comfort.
The Welshman returns near daylight, exhausted and covered in candle-grease and clay, to find Huck delirious with fever.
With physicians at the cave, the Widow Douglas takes on the responsibility of caring for Huck, believing it her duty.
The Welshman affirms Huck's good qualities, which the Widow attributes to a divine mark.
Search parties begin to return to the village, weary, while the most resilient continue exploring uncharted parts of the cavern.
The names 'BECKY & TOM' are discovered traced with candle-smoke on a cave wall, along with a soiled ribbon belonging to Becky.
Mrs. Thatcher, recognizing the ribbon, mourns it as the last relic of her child.
Hopeful shouts from searchers in the cave occasionally arise but always end in disappointment as they realize it's just another searcher's light, not the children.
