segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Some said that now and then, in the cave, a far-away speck of light would glimmer, and then a glorious shout would burst forth and a score of men go trooping down the echoing aisle—and then a sickening disappointment always followed; the children were not there; it was only a searcher’s light.

events.text_segment:
The alarm swept from lip to lip, from group to group, from street to street, and within five minutes the bells were wildly clanging and the whole town was up! The Cardiff Hill episode sank into instant insignificance, the burglars were forgotten, horses were saddled, skiffs were manned, the ferryboat ordered out, and before the horror was half an hour old, two hundred men were pouring down highroad and river toward the cave.
All the long afternoon the village seemed empty and dead. Many women visited Aunt Polly and Mrs. Thatcher and tried to comfort them. They cried with them, too, and that was still better than words. All the tedious night the town waited for news; but when the morning dawned at last, all the word that came was, “Send more candles—and send food.” Mrs. Thatcher was almost crazed; and Aunt Polly, also. Judge Thatcher sent messages of hope and encouragement from the cave, but they conveyed no real cheer.
The old Welshman came home toward daylight, spattered with candle-grease, smeared with clay, and almost worn out. He found Huck still in the bed that had been provided for him, and delirious with fever. The physicians were all at the cave, so the Widow Douglas came and took charge of the patient. She said she would do her best by him, because, whether he was good, bad, or indifferent, he was the Lord’s, and nothing that was the Lord’s was a thing to be neglected. The Welshman said Huck had good spots in him, and the widow said:
“You can depend on it. That’s the Lord’s mark. He don’t leave it off. He never does. Puts it somewhere on every creature that comes from his hands.”
Early in the forenoon parties of jaded men began to straggle into the village, but the strongest of the citizens continued searching. All the news that could be gained was that remotenesses of the cavern were being ransacked that had never been visited before; that every corner and crevice was going to be thoroughly searched; that wherever one wandered through the maze of passages, lights were to be seen flitting hither and thither in the distance, and shoutings and pistol-shots sent their hollow reverberations to the ear down the sombre aisles. In one place, far from the section usually traversed by tourists, the names “BECKY & TOM” had been found traced upon the rocky wall with candle-smoke, and near at hand a grease-soiled bit of ribbon. Mrs. Thatcher recognized the ribbon and cried over it. She said it was the last relic she should ever have of her child; and that no other memorial of her could ever be so precious, because this one parted latest from the living body before the awful death came. Some said that now and then, in the cave, a far-away speck of light would glimmer, and then a glorious shout would burst forth and a score of men go trooping down the echoing aisle—and then a sickening disappointment always followed; the children were not there; it was only a searcher’s light.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
The alarm swept from lip to lip, from group to group, from street to street, and within five minutes the bells were wildly clanging and the whole town was up! News of Tom and Becky's disappearance had spread like wildfire, overshadowing the recent burglary attempt. Men on horseback and in boats formed search parties, heading toward the dark, mysterious cave where the children were last seen. The village felt deserted as the search stretched into the afternoon, many women visiting Aunt Polly and Mrs. Thatcher to offer comfort.

As evening fell, the townspeople anxiously waited, their hopes flickering like the candles they carried. Judge Thatcher sent encouraging messages from the cave, but they did little to ease the growing dread. Near dawn, the Welshman returned, exhausted, covered in candle-grease and clay, to find Huck delirious with fever. The Widow Douglas, believing it her duty, took Huck into her care, while the Welshman spoke kindly of Huck's good qualities, which the Widow saw as a divine mark.

Search parties began to return, weary but hopeful, while others continued exploring uncharted parts of the cavern. Suddenly, they discovered the names 'BECKY & TOM' traced with candle-smoke on a cave wall, along with a soiled ribbon belonging to Becky. Mrs. Thatcher recognized the ribbon and mourned it as the last relic of her child. Occasionally, shouts of hope arose from the depths, only to be dashed when the lights turned out to be just another searcher's lantern, not the children.

events.title: Huck's Fevered Inquiry and a Painful Misunderstanding
detailed_summary: After three agonizing days and nights, the village is in a state of despair.
Even the significant news of liquor being found at the Temperance Tavern barely registers with the public.
Huck, in a moment of lucidity during his illness, cautiously asks the Widow Douglas if anything was discovered at the Temperance Tavern.
The Widow confirms that liquor was found and the tavern has been closed.
Huck, becoming agitated, presses further, specifically asking if Tom Sawyer was the one who found 'it' (meaning the treasure).
The Widow Douglas, misinterpreting Huck's question and overwhelmed by her grief for the missing Tom, bursts into tears, urging Huck to be quiet due to his sickness.
Huck concludes that only liquor was found, as gold would have caused a bigger commotion, and believes the treasure is lost forever.
He is puzzled by the Widow's tears but, exhausted by his thoughts and illness, falls asleep.
The Widow reflects on Huck's question about Tom finding 'it', lamenting that few still have the hope or strength to continue searching for Tom Sawyer.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Three dreadful days and nights dragged their tedious hours along, and the village sank into a hopeless stupor.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Ah, there ain’t many left, now, that’s got hope enough, or strength enough, either, to go on searching.”

events.text_segment:
Three dreadful days and nights dragged their tedious hours along, and the village sank into a hopeless stupor. No one had heart for anything. The accidental discovery, just made, that the proprietor of the Temperance Tavern kept liquor on his premises, scarcely fluttered the public pulse, tremendous as the fact was. In a lucid interval, Huck feebly led up to the subject of taverns, and finally asked—dimly dreading the worst—if anything had been discovered at the Temperance Tavern since he had been ill.
“Yes,” said the widow.
Huck started up in bed, wildeyed:
“What? What was it?”
“Liquor!—and the place has been shut up. Lie down, child—what a turn you did give me!”
“Only tell me just one thing—only just one—please! Was it Tom Sawyer that found it?”
The widow burst into tears. “Hush, hush, child, hush! I’ve told you before, you must not talk. You are very, very sick!”
Then nothing but liquor had been found; there would have been a great powwow if it had been the gold. So the treasure was gone forever—gone forever! But what could she be crying about? Curious that she should cry.
These thoughts worked their dim way through Huck’s mind, and under the weariness they gave him he fell asleep. The widow said to herself:
“There—he’s asleep, poor wreck. Tom Sawyer find it! Pity but somebody could find Tom Sawyer! Ah, there ain’t many left, now, that’s got hope enough, or strength enough, either, to go on searching.”

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
Three dreadful days and nights dragged their tedious hours along, and the village sank into a hopeless stupor. The news of liquor being found at the Temperance Tavern had scarcely stirred the people, so deep was their despair. Huck, lying ill and weak, in a rare moment of clarity, cautiously asked the Widow Douglas if anything had been discovered at the tavern.

"Yes, liquor was found, and the tavern has been closed," she replied, her voice heavy with grief.

Huck, his heart pounding, pressed further, "Was Tom the one who found it? Did Tom find it?"

The Widow, overwhelmed by her sorrow for Tom, burst into tears. "Hush, Huck, you're sick. Be quiet now," she urged, trying to soothe him.

Huck, exhausted and confused, thought that only liquor had been found—if there had been gold, surely there would have been a bigger commotion. He believed the treasure was lost forever. Puzzled by the Widow's tears, he soon fell asleep, his mind swirling with thoughts.

As she watched him sleep, the Widow reflected on Huck's question about Tom finding 'it.' She lamented that few still held hope or strength to continue searching for Tom Sawyer, and the town's spirit was broken.

events.title: Initial Cave Exploration and Discovery of a Hidden Passage
detailed_summary: Tom and Becky participated in the picnic activities, exploring the familiar, named sections of the cave with the larger group.
After engaging in hide-and-seek, they felt tired and decided to wander away from the others.
They amused themselves by examining the names, dates, and addresses written in candle smoke on the cave walls.
As they continued talking and drifting, they entered a part of the cave that lacked these smoke frescoes.
They inscribed their own names with candle smoke beneath an overhanging rock formation before moving on.
Their exploration led them to a striking natural feature: a limestone deposit shaped like a miniature Niagara Falls, formed over ages by trickling water.

Tom managed to get behind this formation to light it up for Becky and, in doing so, discovered it concealed a narrow, steep natural staircase, which immediately ignited his ambition to be an explorer.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Now to return to Tom and Becky’s share in the picnic.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He found that it curtained a sort of steep natural stairway which was enclosed between narrow walls, and at once the ambition to be a discoverer seized him.

events.text_segment: Now to return to Tom and Becky’s share in the picnic. They tripped along the murky aisles with the rest of the company, visiting the familiar wonders of the cave—wonders dubbed with rather over-descriptive names, such as “The Drawing-Room,” “The Cathedral,” “Aladdin’s Palace,” and so on. Presently the hide-and-seek frolicking began, and Tom and Becky engaged in it with zeal until the exertion began to grow a trifle wearisome; then they wandered down a sinuous avenue holding their candles aloft and reading the tangled webwork of names, dates, postoffice addresses, and mottoes with which the rocky walls had been frescoed (in candle-smoke). Still drifting along and talking, they scarcely noticed that they were now in a part of the cave whose walls were not frescoed. They smoked their own names under an overhanging shelf and moved on. Presently they came to a place where a little stream of water, trickling over a ledge and carrying a limestone sediment with it, had, in the slow-dragging ages, formed a laced and ruffled Niagara in gleaming and imperishable stone. Tom squeezed his small body behind it in order to illuminate it for Becky’s gratification. He found that it curtained a sort of steep natural stairway which was enclosed between narrow walls, and at once the ambition to be a discoverer seized him.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text: Now to return to Tom and Becky’s share in the picnic. They had been among the many children exploring the familiar, named sections of the cave with the larger group, playing hide-and-seek and other games. After tiring of the activity, they wandered away from the others, amused by the strange, silent world around them. They examined the walls, which bore the names, dates, and addresses of visitors, written in candle smoke that had left faint, ghostly inscriptions. As they drifted further into the cave, they found themselves in a part where these inscriptions did not appear. They took to inscribing their own names beneath an overhanging rock formation, using candle smoke to leave their mark. Their exploration led them to a remarkable natural feature: a deposit of limestone shaped like a miniature Niagara Falls, formed over ages by trickling water. Tom, eager to explore, managed to get behind this formation and light it up for Becky, revealing that it concealed a narrow, steep natural staircase. This discovery sparked Tom’s adventurous spirit, igniting his desire to become an explorer.

events.title: Deeper Exploration, Bat Encounter, and Growing Apprehension
detailed_summary: Becky joined Tom, and they made a smoke-mark to guide their potential return before embarking on their exploration of the newly found passage.
They journeyed deep into the cave's hidden sections, made another mark, and then diverged to find new sights to report to those above ground.
They discovered a large cavern adorned with numerous stalactites, each as long and thick as a man's leg, and marveled at the sight before exiting through one of its many openings.

This path soon led them to an enchanting spring with a basin covered in glittering, frost-like crystals, located in a cavern supported by fantastical pillars formed by anciently joined stalactites and stalagmites.
Vast clusters of bats, thousands strong, were roosting under the cavern roof; the children's lights agitated them, causing hundreds to fly down, squeaking and aiming for the candles.
Aware of the bats' behavior and the potential danger, Tom quickly grabbed Becky's hand and rushed her into the nearest corridor.
Just as they were exiting the bat cavern, a bat struck Becky's candle with its wing, extinguishing it.
The bats pursued the children for some distance, but Tom and Becky managed to escape by darting into every new passage they encountered.
Shortly thereafter, Tom found a subterranean lake that disappeared into the shadows.
He considered exploring its edges but decided they should rest first.
It was then that the profound silence of their location deeply unsettled the children.
Becky remarked on the long time since she had heard any of the other picnickers.
Tom acknowledged they were far beneath the others, unsure of their direction, and confirmed they wouldn't be able to hear anyone from their current spot.
Becky became increasingly anxious.
She questioned how long they had been down there and insisted they should start heading back.
Tom agreed they should, perhaps.
Becky expressed doubt about Tom's ability to find the way, as the cave's layout seemed utterly confusing to her.
Tom believed he could find the path but worried about the bats potentially extinguishing their remaining candles, suggesting they try a different route to avoid the bat cavern.
Becky, though agreeing, expressed her profound fear of getting lost, shuddering at the terrible possibilities.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Becky responded to his call, and they made a smoke-mark for future guidance, and started upon their quest.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Well. But I hope we won’t get lost. It would be so awful!” and the girl shuddered at the thought of the dreadful possibilities.

events.text_segment:
Becky responded to his call, and they made a smoke-mark for future guidance, and started upon their quest. They wound this way and that, far down into the secret depths of the cave, made another mark, and branched off in search of novelties to tell the upper world about. In one place they found a spacious cavern, from whose ceiling depended a multitude of shining stalactites of the length and circumference of a man’s leg; they walked all about it, wondering and admiring, and presently left it by one of the numerous passages that opened into it. This shortly brought them to a bewitching spring, whose basin was incrusted with a frostwork of glittering crystals; it was in the midst of a cavern whose walls were supported by many fantastic pillars which had been formed by the joining of great stalactites and stalagmites together, the result of the ceaseless water-drip of centuries. Under the roof vast knots of bats had packed themselves together, thousands in a bunch; the lights disturbed the creatures and they came flocking down by hundreds, squeaking and darting furiously at the candles. Tom knew their ways and the danger of this sort of conduct. He seized Becky’s hand and hurried her into the first corridor that offered; and none too soon, for a bat struck Becky’s light out with its wing while she was passing out of the cavern. The bats chased the children a good distance; but the fugitives plunged into every new passage that offered, and at last got rid of the perilous things. Tom found a subterranean lake, shortly, which stretched its dim length away until its shape was lost in the shadows. He wanted to explore its borders, but concluded that it would be best to sit down and rest awhile, first. Now, for the first time, the deep stillness of the place laid a clammy hand upon the spirits of the children. Becky said:
“Why, I didn’t notice, but it seems ever so long since I heard any of the others.”
“Come to think, Becky, we are away down below them—and I don’t know how far away north, or south, or east, or whichever it is. We couldn’t hear them here.”
Becky grew apprehensive.
“I wonder how long we’ve been down here, Tom? We better start back.”
“Yes, I reckon we better. P’raps we better.”
“Can you find the way, Tom? It’s all a mixed-up crookedness to me.”
“I reckon I could find it—but then the bats. If they put our candles out it will be an awful fix. Let’s try some other way, so as not to go through there.”
“Well. But I hope we won’t get lost. It would be so awful!” and the girl shuddered at the thought of the dreadful possibilities.

events.title: Becoming Lost: Failed Attempts and Mounting Despair
detailed_summary: They proceeded silently down a corridor, examining each new opening for any familiar feature, but all were strange.
After each fruitless examination by Tom, Becky would search his face for encouragement, and he would respond with forced cheerfulness, claiming they would find the right way soon.
However, Tom's hope diminished with every failure, and he eventually began to choose diverging paths at random, desperately hoping to find the correct one.
Though he continued to say everything was 'all right,' the dread in his heart made his words sound hollow, as if he were admitting all was lost.
Overcome with fear, Becky clung to his side, trying to suppress her tears, but they came nonetheless.
Finally, she pleaded with Tom to disregard the bats and return the way they came, feeling their situation was only deteriorating.
Tom urged her to listen, and a profound silence enveloped them, so deep their breathing was noticeable.
Tom shouted, and the sound echoed through the empty passages, fading into a faint noise that resembled mocking laughter.
Becky, horrified, begged Tom not to shout again.
Tom, however, felt he must, saying they might be heard, and shouted once more.

The children stood still, listening, but heard nothing.
Tom immediately turned to retrace their steps, hurrying along.
Soon, his indecisive manner revealed another terrifying truth to Becky: he could not find his way back.
Becky exclaimed in distress that Tom hadn't made any marks.
Tom berated himself for his foolishness, admitting he never considered they might need to return and that he couldn't find the way because it was all jumbled.
Becky cried out in despair that they were lost and would never escape the dreadful place, questioning why they ever left the others.
She collapsed to the ground in a frenzy of tears, making Tom fear she might die or lose her sanity.

events.text_segment:
They started through a corridor, and traversed it in silence a long way, glancing at each new opening, to see if there was anything familiar about the look of it; but they were all strange. Every time Tom made an examination, Becky would watch his face for an encouraging sign, and he would say cheerily:
“Oh, it’s all right. This ain’t the one, but we’ll come to it right away!”
But he felt less and less hopeful with each failure, and presently began to turn off into diverging avenues at sheer random, in desperate hope of finding the one that was wanted. He still said it was “all right,” but there was such a leaden dread at his heart that the words had lost their ring and sounded just as if he had said, “All is lost!” Becky clung to his side in an anguish of fear, and tried hard to keep back the tears, but they would come. At last she said:
“Oh, Tom, never mind the bats, let’s go back that way! We seem to get worse and worse off all the time.”
“Listen!” said he.
Profound silence; silence so deep that even their breathings were conspicuous in the hush. Tom shouted. The call went echoing down the empty aisles and died out in the distance in a faint sound that resembled a ripple of mocking laughter.
“Oh, don’t do it again, Tom, it is too horrid,” said Becky.
“It is horrid, but I better, Becky; they might hear us, you know,” and he shouted again.
The “might” was even a chillier horror than the ghostly laughter, it so confessed a perishing hope. The children stood still and listened; but there was no result. Tom turned upon the back track at once, and hurried his steps. It was but a little while before a certain indecision in his manner revealed another fearful fact to Becky—he could not find his way back!
“Oh, Tom, you didn’t make any marks!”
“Becky, I was such a fool! Such a fool! I never thought we might want to come back! No—I can’t find the way. It’s all mixed up.”
“Tom, Tom, we’re lost! we’re lost! We never can get out of this awful place! Oh, why did we ever leave the others!”
She sank to the ground and burst into such a frenzy of crying that Tom was appalled with the idea that she might die, or lose her reason. He sat down by her and put his arms around her; she buried her face in his bosom, she clung to him, she poured out her terrors, her unavailing regrets, and the far echoes turned them all to jeering laughter. Tom begged her to pluck up hope again, and she said she could not. He fell to blaming and abusing himself for getting her into this miserable situation; this had a better effect. She said she would try to hope again, she would get up and follow wherever he might lead if only he would not talk like that any more. For he was no more to blame than she, she said.

events.title: Conserving Resources, Battling Fatigue, and a Dream of Escape
detailed_summary: They resumed their journey, moving aimlessly and at random, driven solely by the instinct to keep moving.
Hope made a brief, unreasoned resurgence, characteristic of youth unfamiliar with repeated failure.
After some time, Tom took Becky's candle and extinguished it, an act of economy that wordlessly conveyed the gravity of their situation.
Becky understood the implication, and her hope vanished once more; she knew Tom possessed a whole candle and several pieces, making his conservation efforts deeply alarming.

Fatigue began to take its toll, yet the children resisted stopping, knowing that sitting down felt like inviting death when time was so critical and movement, in any direction, offered a sliver of hope for progress.
Eventually, Becky's legs could carry her no further, and she sat down.
Tom rested with her, and they spoke of home, friends, the comfort of their beds, and most acutely, the light.
Becky cried, and Tom found his usual encouragements had become worn and sounded sarcastic.
Exhaustion overwhelmed Becky, and she drifted off to sleep, for which Tom was grateful.
He watched her drawn face soften and appear natural under the influence of pleasant dreams, and a smile eventually graced her lips.
Her peaceful expression brought a measure of peace to his own spirit, and his thoughts wandered to past times and dreamlike memories.
While Tom was lost in his thoughts, Becky awoke with a lighthearted laugh, which instantly died on her lips, followed by a groan.
She lamented having slept and wished she hadn't woken, then quickly recanted, not wanting to upset Tom.
Tom reassured her that sleep was beneficial and that they would find their way out.
Becky agreed they could try, but mentioned a beautiful country she had seen in her dream, implying a premonition of death and a journey to an afterlife.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: So they moved on again—aimlessly—simply at random—all they could do was to move, keep moving.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “We can try, Tom; but I’ve seen such a beautiful country in my dream. I reckon we are going there.”

events.text_segment:
So they moved on again—aimlessly—simply at random—all they could do was to move, keep moving. For a little while, hope made a show of reviving—not with any reason to back it, but only because it is its nature to revive when the spring has not been taken out of it by age and familiarity with failure.
By-and-by Tom took Becky’s candle and blew it out. This economy meant so much! Words were not needed. Becky understood, and her hope died again. She knew that Tom had a whole candle and three or four pieces in his pockets—yet he must economize.
By-and-by, fatigue began to assert its claims; the children tried to pay attention, for it was dreadful to think of sitting down when time was grown to be so precious, moving, in some direction, in any direction, was at least progress and might bear fruit; but to sit down was to invite death and shorten its pursuit.
At last Becky’s frail limbs refused to carry her farther. She sat down. Tom rested with her, and they talked of home, and the friends there, and the comfortable beds and, above all, the light! Becky cried, and Tom tried to think of some way of comforting her, but all his encouragements were grown thread-bare with use, and sounded like sarcasms. Fatigue bore so heavily upon Becky that she drowsed off to sleep. Tom was grateful. He sat looking into her drawn face and saw it grow smooth and natural under the influence of pleasant dreams; and by-and-by a smile dawned and rested there. The peaceful face reflected somewhat of peace and healing into his own spirit, and his thoughts wandered away to bygone times and dreamy memories. While he was deep in his musings, Becky woke up with a breezy little laugh—but it was stricken dead upon her lips, and a groan followed it.
“Oh, how could I sleep! I wish I never, never had waked! No! No, I don’t, Tom! Don’t look so! I won’t say it again.”
“I’m glad you’ve slept, Becky; you’ll feel rested, now, and we’ll find the way out.”
“We can try, Tom; but I’ve seen such a beautiful country in my dream. I reckon we are going there.”

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text: So they moved on again—aimlessly—simply at random—all they could do was to move, keep moving. Hope flickered briefly in Tom’s heart, a foolish, unreasoned hope that perhaps they might find help or a way out. Tom took Becky's candle, and with a quick, silent gesture, he extinguished it, conserving its dwindling flame. Becky understood immediately—her hope faded, replaced by a sinking dread, for Tom had a whole candle and many pieces, yet he chose to save them all. Fatigue pressed heavily upon them, yet they refused to stop, knowing that sitting down was like inviting death, and that any movement, no matter how small, was a step toward salvation. At last, Becky's legs could carry her no further, and she sank down, exhausted. Tom sat beside her, and they spoke softly of home, of friends, of their beds, and most of all, of the light that beckoned them. Becky’s eyes filled with tears, and Tom’s usual words of encouragement sounded hollow and sarcastic. Overcome by weariness, Becky drifted into sleep, and Tom watched her peaceful face, a gentle smile touching her lips as she dreamed. Her calm expression brought a quiet comfort to Tom, and his thoughts wandered to distant, happier times. Suddenly, Becky awoke with a light laugh, which quickly died away into a groan. She lamented having slept and wished she hadn’t woken, then quickly changed her mind, not wanting to upset Tom. He reassured her that sleep was good and that they would find their way out. Becky nodded, mentioning a beautiful country she had seen in her dream, a place that seemed to foreshadow death and a journey beyond this life.

events.title: The Last of the Food and the Final Candle's Grim Revelation
detailed_summary: Tom tried to encourage Becky, urging her to remain hopeful and continue their efforts.

They walked onward, hand in hand, feeling utterly hopeless, with no accurate sense of how long they had been trapped, though it seemed like days or weeks; however, the fact their candles were not yet fully consumed indicated this perception was skewed.
After a considerable, unquantifiable time, Tom suggested they move quietly and listen for the sound of dripping water, hoping to find a spring.
They soon located one, and Tom declared it was time to rest again.
Although both were severely tired, Becky felt she could continue a bit longer and was surprised when Tom disagreed, unable to understand his reasoning.
They sat down, and Tom used some clay to affix his candle to the wall before them.
A period of silent thought passed before Becky broke the silence, stating her hunger.
Tom retrieved something from his pocket.
He asked if she remembered it.
A faint smile touched Becky's lips as she recognized it as their 'wedding-cake' from the picnic.
Tom expressed a wish for it to be much larger, as it was all the food they possessed.
Becky explained she had saved it for them to dream on, as adults do with wedding cake, but her sentence trailed off, hinting at a grim alternative outcome.
Tom divided the cake; Becky ate her portion with a good appetite, while Tom only nibbled at his share.
They had ample cold water from the spring to accompany their meager meal.
After a while, Becky suggested they move on again.
Tom remained silent for a moment before speaking.
He asked Becky if she could bear to hear something important.
Becky's face paled, but she indicated she could.
Tom then revealed the grim necessity: they had to remain where they were, near the water source, because the small piece of candle currently burning was their very last.
Becky succumbed to tears and wailing, and Tom's attempts to console her had little success.
Eventually, Becky voiced a flicker of hope, suggesting they would be missed and searched for.
Tom eagerly agreed.
They speculated that the search might already be underway.
They discussed when their absence might be noticed, guessing it would be when the picnic group returned to the boat.
Becky worried it might be dark by then, questioning if their absence would be noted.
Tom was unsure but suggested Becky's mother would miss her as soon as the family returned home.
A look of fright on Becky's face made Tom realize his error: Becky wasn't expected home that night.
The children fell into a somber, thoughtful silence.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Maybe not, maybe not. Cheer up, Becky, and let’s go on trying.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The children became silent and thoughtful.

events.text_segment:
“Maybe not, maybe not. Cheer up, Becky, and let’s go on trying.”
They rose up and wandered along, hand in hand and hopeless. They tried to estimate how long they had been in the cave, but all they knew was that it seemed days and weeks, and yet it was plain that this could not be, for their candles were not gone yet. A long time after this—they could not tell how long—Tom said they must go softly and listen for dripping water—they must find a spring. They found one presently, and Tom said it was time to rest again. Both were cruelly tired, yet Becky said she thought she could go a little farther. She was surprised to hear Tom dissent. She could not understand it. They sat down, and Tom fastened his candle to the wall in front of them with some clay. Thought was soon busy; nothing was said for some time. Then Becky broke the silence:
“Tom, I am so hungry!”
Tom took something out of his pocket.
“Do you remember this?” said he.
Becky almost smiled.
“It’s our wedding-cake, Tom.”
“Yes—I wish it was as big as a barrel, for it’s all we’ve got.”
“I saved it from the picnic for us to dream on, Tom, the way grownup people do with wedding-cake—but it’ll be our—”
She dropped the sentence where it was. Tom divided the cake and Becky ate with good appetite, while Tom nibbled at his moiety. There was abundance of cold water to finish the feast with. By-and-by Becky suggested that they move on again. Tom was silent a moment. Then he said:
“Becky, can you bear it if I tell you something?”
Becky’s face paled, but she thought she could.
“Well, then, Becky, we must stay here, where there’s water to drink. That little piece is our last candle!”
Becky gave loose to tears and wailings. Tom did what he could to comfort her, but with little effect. At length Becky said:
“Tom!”
“Well, Becky?”
“They’ll miss us and hunt for us!”
“Yes, they will! Certainly they will!”
“Maybe they’re hunting for us now, Tom.”
“Why, I reckon maybe they are. I hope they are.”
“When would they miss us, Tom?”
“When they get back to the boat, I reckon.”
“Tom, it might be dark then—would they notice we hadn’t come?”
“I don’t know. But anyway, your mother would miss you as soon as they got home.”
A frightened look in Becky’s face brought Tom to his senses and he saw that he had made a blunder. Becky was not to have gone home that night! The children became silent and thoughtful.

Tom then revealed the grim necessity: they had to remain where they were, near the water source, because the small piece of candle currently burning was their very last.

Becky succumbed to tears and wailing, and Tom's attempts to console her had little success. Eventually, Becky voiced a flicker of hope, suggesting they would be missed and searched for.

Tom eagerly agreed. They speculated that the search might already be underway. They discussed when their absence might be noticed, guessing it would be when the picnic group returned to the boat.

Becky worried it might be dark by then, questioning if their absence would be noted. Tom was unsure but suggested Becky's mother would miss her as soon as the family returned home.

A look of fright on Becky's face made Tom realize his error: Becky wasn't expected home that night. The children fell into a somber, thoughtful silence.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_2.text:
“Maybe not, maybe not. Cheer up, Becky, and let’s go on trying.”

They walked onward, hand in hand, feeling utterly hopeless, with no accurate sense of how long they had been trapped—though it seemed like days or weeks; yet, the fact that their candles were not yet fully consumed suggested their perception was skewed.

After a long, unmeasurable time, Tom suggested they move quietly and listen for the sound of dripping water, hoping to find a spring. Soon, they located one, and Tom declared it was time to rest again.

Although both were severely tired, Becky felt she could continue a little longer, and she was surprised when Tom said they must stop. She looked at him in wonder, not understanding his reasoning.

They sat down, and Tom took some clay and used it to fasten his candle to the wall before them.

A silent pause followed, then Becky broke the silence, saying she was very hungry. Tom reached into his pocket and took out something. He asked if she remembered it. A faint smile touched her lips as she recognized it as their wedding-cake from the picnic.

Tom said he wished it was much larger, for it was all the food they had. Becky explained she had saved it for them to dream on, as grown-up people do with wedding cake, but her voice trailed off, leaving an unspoken thought.

Tom divided the cake, giving Becky her part, which she ate with a good appetite, while Tom only nibbled at his.

They had plenty of cold water from the spring to drink with their little meal.

After a while, Becky suggested they should move on again. Tom was silent for a moment, then spoke.

He asked Becky if she could bear to hear something important. Her face turned pale, but she nodded.

Tom then told her that they must stay where they were, near the water, because the small piece of candle burning was their very last.

Becky burst into tears and began to wail, and Tom tried to comfort her, but it was no use.

Finally, Becky said she thought they would be missed and searched for. Tom eagerly agreed, and they talked about when their absence might be noticed.

They guessed it would be when the picnic party returned to the boat. Becky was worried it might be dark then, and no one would see they were gone.

Tom was not sure, but he thought Becky's mother would miss her as soon as they got home.

A look of fright came over Becky’s face, and Tom saw that he had made a mistake. Becky was not expected home that night.

The children sat quietly, lost in thought, as the darkness settled around them.

events.title: Into Darkness, Fleeting Hope, and Crushing Disappointment
detailed_summary: A fresh outburst of grief from Becky quickly showed Tom that she, too, had grasped the dreadful implication: Mrs. Thatcher might not realize Becky was missing until Sunday morning was well underway.
The children fixated on their tiny piece of candle, watching it melt away slowly and relentlessly.

They saw the half-inch of wick stand alone, observed the feeble flame rise and fall, climb the column of smoke, hover at its peak, and then extinguish, plunging them into absolute, horrifying darkness.
Neither Tom nor Becky could tell how much time passed before Becky became dimly aware that she was crying in Tom's arms.
All they knew was that after what felt like an immense duration, both emerged from a deep, sleep-like stupor, only to resume their suffering.
Tom speculated it might now be Sunday, or possibly Monday.
He attempted to get Becky to talk, but her sorrows were too overwhelming, and all her hope had vanished.
Tom insisted they must have been missed long ago and that a search was undoubtedly in progress.
He decided to shout, hoping someone might come.
He tried, but in the total darkness, the distant echoes sounded so terrifyingly hideous that he refrained from trying again.
The hours passed, and hunger began to afflict the captives once more.
A portion of Tom's half of the cake remained; they divided and consumed it.
However, they seemed even hungrier than before, the small morsel of food only serving to sharpen their desire.
After some time, Tom suddenly urged Becky to be quiet, asking if she heard something.
Both held their breath and listened intently, detecting a sound like the faintest, most distant shout.
Tom instantly responded to it and, taking Becky's hand, began to grope his way down the corridor in the direction of the sound.
He listened again; the sound was repeated, seemingly a little closer.
Tom exclaimed that it was 'them,' their rescuers, and urged Becky along, declaring they were now all right.
The prisoners' joy was nearly overpowering.
Their progress was slow, however, as pitfalls were relatively common and required caution.
They soon reached one such chasm and were forced to stop; it could have been three feet deep or a hundred, but regardless, it was impassable.
Tom lay on his stomach and reached down as far as he could but found no bottom, meaning they had to stay put and wait for the searchers.
They listened, only to realize with sinking hearts that the distant shouts were growing fainter.
A moment or two later, the sounds had vanished completely, bringing an overwhelming sense of misery.
Tom shouted until he was hoarse, but it was futile.
He spoke with forced hopefulness to Becky, but an agonizingly long period of anxious waiting passed with no further sounds.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He talked hopefully to Becky; but an age of anxious waiting passed and no sounds came again.

events.text_segment:
In a moment a new burst of grief from Becky showed Tom that the thing in his mind had struck hers also—that the Sabbath morning might be half spent before Mrs. Thatcher discovered that Becky was not at Mrs. Harper’s.
The children fastened their eyes upon their bit of candle and watched it melt slowly and pitilessly away; saw the half inch of wick stand alone at last; saw the feeble flame rise and fall, climb the thin column of smoke, linger at its top a moment, and then—the horror of utter darkness reigned!
How long afterward it was that Becky came to a slow consciousness that she was crying in Tom’s arms, neither could tell. All that they knew was, that after what seemed a mighty stretch of time, both awoke out of a dead stupor of sleep and resumed their miseries once more. Tom said it might be Sunday, now—maybe Monday. He tried to get Becky to talk, but her sorrows were too oppressive, all her hopes were gone. Tom said that they must have been missed long ago, and no doubt the search was going on. He would shout and maybe some one would come. He tried it; but in the darkness the distant echoes sounded so hideously that he tried it no more.
The hours wasted away, and hunger came to torment the captives again. A portion of Tom’s half of the cake was left; they divided and ate it. But they seemed hungrier than before. The poor morsel of food only whetted desire.
By-and-by Tom said:
“SH! Did you hear that?”
Both held their breath and listened. There was a sound like the faintest, far-off shout. Instantly Tom answered it, and leading Becky by the hand, started groping down the corridor in its direction. Presently he listened again; again the sound was heard, and apparently a little nearer.
“It’s them!” said Tom; “they’re coming! Come along, Becky—we’re all right now!”
The joy of the prisoners was almost overwhelming. Their speed was slow, however, because pitfalls were somewhat common, and had to be guarded against. They shortly came to one and had to stop. It might be three feet deep, it might be a hundred—there was no passing it at any rate. Tom got down on his breast and reached as far down as he could. No bottom. They must stay there and wait until the searchers came. They listened; evidently the distant shoutings were growing more distant! a moment or two more and they had gone altogether. The heart-sinking misery of it! Tom whooped until he was hoarse, but it was of no use. He talked hopefully to Becky; but an age of anxious waiting passed and no sounds came again.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
In a moment a new burst of grief from Becky showed Tom that the thing in his mind had struck hers also—that the Sabbath morning might be half spent before Mrs. Thatcher discovered that Becky was not at Mrs. Harper’s.

They sat in silence, watching their tiny candle melt away, the flame flickering feebly as it struggled against the darkness. The half-inch of wick stood alone, and the smoke curled upward, then vanished, leaving them in utter blackness.

Neither of them knew how long they had been there—hours, perhaps—until Becky’s sobs softened and she began to cry quietly in Tom’s arms. Both felt as if they had been in a deep, sleep-like stupor, only to wake and find their suffering unchanged.

Tom tried to comfort her, asking if she could hear him, if she knew what was happening. But her sorrow was too great, and her hope had vanished. He told her they must have been missed long ago, that searchers were surely looking for them.

He decided to shout, to call for help, but the darkness and the distance made the echoes so hideous that he dared not try again. Hunger gnawed at them anew, and they divided the small piece of cake Tom had left, but it only sharpened their craving.

Suddenly, Tom urged Becky to be quiet, listening intently. Both held their breath, and faintly, they heard a distant shout—so faint it might have been their imagination. Tom responded instantly, grasping Becky’s hand, and they groped their way down the corridor toward the sound.

The shout was repeated, seeming a little nearer. Tom exclaimed that it was their rescuers, and he urged Becky to follow him, assuring her they were now safe. Their joy was almost overwhelming, but caution was necessary; the pitfalls along the way were many.

Soon, they reached a chasm—deep and dark—and had to stop. It might have been three feet or a hundred, but it was impassable. Tom lay on his stomach and reached down as far as he could, but found no bottom, so they had to wait, listening.

As they listened, the distant shouts grew fainter, until finally, they vanished altogether, leaving them in despair. Tom shouted until his voice was hoarse, but it was useless. He tried to speak hope to Becky, but the long hours of waiting passed with no further sound, only the oppressive darkness and their broken spirits.

events.title: A Desperate Exploration and a Terrifying Encounter
detailed_summary: The children groped their way back to the spring.
The weary time continued to pass; they slept again and awoke famished and filled with woe.
Tom now believed it must be Tuesday.
An idea occurred to him: exploring some of the nearby side passages would be preferable to enduring the heavy passage of time in idleness.
He retrieved a kite-line from his pocket, secured it to a rock projection, and he and Becky set off, with Tom leading and unwinding the line as he navigated.
After about twenty steps, the corridor terminated at a 'jumping-off place,' a sudden drop.
Tom got on his knees, felt below, and then extended his hands as far as he could around a corner to his right.
As he stretched a little further, a human hand holding a candle appeared from behind a rock, not twenty yards away.
Tom let out a glorious shout, believing it to be a rescuer.
Instantly, the hand was followed by the body it belonged to—Injun Joe.
Tom was paralyzed with terror and could not move.
The next moment, he felt immense relief as he saw the 'Spaniard' (Injun Joe in disguise) turn and flee out of sight.
Tom was puzzled that Joe hadn't recognized his voice and come to kill him for his testimony in court.
He reasoned that the cave's echoes must have disguised his voice, believing this was undoubtedly the explanation.
The fright left Tom's muscles weak; he told himself that if he could muster the strength to return to the spring, he would stay there and avoid any risk of another encounter with Injun Joe.
He was careful to keep what he had seen a secret from Becky, telling her he had merely shouted 'for luck.'

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The children groped their way back to the spring.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He told her he had only shouted “for luck.”

events.text_segment:
The children groped their way back to the spring. The weary time dragged on; they slept again, and awoke famished and woe-stricken. Tom believed it must be Tuesday by this time.
Now an idea struck him. There were some side passages near at hand. It would be better to explore some of these than bear the weight of the heavy time in idleness. He took a kite-line from his pocket, tied it to a projection, and he and Becky started, Tom in the lead, unwinding the line as he groped along. At the end of twenty steps the corridor ended in a “jumping-off place.” Tom got down on his knees and felt below, and then as far around the corner as he could reach with his hands conveniently; he made an effort to stretch yet a little farther to the right, and at that moment, not twenty yards away, a human hand, holding a candle, appeared from behind a rock! Tom lifted up a glorious shout, and instantly that hand was followed by the body it belonged to—Injun Joe’s! Tom was paralyzed; he could not move. He was vastly gratified the next moment, to see the “Spaniard” take to his heels and get himself out of sight. Tom wondered that Joe had not recognized his voice and come over and killed him for testifying in court. But the echoes must have disguised the voice. Without doubt, that was it, he reasoned. Tom’s fright weakened every muscle in his body. He said to himself that if he had strength enough to get back to the spring he would stay there, and nothing should tempt him to run the risk of meeting Injun Joe again. He was careful to keep from Becky what it was he had seen. He told her he had only shouted “for luck.”

events.title: Becky's Surrender to Despair and Tom's Grim Resolve
detailed_summary: In the long term, however, hunger and profound misery tend to overcome even strong fears.
Another tiresome wait at the spring, followed by another long sleep, brought about changes in their condition and outlook.
The children awoke tormented by a fierce, raging hunger.
Tom now speculated that it must be Wednesday, Thursday, or perhaps even Friday or Saturday, and concluded that any search for them had likely been called off.
He proposed exploring another passage, feeling willing to risk encountering Injun Joe and any other potential terrors.
Becky, however, was extremely weak and had sunk into a state of dreary apathy, unresponsive to any attempts to rouse her.
She declared her intention to wait where she was and die, believing her end would not be long in coming.
She told Tom to take the kite-line and explore if he chose, but she implored him to return to her every little while to speak to her.
Furthermore, she made him promise that when the awful moment of her death arrived, he would stay by her side and hold her hand until it was all over.
Tom, with a choking sensation in his throat, kissed her and made a show of being confident that he would find either the searchers or an escape route from the cave.
He then took the kite-line in his hand and began to grope his way down one of the passages on his hands and knees, suffering from intense hunger and plagued by a sickening sense of impending doom.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Tom kissed her, with a choking sensation in his throat, and made a show of being confident of finding the searchers or an escape from the cave; then he took the kite-line in his hand and went groping down one of the passages on his hands and knees, distressed with hunger and sick with bodings of coming doom.

events.text_segment:
But hunger and wretchedness rise superior to fears in the long run. Another tedious wait at the spring and another long sleep brought changes. The children awoke tortured with a raging hunger. Tom believed that it must be Wednesday or Thursday or even Friday or Saturday, now, and that the search had been given over. He proposed to explore another passage. He felt willing to risk Injun Joe and all other terrors. But Becky was very weak. She had sunk into a dreary apathy and would not be roused. She said she would wait, now, where she was, and die—it would not be long. She told Tom to go with the kite-line and explore if he chose; but she implored him to come back every little while and speak to her; and she made him promise that when the awful time came, he would stay by her and hold her hand until all was over.
Tom kissed her, with a choking sensation in his throat, and made a show of being confident of finding the searchers or an escape from the cave; then he took the kite-line in his hand and went groping down one of the passages on his hands and knees, distressed with hunger and sick with bodings of coming doom.

events.title: Lingering Despair in St. Petersburg
detailed_summary: St. Petersburg remained enveloped in sorrow on Tuesday afternoon as the search for the missing children yielded no results.
Despite numerous public and heartfelt private prayers, there was no encouraging news from the cave.
The majority of those searching had relinquished hope, concluding that Tom and Becky could not be found.
Mrs. Thatcher was gravely ill, frequently experiencing delirium, during which she would call out for Becky and listen intently for a response before succumbing to despair.
Aunt Polly had fallen into a deep state of melancholy, her hair noticeably graying further from the stress.
The village prepared for another night burdened by sadness and a sense of loss.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Tuesday afternoon came, and waned to the twilight.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The village went to its rest on Tuesday night, sad and forlorn.

events.text_segment: Tuesday afternoon came, and waned to the twilight. The village of St. Petersburg still mourned. The lost children had not been found. Public prayers had been offered up for them, and many and many a private prayer that had the petitioner’s whole heart in it; but still no good news came from the cave. The majority of the searchers had given up the quest and gone back to their daily avocations, saying that it was plain the children could never be found. Mrs. Thatcher was very ill, and a great part of the time delirious. People said it was heartbreaking to hear her call her child, and raise her head and listen a whole minute at a time, then lay it wearily down again with a moan. Aunt Polly had drooped into a settled melancholy, and her gray hair had grown almost white. The village went to its rest on Tuesday night, sad and forlorn.

events.title: The Joyful Discovery and Elated Return
detailed_summary: In the dead of night, the village church bells rang out frantically, signaling the children's discovery.
The streets quickly filled with ecstatic, partially clothed residents shouting that Tom and Becky were found.
The celebratory noise escalated with the addition of tin pans and horns as the townsfolk converged and headed towards the river.
They encountered the children arriving in an open carriage, drawn by cheering citizens, and a massive, jubilant procession escorted them up the main street with continuous huzzahs.
The entire village was lit up, and normal routines were abandoned in what became the most memorable night in the town's history.

For the first thirty minutes after their return, a stream of villagers passed through Judge Thatcher's home, emotionally greeting the rescued children, offering comfort to Mrs. Thatcher, and departing overwhelmed with tears of joy.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Away in the middle of the night a wild peal burst from the village bells, and in a moment the streets were swarming with frantic half-clad people, who shouted, “Turn out! turn out! they’re found! they’re found!”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: During the first half-hour a procession of villagers filed through Judge Thatcher’s house, seized the saved ones and kissed them, squeezed Mrs. Thatcher’s hand, tried to speak but couldn’t—and drifted out raining tears all over the place.

events.text_segment:
Away in the middle of the night a wild peal burst from the village bells, and in a moment the streets were swarming with frantic half-clad people, who shouted, “Turn out! turn out! they’re found! they’re found!” Tin pans and horns were added to the din, the population massed itself and moved toward the river, met the children coming in an open carriage drawn by shouting citizens, thronged around it, joined its homeward march, and swept magnificently up the main street roaring huzzah after huzzah!
The village was illuminated; nobody went to bed again; it was the greatest night the little town had ever seen. During the first half-hour a procession of villagers filed through Judge Thatcher’s house, seized the saved ones and kissed them, squeezed Mrs. Thatcher’s hand, tried to speak but couldn’t—and drifted out raining tears all over the place.

events.title: Tom's Harrowing Tale of Escape and the Search's End
characters: Becky Thatcher (in story and as listener)
detailed_summary: Aunt Polly experienced profound happiness, while Mrs. Thatcher's joy was nearly complete, pending notification to her husband who was still at the cave.
Tom, comfortably situated on a sofa and surrounded by an captivated audience, recounted the story of their adventure, embellishing it with striking details.
He described his solitary exploration after leaving Becky, navigating two cave passages using his kite-line for measurement.
He detailed how he followed a third passage to the full length of his kite-line and, just as he considered turning back, noticed a distant glimmer that appeared to be daylight.
He recounted dropping the kite-line, carefully making his way towards the light, and emerging through a small opening to the sight of the Mississippi River.
Tom emphasized his good fortune that it was daytime, which allowed him to spot the light, otherwise he would have missed the escape route and explored no further.
He narrated his return to Becky, who was despondent and initially met his news of an escape route with disbelief, expressing a wish to die.
He explained his efforts to convince her and her overwhelming joy when she finally saw the speck of daylight herself.
Tom described how he exited the opening and then assisted Becky out, after which they both wept with relief.
He recounted how they were discovered by men in a skiff, to whom he explained their dire situation and starved condition.
The men initially doubted their incredible story, noting they were five miles downriver from the cave's valley, but then took them aboard.
They were provided with supper, allowed to rest for several hours after dark, and then brought home.
Before dawn, Judge Thatcher and his small group of searchers were located within the cave, guided by the twine they had laid, and were informed of the children's rescue.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Aunt Polly’s happiness was complete, and Mrs. Thatcher’s nearly so.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Before day-dawn, Judge Thatcher and the handful of searchers with him were tracked out, in the cave, by the twine clews they had strung behind them, and informed of the great news.

events.text_segment:
Aunt Polly’s happiness was complete, and Mrs. Thatcher’s nearly so. It would be complete, however, as soon as the messenger dispatched with the great news to the cave should get the word to her husband. Tom lay upon a sofa with an eager auditory about him and told the history of the wonderful adventure, putting in many striking additions to adorn it withal; and closed with a description of how he left Becky and went on an exploring expedition; how he followed two avenues as far as his kite-line would reach; how he followed a third to the fullest stretch of the kite-line, and was about to turn back when he glimpsed a far-off speck that looked like daylight; dropped the line and groped toward it, pushed his head and shoulders through a small hole, and saw the broad Mississippi rolling by!
And if it had only happened to be night he would not have seen that speck of daylight and would not have explored that passage any more! He told how he went back for Becky and broke the good news and she told him not to fret her with such stuff, for she was tired, and knew she was going to die, and wanted to. He described how he labored with her and convinced her; and how she almost died for joy when she had groped to where she actually saw the blue speck of daylight; how he pushed his way out at the hole and then helped her out; how they sat there and cried for gladness; how some men came along in a skiff and Tom hailed them and told them their situation and their famished condition; how the men didn’t believe the wild tale at first, “because,” said they, “you are five miles down the river below the valley the cave is in”—then took them aboard, rowed to a house, gave them supper, made them rest till two or three hours after dark and then brought them home.
Before day-dawn, Judge Thatcher and the handful of searchers with him were tracked out, in the cave, by the twine clews they had strung behind them, and informed of the great news.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
Aunt Polly’s happiness was complete, and Mrs. Thatcher’s nearly so, for she was waiting to hear news of her husband, still in the cave. Tom, comfortably seated on the sofa with Becky Thatcher listening intently, began to tell the story of their adventure, embellishing it with vivid details. He described how he had left Becky and wandered alone through the cave, using his kite-line to measure the passages. He followed a third passage to its full length, and just as he was about to turn back, he saw a faint glimmer of light—daylight—distant and promising.

He dropped his kite-line carefully and made his way toward the light, emerging through a small opening to see the mighty Mississippi River stretching out before him. Tom emphasized that it was fortunate it was daytime, for the light guided him out; had it been night, he might have missed the escape altogether. He hurried back to Becky, who was despondent and at first refused to believe his story, even wishing she could die. But Tom convinced her, and when she finally saw the speck of daylight herself, her joy was overwhelming.

Together, they climbed out of the opening, and Tom helped Becky out afterward. Both children wept with relief, overwhelmed by their escape. Soon, men in a skiff appeared, and Tom explained their plight and starved condition. The men doubted their story at first, noting they were five miles downriver from the cave’s valley, but they took the children aboard. They gave them supper, let them rest after dark, and then took them home.

Before dawn, Judge Thatcher and a small group of searchers, guided by the twine they had laid in the cave, found the children and were told of their rescue, filling everyone with joy and relief.

events.title: Tom and Becky's Slow Path to Recovery
detailed_summary: Tom and Becky quickly learned that the severe hardships of three days and nights in the cave—toil and hunger—would have lingering effects.
Both children were confined to their beds throughout Wednesday and Thursday, appearing to grow increasingly fatigued and worn down.
Tom showed some improvement by Thursday, was able to venture downtown on Friday, and seemed almost fully recovered by Saturday.
Becky's recuperation was more prolonged; she did not leave her room until Sunday and looked as though she had endured a debilitating illness.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Three days and nights of toil and hunger in the cave were not to be shaken off at once, as Tom and Becky soon discovered.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Tom got about, a little, on Thursday, was downtown Friday, and nearly as whole as ever Saturday; but Becky did not leave her room until Sunday, and then she looked as if she had passed through a wasting illness.

events.text_segment: Three days and nights of toil and hunger in the cave were not to be shaken off at once, as Tom and Becky soon discovered. They were bedridden all of Wednesday and Thursday, and seemed to grow more and more tired and worn, all the time. Tom got about, a little, on Thursday, was downtown Friday, and nearly as whole as ever Saturday; but Becky did not leave her room until Sunday, and then she looked as if she had passed through a wasting illness.

events.title: Updates on Huck's Health and Other Town News
detailed_summary: Tom became aware of Huck's illness and attempted to visit him on Friday, but was not allowed into Huck's bedroom; similar attempts on Saturday and Sunday were also unsuccessful.
He was permitted daily visits thereafter but received a strict warning from the Widow Douglas to remain quiet about his cave adventure and to avoid any stimulating conversation topics.
While at home, Tom received updates about the incident on Cardiff Hill.
He also learned that the body of the 'ragged man' had been discovered in the river near the ferry landing, with the assumption that he had drowned while trying to escape.

events.title: The Cave's Sealing and Tom's Shocking Realization
detailed_summary: Approximately two weeks after his rescue, Tom set out to visit Huck, who was now considered strong enough to handle exciting news, which Tom believed he possessed.
Tom's route took him past Judge Thatcher's house, where he decided to stop and see Becky.
The Judge and some of his friends engaged Tom in conversation, during which one person ironically inquired if Tom would be interested in returning to the cave.
Tom responded casually that he wouldn't mind.
Judge Thatcher then revealed that steps had been taken to ensure no one would get lost in the cave again.
He explained that, two weeks prior, he had the main entrance of the cave sealed with a boiler-iron door, which was triple-locked, and that he held the keys.
Upon hearing this, Tom turned deathly pale from shock.
Water was brought and thrown in his face to revive him.
Once recovered, when asked what was wrong, Tom uttered the horrifying revelation that Injun Joe was still inside the cave.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: About a fortnight after Tom’s rescue from the cave, he started off to visit Huck, who had grown plenty strong enough, now, to hear exciting talk, and Tom had some that would interest him, he thought.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Oh, Judge, Injun Joe’s in the cave!”

events.text_segment:
About a fortnight after Tom’s rescue from the cave, he started off to visit Huck, who had grown plenty strong enough, now, to hear exciting talk, and Tom had some that would interest him, he thought. Judge Thatcher’s house was on Tom’s way, and he stopped to see Becky. The Judge and some friends set Tom to talking, and some one asked him ironically if he wouldn’t like to go to the cave again. Tom said he thought he wouldn’t mind it. The Judge said:
“Well, there are others just like you, Tom, I’ve not the least doubt. But we have taken care of that. Nobody will get lost in that cave any more.”
“Why?”
“Because I had its big door sheathed with boiler iron two weeks ago, and triple-locked—and I’ve got the keys.”
Tom turned as white as a sheet.
“What’s the matter, boy! Here, run, somebody! Fetch a glass of water!”
The water was brought and thrown into Tom’s face.
“Ah, now you’re all right. What was the matter with you, Tom?”
“Oh, Judge, Injun Joe’s in the cave!”

events.title: Discovery of Injun Joe's Body and His Desperate Last Efforts
detailed_summary: Widespread news of the cave's unlocking drew numerous townspeople, including Tom Sawyer accompanied by Judge Thatcher, to the site via skiffs and a ferryboat.
Upon opening the cave, they discovered Injun Joe lying dead, his face positioned near a crack in the door, as if he had spent his final moments gazing towards the outside world.

Tom experienced a profound mixture of compassion for the suffering Injun Joe must have endured, alongside a significant sense of relief and safety, realizing the immense burden of fear he had unknowingly carried.

Evidence of Injun Joe's desperate attempts to escape was apparent: a bowie-knife with a broken blade lay nearby, and the door's foundation beam was heavily chipped, though this effort was ultimately futile due to the solid rock sill outside.
It was clear he had undertaken this labor not with any real hope of escape, but merely to occupy his mind and pass the agonizing time.
His desperation was further evidenced by the fact that he had consumed all available candle remnants and even resorted to eating bats, leaving only their claws.
A poignant detail was a stalagmite he had broken off, placing a stone with a hollow he'd carved on its stump to painstakingly collect dripping water, a testament to his desperate fight for survival.
The narrative reflects on the immense span of history this single water drip has witnessed.

This makeshift water-collecting stone, Injun Joe's 'cup,' subsequently became the most compelling and frequently observed artifact for tourists visiting McDougal's cave, surpassing even its other famed formations.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Within a few minutes the news had spread, and a dozen skiff-loads of men were on their way to McDougal’s cave, and the ferryboat, well filled with passengers, soon followed.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Injun Joe’s cup stands first in the list of the cavern’s marvels; even “Aladdin’s Palace” cannot rival it.

events.text_segment:
Within a few minutes the news had spread, and a dozen skiff-loads of men were on their way to McDougal’s cave, and the ferryboat, well filled with passengers, soon followed. Tom Sawyer was in the skiff that bore Judge Thatcher.
When the cave door was unlocked, a sorrowful sight presented itself in the dim twilight of the place. Injun Joe lay stretched upon the ground, dead, with his face close to the crack of the door, as if his longing eyes had been fixed, to the latest moment, upon the light and the cheer of the free world outside. Tom was touched, for he knew by his own experience how this wretch had suffered. His pity was moved, but nevertheless he felt an abounding sense of relief and security, now, which revealed to him in a degree which he had not fully appreciated before how vast a weight of dread had been lying upon him since the day he lifted his voice against this bloody-minded outcast.
Injun Joe’s bowie-knife lay close by, its blade broken in two. The great foundation-beam of the door had been chipped and hacked through, with tedious labor; useless labor, too, it was, for the native rock formed a sill outside it, and upon that stubborn material the knife had wrought no effect; the only damage done was to the knife itself. But if there had been no stony obstruction there the labor would have been useless still, for if the beam had been wholly cut away Injun Joe could not have squeezed his body under the door, and he knew it. So he had only hacked that place in order to be doing something—in order to pass the weary time—in order to employ his tortured faculties. Ordinarily one could find half a dozen bits of candle stuck around in the crevices of this vestibule, left there by tourists; but there were none now. The prisoner had searched them out and eaten them. He had also contrived to catch a few bats, and these, also, he had eaten, leaving only their claws. The poor unfortunate had starved to death. In one place, near at hand, a stalagmite had been slowly growing up from the ground for ages, builded by the water-drip from a stalactite overhead. The captive had broken off the stalagmite, and upon the stump had placed a stone, wherein he had scooped a shallow hollow to catch the precious drop that fell once in every three minutes with the dreary regularity of a clock-tick—a dessertspoonful once in four and twenty hours. That drop was falling when the Pyramids were new; when Troy fell; when the foundations of Rome were laid; when Christ was crucified; when the Conqueror created the British empire; when Columbus sailed; when the massacre at Lexington was “news.”
It is falling now; it will still be falling when all these things shall have sunk down the afternoon of history, and the twilight of tradition, and been swallowed up in the thick night of oblivion. Has everything a purpose and a mission? Did this drop fall patiently during five thousand years to be ready for this flitting human insect’s need? and has it another important object to accomplish ten thousand years to come? No matter. It is many and many a year since the hapless half-breed scooped out the stone to catch the priceless drops, but to this day the tourist stares longest at that pathetic stone and that slow-dropping water when he comes to see the wonders of McDougal’s cave. Injun Joe’s cup stands first in the list of the cavern’s marvels; even “Aladdin’s Palace” cannot rival it.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
Within a few minutes the news had spread, and a dozen skiff-loads of men were on their way to McDougal’s cave, and the ferryboat, well filled with passengers, soon followed. When the cave was finally opened, the crowd surged inside, and among them was Tom Sawyer, accompanied by Judge Thatcher. They entered the dark, silent cavern, and as they moved deeper, they saw Injun Joe lying dead near a crack in the door, his face turned outward as if he had spent his last moments gazing toward the outside world. Tom felt a strange mixture of compassion for the suffering Injun Joe must have endured and a profound sense of relief and safety, realizing the immense burden of fear he had unknowingly carried.

Evidence of Injun Joe’s desperate attempt to escape was scattered around: a broken bowie-knife lay nearby, and the foundation beam of the door was heavily chipped, though the solid rock sill outside had thwarted any real escape. It was clear he had labored here not with hope of freedom but merely to pass the time and occupy his mind. His desperation was further evidenced by the fact that he had consumed all available candle remnants and even resorted to eating bats, leaving only their claws behind. A poignant detail was a stalagmite he had broken off, placing a hollowed stone on its stump to collect dripping water—a testament to his desperate fight for survival.

This tiny water drip, which had witnessed countless moments in the cavern’s long history, became a symbol of endurance. The makeshift water-collecting stone, Injun Joe’s 'cup,' grew to be the most fascinating artifact for visitors, surpassing even the cavern’s other famed formations. It stood as a silent witness to the tragic struggle and the passage of time, a small but powerful reminder of the depths of human desperation and the enduring hope for survival.

events.title: Injun Joe's Funeral and the Quashing of a Pardon Petition
detailed_summary: Injun Joe was interred near the cave's entrance, an event that attracted a large assembly of people from the surrounding seven-mile radius, complete with children and provisions.
Attendees openly admitted finding the funeral nearly as fulfilling an experience as a public hanging might have been.
This funeral effectively terminated any further progress on a petition that was being circulated to request a pardon for Injun Joe from the governor.
The petition had garnered significant support, with numerous emotional meetings and a committee of sentimental women prepared to appeal directly to the governor.

The narrator cynically observes that despite Injun Joe being suspected of killing five villagers, there would always be individuals willing to support such a petition, even for someone as malevolent as Satan.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Injun Joe was buried near the mouth of the cave; and people flocked there in boats and wagons from the towns and from all the farms and hamlets for seven miles around; they brought their children, and all sorts of provisions, and confessed that they had had almost as satisfactory a time at the funeral as they could have had at the hanging.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: If he had been Satan himself there would have been plenty of weaklings ready to scribble their names to a pardon-petition, and drip a tear on it from their permanently impaired and leaky water-works.

events.text_segment:
Injun Joe was buried near the mouth of the cave; and people flocked there in boats and wagons from the towns and from all the farms and hamlets for seven miles around; they brought their children, and all sorts of provisions, and confessed that they had had almost as satisfactory a time at the funeral as they could have had at the hanging.
This funeral stopped the further growth of one thing—the petition to the governor for Injun Joe’s pardon. The petition had been largely signed; many tearful and eloquent meetings had been held, and a committee of sappy women been appointed to go in deep mourning and wail around the governor, and implore him to be a merciful ass and trample his duty under foot. Injun Joe was believed to have killed five citizens of the village, but what of that? If he had been Satan himself there would have been plenty of weaklings ready to scribble their names to a pardon-petition, and drip a tear on it from their permanently impaired and leaky water-works.

events.title: Tom Reveals the Treasure's True Location to Huck
detailed_summary: The morning following the funeral, Tom sought out Huck for a private and significant conversation.

Huck, already aware of Tom's cave escapade from the Welshman and Widow Douglas, anticipated Tom's news was about failing to find treasure at 'No. 2,' the Temperance Tavern, and expressed his resignation that they'd never find the money.
Tom corrected Huck, stating he hadn't implicated the tavern-keeper.
Huck then shared his own untold story of secretly following Injun Joe to the widow's house on the night of the picnic, fearing retaliation from Injun Joe's associates.
After Huck finished his account, Tom astonished him by declaring that the treasure was never located in 'No. 2.'
Tom then dramatically revealed to a keenly observant Huck that the treasure was, in fact, hidden within the cave.
Huck, initially disbelieving then blazing with excitement, questioned Tom's sincerity, to which Tom affirmed he was entirely earnest and asked for Huck's help to retrieve it.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The morning after the funeral Tom took Huck to a private place to have an important talk.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Will you go in there with me and help get it out?”

events.text_segment:
The morning after the funeral Tom took Huck to a private place to have an important talk. Huck had learned all about Tom’s adventure from the Welshman and the Widow Douglas, by this time, but Tom said he reckoned there was one thing they had not told him; that thing was what he wanted to talk about now. Huck’s face saddened. He said:
“I know what it is. You got into No. 2 and never found anything but whiskey. Nobody told me it was you; but I just knowed it must ’a’ ben you, soon as I heard ’bout that whiskey business; and I knowed you hadn’t got the money becuz you’d ’a’ got at me some way or other and told me even if you was mum to everybody else. Tom, something’s always told me we’d never get holt of that swag.”
“Why, Huck, I never told on that tavern-keeper. You know his tavern was all right the Saturday I went to the picnic. Don’t you remember you was to watch there that night?”
“Oh yes! Why, it seems ’bout a year ago. It was that very night that I follered Injun Joe to the widder’s.”
“You followed him?”
“Yes—but you keep mum. I reckon Injun Joe’s left friends behind him, and I don’t want ’em souring on me and doing me mean tricks. If it hadn’t ben for me he’d be down in Texas now, all right.”
Then Huck told his entire adventure in confidence to Tom, who had only heard of the Welshman’s part of it before.
“Well,” said Huck, presently, coming back to the main question, “whoever nipped the whiskey in No. 2, nipped the money, too, I reckon—anyways it’s a goner for us, Tom.”
“Huck, that money wasn’t ever in No. 2!”
“What!” Huck searched his comrade’s face keenly. “Tom, have you got on the track of that money again?”
“Huck, it’s in the cave!”
Huck’s eyes blazed.
“Say it again, Tom.”
“The money’s in the cave!”
“Tom—honest injun, now—is it fun, or earnest?”
“Earnest, Huck—just as earnest as ever I was in my life. Will you go in there with me and help get it out?”
